translated: And there is a Vedic text about his being the soul of all: 'When one knows him, in whom all these beings have their soul,

original: tatra ko mohaḥ kaḥ śokaḥ ekatvamanupaśyataḥ' ī /
analyzed: tatra kaḥ mohaḥ kaḥ śokaḥ eka tvam anupaśyataḥ
translated: then all doubts are solved' (Śvet.

analyzed: iti evaṃvidhā
translated: Such is the text.

original: ataśca siddhamātmabhedakalpanayāpi kapilasya tantraṃ vedaviruddhaṃ vedānusārimanuvacanaviruddhaṃ ca /
analyzed: atas ca siddham ātma bheda kalpanayā api kapilasya tantram veda viruddham veda anusāri manu vacana viruddham ca
translated: And therefore it is established that the system of Kapila, even if it assumes a plurality of souls, is opposed to the Veda, and is opposed to the words of Manu, which are in accordance with the Veda.

analyzed: na kevalam svatantra prakṛti kalpanayā eva iti
translated: And not only by the assumption of an independent prakriti.

original: vedasya hi nirapekṣaṃ svārthe prāmāṇyaṃ raveriva rūpaviṣaye /
analyzed: vedasya hi nirapekṣam svārthe prāmāṇyam raveḥ iva rūpa viṣaye
translated: For the Veda has an independent authority in its own matter, as the sun has in the matter of form.

original: puruṣavacasāṃ tu mūlāntarāpekṣaṃ vaktusmṛtivyavahitaṃ ceti viprakarṣaḥ /
analyzed: puruṣa vacasām tu mūla antara apekṣam vaktu smṛti vyavahitam ca iti viprakarṣaḥ
translated: But the words of men depend on another source, and are interrupted by the memory of the speaker. Thus there is a difference.

analyzed: tasmāt veda viruddhe viṣaye smṛti anavakāśa prasaṅgaḥ na doṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, in a matter opposed to the Veda, the non-occurrence of Smṛti is not a fault.

analyzed: dvitīye smṛti tarkābhyām avirodhaḥ
translated: The summary verse is: 'In the second, non-contradiction with memory and reasoning, the fault of others,

analyzed: bhūta bhoktṛ śruteḥ liṅga śruteḥ api aviruddha tā iti saṃgraha ślokaḥ
translated: and the non-contradiction of the indication of the heard about the experiencer of the elements.'

analyzed: parama ṛṣiḥ kapilaḥ
translated: The supreme sage is Kapila.

analyzed: anyāḥ āsuri pañcaśikha ādi praṇītāḥ
translated: Others are composed by Asuri, Pañcaśikha, and others.

analyzed: upacaritam śruti artham pratipadyeran iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that they would understand the meaning of the Vedas figuratively.

analyzed: sūkṣma tvam atīndriya tvam
translated: Subtlety means being beyond the senses.

analyzed: avijñeya tvam pramāṇa antara avagāhya tvam
translated: Being unknowable means being beyond the reach of other means of knowledge.

analyzed: kāyāḥ brahma ādayaḥ
translated: The bodies are Brahmā and others.

analyzed: śāśvatikaḥ kūṭasthaḥ  śruti virodhe smṛti prāmāṇyam anapekṣam heyam
translated: Eternal means unchanging.🔽In the case of contradiction with the Vedas, the validity of the Smṛti should be rejected without regard.

analyzed: hi yatas sati virodhe śruti anumānam bhavati
translated: For if there is no contradiction, then the Vedas are inferred.

analyzed: prataptuḥ dāhakasya
translated: Of the burner, the one who burns.

analyzed: viśve mūrdhanaḥ u sya eva sarvatra pratibimbita tvāt
translated: The universe is the head of this, because it is reflected everywhere.

analyzed: evam viśvabhuja ādau yojyam
translated: This should be applied similarly to Viśvabhuj and others.

analyzed: kutas ca smṛti anavakāśa prasaṅgaḥ na doṣaḥ
translated: And why is the non-occurrence of Smṛti not a fault?

analyzed: itareṣām ca anupalabdheḥ
translated: And because the others are not perceived.

original: pradhānāditarāṇi yāni pradhānapariṇāmatvaṃ na samṛtau kalpitāni mahadādīni na tāni vede loke vopalabhyante /
analyzed: pradhānāt itarāṇi yāni pradhāna pariṇāma tvam na samṛtau kalpitāni mahat ādīni na tāni vede loke vā upalabhyante
translated: The Mahat and other principles, which are not imagined in the Smṛti to be evolutions of the primordial matter, are not found in the Vedas or in the world.

analyzed: bhūta indriyāṇi tāvat loka veda prasiddha tvāt śakyante smartum
translated: The elements and senses are known to the world and the Vedas, so they can be remembered.

analyzed: a loka veda prasiddha tvāt tu mahat ādīnām ṣaṣṭhasya iva indriya arthasya na smṛtiḥ avakalpate
translated: But the great elements and so on are not known to the world or the Vedas, so their memory is not possible, like the object of the sixth sense.

original: yadapi kvacittatparamiva śravaṇamavabhāsate tadapyatatparaṃ vyākhyātam 'ānumānikamapyekeṣām' bra / / / ityatra /
analyzed: yat api kvacid tad param iva śravaṇam avabhāsate tat api atatparam vyākhyātam ānumānikam api ekeṣām iti atra
translated: Even where it appears as if the scriptures refer to them, that is explained as not referring to them, as in 'For some, even inference' (Brahmasutra 1.1.30).

analyzed: kārya smṛteḥ aprāmāṇyāt kāraṇa smṛteḥ api aprāmāṇyam yuktam iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: The idea is that because the memory of the effect is not valid, the memory of the cause should also be considered invalid.

original: tasmādapi na smṛtyanavakāśaprasaṅgo doṣaḥ /🔽tarkāvaṣṭambhaṃ tu 'na vilakṣaṇatvāt' bra / / /
analyzed: tasmāt api na smṛti anavakāśa prasaṅgaḥ doṣaḥ  tarka avaṣṭambham tu na vilakṣaṇa tvāt
translated: Therefore, the fault of the impossibility of memory does not arise.

analyzed: iti ārabhya unmathiṣyati
translated: But the stubbornness of reasoning will be refuted starting from 'Not because of being different' (Brahmasutra 2.1.11).

analyzed: yoga pratyukti adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on the refutation of Yoga.

analyzed: etena yogaḥ pratyuktaḥ
translated: By this, Yoga is refuted.

analyzed: etena sāṃkhya smṛti pratyākhyānena yoga smṛtiḥ api pratyākhyātā draṣṭavyā iti atidiśati
translated: By this refutation of the Samkhya Smriti, the Yoga Smriti should also be considered refuted. This is the extension.

analyzed: tatra api śruti virodhena pradhānam svatantram eva kāraṇam
translated: There also, by contradicting the scriptures, the prakriti is considered to be the independent cause.

analyzed: mahat ādīni ca kāryāṇi aloka veda prasiddhāni kalpyante
translated: And the effects like mahat and so on, which are not known to the world or the Vedas, are postulated.

analyzed: nanu evam sati samāna nyāya tvāt pūrveṇa eva etat gatam kimartham punar atidiśyate
translated: If this is so, then, on the ground of the same reasoning, this has been already settled by the former (Sūtra); why is it again stated by way of a separate Sūtra?

analyzed: asti hi atra abhyadhikā āśaṅkā
translated: For there is a further doubt here.

original: samyagdarśanābhyupāyo hi yogo vede vihitaḥ 'śrotavyo mantavyo nididhyāsitavyaḥ' bṛ / / / iti /🔽'tryunnataṃ sthāpya samaṃ śarīram' śve / /🔽ityādinā cāsanādikalpanāpuraḥsaraṃ bahuprapañcaṃ yogavidhānaṃ śvetāśvataropaniṣadi dṛśyate /
analyzed: samyak darśana abhyupāyaḥ hi yogaḥ vede vihitaḥ śrotavyaḥ mantavyaḥ nididhyāsitavyaḥ iti  tri unnatam sthāpya samam śarīram śve  ityādinā ca āsana ādi kalpanā puraḥsaram bahu prapañcam yoga vidhānam śvetāśvatara upaniṣadi dṛśyate
translated: For Yoga, the means to perfect knowledge, is enjoined in the Veda: 'It should be heard, thought about, and contemplated' (Br. 1.4.23).🔽And in the Śvetāśvatara Upaniṣad, the injunction of Yoga is seen with many details, beginning with the arrangement of the posture: 'Having placed the body erect and steady' (Śvet. 6.23).

original: liṅgāni ca vaidikāni yogaviṣayāṇi sahasraśa upalabhyante 'tāṃ yogamiti manyante sthirāmindriyadhāraṇām' kā / / /
analyzed: liṅgāni ca vaidikāni yoga viṣayāṇi sahasraśas upalabhyante tām yogam iti manyante sthirām indriya dhāraṇām kā
translated: And thousands of Vedic indications relating to Yoga are found, such as: 'They consider that Yoga to be the firm retention of the senses' (Ka. 1.3.12).

analyzed: iti vidyām etām yoga vidhim ca kṛtsnam kā
translated: And: 'This knowledge and the entire method of Yoga' (Ka. 1.3.12).

analyzed: iti ca evamādīni
translated: And so on.

original: yogaśāstre 'pi 'atha tattvadarśanopāyo yogaḥ' iti samyagdarśanābhyupāyatvenaiva yogoṅgīkriyate /
analyzed: yoga śāstre pi atha tattva darśana upāyaḥ yogaḥ iti samyak darśana abhyupāya tvena eva yogaḥ ṅgīkriyate
translated: Even in the Yoga scriptures, Yoga is accepted as the means to perfect knowledge alone, as stated in the first aphorism: 'Now, Yoga is the means to the realization of reality.'

analyzed: atas saṃpratipanna artha eka deśa tvāt aṣṭaka ādi smṛti vat yoga smṛtiḥ api anapavadanīyā bhaviṣyati iti
translated: Therefore, like the Smṛti regarding the Aṣṭakā rite, the Smṛti regarding Yoga will also be unimpeachable, because it pertains to a part of the same subject that is well-known.

analyzed: iyam api adhikā śaṅkā atideśena nivartyate
translated: This doubt also is removed by the extension of the above argument.

analyzed: artha eka deśa saṃpratipattau api artha eka deśa vipratipatteḥ pūrva uktāyāḥ darśanāt
translated: Because even when there is agreement about a part of the meaning, there is disagreement about another part of the meaning, as shown by the previous statement.

original: satīṣvapyadhyātmaviṣayāsu bahvīṣu smṛtiṣu sāṃkhyayogasmṛtyoreva nirākaraṇe yatnaḥ kṛtaḥ /
analyzed: satīṣu api adhyātma viṣayāsu bahvīṣu smṛtiṣu sāṃkhya yoga smṛtyoḥ eva nirākaraṇe yatnaḥ kṛtaḥ
translated: Although there are many Smritis dealing with the internal self, the Sankhya and Yoga Smritis alone have been refuted.

analyzed: sāṃkhya yogau hi parama puruṣa artha sādhana tvena loke prakhyātau
translated: For the Sankhya and Yoga systems are well-known in the world as means to the highest human goal.

analyzed: śiṣṭaiḥ ca parigṛhītau
translated: And they are accepted by the learned.

analyzed: liṅgena na śrautena upabṛṃhitau
translated: They are not supported by Vedic injunctions.

original: 'tatkāraṇaṃ sāṃkhyayogābhipannaṃ jñātvā devaṃ mucyate sarvapāśaiḥ' śvaṃ / / iti /
analyzed: tad kāraṇam sāṃkhya yoga abhipannam jñātvā devam mucyate sarva pāśaiḥ śvam iti
translated: It is said: Having known that God, which is the cause of the Sankhya and Yoga systems, one is freed from all bonds. (Moks. Up. 1-2)

original: nirākaraṇaṃ tu na sāṃkhyajñānena vedanirapekṣeṇa yogamārgeṇa vā niḥśreyasamadhigamyata iti /
analyzed: nirākaraṇam tu na sāṃkhya jñānena veda nirapekṣeṇa yoga mārgeṇa vā niḥśreyasam adhigamyate iti
translated: But the refutation is that liberation is not attained by the Sankhya knowledge or by the Yoga path, without dependence on the Vedas.

original: śrutirhi vaidikādātmaikatvavijñānādanyanniḥśreyasasādhanaṃ vārayati 'tameva viditvātimṛtyumeti nānyaḥ panthā vidyate 'yanāya' śvaṃ / / iti
analyzed: śrutiḥ hi vaidikāt ātma ekatva vijñānāt anyat niḥśreyasa sādhanam vārayati tam eva viditvā atimṛtyum eti na anyaḥ panthāḥ vidyate iti
translated: For the Vedas deny any means to liberation other than the knowledge of the non-duality of the self: Having known Him alone, one goes beyond death. There is no other path to go by. (Tai. Up. 2.1)

original: dvaitino hi te sāṃkhyā yogāśca nātmaikatvadarśinaḥ /
analyzed: dvaitinaḥ hi te sāṃkhyāḥ yogāḥ ca na ātma eka tva darśinaḥ
translated: For the Sankhyas and Yogas are dualists, not seers of the non-duality of the self.

analyzed: yat tu darśanam uktam tat kāraṇam sāṃkhya yoga abhipannam iti
translated: As for the view that has been stated, that the cause is attained by the Sankhyas and the Yogins,

original: vaidikameva tatra jñānaṃ dhyānaṃ ca sāṃkhyayogaśabdābhyāmabhilapyate pratyāsatterityavagantavyam /
analyzed: vaidikam eva tatra jñānam dhyānam ca sāṃkhya yoga śabdābhyām abhilapyate pratyāsatteḥ iti avagantavyam
translated: it should be understood that the knowledge and meditation mentioned there by the words Sankhya and Yoga are the Vedic knowledge and meditation itself, because of proximity.

original: yena tvaṃśena na virudhyete teneṣṭameva sāṃkhyayogasmṛtyoḥ sāvakāśatvam /🔽tadyathā 'asaṅgo hyayaṃ puruṣaḥ' bṛ / / /
analyzed: yena tu aṃśena na virudhyete tena iṣṭam eva sāṃkhya yoga smṛtyoḥ sāvakāśa tvam  tat yathā a saṅgaḥ hi ayam puruṣaḥ
translated: And in so far as they are not opposed, the Sankhya and Yoga Smritis are accepted as having a basis.

original: ityevamādiśrutiprasiddhameva puruṣasya viśuddhatvaṃ nirguṇapuruṣanirūpaṇena sāṃkhyairabhyupagamyate /🔽tathāca yogairapi 'atha parivrāḍvivarṇavāsā muṇḍo 'parigrahaḥ' jābā /
analyzed: iti evamādi śruti prasiddham eva puruṣasya viśuddha tvam nirguṇa puruṣa nirūpaṇena sāṃkhyaiḥ abhyupagamyate  tathā ca yogaiḥ api atha parivrāj vivarṇa vāsāḥ parigrahaḥ jābā
translated: For instance, the Sankhyas accept the purity of the Spirit, which is well known from such Vedic texts as, 'This Spirit is unattached' (Bhagavadgita 13.31), by describing the Spirit as being without qualities.

analyzed: iti evamādi śruti prasiddham eva nivṛtti niṣṭha tvam pravrajyā ādi upadeśena anugamyate
translated: Similarly, the Yogins follow the state of being devoted to renunciation, which is well known from such Vedic texts as, 'Then the wandering ascetic, with his clothes of a different colour, shaven, without possessions' (Jaiminiya Upanishad Brahmana 3.3.1), by teaching renunciation etc.

analyzed: etena sarvāṇi tarka smaraṇāni prativaktavyāni
translated: By this, all the Smritis of logic should be refuted.

analyzed: tāni api tarka upapattibhyām tattva jñānāya upakurvanti iti ced upakurvantu nāma
translated: If it is argued that they also help in the knowledge of truth by logic and reasoning, let them help.

original: tattvajñānaṃ tu vedāntavākyebhya eva bhavati 'nāvedavinmanute taṃ bṛhantam' tai / brā / / / /
analyzed: tattva jñānam tu vedānta vākyebhyaḥ eva bhavati na a veda vid manute tam bṛhantam tai brā
translated: But the knowledge of truth arises from the Vedanta texts alone. One who does not know the Veda does not understand that great one (Tai. Br. 1.1.2).

analyzed: tam tvā aupaniṣadam puruṣam pṛcchāmi bṛ
translated: I ask about that person who is taught in the Upanishads (Br. 1.4.16).

analyzed: iti evamādi śrutibhyaḥ
translated: Thus it is understood from such Vedic texts.

analyzed: trīṇi uraḥ grīva śirāṃsi unnatāni yasmin śarīre tat tri unnatam
translated: That body which has three elevated parts, chest, neck, and head, is called triyugma.

analyzed: tarkaḥ numānam anugrāhyam mānam  upapattiḥ anugrāhikā yuktiḥ iti bhedaḥ
translated: Tarka is inference, which is to be accepted as valid knowledge.

analyzed: vilakṣaṇa tva adhikaraṇam sū
translated: Upanaya is the concluding argument that supports the conclusion. This is the difference between them.🔽The section on the difference of nature. Sutra:

original: na vilakṣaṇatvād asya tathātvaṃ ca śabdāt / / / /
analyzed: na vilakṣaṇa tvāt asya tathātvam ca śabdāt
translated: Not so, because of its difference from that, and because of the word.

original: brahmāsya jagato nimittakāraṇaṃ prakṛtiścetyasya pakṣasyākṣepaḥ smṛtinimittaḥ parihṛtaḥ /
analyzed: brahma asya jagataḥ nimitta kāraṇam prakṛtiḥ ca iti asya pakṣasya ākṣepaḥ smṛti nimittaḥ parihṛtaḥ
translated: The objection based on smrti has been refuted that Brahman is the material cause and the efficient cause of this world.

analyzed: tarka nimittaḥ idānīm ākṣepaḥ parihriyate
translated: Now the objection based on reasoning is being refuted.

analyzed: kutas punar asmin avadhārite āgama arthe tarka nimittasya ākṣepasya avakāśaḥ
translated: But how can there be scope for an objection based on reasoning regarding the meaning of the scriptures that has been ascertained?

original: nanu dharma iva brahmaṇyanapekṣa āgamo bhavitumarhati /
analyzed: nanu dharmaḥ iva brahmaṇi anapekṣaḥ āgamaḥ bhavitum arhati
translated: Just as in the case of dharma, so also in the case of Brahman, the scriptures may be independent.

original: bhavedayamavaṣṭambho yadi pramāṇāntarānavagāhya āgamamātraprameyo 'yamarthaḥ syādanuṣṭheyarūpa iva dharmaḥ /
analyzed: bhavet ayam avaṣṭambhaḥ yadi pramāṇa antarān avagāhyaḥ āgama mātra prameyaḥ yam arthaḥ syāt anuṣṭheya rūpaḥ iva dharmaḥ
translated: This [argument] would hold if this matter were to be known only by scripture, not by other means of knowledge, like the nature of what is to be performed [in the case of injunctions].

analyzed: pariniṣpanna rūpam tu brahma avagamyate
translated: But Brahman is known to be of the nature of the fully accomplished [reality].

original: pariniṣpanne ca vastuni pramāṇāntarāṇāmastyavakāśo yathā pṛthivyādiṣu /
analyzed: pariniṣpanne ca vastuni pramāṇa antarāṇām asti avakāśaḥ yathā pṛthivī ādiṣu
translated: And in the case of a fully accomplished entity, there is scope for other means of knowledge, as in the case of earth and so on.

analyzed: yathā ca śrutīnām paraspara virodhe sati eka vaśena itarāḥ nīyante
translated: And just as when there is mutual contradiction among the Vedic statements, one is interpreted in terms of the other,

analyzed: evam pramāṇa antara virodhe tad vaśena eva śrutiḥ nīyeta
translated: in the same way, when there is contradiction with other means of knowledge, the Vedic statement should be interpreted in terms of that [other means of knowledge].

analyzed: dṛṣṭa sāmyena ca adṛṣṭam artham samarthayantī yuktiḥ anubhavasya saṃnikṛṣyate
translated: And reasoning, which establishes an unseen matter by analogy with a seen one, is brought closer to experience.

analyzed: viprakṛṣyate tu śrutiḥ aitihya mātreṇa sva artha abhidhānāt
translated: But the Vedic statement is set apart, because it merely states its own meaning [without any such analogy].

original: anubhavāvasānaṃ ca brahmavijñānamavidyāyā nivartakaṃ mokṣasādhanaṃ ca dṛṣṭaphalatayeṣyate /
analyzed: anubhava avasānam ca brahma vijñānam avidyāyāḥ nivartakam mokṣa sādhanam ca dṛṣṭa phala tayā iṣyate
translated: And the knowledge of Brahman, which ends in experience, is accepted as the means to liberation, which puts an end to ignorance, by being the seen result.

original: śrutirapi 'śrotavyo mantavyaḥ' iti śravaṇavyatirekeṇa mananaṃ vidadhatī tarkamapyatrādartavyaṃ darśayati /
analyzed: śrutiḥ api śrotavyaḥ mantavyaḥ iti śravaṇa vyatirekeṇa mananam vidadhatī tarkam api atra ādartavyam darśayati
translated: And the Vedic statement, by enjoining reflection apart from hearing, shows that reasoning also should be resorted to in this [matter].

analyzed: atas tarka nimittaḥ punar ākṣepaḥ kriyate na vilakṣaṇa tvāt asya iti
translated: Therefore, the objection is again raised on the basis of reasoning, saying Because of its dissimilarity.

original: yaduktaṃ cetanaṃ brahma jagataḥ kāraṇaṃ prakṛtiriti /
analyzed: yat uktam cetanam brahma jagataḥ kāraṇam prakṛtiḥ iti
translated: What was said - that the conscious Brahman is the cause of the world, the primordial nature -

analyzed: tat na upapadyate
translated: that is not tenable.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

analyzed: vilakṣaṇa tvāt asya vikārasya prakṛtyāḥ
translated: Because of the dissimilarity of this effect from the primordial nature.

original: idaṃ hi brahmakāryatvenābhipreyamāṇaṃ jagat brahmavilakṣaṇamacetanamaśuddhaṃ ca dṛśyate /
analyzed: idam hi brahma kāryatvena abhipreyamāṇam jagat brahma vilakṣaṇam acetanam aśuddham ca dṛśyate
translated: For this world, which is intended to be the effect of Brahman, is seen to be dissimilar to Brahman, non-conscious and impure.

original: brahma ca jagadvilakṣaṇaṃ cetanaṃ śuddhaṃ ca śrūyate /
analyzed: brahma ca jagat vilakṣaṇam cetanam śuddham ca śrūyate
translated: And Brahman is heard to be dissimilar to the world, conscious and pure.

analyzed: na ca vilakṣaṇa tvam prakṛti vikāra bhāvaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ
translated: And dissimilarity is not seen to be the relation of primordial nature and effect.

original: nahi rucakādayo vikārā mṛtprakṛtikā bhavanti śarāvādayo vā suvarṇaprakṛtikāḥ /
analyzed: nahi rucaka ādayaḥ vikārāḥ mṛd prakṛtikāḥ bhavanti śarāva ādayaḥ vā suvarṇa prakṛtikāḥ
translated: For pots etc. are not effects of clay as primordial nature, nor are cups etc. effects of gold as primordial nature.

original: mṛdaiva tu mṛdānvitā vikārāḥ kriyante suvarṇena ca suvarṇānvitāḥ /
analyzed: mṛdā eva tu mṛdā anvitāḥ vikārāḥ kriyante suvarṇena ca suvarṇa anvitāḥ
translated: But only with clay are effects of clay made, and with gold only effects of gold.

original: tathedamapi jagadacetanaṃ sukhaduḥkhamohānvitaṃ sadacetanasyaiva sukhaduḥkhamohātmakasya kāraṇasya kāryaṃ bhavitumarhatīti na vilakṣaṇasya
analyzed: tathā idam api jagat acetanam sukha duḥkha moha anvitam sat acetanasya eva sukha duḥkha moha ātmakasya kāraṇasya kāryam bhavitum arhati iti na vilakṣaṇasya
