translated: But in the third (argument), there is an absence of examples.

original: kiṃ hi yaccaitanyenānanvitaṃ tadabrahmaprakṛtikaṃ dṛṣṭamiti brahmavādinaṃ pratyudāhriyeta /
analyzed: kim hi yat caitanyena ananvitam tat abrahma prakṛtikam dṛṣṭam iti brahma vādinam pratyudāhriyeta
translated: For what is not associated with consciousness is not seen to be of a nature other than Brahman, which could be cited to one who maintains that Brahman is the cause.

analyzed: samastasya vastu jāyasya brahma prakṛti tva abhyupagamāt
translated: Because it is accepted that the entire class of existent things has Brahman as its cause.

analyzed: āgama virodhaḥ tu prasiddhaḥ eva
translated: And the contradiction with the scriptures is well-known itself.

analyzed: cetanam brahma jagataḥ kāraṇam prakṛtiḥ ca iti āgama tātparyasya prasādhita tvāt
translated: For it has been established that the purport of the scriptures is that Brahman, which is conscious, is the cause and the material cause of the world.

analyzed: yat tu uktam pariniṣpanna tvāt brahmaṇi pramāṇa antarāṇi saṃbhaveyuḥ iti
translated: As for what was said that other means of knowledge may be possible in regard to Brahman because it is fully accomplished,

analyzed: tat api manoratha mātram
translated: that too is mere wishful thinking.

analyzed: rūpa ādi abhāvāt hi na ayam arthaḥ pratyakṣasya gocaraḥ
translated: For this meaning is not the object of perception, because form, etc. do not exist.

analyzed: liṅga ādi abhāvāt ca na anumāna ādīnām
translated: And because there is no inferential mark, etc., it is not of inference, etc.

analyzed: āgama mātra samadhigamyaḥ eva tu ayam arthaḥ dharma vat
translated: This meaning is to be comprehended only by scripture, like dharma.

original: tathāca śrutiḥ 'naiṣā tarkeṇa matirāpaneyā proktānyenaiva sujñānāya preṣṭha' kā / / / iti /
analyzed: tathā ca śrutiḥ na eṣā tarkeṇa matiḥ āpaneyā proktā anyena eva su jñānāya preṣṭha kā iti
translated: And thus the scripture says: This idea is not to be removed by reasoning. It has been declared by another for the sake of good knowledge, O dear one.

analyzed: kaḥ addhā veda kaḥ iha pravocat
translated: Who indeed knows? Who here would proclaim it?

analyzed: iyam visṛṣṭiḥ yatas ābabhūva ṛsam
translated: And the two verses, 'From Him hath proceeded this creation' (Rig-veda, X, 90, 1),

original: iti caite ṛcau siddhānāmapīśvarāṇāṃ durbodhatāṃ jagatkāraṇasya darśayataḥ /
analyzed: iti ca ete ṛcau siddhānām api īśvarāṇām durbodhatām jagat kāraṇasya darśayataḥ
translated: show that even the perfected Lords have difficulty in understanding the cause of the world.

original: smṛtirapi bhavati 'acintyāḥ khalu ye bhāvā na tāṃstarkeṇa yojayet' iti /
analyzed: smṛtiḥ api bhavati acintyāḥ khalu ye bhāvāḥ na tān tarkeṇa yojayet iti
translated: There is also a Smriti text: 'Those things which are inconceivable should not be reasoned about.'

analyzed: avyaktaḥ yama cintyaḥ yama vikāryaḥ yam ucyate iti ca
translated: And, 'He is said to be unmanifest, inconceivable, and immutable.'

original: 'na me viduḥ suragaṇāḥ prabhavaṃ na maharṣayaḥ /
analyzed: na me viduḥ sura gaṇāḥ prabhavam na mahā ṛṣayaḥ
translated: 'The hosts of gods do not know my origin, nor the great sages.

original: ahamādirhi devānāṃ maharṣīṇāṃ ca sarvaśaḥ' gī / /
analyzed: aham ādiḥ hi devānām mahā ṛṣīṇām ca sarvaśas
translated: For I am the beginning of all the gods and the great sages.'

analyzed: iti ca evañjātīyakā
translated: And there are other such texts.

original: yadapi śravaṇavyatirekeṇa mananaṃ vidadhacchabda eva tarkamapyādartavyaṃ darśayatītyuktam /
analyzed: yat api śravaṇa vyatirekeṇa mananam vidadhat śabdaḥ eva tarkam api ādartavyam darśayati iti uktam
translated: It has been said that the word itself, by enjoining reflection apart from hearing, shows that reasoning also should be accepted.

analyzed: na anena miṣeṇa śuṣka tarkasya atra ātmalābhaḥ saṃbhavati
translated: But reasoning by itself cannot be admitted here in this way.

analyzed: śruti anugṛhītaḥ eva hi atra tarkaḥ nubhava aṅga tvena āśrīyate
translated: For reasoning, when it is assisted by the scriptures, is accepted here as a means of knowledge.

analyzed: svapnānta buddhāntayoḥ ubhayoḥ itaretara vyabhicārāt ātmanaḥ nanu āgata tvam
translated: The soul is not affected by the two states, the waking state and the dream state, because they are mutually contradictory.

analyzed: saṃprasāde ca prapañca parityāgena sat ātmanā saṃpatteḥ niṣprapañca sat ātma tvam
translated: And in the state of perfect bliss, there is identity with the Self of Being through the abandonment of the world of plurality; hence the nature of being without plurality and of being the Self of Being.

analyzed: prapañcasya brahma prabhava tvāt kārya kāraṇa ananyatva nyāyena brahma avyatirekaḥ iti evañjātīyakaḥ
translated: Since the world of plurality has Brahman for its source, there is non-difference from Brahman by the principle that effect is not different from cause. Such is the kind of argument.

analyzed: tarka apratiṣṭhānāt
translated: Because reasoning is not established.

analyzed: iti ca kevalasya tarkasya avipralambhaka tvam darśayiṣyati
translated: And he will show that mere reasoning is deceptive.

original: yo 'pi cetanakāraṇaśravaṇabalenaiva samastasya jagataścetanatāmutprekṣate tasyāpi🔽vijñānaṃ cāvijñānaṃ ca iti cetanācetanavibhāgaśravaṇaṃ vibhāvanāvibhāvanābhyāṃ caitanyasya
analyzed: yaḥ pi cetana kāraṇa śravaṇa balena eva samastasya jagataḥ cetanatām utprekṣate tasya api  vijñānam ca a vijñānam ca iti cetana acetana vibhāga śravaṇam vibhāvanā a vibhāvanābhyām caitanyasya
translated: And he who imagines the sentience of the entire world by the power of hearing about the conscious cause alone,

analyzed: śakyate eva yojayitum
translated: for him, the hearing of the division of consciousness and non-consciousness into conscious and non-conscious can be explained by manifestation and non-manifestation of sentience.

analyzed: parasya eva tu idam api vibhāga śravaṇam na yujyate
translated: But for the other, even this hearing of the division is not proper.

analyzed: katham
translated: How?

original: paramakāraṇasya hyatra samastajagadātmanā samavasthānaṃ śrāvyate 'vijñānaṃ cāvijñānaṃ cābhavat' iti /
analyzed: parama kāraṇasya hi atra samasta jagat ātmanā samavasthānam śrāvyate vijñānam ca a vijñānam ca abhavat iti
translated: For here, the supreme cause is heard to exist in the form of the entire world: 'Consciousness and non-consciousness became.'

analyzed: tatra yathā cetanasya acetana bhāvaḥ na upapadyate vilakṣaṇa tvāt
translated: There, just as the state of being non-conscious is not possible for the conscious, because of being of a different nature,

analyzed: evam acetanasya api cetana bhāvaḥ na upapadyate
translated: Thus, the state of being conscious is not possible even for the insentient.

original: pratyuktatvāttu vilakṣaṇatvasya yathāśrutyaiva kāraṇaṃ grahītavyaṃ bhavati // //
analyzed: pratyukta tvāt tu vilakṣaṇa tvasya yathāśrutyā eva kāraṇam grahītavyam bhavati
translated: But since the difference has been refuted, the cause should be accepted just as it is heard.

analyzed: pāriṇāmikaḥ tad tad keśa ādi gata pariṇāma ātmakaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is based on the transformation of each hair, etc.

original: eṣā vedāntaśāstrajanyā matistarkeṇa svamatyūhamātreṇāpaneyā bādhārhā na /
analyzed: eṣā vedānta śāstra janyā matiḥ tarkeṇa sva matyūha mātreṇa apaneyā bādhā arhā na
translated: This understanding produced by the Vedanta scriptures should not be removed by mere reasoning, by one's own reasoning, and should be subject to refutation.

analyzed: yat vā tarkeṇa prāptavyāḥ na iti arthaḥ
translated: Or the meaning is that it should not be attained by reasoning.

original: kintu anyena nipuṇenācāryeṇa proktaprabodhitā satī sujñānāya sākṣātkārāya bhavati /
analyzed: kintu anyena nipuṇena ācāryeṇa prokta prabodhitā satī su jñānāya sākṣātkārāya bhavati
translated: But when it is spoken of, made known, by another wise teacher, it becomes for the attainment of true knowledge, for the realization of Brahman.

analyzed: he preṣṭha priyatama iti nāciketa saṃprati yama saṃbodhanam
translated: O beloved, O most dear one, this is the address of Naciketas to Yama.

original: iyaṃ visṛṣṭirākāśādisṛṣṭiḥ kutaḥ kasmājjātā kasmācca sthitiṃ prāptetyaddhā tattvena ko veda / na ko 'pi /
analyzed: iyam visṛṣṭiḥ ākāśa ādi sṛṣṭiḥ kutas kasmāt jātā kasmāt ca sthitim prāptā iti addhā tattvena kaḥ veda na kaḥ pi
translated: Who indeed knows the truth of this creation, the creation of space and so on? From what is it born? And why does it exist? No one knows.

original: kaḥ pravocat na ko 'pi pravaktābhūt /🔽vipralambhakatvaṃ arthaviśeṣāvyavasthāpakatvam /
analyzed: kaḥ pravocat na kaḥ pi pravaktā abhūt
translated: Who has spoken? No one has spoken.🔽Deceit means not establishing a particular meaning.

analyzed: asat iti ced na pratiṣedha mātra tvāt
translated: If it is said to be non-existent, it is not so, because it is mere negation.

original: yadi cetanaṃ śuddhaṃ śabdavihīnaṃ ca brahma tadviparūtasyācetanasyāśuddhasya śabdādimataśca kāryasya kāraṇamiṣyetāsattarhi kāryaṃ prāgutpatteriti
analyzed: yadi cetanam śuddham śabda vihīnam ca brahma tad viparūtasya acetanasya aśuddhasya śabda ādimataḥ ca kāryasya kāraṇam iṣyeta asat tarhi kāryam prāk utpatteḥ iti
translated: If Brahman, which is intelligent, pure, and devoid of sound, is the cause of the effect, which is the opposite of that, i.e., non-intelligent, impure, and possessed of sound, then the effect would be non-existent before its production.

analyzed: prasajyeta
translated: This would be the consequence.

analyzed: aniṣṭam ca etat satkārya vādinaḥ tava iti ced
translated: And this is undesirable for you, who maintain the doctrine of the existence of the effect.

analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ
translated: This is not a fault.

analyzed: pratiṣedha mātra tvāt
translated: Because it is mere negation.

analyzed: pratiṣedha mātram hi idam na asya pratiṣedhasya pratiṣedhyam asti
translated: This is mere negation. There is nothing to be negated by this negation.

original: nahyayaṃ pratiṣedhaḥ prāgutpatteḥ sattvaṃ kāryasya pratiṣeddhuṃ śaknoti /
analyzed: na hi ayam pratiṣedhaḥ prāk utpatteḥ sattvam kāryasya pratiṣeddhum śaknoti
translated: For this negation cannot negate the existence of the effect prior to its production.

analyzed: katham
translated: How?

original: yathaiva hīdānāmapīdaṃ kāryaṃ kāraṇātmanā sadevaṃ prāgutpatterapīti gamyate /
analyzed: yathā eva hi idānām api idam kāryam kāraṇa ātmanā sat evam prāk utpatteḥ api iti gamyate
translated: For just as this effect is known to exist in the form of its cause even now, so it was even before its production.

analyzed: nahi idānām api idam kāryam kāraṇa ātmānam antareṇa svatantram eva asti
translated: For even now this effect does not exist independently, apart from the nature of its cause.

analyzed: sarvam tam parādāt yaḥ nyatra ātmanaḥ sarvam veda bṛ
translated: All that is this, the first one gave to the other than the self; all that is this, one knows (Br. 3.8.9).

analyzed: ityādi śravaṇāt
translated: Thus it is heard.

analyzed: kāraṇa ātmanā tu sattvam kāryasya prāc utpatteḥ aviśiṣṭam
translated: But the existence of the effect in the form of its cause before its production is not different.

analyzed: nanu śabda ādi hīnam brahma jagataḥ kāraṇam
translated: But Brahman, devoid of sound etc., is the cause of the world.

analyzed: bāḍham
translated: Certainly.

original: natu śabdādimatkāryaṃ kāraṇātmanā hīnaṃ prāgutpatteridānīṃ vāsti /
analyzed: na tu śabda ādimat kāryam kāraṇa ātmanā hīnam prāk utpatteḥ idānīm vā asti
translated: But the effect, which consists of sound, etc., is not, prior to its origination, devoid of the nature of its cause.

analyzed: tena na śakyate vaktum prāk utpatteḥ asatkāryam iti
translated: Therefore it cannot be said that the effect did not exist prior to its origination.

analyzed: vistareṇa ca etat kārya kāraṇa ananyatva vāde vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: And this will be discussed at length in the doctrine of the non-difference of cause and effect.

analyzed: apītau tadvat prasaṅgāt asamañjasam  / atra āha yadi sthaulya sāvayavatva acetana tva paricchinna tva aśuddhi ādi dharmakam kāryam
translated: Even in the state of dissolution, it is not tenable due to the contingence of the same effect.

original: brahmakāraṇamabhyupagamyeta tadapītau pralaye pratisaṃsṛjyamānaṃ kāryaṃ kāraṇāvibhāgamāpadyamānaṃ🔽kāraṇamātmīyena dharmeṇa dūṣayedityapītau kāraṇasyāpi brahmaṇaḥ kāryasyevāśuddhyādirūpaprasaṅgātsarvajñaṃ
analyzed: brahma kāraṇam abhyupagamyeta tad apītau pralaye pratisaṃsṛjyamānam kāryam kāraṇa avibhāgam āpadyamānam  kāraṇam ātmīyena dharmeṇa dūṣayet iti apītau kāraṇasya api brahmaṇaḥ kāryasya iva aśuddhi ādi rūpa prasaṅgāt sarvajñam
translated: Here it is said: If Brahman, which is the cause, is accepted as having the qualities of grossness, having parts, being insentient, being limited, being impure, etc., then that effect, which is being reabsorbed in the state of dissolution, becoming undifferentiated from the cause,

analyzed: brahma jagat kāraṇam iti asamañjasam idam aupaniṣadam darśanam
translated: would taint the cause with its own qualities. Therefore, due to the contingence of Brahman, the cause, having the form of impurity, etc., like the effect, the Upanisadic doctrine that Brahman, the omniscient one, is the cause of the world, is not tenable.

analyzed: api ca samastasya vibhāgasya avibhāga prāpteḥ punar utpattau niyama kāraṇa abhāvāt bhoktṛ bhogya ādi vibhāgena utpattiḥ na prāpnoti iti asamañjasam
translated: Moreover, since the entire division would attain non-division, and there would be no cause for the re-origination of the division, the re-origination in the form of the division of the enjoyer and the enjoyed, etc., would not occur. Therefore it is not tenable.

original: apica bhoktṛṇāṃ pareṇa brahmaṇāvibhāgaṃ gatānāṃ karmādinimittapralaye 'pi punarutpattāvabhyupagamyamānāyāṃ muktānāmapi punaruttattiprasaṅgādasamañjasam
analyzed: api ca bhoktṛṇām pareṇa brahmaṇā avibhāgam gatānām karma ādi nimitta pralaye punarutpattau abhyupagamyamānāyām muktānām api punaruttatti prasaṅgāt asamañjasam
translated: Moreover, if it be admitted that the souls, which have become non-different from the highest Brahman, are again produced at the time of a new creation, although the cause of creation, action, &c, has ceased to exist, then it follows that even the released souls are again produced, and this is absurd

analyzed: atha idam jagat apītau api vibhaktam eva pareṇa brahmaṇā avatiṣṭheta
translated: If, on the other hand, the world, even during the state of dissolution, abides nondifferent from the highest Brahman,

analyzed: evam api apītīḥ ca na saṃbhavati
translated: then the dissolution itself is impossible

analyzed: kāraṇa avyatiriktam ca kāryam na saṃbhavati iti asamañjasam eva iti
translated: And that an effect can exist without being different from its cause is impossible; so that the doctrine of the Sāṅkhyas is altogether absurd

analyzed: atrā ucyate
translated: To this we make the following reply

analyzed: na tu dṛṣṭānta bhāvāt
translated: But not so, on account of the absence of an instance

original: naivāsmadīye darśane kiñcidasāmañjasyamasti /🔽yattāvadabhihitaṃ kāraṇamapigacchatkāryaṃ kāraṇamātmīyena dharmeṇa dūṣayediti /
analyzed: na eva asmadīye darśane kiñcid asāmañjasyam asti  yat tāvat abhihitam kāraṇam apigacchat kāryam kāraṇam ātmīyena dharmeṇa dūṣayet iti
translated: In our doctrine there is no difficulty whatever

analyzed: tat adūṣaṇam
translated: As to what has been said that the effect, when reabsorbed into the cause, must contaminate the cause by its own qualities, we reply that this is no objection

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

analyzed: dṛṣṭānta abhāvāt
translated: On account of the absence of an instance

original: santi hi dṛṣṭāntā yathā kāraṇamapigacchatkāryaṃ kāraṇamātmīyena dharmeṇa na dūṣayati /
analyzed: santi hi dṛṣṭāntāḥ yathā kāraṇam apigacchat kāryam kāraṇam ātmīyena dharmeṇa na dūṣayati
translated: There are instances of effects not contaminating the cause by their own qualities, even when reabsorbed into it

original: tadyathā śarāvādayo mṛtprakṛtikā vikārā vibhāgāvasthāyāmuccāvacamadhyamaprabhedāḥ santaḥ punaḥ prakṛtimapigacchanto na tāmātmīyena dharmeṇa 🔽saṃsṛjanti /
analyzed: tat yathā śarāva ādayaḥ mṛd prakṛtikāḥ vikārāḥ vibhāga avasthāyām uccāvaca madhyama prabhedāḥ santaḥ punar prakṛtim apigacchantaḥ na tām ātmīyena dharmeṇa  / saṃsṛjanti
translated: For example, things like a pot, which are modifications of clay, having distinctions of high, low, and medium in the state of separation, when they again return to the original nature, do not mix that [original nature] with their own attributes.

original: rucakādayaśca suvarṇavikārā apītau na suvarṇamātmīyena dharmeṇa saṃsṛjanti /
analyzed: rucaka ādayaḥ ca suvarṇa vikārāḥ apītau na suvarṇam ātmīyena dharmeṇa saṃsṛjanti
translated: And things like gold ornaments, even when melted, do not mix gold with their own attributes.

original: pṛthivīvikāraścaturvidho bhūtagrāmo na pṛthivīmapītāvātmīyena dharmeṇa saṃsṛjati /
analyzed: pṛthivī vikāraḥ caturvidhaḥ bhūta grāmaḥ na pṛthivīm api itau ātmīyena dharmeṇa saṃsṛjati
translated: And the four types of beings, which are modifications of earth, do not mix earth with their own attributes even when melted.

analyzed: tvad pakṣasya tu na kaścid dṛṣṭāntaḥ asti
translated: But in your view, there is no example at all.

original: apītireva hi na saṃbhavedyadi kāraṇe kāryaṃ svadharmeṇaivāvatiṣṭheta /
analyzed: apītiḥ eva hi na saṃbhavet yadi kāraṇe kāryam svadharmeṇa eva avatiṣṭheta
translated: For if the effect were to remain in the cause with its own attributes, the melting itself would not be possible.

original: ananyatve 'pi kāryakāraṇayoḥ kāryasya kāraṇātmatvaṃ natu kāraṇasya kāryātmatvaṃ 'ārambhaṇaśabdādibhyaḥ' iti vakṣyāmaḥ bra /sū / / / /
analyzed: ananya tve pi kārya kāraṇayoḥ kāryasya kāraṇa ātmatvam na tu kāraṇasya kārya ātmatvam ārambhaṇa śabda ādibhyaḥ iti vakṣyāmaḥ brasū
translated: Even if the effect and the cause are not different, we will explain that the effect has the nature of the cause, but the cause does not have the nature of the effect, because of the words 'ārambhaṇa' etc. (Br. Sū. 1.1.10).

original: atyalpaṃ cedamucyate kāryamapītāvātmīyena dharmeṇa kāraṇaṃ saṃsṛjediti /
analyzed: ati alpam ca idam ucyate kāryam apītau ātmīyena dharmeṇa kāraṇam saṃsṛjet iti
translated: And this is said to be very little: that the effect should mix with the cause with its own attributes even when melted.

analyzed: sthitau api samānaḥ yam prasaṅgaḥ
translated: This same consequence applies even in the state of existence.

analyzed: kārya kāraṇayoḥ ananyatva abhyupagamāt
translated: Because the non-difference of the effect and the cause is accepted.

analyzed: idam sarva yat ayam ātmā bṛ
translated: 'This all is that Self' (Br. Up. 4.5.7).

analyzed: ātmā eva idam sarvam chā
translated: 'The Self is all this' (Ch. Up. 7.25.2).

analyzed: brahma eva idam amṛtam purastāt
translated: 'Brahman alone, immortal, is in front' (Mu. Up. 2.2.12).

analyzed: sarvam khalu idam brahma chā
translated: 'All this is indeed Brahman' (Ch. Up. 3.14.1).

original: ityevamādyābhirhi śrutibhiraviśeṣeṇa triṣvapi kāleṣu kāryasya kāraṇānanyatvaṃ śrāvyate /
analyzed: iti evamādyābhiḥ hi śrutibhiḥ aviśeṣeṇa triṣu api kāleṣu kāryasya kāraṇa ananya tvam śrāvyate
translated: For by these and other such passages, the non-difference of the effect from the cause is declared without distinction in all three times.

original: tatra yaḥ parihāraḥ kāryasya taddharmāṇāṃ cāvidyādhyāropitatvānna taiḥ kāraṇaṃ saṃsṛjyata iti /
analyzed: tatra yaḥ parihāraḥ kāryasya tad dharmāṇām ca avidyā adhyāropita tvāt na taiḥ kāraṇam saṃsṛjyate iti
translated: There, the same reply is given to the effect and its properties being superimposed by ignorance, that the cause is not connected with them.

analyzed: api itau api sa samānaḥ
translated: And this is also the same in the past.

original: asti cāyamaparo dṛṣṭānto yathā svayaṃ prasāritayā māyayā māyāvī triṣvapi kāleṣu na saṃspaśyate /
analyzed: asti ca ayam aparaḥ dṛṣṭāntaḥ yathā svayam prasāritayā māyayā māyāvī triṣu api kāleṣu na saṃspaśyate
translated: And there is this other example: Just as a magician is not touched by his own magic in all three times,

analyzed: avastu tvāt
translated: because it is unreal.

original: evaṃ paramātmāpi saṃsāramāyayā na saṃspṛśyata iti /
analyzed: evam paramātmā api saṃsāra māyayā na saṃspṛśyate iti
translated: In the same way, the supreme Self is not touched by the magic of transmigration.

original: yathā ca svapnadṛgekaḥ svapnadarśanamāyayā na saṃspṛśyata iti /
analyzed: yathā ca svapna dṛś ekaḥ svapna darśana māyayā na saṃspṛśyate iti
translated: And just as the dreamer is not touched by the magic of dreaming,

analyzed: prabodha saṃpradāyoḥ an anvāgata tvāt
translated: because the time of waking and the time of dreaming are not connected.

analyzed: evam avasthā traya sākṣī ekaḥ vyabhicārī avasthā trayeṇa vyabhicāriṇā na saṃspṛśyate
translated: In the same way, the one who is the witness of the three states is not touched by the three changing states.

analyzed: māyā mātram hi etat yat paramātmanaḥ vasthā traya ātmanā avabhāsanam rajjvā iva sarpa ādi bhāvena iti
translated: For this is mere illusion, that the highest Self appears in the three states, as a rope appears as a snake.

original: atroktaṃ vedāntārthasaṃpradāyavidbhirācāryaiḥ 'anādimāyayā supto yadā jīvaḥ prabudhyate /
analyzed: atra uktam vedānta artha saṃpradāya vidbhiḥ ācāryaiḥ anādi māyayā suptaḥ yadā jīvaḥ prabudhyate
translated: Here the teachers who know the traditional interpretation of the Vedanta have said: 'When the individual soul, asleep by beginningless illusion, awakens,

original: ajamanidramasvapnamadvaitaṃ budhyate tadā' gauḍapā / kāri / / iti /
analyzed: ajam anidram asvapnam advaitam budhyate tadā iti
translated: then it knows the unborn, undeluded, dreamless, non-dual Self.' (Gauḍapādīyākāśaśāstra 1.14)

original: tatra yaduktamapītau kāraṇasyāpi kāryasyeva sthaulyādidoṣaprasaṅga ityetadayuktam /
analyzed: tatra yat uktam apītau kāraṇasya api kāryasya iva sthaulya ādi doṣa prasaṅgaḥ iti etat ayuktam
translated: Here it is said that the objection that even the cause, like the effect, would incur the fault of having extension, etc., during manifestation, is not correct.

original: yatpunaretaduktaṃ samastasya vibhāgasyāvibhāgaprāpteḥ punarvibhāgenotpattau niyamakāraṇaṃ nopapadyata iti /
analyzed: yat punar etat uktam samastasya vibhāgasya avibhāga prāpteḥ punar vibhāgena utpattau niyama kāraṇam na upapadyate iti
translated: Again, the objection that there is no logical ground for the re-origination of the entire differentiated universe by differentiation after the attainment of non-differentiation is also not valid.

analyzed: ayam api adoṣaḥ
translated: This is also faultless.

analyzed: dṛṣṭānta bhāvāt eva
translated: Because of the analogy.

original: yathāhi suṣuptisamādhyādāvapi satyāṃ svābhāvikyāmavibhāgaprāptau mithyājñānasyānapoditatvātpūrvavatpunaḥ prabodhe vibhāgo bhavatyevamihāpi
analyzed: yathā hi suṣupti samādhi ādau api satyām svābhāvikyām avibhāga prāptau mithyājñānasya anapodita tvāt pūrvavat punar prabodhe vibhāgaḥ bhavati evam iha api
translated: Just as even in deep sleep, meditation, etc., when there is the natural attainment of non-differentiation, the differentiation occurs again as before upon awakening due to the non-denial of false knowledge, so it is here also.

original: śrutiścātra bhavati 'imāḥ sarvāḥ prajāḥ sati saṃpadya na viduḥ sati saṃpadyāmaha
analyzed: śrutiḥ ca atra bhavati imāḥ sarvāḥ prajāḥ sati saṃpadya na viduḥ sati saṃpadyāmaha
translated: And here there is the Vedic text: 'All these beings, attaining existence, do not know We have attained existence.

original: iti ta iha vyāghro vā siṃho vā vṛko vā varāho vā kīṭo vā pataṅgo vā daṃśo vā maśako
analyzed: iti te iha vyāghraḥ vā siṃhaḥ vā vṛkaḥ vā varāhaḥ vā kīṭaḥ vā pataṅgaḥ vā daṃśaḥ vā maśakaḥ
translated: Thus, in this world, they become whatever they are, a tiger, a lion, a wolf, a boar, a worm, a fly, a gadfly, or a mosquito.

original: vā yadyadbhavanti tadā bhavanti' chā / / / / iti /
analyzed: vā yat yat bhavanti tadā bhavanti chā iti
translated: Thus it is said.

original: yathā hyavibhāge 'pi paramātmani mithyājñānapratibaddho vibhāgavyavahāraḥ svapnavadavyāhataḥ sthito dṛśyate /
analyzed: yathā hi avibhāge pi paramātmani mithyā jñāna pratibaddhaḥ vibhāga vyavahāraḥ svapna vat avyāhataḥ sthitaḥ dṛśyate
translated: For just as, even in the undivided Supreme Self, the usage of division based on false knowledge is seen to stand uncontradicted like in a dream,

analyzed: evam api itau api mithyā jñāna pratibaddhā eva vibhāga śaktiḥ anumāsyate
translated: in the same way, even in the state of dissolution, the power of division based on false knowledge is inferred.

analyzed: etena muktānām punarutpatti prasaṅgaḥ pratyuktaḥ
translated: By this, the possibility of rebirth for the liberated is answered.

analyzed: samyak jñānena mithyājñānasya apodita tvāt
translated: Because false knowledge is removed by true knowledge.

original: yaḥ punarayamante 'paro vikalpa utprekṣito 'thedaṃ jagadapītāvapi vibhaktameva pareṇa brahmaṇāvatiṣṭheteti /
analyzed: yaḥ punar ayam ante paraḥ vikalpaḥ utprekṣitaḥ thā idam jagat apītau api vibhaktam eva pareṇa brahmaṇā avatiṣṭheta iti
translated: As for this other option imagined at the end, that even in the state of dissolution, this world remains divided from the supreme Brahman,

analyzed: saḥ u pi anabhyupagamāt eva pratiṣiddhaḥ
translated: that too is refuted simply because it is not accepted.

analyzed: tasmāt samañjasam idam aupaniṣadam darśanam
translated: Therefore, this Upanishadic view is coherent.

analyzed: apigacchat līyamānam
translated: Even though it goes, i.e., dissolves.

analyzed: vibhāga avasthā sthiti kālaḥ
translated: The state of division is the period of persistence.

analyzed: sati brahmaṇi ekībhūya na viduḥ iti ajñāna uktiḥ
translated: When Brahman exists, they do not know by becoming one. This is said out of ignorance.

original: iha suṣupteḥ prāk prabodhe yena jātyādinā vibhaktā bhavanti tadā punarutthānakāle tathaiva bhavantīti vibhāgoktiḥ /
analyzed: iha suṣupteḥ prāk prabodhe yena jāti ādinā vibhaktāḥ bhavanti tadā punar utthāna kāle tathā eva bhavanti iti vibhāga uktiḥ
translated: Here, before deep sleep, when they are differentiated by birth etc., then at the time of rising again they become just as they were. This is the statement of differentiation.

analyzed: sva pakṣa doṣāt ca
translated: And because of the faults in one's own position...

original: svapakṣe caite prativādinaḥ sādhāraṇā doṣāḥ prāduṣyuḥ /
analyzed: sva pakṣe ca ete prativādinaḥ sādhāraṇāḥ doṣāḥ prāduṣyuḥ
translated: And these faults common to the opponent would appear in one's own position.

analyzed: katham iti ucyate
translated: How is this said?

analyzed: yat tāvat abhihitam vilakṣaṇa tvāt na idam jagat brahma prakṛtikam iti
translated: As for what was said, This world cannot have Brahman as its material cause because of being different,

analyzed: pradhāna prakṛtika tāyām api samānam etat
translated: this is the same even in the doctrine of Prakriti as the material cause.

original: śabdādihīnātpradhānācchabdādimato jagata utpattyabhyupagamāt /🔽ata eva ca vilakṣaṇakāryotpattyabhyupagamātsamānaḥ prāgutpatterasatkāryavādaprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: śabda ādi hīnāt pradhānāt śabda ādimataḥ jagataḥ utpatti abhyupagamāt  atas eva ca vilakṣaṇa kārya utpatti abhyupagamāt samānaḥ prāk utpatteḥ asatkārya vāda prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Because it is accepted that the world, which has sound etc., originates from Prakriti, which is devoid of sound etc.🔽And for this very reason, because of accepting the origination of an effect that is different, the same fault of the doctrine of non-existence of the effect before origination applies.

analyzed: tathā api itau kāryasya kāraṇa vibhāga abhyupagamāt tadvat prasaṅgaḥ pi samānaḥ
translated: Similarly, because of accepting the separation of the effect from the cause in the state of dissolution, the same fault of being like that applies.

analyzed: tathā mṛdita sarva viśeṣeṣu vikāreṣu apītau avibhāga ātma tām gateṣu idam asya puruṣasya upādānam idam asya iti
translated: Similarly, when all modifications, in which all distinctions are destroyed, have become undifferentiated in the state of dissolution, this is the material cause of this Purusha, this of that,

original: prākpralayātpratipuruṣaṃ ye niyatā bhedā na te tathaiva punarutpatau niyantuṃ śakyante kāraṇābhāvāt /
analyzed: prāk pralayāt prati puruṣam ye niyatāḥ bhedāḥ na te tathā eva punarutpatau niyantum śakyante kāraṇa abhāvāt
translated: Before the dissolution, the particular modifications that are restricted to each individual soul cannot be so restricted again at the time of creation, because there is no cause for it.

analyzed: vinā eva kāraṇena niyame bhyupagamyamāne kāraṇa abhāva sāmyāt muktānām api punar bandha prasaṅgaḥ
translated: If it were admitted that they are so restricted without any cause, then even the liberated souls would have to be re-bound, because the absence of cause would be the same in both cases.

analyzed: atha kecid bhedāḥ api itau avibhāgam āpadyante kenacid na iti ced
translated: If it be said that some of the modifications do become undifferentiated at the time of creation, while some do not,

original: ye nāpadyante teṣāṃ pradhānakāryatvaṃ na prāpnotītyevamete doṣāḥ sādhāraṇatvānnānyatarasminpakṣe codayitavyā bhavantītyadoṣatāmevaiṣāṃ draḍhayati
analyzed: ye na āpadyante teṣām pradhāna kārya tvam na prāpnoti iti evam ete doṣāḥ sādhāraṇa tvāt na anyatarasmin pakṣe codayitavyāḥ bhavanti iti adoṣa tām eva eṣām draḍhayati
translated: then those that do not become so cannot be the effects of Primordial Matter. Thus, these objections being common to both views, should not be urged against either of them. In order to strengthen the view that they are not objections, he says

analyzed: avaśya āśrayitavya tvāt  prāduṣ prādurbhū
translated: Because it is absolutely necessary to admit...🔽If it be said that even so, there would be no liberation, because of the uncertainty of reasoning,

original: tarkāpratiṣṭhānād apy anyathānumeyam iti ced evam apy anirmokṣaprasaṅgaḥ / / / /
analyzed: tarka apratiṣṭhānāt api anyathā anumeyam iti ced evam api anirmokṣa prasaṅgaḥ
translated: we say that even so, there would be the undesirable contingency of no liberation.

analyzed: itas ca na āgama gamya ṛthe kevalena tarkeṇa pratyavasthātavyam
translated: For this reason also, one should not rely on mere reasoning in a matter that is knowable only through scriptures.

analyzed: yasmin nirāgamāḥ puruṣa utprekṣā mātra nibandhanāḥ tarkāḥ apratiṣṭhitāḥ bhavanti
translated: Reasonings, which are not based on scriptures, but are based merely on the imagination of men, are not well-founded.

analyzed: utprekṣāyāḥ niḥ aṅ kuśa tvāt
translated: Because imagination is unrestrained.

original: tathāhi kaiścidabhiyuktairyatnenotprekṣitāstarkā abhiyuktarairanyairābhāsyamānā dṛśyante /🔽tairapyutprekṣitāḥ santastato 'nyairābhāsyanta iti na pratiṣṭhitatvaṃ tarkāṇāṃ śakyamāśrayituṃ /
analyzed: tathā hi kaiścid abhiyuktaiḥ yatnena utprekṣitāḥ tarkāḥ abhiyuktaraiḥ anyaiḥ ābhāsyamānāḥ dṛśyante  taiḥ api utprekṣitāḥ santaḥ tatas nyaiḥ ābhāsyante iti na pratiṣṭhita tvam tarkāṇām śakyam āśrayitum
translated: For we see that arguments which are set forth with great effort by some learned men are shown to be fallacious by others who are more learned.

original: puruṣamativairūpyāt /🔽atha kasyacitprasiddhamāhātmyasya kapilasya cānyasya vā saṃmatastarkaḥ pratiṣṭhita ityāśrīyeta /
analyzed: puruṣa mati vairūpyāt  atha kasyacid prasiddha māhātmyasya kapilasya ca anyasya vā saṃmataḥ tarkaḥ pratiṣṭhitaḥ iti āśrīyeta
translated: And those arguments which are set forth by the latter are shown to be fallacious by others. Thus we cannot rely on the stability of arguments, because the minds of men are so various.

analyzed: evam api apratiṣṭhita tvam eva
translated: If, on the other hand, we were to rely on an argument which is accepted by some famous and great man, such as Kapila or some other, even so there would be no stability.

analyzed: prasiddha māhātmya anumatānām api tīrthakarāṇām kapila kaṇabhuj prabhṛtīnām paraspara vipratipatti darśanāt
translated: For we see that even those teachers who are famous and great, such as Kapila, Kanāda, and others, disagree with one another.

analyzed: atas ucyeta anyathā vayam anumāsyāmahe yathā na a pratiṣṭhā doṣaḥ bhaviṣyati
translated: Therefore it might be said that we will argue in such a way that the fault of instability will not occur.

original: nahi pratiṣṭhitastarka eva nāstīti śakyate vaktum /
analyzed: nahi pratiṣṭhitaḥ tarkaḥ eva na asti iti śakyate vaktum
translated: For it cannot be said that there is no stable argument at all.

analyzed: etat api hi tarkāṇām apratiṣṭhita tvam tarkeṇa eva pratiṣṭhāpyate
translated: For this instability of arguments is itself established by an argument.

analyzed: keṣāṃcid tarkāṇām apratiṣṭhita tva darśanena anyeṣām api tad jātīyakānām tarkāṇām apratiṣṭhita tvāt
translated: Because some reasonings are seen to be unestablished, other reasonings of the same kind are also unestablished.

analyzed: sarva tarka apratiṣṭhāyām ca lokavyavahāra uccheda prasaṅgaḥ
translated: And if all reasonings are unestablished, there would be the undesirable consequence of the cessation of worldly conventions.

original: atītavartamānādhvasāmyena hyanāgate 'pyadhvani sukhaduḥkhaprāptiparihārāya pravartamāno loko dṛśyate /
analyzed: atīta vartamāna adhva sāmyena hi anāgate pi adhvani sukha duḥkha prāpti parihārāya pravartamānaḥ lokaḥ dṛśyate
translated: For the world is seen to engage in activities for attaining happiness and avoiding suffering in the future time as well, by the similarity of past and present times.

original: śrutyarthavipratipattau cārthābhāsanirākaraṇena samyagarthanirdhāraṇaṃ tarkeṇaiva vākyavṛttinirūpaṇarūpeṇa kriyate /🔽manurapi caivaṃ manyate 'pratyakṣamanumānaṃ ca śāstraṃ ca vividhāgamam /
analyzed: śruti artha vipratipattau ca artha ābhāsa nirākaraṇena samyak artha nirdhāraṇam tarkeṇa eva vākya vṛtti nirūpaṇa rūpeṇa kriyate  manuḥ api ca evam manyate pratyakṣam anumānam ca śāstram ca vividha āgamam
translated: And in the case of disagreement about the meaning of the scriptures, the determination of the correct meaning by the exclusion of false meanings is done by reasoning itself in the form of determining the function of the sentences.

original: trayaṃ suviditaṃ kāryaṃ dharmaśuddhimabhīpsitā //🔽' iti /🔽'ārṣaṃ dharmopadeśaṃ ca vedaśāstravirodhinā /
analyzed: trayam su viditam kāryam dharma śuddhim abhīpsitā  iti  ārṣam dharma upadeśam ca veda śāstra virodhinā
translated: And Manu also thinks thus: The three - perception, inference, and the various scriptures - should be well known, for the sake of the purity of dharma.

analyzed: yaḥ tarkeṇa anusaṃdhatte sa dharmam veda na itaraḥ
translated: And he who investigates with reasoning the teaching of dharma by the sages, which is contrary to the Vedas and scriptures, he knows dharma, not the other.

analyzed: iti ca bruvan
translated: Thus speaking.

analyzed: ayam eva tarkasya alaṅkāraḥ yat apratiṣṭhita tvam nāma
translated: This is indeed the ornament of reasoning, namely what is called unestablishment.

analyzed: evam hi tāvat yat tarka parityāgena niravadyaḥ tarkaḥ pratipattavyaḥ bhavati
translated: For in this way, indeed, the faultless reasoning should be accepted by abandoning the reasoning that is faulty.

original: nahi pūrvajo mūḍha āsīdityātmanāpi mūḍhena bhavitavyamiti kiñcidasti pramāṇam /
analyzed: nahi pūrvajaḥ mūḍhaḥ āsīt iti ātmanā api mūḍhena bhavitavyam iti kiñcid asti pramāṇam
translated: For there is no valid means of knowledge whatsoever that says, Since the previous person was deluded, one must be deluded oneself.

analyzed: tasmāt na tarka apratiṣṭhānam doṣaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that Therefore, the lack of establishment of reasoning is not a fault,

analyzed: evam api a vimokṣa prasaṅgaḥ
translated: then even so, there is the consequence of non-liberation.

original: yadyapi kvacidviṣaye tarkasya pratiṣṭhitatvamupalakṣyate tathāpi prakṛte tāvadviṣaye prasajyata evāpratiṣṭhitatvadoṣādanirmokṣastarkasya /
analyzed: yadi api kvacid viṣaye tarkasya pratiṣṭhita tvam upalakṣyate tathā api prakṛte tāvat viṣaye prasajyate eva apratiṣṭhita tva doṣāt anirmokṣaḥ tarkasya
translated: Even though the establishment of reasoning is observed in some cases, still, in the present case, the fault of lack of establishment applies, and there is no liberation for reasoning.

analyzed: nahi idam ati gambhīram bhāva yāthātmyam mukti nibandhanam āgamam antareṇa utprekṣitum api śakyam
translated: For this extremely profound reality of the nature of existence, which is the basis of liberation, cannot be imagined even without scripture.

analyzed: rūpa ādi abhāvāt hi na ayam arthaḥ pratyakṣa gocaraḥ
translated: Because of the absence of form and so on, this meaning is not the domain of perception.

analyzed: liṅga ādi abhāvāt ca na anumāna ādīnām iti ca avocāma
translated: And because of the absence of inferential marks and so on, it is not of inference and so on, we have said.

original: apica samyagjñānānmokṣa iti sarveṣāṃ mokṣavādināmabhyupagamaḥ /🔽tacca samyagjñānamekarūpaṃ vastutantratvāt /
analyzed: api ca samyak jñānāt mokṣaḥ iti sarveṣām mokṣa vādinām abhyupagamaḥ  tat ca samyak jñānam eka rūpam vastu tantra tvāt
translated: Moreover, all those who speak of liberation accept that liberation comes from right knowledge.🔽And that right knowledge is of one form, because it depends on reality.

analyzed: eka rūpeṇa hi avasthitaḥ yaḥ ṛthaḥ sa paramārthaḥ
translated: For that object which exists in one form is the ultimate reality.

original: loke tadviṣayaṃ jñānaṃ samyagjñānamityucyate yathāgniruṣṇā iti /
analyzed: loke tad viṣayam jñānam samyak jñānam iti ucyate yathā agniḥ uṣṇāḥ iti
translated: That knowledge of the world which has that for its object is called right knowledge, just as fire is hot.

analyzed: tatra evam sati samgjñāne puruṣāṇām vipratipattiḥ anupapannā
translated: In that case, the disagreement of men regarding right knowledge is not possible.

analyzed: tarka jñānānām tu anyonya virodhāt prasiddhā vipratipattiḥ
translated: But the disagreement of reasonings is well known due to mutual contradiction.

original: yaddhi kenacittārkikeṇedameva samyagjñānamiti pratipāditaṃ tadapareṇa vyutthāpyate /
analyzed: yat hi kenacid tārkikeṇa idam eva samyak jñānam iti pratipāditam tat apareṇa vyutthāpyate
translated: For what is taught by some logician as right knowledge is refuted by another.

original: tenāpi pratiṣṭhāpitaṃ tato 'pareṇa vyutthāpyata iti prasiddhaṃ loke /
analyzed: tena api pratiṣṭhāpitam pareṇa vyutthāpyate iti prasiddham loke
translated: What is established by him is again refuted by another. This is well known in the world.

analyzed: katham eka rūpa anavasthita viṣayam tarka prabhavam samyak jñānam bhavet
translated: How can the reasoning-born right knowledge have an unstable object of one form?

original: naca pradhānavādī tarkavidāmuttama iti sarvāstārkikaiḥ parigṛhīto yena tadīyaṃ mataṃ samyagjñānamiti pratipadyemahi /
analyzed: na ca pradhāna vādī tarka vidām uttamaḥ iti sarvāḥ tārkikaiḥ parigṛhītaḥ yena tadīyam matam samyak jñānam iti pratipadyemahi
translated: And the proponent of pradhāna is not accepted by all logicians as the best, by whom we could understand that his view is right knowledge.

original: naca śakyante 'tītānāgatavartamānāstārkikā ekasmindeśe kāle ca samāhartuṃ yena tanmatirekarūpaikārthaviṣayā samyaṅmatiriti syāta /
analyzed: na ca śakyante tīta anāgata vartamānāḥ tārkikāḥ ekasmin deśe kāle ca samāhartum yena tad matiḥ eka rūpa eka artha viṣayā samyak matiḥ iti syāta
translated: And it is not possible to bring together all the logicians of the past, future and present in one place and time, by whom their view with a single form and single object could be right knowledge.

original: vedasya tu nityatve vijñānotpattihetutve ca sati vyavasthitārthaviṣayatvopapattestajjanitasya jñānasya samyaktvamatītānāgatavartamānaiḥ sarvairapi
analyzed: vedasya tu nitya tve vijñāna utpatti hetu tve ca sati vyavasthita artha viṣaya tva upapatteḥ tad janitasya jñānasya samyaktvam atīta anāgata vartamānaiḥ sarvaiḥ api
translated: But when the Veda is eternal and the cause of the production of knowledge, it is possible that it has for its object a well-established meaning, and so the knowledge produced by it must be true, and this cannot be denied by all, past, future, and present,

analyzed: tārkikaiḥ apahnotum aśakyam
translated: even by logicians.

analyzed: atas siddham asya eva aupaniṣadasya jñānasya samyak jñāna tvam
translated: Therefore, it is established that this knowledge of the Upanishads alone is true knowledge.

analyzed: atas nyatra samyak jñāna tva anupapatteḥ saṃsāra avimokṣaḥ eva prasajyeta
translated: From this, since true knowledge is not possible in anything else, the consequence would be that there would be no liberation from worldly existence.

original: ata āgamavaśenāgamānusāritarkavaśena ca cetanaṃ brahmajagataḥ kāraṇaṃ prakṛtiśceti sthitam // //
analyzed: atas āgama vaśena āgama anusāri tarka vaśena ca cetanam brahma jagataḥ kāraṇam prakṛtiḥ ca iti sthitam  /
translated: Therefore, it is established that the intelligent Brahman is the cause and material cause of the world, by the authority of the scriptures and by reasoning which follows the scriptures.

analyzed: tarkasya kaivalyam anugrāhya āgama rāhityam
translated: Reasoning is independent when it is devoid of scriptures to be followed.

analyzed: dharmasya śuddhiḥ adharmāt bheda nirṇayaḥ
translated: Purification of dharma is the ascertainment of the difference from adharma.

analyzed: atigam abhīra tvam āgama ati rmekā māna ayogya tvam
translated: Depth of transcendence is the unsuitability of the scriptures for those who are not fit for the scriptures.

analyzed: bhāva yāthātmyam kāraṇa gatam advitīya tvam
translated: The nature of existence is the non-duality inherent in the cause.🔽The basis of liberation is the state of being solely of true bliss and consciousness.

analyzed: śiṣṭa parigraha adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on the inclusion of the learned. Sutra.

analyzed: etena śiṣṭa a parigrahāḥ api vyākhyātāḥ
translated: By this, the non-inclusion of the learned is also explained.

analyzed: vaidikasya darśanasya pratyāsanna tvāt gurutara tarka bala upeta tvāt veda anusāribhiḥ ca kaiścid śiṣṭhaiḥ
translated: Because the Vedāntic view is proximate, because it is endowed with the force of very weighty reasoning, and because it is partially accepted by some wise men who follow the Vedas,

analyzed: kenacid aṃśena parigṛhīta tvāt pradhāna kāraṇa vādam tāvat vyapāśritya yaḥ tarka nimitta
translated: the objection based on reasoning that has been raised against the Vedāntic statements regarding the Self,

analyzed: ākṣepaḥ vedānta vākyeṣu udbhāvitaḥ sa parihṛtaḥ
translated: that objection has been refuted.

original: idānīmaṇvādivādavyapāśrayeṇāpi kaiścinmandamatibhirvedāntavākyeṣu punastarkanimitta ākṣepa āśaṅkyata ityataḥ pradhānamallanibarhaṇanyāyenātidiśati
analyzed: idānīm aṇu ādi vāda vyapāśrayeṇa api kaiścid manda matibhiḥ vedānta vākyeṣu punar tarka nimittaḥ ākṣepaḥ āśaṅkyate iti atas pradhāna malla nibarhaṇa nyāyena atidiśati
translated: Now, some slow-witted people may again suspect an objection based on reasoning in the Vedāntic statements, relying on the atomic and other theories. Therefore, he supersedes the principal one like in the wrestling match of Malla-Nibarhana.

original: parigṛhyanta iti parigrahāḥ na parigrahā aparigrahāḥ śiṣṭānāmaparigrahāḥ /🔽etena prakṛtena pradhānakāraṇavādanirākaraṇakāraṇena śiṣṭairmanuvyāsaprabhṛtibhiḥ
analyzed: parigṛhyante iti parigrahāḥ na parigrahāḥ a parigrahāḥ śiṣṭānām a parigrahāḥ  etena prakṛtena pradhāna kāraṇa vāda nirākaraṇa kāraṇena śiṣṭaiḥ manu vyāsa prabhṛtibhiḥ
translated: Those that are accepted are the acceptances. Those that are not acceptances are the non-acceptances, the non-acceptances of the wise.

analyzed: ye ṇu ādi kāraṇa vādāḥ te pi pratiṣiddha tayā vyākhyātā nirākṛtā
translated: By this present reason, by the reason for refuting the theory of primordial matter as the cause, those atomic and other theories of causation that are not accepted by any part by the wise such as Manu, Vyāsa, etc.,

analyzed: draṣṭavyāḥ tulya tvāt nirākaraṇa kāraṇasya na atra punar āśaṅkitavyam kiñcid asti
translated: are to be seen as refuted, explained, and rejected. Because the reason for refutation is the same, nothing should be suspected here again.

original: tulyamātrāpi paramagambhīrasya jagatkāraṇasya tarkānavagāhyatvaṃ tarkasyāpratiṣṭhitatvamanyathānumāne 'pyavimokṣa āgamavirodhaścetyevañjātīyakaṃ
analyzed: tulya mātrā api parama gambhīrasya jagat kāraṇasya tarka anavagāhya tvam tarkasya apratiṣṭhita tvam anyathā anumāne pi avimokṣaḥ āgama virodhaḥ ca iti evañjātīyakam
translated: The refutation of the arguments of the opponent, viz., that even if the Vedānta texts are of the same amount, the cause of the world, which is very deep, cannot be fathomed by reasoning, that reasoning is not established, that there is no escape even in inference, and that there is contradiction with scripture, is as follows:

analyzed: nirākaraṇam
translated: The refutation is as follows.

analyzed: bhoktṛ āpattyā adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on the consequence of being the enjoyer. Sutra

analyzed: bhoktṛ āpatteḥ avibhāgaḥ ced syāt loka vat
translated: If it is argued that there is no division because of the consequence of being the enjoyer, it would be like in the world.

analyzed: anyathā punar brahma kāraṇa vādaḥ tarka balena eva ākṣipyate
translated: On the other hand, the doctrine of Brahman as the cause is refuted by reasoning itself.

original: yadyapi śrutiḥ pramāṇaṃ svaviṣaye bhavati tathāpi pramāṇāntareṇa viṣayāpahāre 'nyaparā bhavitumarti /
analyzed: yadi api śrutiḥ pramāṇam sva viṣaye bhavati tathā api pramāṇa antareṇa viṣaya apahāre
translated: Even though the Veda is a means of valid knowledge in its own domain, still, when the object is removed by another means of valid knowledge, it can have a different purport.

analyzed: yathā mantra arthavādau
translated: Like the meaning of mantras and arthavadas.

analyzed: tarke pi sva viṣayāt anyatra apratiṣṭhitaḥ syāt yathā dharma adharmayoḥ
translated: Reasoning too would not be established elsewhere than in its own domain, like in the case of dharma and adharma.

analyzed: kim atas yadi evam
translated: What then if it is so?

analyzed: atas idam ayuktam yat pramāṇa antara prasiddha artha bādhanam śruteḥ
translated: This is improper, that the Veda contradicts an object known by another means of valid knowledge.

original: kathaṃ punaḥ pramāṇāntaraprasiddhor'thaḥ śrutyā bādhyata iti /
analyzed: katham punar pramāṇa antara prasiddhaḥ ūrthaḥ śrutyā bādhyate iti
translated: How is an object known by another means of valid knowledge contradicted by the Veda?

original: atrocyate prasiddho hyayaṃ bhoktṛbhogyavibhāgo loke bhoktā cetanaḥ śārīro bhogyāḥ śabdādayo viṣayā iti /
analyzed: atrā ucyate prasiddhaḥ hi ayam bhoktṛ bhogya vibhāgaḥ loke bhoktā cetanaḥ śārīraḥ bhogyāḥ śabda ādayaḥ viṣayāḥ iti
translated: To this we reply: The distinction of enjoyer and object of enjoyment is well known in the world. The enjoyer is the embodied soul, the conscious being; the objects of enjoyment are sound, etc.

original: yathā bhoktā devadatto bhojya odana iti /
analyzed: yathā bhoktā devadattaḥ bhojyaḥ odanaḥ iti
translated: Just as Devadatta is the enjoyer, and rice the object of enjoyment.

original: tasya ca vibhāgasyābhāvaḥ prasajyeta yadi bhoktā bhogyabhāvamāpadyeta /
analyzed: tasya ca vibhāgasya abhāvaḥ prasajyeta yadi bhoktā bhogya bhāvam āpadyeta
translated: And this distinction would be non-existent if the enjoyer were to become the object of enjoyment,

analyzed: bhogyam vā bhoktṛ bhāvam āpadyeta
translated: or if the object of enjoyment were to become the enjoyer.

analyzed: tayoḥ ca itaretarabhāva āpattiḥ parama kāraṇāt brahmaṇaḥ na anyatvāt prasajyeta
translated: And the assumption of these two becoming each other would follow from the enjoyer and the object of enjoyment not being different from Brahman, the highest cause.

analyzed: na ca asya prasiddhasya vibhāgasya bādhanam yuktam
translated: And it is not proper to deny this well-known distinction.

analyzed: yathā tu adyatve bhoktṛ bhogyayoḥ vibhāgaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ tathā atīta anāgatayoḥ api kalpayitavyaḥ
translated: Just as the distinction of enjoyer and object of enjoyment is seen in the present, it should be imagined to have existed in the past and future as well.

analyzed: tasmāt prasiddhasya asya bhoktṛ bhogya vibhāgasya abhāva prasaṅgāt ayuktam idam brahma kāraṇatā avadhāraṇam iti ced kaścid codayet tam pratibrūyāt syāt loka vat iti
translated: Therefore, because of the consequence of the non-existence of this well-known distinction of enjoyer and object of enjoyment, it is improper to determine Brahman as the cause. If someone were to object in this way, one should reply: It would be like in the world.

original: upapadyata evāyamasmatpakṣe 'pi vibhāgaḥ evaṃ loke dṛṣṭatvāt /
analyzed: upapadyate eva ayam asmad pakṣe vibhāgaḥ evam loke dṛṣṭa tvāt
translated: This distinction is possible in our view as well, because it is seen in the world in this way.

original: tathāhi samudrādudakātmano 'nanyatve 'pi tadvikārāṇāṃ phenavīcītaraṅgādīnāmitaretaravibhāga itaretarasaṃśleṣādilakṣaṇaśca vyavahāra upalabhyate
analyzed: tathā hi samudrāt udaka ātmanaḥ tad vikārāṇām phena vīcī taraṅga ādīnām itaretara vibhāgaḥ itaretara saṃśleṣa ādi lakṣaṇaḥ ca vyavahāraḥ upalabhyate
translated: For instance, even though the water and the modifications of water, such as foam, waves, ripples, etc., are not different from the ocean, yet their mutual distinction and the usage characterized by mutual contact, etc., are observed.

analyzed: na ca samudrāt udaka ātmanaḥ na anyatve pi tad vikārāṇām phena taraṅga ādīnām itaretarabhāva āpattiḥ bhavati
translated: And even though they are not different from the water of the ocean, the modifications such as foam, waves, etc., do not become mutually identical.

analyzed: na ca teṣām itaretarabhāva anāpattau api samudra ātmanaḥ nya tvam bhavati
translated: And even though they do not become mutually identical, they do not become different from the nature of the ocean.

analyzed: evam iha api na ca bhoktṛ bhogyayoḥ itaretarabhāva āpattiḥ
translated: In the same way, here also, the enjoyer and the object of enjoyment do not become mutually identical.

analyzed: na ca parasmāt brahmaṇaḥ bhaviṣyati
translated: And they will not be different from Brahman, the Supreme.

analyzed: yadi api bhoktā na brahmaṇaḥ vikāraḥ
translated: Even though the enjoyer is not a modification of Brahman,

analyzed: tat sṛṣṭvā tat eva anuprāviśat taiḥ  iti sraṣṭuḥ eva avikṛtasya kārya anupraveśena bhoktṛ tva śravaṇāt
translated: having created that, he entered into it.🔽Thus, because of the statement that the unchanged creator is the enjoyer by entering into the effect,

analyzed: tathā api kāryam anupraviṣṭasya asti upādhi nimittaḥ vibhāgaḥ ākāśasya iva ghaṭa ādi upādhi nimitta
translated: even so, for one who has entered into the effect, there is distinction due to limiting adjuncts, like the distinction of space due to limiting adjuncts such as pot, etc.

analyzed: iti atas parama kāraṇa brahmaṇaḥ bhoktṛ bhogya lakṣaṇaḥ vibhāgaḥ
translated: Thus, it is established that the distinction into enjoyer and object of enjoyment is possible even though there is non-difference from Brahman, the supreme cause,

analyzed: samudra taraṅga ādi nyāyena iti uktam     anya para tvam gauṇa arthaka tvam  vibhāgaḥ janma
translated: like the analogy of the ocean and its waves, etc.

analyzed: yat vā tathā api iti śabdena eva uktaḥ parihāraḥ
translated: The word api (even) indicates that the objection has been answered.

analyzed: ārambhaṇa adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on the beginning. Sutra.

analyzed: tad ananya tvam ārambhaṇa śabda ādibhyaḥ
translated: Non-difference from that is understood from words like arambhana (cause).

original: abhyupagamya cemaṃ vyāvahārikaṃ bhoktṛbhogyalakṣaṇaṃ vibhāgaṃ syāllokavaditi parihāroṣa'bhihitaḥ /
analyzed: abhyupagamya ca imam vyāvahārikam bhoktṛ bhogya lakṣaṇam vibhāgam syāt loka vat iti
translated: And the answer has been stated that the distinction into enjoyer and object of enjoyment, which is conventionally accepted, may exist like in the world.

analyzed: na tu ayam vibhāgaḥ paramārthataḥ sti yasmāt tayoḥ kārya kāraṇayoḥ ananyatvam avagamyate
translated: But this distinction does not exist ultimately, because the non-difference of those two, cause and effect, is understood.

analyzed: kāryam ākāśa ādikam bahu prapañcam jagat
translated: The effect is the world with many manifestations, beginning with space.

analyzed: kāraṇam param brahma
translated: The cause is the supreme Brahman.

analyzed: tasmāt kāraṇāt paramārthataḥ na anyatvam vyatirekeṇa abhāvaḥ kāryasya avagamyate
translated: Therefore, from that cause, the non-difference of the effect is understood ultimately, i.e., its non-existence apart from the cause.

analyzed: kutas  ārambhaṇa śabda ādibhyaḥ
translated: From what?🔽From words like arambhana (cause).

analyzed: ārambhaṇa śabdaḥ tāvat
translated: First, the word arambhana (cause).

original: ekavijñānena sarvavijñānaṃ pratijñāya dṛṣṭāntāpekṣāyāmucyate 'yathā somyaikena mṛtpiṇḍena
analyzed: eka vijñānena sarva vijñānam pratijñāya dṛṣṭānta apekṣāyām ucyate yathā somya ekena mṛd piṇḍena
translated: Having undertaken the proposition that by knowing one thing everything is known, when the need for an example arises, it is said: Just as, my dear, by one clod of clay

original: sarvaṃ mṛnmayaṃ vijñātaṃ syādvācārambhaṇaṃ vikāro nāmadheyaṃ mṛttiketyeva satyam' chā / / / iti /
analyzed: sarvam mṛd mayam vijñātam syāt vācā ārambhaṇam vikāraḥ nāmadheyam mṛttikā iti eva satyam chā iti
translated: everything made of clay would be known, the modification is a verbal designation, the name 'clay' alone is true.

original: etaduktaṃ bhavati ekena mṛtpiṇḍena paramārthato mṛdātmanā vijñātena sarvaṃ mṛnmayaṃ ghaṭaśarāvodañcanādikaṃ mṛdātmakatvāviśeṣādvijñātaṃ bhavet
analyzed: etat uktam bhavati ekena mṛd piṇḍena paramārthataḥ mṛd ātmanā vijñātena sarvam mṛd mayam ghaṭa śarāva udañcana ādikam mṛd ātmaka tva aviśeṣāt vijñātam bhavet
translated: This is what is said: By knowing one clod of clay in reality as having the nature of clay, everything made of clay, such as pots, bowls, water jars, etc., would be known, because there is no difference in having the nature of clay.

original: yato vācārambhaṇaṃ vikāro nāmadheyaṃ vācaiva kevalamastītyārabhyate /
analyzed: yatas vācā ārambhaṇam vikāraḥ nāmadheyam vācā eva kevalam asti iti ārabhyate
translated: Because the modification is a mere verbal designation, it is begun by speech alone.

analyzed: vikāraḥ ghaṭaḥ śarāvaḥ udañcanam ca iti
translated: The modification is a pot, a bowl, a water jar.

analyzed: na tu vastu vṛttena vikāraḥ nāma kaścid asti
translated: But in reality, there is no such thing as modification.

analyzed: nāmadheya mātram hi etat anṛtam mṛttikā iti eva satyam iti
translated: For this is merely a name, a falsehood. 'Clay' alone is true.

analyzed: eṣa brahmaṇaḥ dṛṣṭāntaḥ āmnātaḥ
translated: This is the example of Brahman that is stated in the Upanishad.

original: tatra śrutādvācārambhaṇaśabdāddārṣṭāntike 'pi brahmavyatirekeṇa kāryajātasyābhāva iti gamyate /
analyzed: tatra śrutāt vācā ārambhaṇa śabdāt dārṣṭāntike brahma vyatirekeṇa kārya jātasya abhāvaḥ iti gamyate
translated: From the word 'vācārambhaṇa' heard there, it is understood that in the case of Brahman also, the effect-series does not exist apart from Brahman.

analyzed: punar ca tejaḥ bannānām brahma kārya tām uktvā tejaḥ banna kāryāṇām tejaḥ banna vyatirekeṇa abhāvam
translated: And again, after declaring that fire, water, and food are the effects of Brahman, he declares that the effects of fire, water, and food are non-existent apart from fire, water, and food,

original: bravīti 'apāgādagneragnitvaṃ vācārambhaṇaṃ vikāro nāmadheyaṃ trīṇi rūpāṇītyeva satyam'
analyzed: bravīti apāgāt agneḥ agni tvam vācā ārambhaṇam vikāraḥ nāmadheyam trīṇi rūpāṇi iti eva satyam
translated: saying, The fireness of fire has departed. Speech is mere sound. Modification is a name. The three forms are indeed the truth.

analyzed: chā ityādinā
translated: And so on.

original: ārambhaṇaśabdādibhya ityādiśabdāt 'aitadātmyamidaṃ sarvaṃ tatsatyaṃ sa ātmā tattvamasi' chā / / /
analyzed: ārambhaṇa śabda ādibhyaḥ iti ādi śabdāt aitadātmyam idam sarvam tat satyam saḥ ātmā tat tvam asi chā
translated: From words like mere sound, and from the word and so on, the following passages should be quoted, which are devoted to teaching the oneness of the Self: All this has that as its Self. That is the truth. That art thou, O Śvetaketu.

analyzed: idam sarvam yat ayam ātmā bṛ
translated: All this is that Self.

analyzed: brahma eva idam sarvam mu
translated: All this is indeed Brahman.

analyzed: ātmā eva idam sarvam chā
translated: The Self is indeed all this.

analyzed: na iha nānā asti kiñcana
translated: There is no diversity here of anything.

analyzed: iti evamādi api ātma ekatva pratipādana param vacana jātam udāhartavyam
translated: And so on.

analyzed: na ca anyathā eka vijñānena sarva vijñānam saṃpadyate
translated: And the knowledge of all is not accomplished by the knowledge of one thing, if that one thing is different from all.

analyzed: tasmāt yathā ghaṭa karaka ādi ākāśānām mahākāśa ananyatvam
translated: Therefore, just as the space in a jar, in a mountain, etc., is not different from the great space,

analyzed: yathā ca mṛgatṛṣṇikā udaka ādīnām ūṣara ādibhyaḥ na anyatvam dṛṣṭa naṣṭa sva rūpa tvāt sva rūpeṇa anupākhya tvāt
translated: and just as the water in a mirage, etc., is not different from the desert, etc., because its seen form is destroyed, and it cannot be described as having its own form,

analyzed: evam asya bhogya bhoktṛ ādi prapañca jātasya brahma vyatirekeṇa abhāvaḥ iti draṣṭavyam
translated: Thus it should be understood that this entire manifold creation, consisting of the enjoyer, the enjoyed, etc., does not exist apart from Brahman.

analyzed: nanu aneka ātmakam brahma
translated: But Brahman has many selves.

analyzed: yathā vṛkṣaḥ neka śākhaḥ evam aneka śakti pravṛtti yuktam brahma
translated: Just as a tree has many branches, so Brahman is endowed with many powers and activities.

analyzed: atas ekatvam nānātvam ca ubhayam api satyam eva
translated: Therefore, both unity and diversity are true.

original: yathā vṛkṣa ityanekatvaṃ śākhā iti nānātvam /🔽yathāca samudrātmanaikatvaṃ phenataraṅgādyātmanā nānātvam /
analyzed: yathā vṛkṣaḥ iti anekatvam śākhāḥ iti nānātvam  yathā ca samudra ātmanā ekatvam phena taraṅga ādi ātmanā nānātvam
translated: Just as a tree is diversity, and the branches are diversity.🔽And just as the ocean is one in itself, but diverse in the form of foam, waves, etc.

analyzed: yathā ca mṛd ātmanā ekatvam ghaṭa śarāva ādi ātmanā nānātvam
translated: And just as clay is one in itself, but diverse in the form of pots, jars, etc.

analyzed: tatra eka tva aṃśena jñānāt mokṣa vyavahāraḥ setsyati
translated: There, the usage of knowledge for the sake of liberation will be established by the part of unity.

original: nānātvāṃśena tu karmakāṇḍāśrayau laukikavaidikavyavahārau setsyata iti /
analyzed: nānātva aṃśena tu karmakāṇḍa āśrayau laukika vaidika vyavahārau setsyataḥ iti
translated: But the worldly and Vedic usages based on the section of karmakāṇḍa will be established by the part of diversity.

analyzed: evam ca mṛd ādi dṛṣṭāntāḥ anurūpāḥ bhaviṣyanti iti
translated: And in this way, the examples of clay, etc. will be appropriate.

analyzed: na evam syāt
translated: This should not be so.

analyzed: mṛttikā iti eva satyam iti prakṛti mātrasya dṛṣṭānte satya tva avadhāraṇāt
translated: Because in the example, only the primordial nature is determined to be true by the statement Only clay is true.

analyzed: vācā ārambhaṇa śabdena ca vikāra jātasya anṛta tva abhidhānāt
translated: And because the category of modifications is declared to be false by the word vācārambhaṇa (dependent on speech).

original: dārṣṭāntike 'pi 'aitadātmyamidaṃ sarvaṃ tatsatyam' iti ca paramakāraṇasyaivaikasya satyatvāvadhāraṇāt 'sa ātmā tattvamasi śvetaketo' iti ca 🔽śārīrasya brahmabhāvopadeśāt /
analyzed: dārṣṭāntike aitadātmyam idam sarvam tat satyam iti ca parama kāraṇasya eva ekasya satya tva avadhāraṇāt saḥ ātmā tat tvam asi śvetaketo iti ca  śārīrasya brahma bhāva upadeśāt
translated: In the Vedanta also, in the passage, This is all that, that is the truth, it is declared that the highest cause alone is the truth. And in the passage, That is the Self, that is the truth, O Śvetaketu, it is taught that the individual soul is of the nature of Brahman.

original: svayaṃ prasiddhaṃ hyetaccharīrasya brahmātmatvamupadiśyate na yatnāntaraprasādhyam /
analyzed: svayam prasiddham hi etat śarīrasya brahma ātmatvam upadiśyate na yatna antara prasādhyam
translated: For it is taught that the individual soul is of the nature of Brahman, which is well known by itself, and not to be established by any other effort.

original: ataścedaṃ śāstrīyaṃ brahmātmatvamavagamyamānaṃ svābhāvikasya śārīrātmatvasya bādhakaṃ saṃpadyate /
analyzed: atas ca idam śāstrīyam brahma ātmatvam avagamyamānam svābhāvikasya śārīra ātmatvasya bādhakam saṃpadyate
translated: And therefore this Brahmanhood of the individual soul, which is taught by the scriptures, becomes the sublater of the natural Brahmanhood of the individual soul.

analyzed: rajju ādi buddhayaḥ iva sarpa ādi buddhīnām
translated: As the notions of a serpent, &c., are sublated by the knowledge of a rope, &c.

original: bādhite ca śārīrātmatvasya tadāśrayaḥ samastaḥ svābhāviko vyavahāro bādhito bhavati yatprasiddhaye nānātvāṃśo 'paro brahmaṇaḥ kalpyeta /
analyzed: bādhite ca śārīra ātma tvasya tad āśrayaḥ samastaḥ svābhāvikaḥ vyavahāraḥ bādhitaḥ bhavati yad prasiddhaye paraḥ brahmaṇaḥ kalpyeta
translated: And when the Brahmanhood of the individual soul is sublated, then the whole natural course of action, which has that Brahmanhood for its basis, is sublated, for the sake of establishing which the other part of Brahman, the manifold, would be imagined.

analyzed: darśayati ca
translated: And it is shown

analyzed: yatra tu asya sarvam ātmā eva abhūt tat kena kam paśyet bṛ
translated: in the passage, But when the Self only is all this, how should he see another? Bṛ Up , ,

original: ityādinā brahmātmatvadarśinaṃ prati samastasya kriyākārakaphalalakṣaṇasya vyavahārasyābhāvam /
analyzed: ityādinā brahma ātma tva darśinam prati samastasya kriyā kāraka phala lakṣaṇasya vyavahārasya abhāvam
translated: that for one who sees the identity of Brahman and the individual soul the whole course of action, which is characterized by the agent, the object, and the result, does not exist.

analyzed: na ca ayam abhidhīyate iti yuktam vaktum
translated: Nor is it proper to say that this absence of practical existence is said to be confined to a particular state.

analyzed: tat tvam asi iti brahma ātma bhāvasya anavasthā viśeṣa nibandhana tvāt
translated: Because the state of Brahman-hood, declared in the text, 'That thou art,' is not confined to a particular state.

original: taskaradṛṣṭāntena cānṛtābhisaṃdhasya bandhanaṃ satyābhisaṃdhasya ca mokṣaṃ darśayannekatvamevaikaṃ pāramārthikaṃ darśayati chā / / /
analyzed: taskara dṛṣṭāntena ca anṛta abhisaṃdhasya bandhanam satya abhisaṃdhasya ca mokṣam darśayan ekatvam eva ekam pāramārthikam darśayati chā
translated: And by the illustration of the thief, showing the bondage of one who is attached to untruth and the liberation of one who is attached to truth, he shows that unity alone is the one reality.

analyzed: mithyā jñāna vijṛmbhitam ca nānātvam
translated: And diversity is the manifestation of false knowledge.

original: ubhayasatyatāyāṃ hi kathaṃ vyavahāragocaro 'pi janturanṛtābhisaṃdha ityucyeta /
analyzed: ubhaya satya tāyām hi katham vyavahāra gocaraḥ jantuḥ anṛta abhisaṃdhaḥ iti ucyeta
translated: For if both were true, how could one who is within the range of practical existence be said to be attached to untruth?

original: 'mṛtyoḥ sa mṛtyumāpnoti ya iha nāneva paśyati' bṛ / / /
analyzed: mṛtyoḥ sa mṛtyum āpnoti yaḥ iha nānā iva paśyati
translated: 'He who sees diversity here attains death from death,'

analyzed: iti ca bheda dṛṣṭim apavadan eva etat darśayati
translated: and by condemning the view of diversity, he shows this.

analyzed: na ca asmin darśane jñānāt mokṣaḥ iti upapadyate
translated: And in this view, liberation from knowledge is not logically possible.

analyzed: samyak jñana apanodyasya kasyacid mithyājñānasya saṃsāra kāraṇa tvena anabhyupagamāt
translated: Because no false knowledge, which is to be removed by right knowledge, is accepted as the cause of transmigration.

analyzed: ubhaya satyatāyām hi katham ekatva vijñānena nānātva jñānam apanudyate iti ucyate
translated: For if both were true, how can it be said that the knowledge of unity removes the knowledge of diversity?

analyzed: nanu ekatva ekānta abhyupagame nānātva abhāvat pratyakṣa ādīni laukikāni pramāṇāni vyāhanyeran nirviṣaya tvāt
translated: But if you maintain the doctrine of absolute unity, then, there being no plurality, all the ordinary means of knowledge, perception, &c., would be set aside, because they would have no objects;

analyzed: sthāṇu ādiṣu iva puruṣa ādi jñānāni  tathā vidhi pratiṣedha śāstram api bheda apekṣa tvāt tad abhāve vyāhanyeta
translated: just as the knowledge that a post is a man, &c., is set aside.🔽And the scriptures enjoining what is to be done and prohibiting what is not to be done would be set aside, because they depend on the distinction of different things, and that would be abolished.

analyzed: mokṣa śāstrasya api śiṣya śāsitṛ ādi bheda apekṣa tvāt tad abhāve vyāghātaḥ syāt
translated: And the scriptures on final release would be set aside, because they depend on the distinction of the pupil and the teacher, &c., and that would be abolished.

analyzed: katham ca anṛtena mokṣa śāstreṇa pratipāditasya ātma ekatvasya satya tvam upapadyeta iti
translated: And how can the truth of the unity of the self, taught by the false scriptures on final release, be accounted for?

analyzed: atrā ucyate na eṣa doṣaḥ
translated: To this we reply: This is no fault.

analyzed: sarva vyavahārāṇām eva prāk brahma ātmatā vijñānāt satya tva upapatteḥ
translated: For all ordinary experience is true before the knowledge of the self as Brahman.

analyzed: svapna vyavahārasya iva prāk prabodhāt
translated: Just as the experience in a dream is true before waking.

analyzed: yāvat hi na satya ātma ekatva pratipattiḥ tāvat pramāṇa prameya phala lakṣaṇeṣu vikāreṣu anṛta tva buddhiḥ na kasyacid utpadyate
translated: For as long as there is no knowledge of the self as one with the true Brahman, so long no one has the idea that the modifications, which are the means of knowledge, the objects of knowledge, and the results of knowledge, are false.

original: vikārāneva tvahaṃ mametyavidyāyāmātmīyena bhāvena sarvo jantuḥ pratipadyate svābhāvikīṃ brahmātmatāṃ hitvā /
analyzed: vikārān eva tu aham mama iti avidyāyām ātmīyena bhāvena sarvaḥ jantuḥ pratipadyate svābhāvikīm brahma ātmatām hitvā
translated: But all creatures, abandoning their natural state of being one with Brahman, apprehend the modifications as the self and as mine through the feeling of selfhood produced by Nescience.

analyzed: tasmāt prāk brahma ātmatā pratibodhāt upapannaḥ sarvaḥ laukikaḥ vaidikaḥ ca vyavahāraḥ
translated: Therefore, all ordinary and Vedic usage is intelligible before the knowledge of Brahman as the Self.

original: yathā suptasya prākṛtasya janasya svapna uccāvacānbhāvānpaśyato niścitameva pratyakṣābhimataṃ vijñānaṃ bhavati prākprabodhāt /
analyzed: yathā suptasya prākṛtasya janasya svapne uccāvacān bhāvān paśyataḥ niścitam eva pratyakṣa abhimatam vijñānam bhavati prāk prabodhāt
translated: Just as for an ordinary man asleep, when he sees various things in a dream, there is a definite cognition which is accepted as perception, before he awakes.

analyzed: na ca pratyakṣa ābhāsa abhiprāyaḥ tad kāle bhavati tadvat
translated: And he does not have the idea that it is a false perception at that time. It is the same here.

original: kathaṃ tvasatyena vedāntavākyena satyasya brahmātmatvasya pratipattirupapadyeta /
analyzed: katham tu asatyena vedānta vākyena satyasya brahma ātmatvasya pratipattiḥ upapadyeta
translated: But how can the knowledge of the truth, Brahman being the Self, be intelligible by a false Vedanta text?

analyzed: nahi rajju sarpeṇa dṛṣṭaḥ mriyate
translated: For one is not seen to die by a rope-snake.

analyzed: na api mṛgatṛṣṇikā ambhasā pāna avagāhana ādi prayojanam kriyate iti
translated: Nor is the purpose of drinking, bathing, etc. accomplished by the water of a mirage.

analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ  śaṅkā viṣa ādi nimitta maraṇa ādi kārya upalabdheḥ
translated: This is not a fault.🔽Because the effect such as death caused by fear, grief, etc. is observed.

analyzed: svapna darśana avasthasya ca sarpa daṃśana udaka snāna ādi kārya darśanāt
translated: And because the effect such as a snake bite, bathing in water, etc. is seen in the state of dreaming.

analyzed: tad kāryam api anṛtam eva iti ced brūyāt
translated: If one were to say that even that effect is false,

original: tatra brūmaḥ yadyapi svapnadarśanāvasthasya sarpadaṃśanodakasnānādikāryamanṛtaṃ tathāpi tadavagatiḥ satyameva phalaṃ /
analyzed: tatra brūmaḥ yadi api svapna darśana avasthasya sarpa daṃśana udaka snāna ādi kāryam anṛtam tathā api tad avagatiḥ satyam eva phalam
translated: To this we reply: Although the effects of the acts of being bitten by a serpent, bathing in water, etc., of one who is in the state of seeing a dream are untrue, yet the cognition of them is a true result.

analyzed: pratibuddhasya api a bādhyamāna tvāt
translated: Because it is not contradicted even by one who has awakened.

original: nahi svapnādutthitaḥ svapnadṛṣṭaṃ sarpadaṃśanodakasnānādikāryaṃ mithyeti manyamānastadavagatimapi mithyeti manyate kaścit /
analyzed: nahi svapnāt utthitaḥ svapna dṛṣṭam sarpa daṃśana udaka snāna ādi kāryam mithyā iti manyamānaḥ tad avagatim api mithyā iti manyate kaścid
translated: For when one has risen from sleep, no one thinks that the cognition of the effects of being bitten by a serpent, bathing in water, etc., seen in a dream is false, and thinks that the cognition of them is also false.

analyzed: etena svapna dṛśaḥ vagati a bādhanena deha mātra ātma vādaḥ dūṣitaḥ veditavyaḥ
translated: By this, i.e., by the non-contradiction of the cognition of one who sees a dream, the doctrine that the Self is the body alone should be understood to be refuted.

original: tathāca śrutiḥ 'yadā karmasu kāmyeṣu striyaṃ svapneṣu paśyati /
analyzed: tathā ca śrutiḥ yadā karmasu kāmyeṣu striyam svapneṣu paśyati
translated: And thus the Śruti says: 'When one sees a woman in his dreams in connection with desirable acts,

analyzed: samṛddhim tatra jānīyāt tasmin svapna nidarśane chā
translated: one should know that there is prosperity in that, in that vision in a dream.'

original: ityasatyena svapnadarśanena satyāyāḥ samṛddheḥ pratipattiṃ darśayati /
analyzed: iti asatyena svapna darśanena satyāyāḥ samṛddheḥ pratipattim darśayati
translated: Thus it shows that by a false vision in a dream, there is the knowledge of a true prosperity.

original: tathā pratyakṣadarśaneṣu keṣucidariṣṭeṣu jāteṣu 'na ciramiva jīviṣyatīti vidyāt'
analyzed: tathā pratyakṣa darśaneṣu keṣucid ariṣṭeṣu jāteṣu na ciram iva jīviṣyati iti vidyāt
translated: Similarly, when some evil omens have occurred in actual experience, it is said: 'One should know that he will live for not long.'

original: ityuktvā 'atha svapnāḥ puruṣaṃ kṛṣṇaṃ kṛṣṇadantaṃ paśyati sa enaṃ hanti' ityādinā
analyzed: iti uktvā atha svapnāḥ puruṣam kṛṣṇam kṛṣṇa dantam paśyati saḥ enam hanti ityādinā
translated: Then, after saying this, it is said: 'One sees a man who is black and has black teeth. He kills him.'

original: tena tenāsatyenaiva svapnadarśanena satyaṃ maraṇaṃ sūcyata iti darśayati /
analyzed: tena tena asatyena eva svapna darśanena satyam maraṇam sūcyate iti darśayati
translated: He shows that by means of that false dream-vision the true death is indicated.

original: prasiddhaṃ cedaṃ loke 'nvayavyatirekakuśalānāmīdṛśena svapnadarśanena sādhvāgamaḥ sūcyata īdṛśenāsādhvāgama iti /
analyzed: prasiddham ca idam loke nvaya vyatireka kuśalānām īdṛśena svapna darśanena sādhu āgamaḥ sūcyate īdṛśena asādhu āgamaḥ iti
translated: And this is well known in the world to those skilled in positive and negative concomitance that a good omen is indicated by such a dream-vision, and a bad omen by such another.

analyzed: tathā ākāra ādi satya akṣara pratipattiḥ ddaṣṭā rekhā anṛta akṣara pratipatteḥ
translated: And the cognition of the true syllables 'tat', etc. is seen to be like the cognition of the false syllables 'rekhā', etc.

original: apicāntyamidaṃ pramāṇamātmaikatvasya pratipādakaṃ nātaḥ paraṃ kiñcidākāṅkṣyamasti /
analyzed: api ca antyam idam pramāṇam ātma ekatvasya pratipādakam na atas param kiñcid ākāṅkṣyam asti
translated: Moreover, this last means of knowledge teaches the oneness of the self. Nothing else is to be desired beyond this.

original: yathāhi loke yajetetyukte kiṃ kena kathamityākāṅkṣyate naivaṃ 'tattvamasi' 'ahaṃ brahmāsmi' ityukte kiñcidanyadākāṅkṣyamasti /
analyzed: yathā hi loke yajeta iti ukte kim kena katham iti ākāṅkṣyate na evam tat tvam asi aham brahma asmi iti ukte kiñcid anyat ākāṅkṣyam asti
translated: For just as when 'one should sacrifice' is said, it is desired what, by whom, and how, not so when 'that thou art' and 'I am Brahman' are said, is anything else desired?

analyzed: sarva ātma eka tva viṣaya tva avagateḥ
translated: Because it is understood to have the oneness of all as its content.

analyzed: sati hi asmin avaśiṣyamāṇa irthe ākāṅkṣā syāt
translated: For if this were the only meaning remaining, there would be desire.

analyzed: na tu ātma ekatva vyatirekeṇa avaśiṣyamāṇaḥ sti yaḥ ākāṅkṣyeta
translated: But there is no other meaning remaining apart from the oneness of the self that could be desired.

analyzed: na ca iyam avagatiḥ nā upapadyate iti śakyam vaktum
translated: And it cannot be said that this understanding is not possible.

analyzed: tat ha asya vijajñau chā
translated: Then he understood it. Chā.

analyzed: ityādi śrutibhyaḥ
translated: Thus it is said in the Śruti.

original: avagatisādhanānāṃ ca śravaṇādīnāṃ vedānuvacanādīnāṃ ca vidhānāt /
analyzed: avagati sādhanānām ca śravaṇa ādīnām veda anuvacana ādīnām ca vidhānāt
translated: And because the means of knowledge, such as hearing, etc., and the Vedic recitations, etc., are enjoined.

analyzed: na ca iyam avagatiḥ anarthikā bhrāntiḥ vā iti śakyam vaktum
translated: And it cannot be said that this knowledge is useless or false.

analyzed: avidyā nivṛtti phala darśanāt
translated: Because it is seen to have the result of the cessation of ignorance.

analyzed: bādhaka jñāna antara abhāvāt ca
translated: And because there is no other contradictory knowledge.

analyzed: prāk ca ātma eka tva avagateḥ avyāhataḥ sarvaḥ satya anṛta vyavahāraḥ laukikaḥ vaidikaḥ ca iti avocāma
translated: And before the knowledge of the oneness of the Self, all the worldly and Vedic transactions of truth and falsehood are unobstructed, as we have said.

original: tasmādantyena pramāṇena pratipādita ātmaikatve samastasya prācīnasya bhedavyavahārasya bādhitatvānnānekātmakabrahmakalpanāvakāśo 'sti /
analyzed: tasmāt antyena pramāṇena pratipādite ātma ekatve samastasya prācīnasya bheda vyavahārasya bādhita tvāt na aneka ātmaka brahma kalpanā avakāśaḥ sti
translated: Therefore, in the Self, which is taught by the last means of knowledge to be one, all the former transactions of difference are contradicted, so there is no room for postulating a Brahman with many aspects.

analyzed: nanu mṛd ādi dṛṣṭānta praṇayanāt pariṇāma vat brahma śāstrasya abhimatam iti gamyate
translated: But from the presentation of the examples of clay, etc., it is understood that Brahman with modifications is the intended meaning of the scriptures.

original: pariṇāmino hi mṛdādayor'thā loke samadhigatā iti /
analyzed: pariṇāminaḥ hi mṛd ādayaḥ arthāḥ loke samadhigatāḥ iti
translated: For in the world, things with modifications such as clay, etc., are well known.

analyzed: na iti ucyate
translated: No, it is said.

original: 'sa vā eṣa mahājana ātmājaro 'maro 'mṛto 'bhayo brahma' bṛ / / /
analyzed: sa vai eṣa mahā janaḥ ātmā ajaraḥ maraḥ mṛtaḥ bhayaḥ brahma bṛ
translated: That is this great being, the Self, undecaying, immortal, immortal, fearless, Brahman (Br. 3.9.26).

analyzed: saḥ eṣa na iti na iti ātmā bṛ
translated: That is this, 'neti neti' (not so, not so), the Self (Br. 2.3.6).

analyzed: a sthūlam an aṇu bṛ
translated: Not gross, not subtle (Br. 3.8.8).

analyzed: ityādyābhyaḥ sarva vikriyā pratiṣedha śrutibhyaḥ brahmaṇaḥ kūṭastha tva avagamāt
translated: Thus, from all these passages which deny all change of Brahman, it follows that Brahman is unchangeable.

original: nahyekasya brahmaṇaḥ pariṇāmadharmatvaṃ tadrahitatvaṃ ca śkyaṃ pratipattum /🔽sthitigativatsyāditi cet / na /
analyzed: nahi ekasya brahmaṇaḥ pariṇāma dharma tvam tad rahita tvam ca śkyam pratipattum  sthiti gati vat syāt iti ced na
translated: For it is impossible to ascribe to Brahman, which is one only, the attribute of modification and at the same time that of being devoid of it.

analyzed: kūṭasthasya iti viśeṣaṇāt
translated: If you say that the case is analogous to that of motion and rest, we reply that that is not analogous;🔽because the text declares Brahman to be unchangeable.

analyzed: nahi kūṭasthasya brahmaṇaḥ sthiti gati vat aneka dharma āśraya tvam saṃbhavati
translated: For to Brahman, which is unchangeable, it is impossible to ascribe the two attributes of motion and rest, as it is possible to ascribe them to a man.

analyzed: kūṭastham ca nityam brahma sarva vikriyā pratiṣedhāt iti avocāma
translated: And we have already shown that Brahman is unchangeable and eternal, because all change is denied of it.

original: naca yathā brahmaṇa ātmaikatvadarśanaṃ mokṣasādhanamevaṃ jagadākārapariṇāmitvadarśanamapi svatantrameva kasmaicitphalāyābhipreyate /
analyzed: na ca yathā brahmaṇaḥ ātma ekatva darśanam mokṣa sādhanam evam jagat ākāra pariṇāmi tva darśanam api svatantram eva kasmaicid phalāya abhipreyate
translated: And just as the knowledge of the unity of the Self is the means of attaining final release, so the knowledge of the modification of Brahman into the world is not assumed to be a separate means of attaining a certain fruit,

analyzed: pramāṇa abhāvāt
translated: because there is no evidence for such an assumption.

original: kūṭasthabrahmātmavijñānādeva hi phalaṃ darśayati śāstram 'sa eṣa neti netyātmā' ityupakramya 'abhayaṃ vai janaka prāpto 'si' bṛ / / /🔽ityevañjātīyakam /
