translated: For the sacred texts declare that the knowledge of the unchangeable Brahman is the only means of attaining the fruit of final release; cp eg Bṛ Up , , , He is to be described by No, no! and Janaka, you have attained fearlessness!

analyzed: tatra etat siddham bhavati brahma prakaraṇe sarva dharma viśeṣa rahita brahma darśanāt eva
translated: It is established there that when the result is accomplished by the mere vision of Brahman devoid of all attributes in the section on Brahman,

analyzed: phala siddhau satyām yat tatra aphalam śrūyate brahmaṇaḥ jagat ākāra pariṇāmi tva ādi tat brahma darśana upāya tvena eva viniyujyate
translated: what is mentioned there as fruitless, such as Brahman's transformation into the form of the world, is employed only as a means to the vision of Brahman.

analyzed: phalavat saṃnidhau aphalam tat aṅgam itivat  na tu svatantram phalāya kalpyate iti
translated: Like in the presence of something fruitful, what is fruitless is its auxiliary.🔽But it is not imagined to be an independent means to a result.

analyzed: nahi pariṇāmavat tva vijñānāt pariṇāmavat tvam ātmanaḥ phalam syāt iti vaktum yuktam
translated: For it is not proper to say that the result of knowing Brahman's transformability would be the transformability of the self.

analyzed: kūṭastha nitya tvāt mokṣasya
translated: Because liberation is immutable and eternal.

original: kūṭasthabrahmātmavādina ekatvaikāntyādīśitrīśitavyābhāva īśvarakāraṇapratijñāvirodha iti cet / na /
analyzed: kūṭastha brahma ātma vādinaḥ ekatva aikāntyāt īśitṛ īśitavya abhāvaḥ īśvara kāraṇa pratijñā virodhaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that for those who maintain Brahman to be the immutable self, the non-existence of the distinction between the ruler and the ruled contradicts the assertion that God is the cause, it is not so.

analyzed: avidyā ātmaka nāma rūpa bīja vyākaraṇa apekṣa tvāt sarvajña tvasya
translated: Because omniscience depends on the manifestation of the seeds of name and form which are of the nature of ignorance.

analyzed: tasmāt vai etasmāt ātmanaḥ ākāśaḥ saṃbhūtaḥ
translated: From that Self, indeed, space was produced (Tai. 2.1).

analyzed: ityādi vākyebhyaḥ nitya śuddha buddha mukta svarūpāt sarvajñāt sarva śakteḥ īśvarāt jagat jani sthi
translated: From such statements, the world's origin, persistence,

analyzed: ti pralayāḥ na acetanāt pradhānāt anyasmāt vā iti eṣa ṛthaḥ pratijñātaḥ janma ādyasya yatas
translated: The sense of this is that the origination, &c, of the world cannot be due to any other cause than the intelligent Lord.

analyzed: brasū iti
translated: This is the proposition set forth in the Sūtra, The origination, &c, of the world is due to Brahman.

original: sā pratijñā tadavasthaiva na tadviruddhor'thaḥ punarihocyate /
analyzed: sā pratijñā tad avasthā eva na tad viruddha ūrthaḥ punar iha ucyate
translated: This proposition remains unshaken; the sense of the Sūtra is not contrary to it.

analyzed: katham nā ucyate tyantam ātmanaḥ ekatvam advitīya tvam ca bruvatā
translated: How so? The Sūtra teaches the absolute oneness of the Self, and the absence of a second.

analyzed: śruṇu yathā nā ucyate
translated: Listen how it does not teach that.

original: sarvajñasyeśvarasyātmabhūta ivāvidyākalpite nāmarūpe tattvānyatvābhyāmanirvacanīye saṃsāraprapañcabījabhūte sarvajñasyeśvarasya māyāśaktiḥ 🔽prakṛtiriti ca śrutismṛtyorabhilapyete /
analyzed: sarvajñasya īśvarasya ātma bhūte iva avidyā kalpite nāma rūpe tattva anya tvābhyām anirvacanīye saṃsāra prapañca bīja bhūte sarvajñasya īśvarasya māyā śaktiḥ  prakṛtiḥ iti ca śruti smṛtyoḥ abhilapyete
translated: The power of illusion of the omniscient Lord, which is the seed of the world, which is imagined by Nescience to be the Self of the Lord, and which is not to be defined as either the same as or different from him, is called by the Śrutis and Smṛtis pradhāna, prakriti, and so on

original: tābhyāmanyaḥ sarvajña īśvaraḥ 'ākāśo vai nāma nāmarūpayornirvahitā te yadantarā tadbrahma' chā / / / iti śruteḥ /
analyzed: tābhyām anyaḥ sarvajñaḥ īśvaraḥ ākāśaḥ vai nāma nāma rūpayoḥ nirvahitā te yat antarā tat brahma chā  iti śruteḥ
translated: The omniscient Lord himself is different from those two, as appears from the following passages, He who is called Ākāśa, he is the revealer of name and form; what is between them is Brahman Ch Up , , ;

analyzed: nāma rūpe vyākaravāṇi chā
translated: I will send forth name and form Ch Up , , ;

original: 'sarvāṇi rūpāṇi vicitya dhīro nāmāni kṛtvābhivadanyadāste' tai / ā / / /
analyzed: sarvāṇi rūpāṇi vicitya dhīraḥ nāmāni kṛtvā abhivadan yadā āste taiḥ
translated: The wise one, having diversified all forms and created names, sits calling the created things by their names Bṛ Up , , ;

analyzed: ekam bījam bahudhā yaḥ karoti śvam
translated: He who makes the one seed manifold Śve Up ,

analyzed: ityādi śrutibhyaḥ ca
translated: and other passages.

analyzed: evam avidyā kṛta nāma rūpa upādhi anurodhī īśvaraḥ bhavati
translated: In the same way, the Lord is dependent on the limiting adjuncts of name and form, which are produced by Nescience.

analyzed: vyoma iva ghaṭa karaka ādi upādhi anurodhi
translated: He is like the all-pervading space, which is dependent on the limiting adjuncts such as the jar, the potsherd, etc.

original: sa ca svātmabhūtāneva ghaṭākāśasthānīyānavidyāpratyupasthāpitanāmarūpakṛtakāryakaraṇasaṃghātānurodhino jīvākhyānvijñānātmanaḥ pratīṣṭe vyavahāraviṣaye
analyzed: sa ca sva ātma bhūtān eva ghaṭa ākāśa sthānīyān avidyā pratyupasthāpita nāma rūpa kṛta kārya karaṇa saṃghāta anurodhinaḥ jīva ākhyān vijñāna ātmanaḥ pratīṣṭe vyavahāra viṣaye
translated: And He is dependent on the aggregates of body and organs, which are produced by name and form, and are superimposed by Nescience, and are called individual souls or individual selves.

analyzed: tat evam avidyā ātmaka upādhi pariccheda apekṣam eva īśvarasya īśvara tvam sarvajña tvam sarva śakti tvam
translated: Thus, the lordship, omniscience, and omnipotence of the Lord are dependent on the limiting adjuncts, which are characterized by Nescience.

original: ca na paramārthato vidyāyāpāstasarvopādhisvarūpa ātmanīśitrīśitavyasarvajñatvādivyavahāra upapadyate /
analyzed: ca na paramārthataḥ vidyāya apāsta sarva upādhi svarūpaḥ ātmani īśitṛ īśitavya sarvajña tva ādi vyavahāraḥ upapadyate
translated: In reality, in the Self, whose nature is devoid of all limiting adjuncts by the knowledge of Brahman, the usage of being the ruler, the ruled, the omniscient, etc. is not possible.

original: tathācoktam 'yatra nānyatpaśyati nānyacchṛṇoti nānyadvijānāti sa bhūmā' chā / / /
analyzed: tathā ca uktam yatra na anyat paśyati na anyat śṛṇoti na anyat vijānāti sa bhūmā chā
translated: And thus it is said: Where one sees nothing else, hears nothing else, understands nothing else, that is the Absolute (Ch. 7.24.1).

analyzed: iti yatra tu asya sarvam ātmā eva abhūt tat kena paśyet bṛ
translated: When everything has become the Self alone, by what and whom should one see? (Br. 4.3.31).

analyzed: ityādinā ca
translated: And so on.

original: evaṃ paramārthāvasthāyāṃ sarvavyavahārābhāvaṃ vadanti vedāntāḥ sarve /
analyzed: evam paramārtha avasthāyām sarva vyavahāra abhāvam vadanti vedāntāḥ sarve
translated: Thus, all the Vedanta texts declare the absence of all usage in the state of the highest truth.

original: tatheśvaragītāsvapi 'na kartṛtvaṃ na karmāṇi lokasya sṛjati prabhuḥ /
analyzed: tathā īśvaragītāsu api na kartṛ tvam na karmāṇi lokasya sṛjati prabhuḥ
translated: So also in the Bhagavadgītā: “The Lord does not cause the world to act, nor does he not act.

analyzed: na karma phala saṃyogam svabhāvaḥ tu pravartate
translated: For action proceeds from the nature of things.

original: nādatte kasyacitpāpaṃ na caiva sukṛtaṃ vibhuḥ /
analyzed: na ādatte kasyacid pāpam na ca eva sukṛtam vibhuḥ
translated: The all-pervading one does not take the sin of anyone, nor does he take the good of anyone.

original: ajñānenāvṛtaṃ jñānaṃ tena muhyanti jantavaḥ' gī / / /
analyzed: ajñānena āvṛtam jñānam tena muhyanti jantavaḥ
translated: Knowledge is covered by ignorance; therefore living beings are deluded.”

analyzed: iti paramārtha avasthāyām īśitṛ īśitavya ādi vyavahāra abhāvaḥ pradarśyate
translated: Thus in the state of the highest truth, the absence of the usage of the Lord, the object of control, etc. is shown.

original: vyavahārāvasthāyāṃ tūktaḥ śrutāvapīśvarādivyavahāraḥ 'eṣa sarveśvara eṣa bhūtādhipatireṣa bhūtapāla eṣa seturvidhāraṇa eṣāṃ lokānāmasaṃbhedāya' 🔽bṛ / / / iti /🔽tathāceśvaragītāsvapi 'īśvaraḥ sarvabhūtānāṃ hṛddeśer'juna tiṣṭhati /
analyzed: vyavahāra avasthāyām tu uktaḥ śrutau api īśvara ādi vyavahāraḥ eṣa sarva īśvaraḥ eṣa bhūta adhipatiḥ eṣa bhūta pālaḥ eṣa setuḥ vidhāraṇaḥ eṣām lokānām a saṃbhedāya  bṛ iti  tathā ca īśvaragītāsu api īśvaraḥ sarva bhūtānām hṛd deśeḥ juna tiṣṭhati
translated: But in the state of usage, the usage of the Lord, etc. is stated in the Veda also: “He is the Lord of all, the ruler of beings, the protector of beings, the dam, the support of these worlds, for the non-mixture (of the worlds).”

analyzed: bhrāmayan sarva bhūtāni yantra ārūḍhāni māyayā iti
translated: And so also in the Bhagavadgītā: “The Lord, O Arjuna, stands in the heart of all beings, turning about all beings as if they were mounted on a machine, by his Māyā.”

analyzed: sūtrakāraḥ pi paramārtha abhiprāyeṇa tad anya tvam iti āha
translated: The author of the aphorisms also says “It is different from that” with the intention of the highest truth.

original: vyavahārābhiprāyeṇa tu syāllokavaditi mahāsamudrasthānīyatāṃ brahmaṇaḥ kathayati /
analyzed: vyavahāra abhiprāyeṇa tu syāt loka vat iti mahā samudra sthānīya tām brahmaṇaḥ kathayati
translated: But with the intention of usage, he says “It may be like the world” and declares the state of Brahman as being like the great ocean.

original: apratyākhyāyaiva kāryaprapañcaṃ pariṇāmaprakriyāṃ cāśrayati saguṇopāsaneṣūpayokṣyata iti // //
analyzed: a pratyākhyāya eva kārya prapañcam pariṇāma prakriyām ca āśrayati sa guṇa upāsaneṣu upayokṣyate iti
translated: He accepts the process of transformation, without denying the manifestation of effects, because it will be useful in the meditations with attributes.

original: FN / dṛṣṭaṃ prātītikaṃ naṣṭhamanityaṃ yatsvarūpaṃ tadrūpeṇānupākhyatvātsattāsphūrtiśūnyatvādananyatvamiti saṃbandhaḥ /
analyzed: dṛṣṭam prātītikam naṣṭham anityam yat svarūpam tad rūpeṇa anupākhya tvāt sattā sphūrti śūnya tvāt ananyatvam iti saṃbandhaḥ
translated: The seen, phenomenal, perishable, impermanent nature of Brahman is not to be identified with Brahman, because it is devoid of existence and manifestation, and because it is not different from Brahman.

analyzed: tayā kṛtaḥ svābhāvikaḥ
translated: The natural is that which is produced by ignorance.

analyzed: eka tvasya ekāntaḥ kaivalyam
translated: The extreme of oneness is isolation.

analyzed: vyāhanyeran apramāṇāni syuḥ
translated: The means of valid knowledge would be contradicted.

analyzed: satya tvam bādhā bhāvaḥ
translated: Truth is the absence of contradiction.
Contradiction is the ascertainment of falsity.

original: rekhāsvakāratvādibhrāntyā satyā akārādayo jñāyanta iti prasiddham /
analyzed: rekhāsu akāra tva ādi bhrāntyā satyā akāra ādayaḥ jñāyante iti prasiddham
translated: It is well known that due to the illusion of the lines being the letter a and so on, the real letters a and so on are known.

analyzed: bhāve ca upalabdheḥ
translated: And because it is perceived when it exists.

analyzed: itas ca kāraṇāt ananya tvam kāryasya
translated: And for this reason also, the effect is not different from the cause.

original: yatkāraṇaṃ bhāva eva kāraṇasya kāryamupalabhyate / nābhāve /
analyzed: yatkāraṇam bhāve eva kāraṇasya kāryam upalabhyate na abhāve
translated: Because the effect is perceived only when the cause exists, not when it does not exist.

original: tadyathā satyāṃ mṛdi ghaṭa upalabhyate satsu ca tantuṣu paṭaḥ /
analyzed: tat yathā satyām mṛdi ghaṭaḥ upalabhyate satsu ca tantuṣu paṭaḥ
translated: For example, a pot is perceived when clay exists, and a cloth when threads exist.

analyzed: na ca niyamena anya bhāve nyasya upalabdhiḥ dṛṣṭā
translated: And it is not seen that one is perceived when another exists as a rule.

analyzed: na hi aśvaḥ goḥ anyaḥ san gorbhāvaḥ eva upalabhyate
translated: For a horse, though different from a cow, is not perceived only when a cow exists.

analyzed: na ca kulāla bhāvaḥ eva ghaṭaḥ upalabhyate
translated: And a pot is not perceived to exist only when a potter exists.

analyzed: sati api nimitta naimittika bhāve
translated: Even if there is a relation of cause and effect, because [the pot] is different [from the potter].

analyzed: nanu anyasya bhāve pi anyasya upalabdhiḥ niyatā dṛśyate
translated: Isn't it seen that the perception of one thing is always determined by the existence of another?

analyzed: yathā agni bhāve dhūmasya iti
translated: For example, the perception of smoke is determined by the existence of fire.

analyzed: na iti ucyate
translated: No, it is said.

analyzed: uddhāpite pi agnau gopāla ghuṭikā ādi dhāritasya dhūmasya dṛśyamāna tvāt
translated: Because smoke is seen to exist even when the fire has been removed, as when it is carried by the wind or by a cowherd's basket.

original: atha dhūmaṃ kayācidavasthayā viśiṃṣyādīdṛśo dhūmo nāsatyāgnau bhavatīti /
analyzed: atha dhūmam kayācid avasthayā viśiṃṣyāt īdṛśaḥ dhūmaḥ nāsatya agnau bhavati iti
translated: If [the opponent] were to distinguish smoke by some state, saying Smoke of this kind does not occur without fire,

original: naivamapi kaściddoṣaḥ tadbhāvānuraktāṃ hi buddhiṃ kāryakāraṇayorananyatve hetuṃ vayaṃ vadāmaḥ /
analyzed: na evam api kaścid doṣaḥ tad bhāva anuraktām hi buddhim kārya kāraṇayoḥ ananyatve hetum vayam vadāmaḥ
translated: even so there is no fault, because we state that a cognition affected by that [state] is the reason for the non-difference of cause and effect when they are different.

analyzed: na ca asau agni dhūmayoḥ vidyate
translated: And that [state] does not exist for fire and smoke.

analyzed: bhāvāt ca upalabdheḥ iti vā sūtram
translated: Or the sūtra [may be interpreted as follows]: And because [the effect] is perceived when [the cause] exists.

analyzed: na kevalam śabdāt eva kārya kāraṇayoḥ ananyatvam
translated: The non-difference of cause and effect is not only due to the word [of scripture].

analyzed: pratyakṣa upalabdhi bhāvāt ca tayoḥ ananyatvam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: and also because their non-difference is perceived by direct perception.

analyzed: bhavati hi pratyakṣa upalabdhiḥ kārya kāraṇayoḥ ananya tve
translated: For direct perception of the non-difference of cause and effect occurs.

analyzed: tat yathā
translated: For example,

original: tantusaṃsthāne paṭe tantuvyatirekeṇa paṭo nāma kāryaṃ naivopalabhyate kevalāstu tantava ātānavitānavantaḥ pratyakṣamupalabhyante /
analyzed: tantu saṃsthāne paṭe tantu vyatirekeṇa paṭaḥ nāma kāryam na eva upalabhyate kevalāḥ tu tantavaḥ ātāna vitānavantaḥ pratyakṣam upalabhyante
translated: In a cloth woven with threads, a product called cloth is not at all perceived apart from the threads. Only the threads stretched out are directly perceived.

analyzed: tathā tantuṣu aṃśavaḥ oṃśuṣu tad avayavāḥ
translated: Similarly, in the threads there are parts, and in those parts there are sub-parts.

original: anayā pratyakṣopalabdhyā lohitaśuklakṛṣṇāni trīṇi tato rūpāṇi vāyumātramākāśamātraṃ cetyanumeyam /
analyzed: anayā pratyakṣa upalabdhyā lohita śukla kṛṣṇāni trīṇi tatas rūpāṇi vāyu mātram ākāśa mātram ca iti anumeyam
translated: By this direct perception, the three colors - red, white, and black - and mere air and mere space are to be inferred.

analyzed: tatas param brahma ekam eva advitīyam
translated: Beyond that, Brahman alone is true, without a second.

analyzed: tatra sarva pramāṇānām niṣṭhām avocāma
translated: There we have stated the culmination of all means of knowledge.

original: FN / kāraṇasya bhāve sattve upalabdhau ca kāryasya sattvādupalabdheścānanyatvamiti sūtrārthaḥ /
analyzed: kāraṇasya bhāve sattve upalabdhau ca kāryasya sattvāt upalabdhyāḥ ca ananyatvam iti sūtra arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the sutra is: because of the existence, i.e., being, and perception of the effect when there is the existence, i.e., being, and perception of the cause, they are not different.

analyzed: sa tvāt ca aparasya  /
translated: And because of the existence of another.

analyzed: itas ca kāraṇāt kāryasya ananya tvam
translated: And for this reason also, the effect is not different from the cause.

original: yatkāraṇaṃ prāgutpatteḥ kāraṇātmanaiva kāraṇe sattvamavarakālīnasya kāryasya śrūyate /🔽'sadeva somyedamagra āsīt' chā / / /
analyzed: yatkāraṇam prāk utpatteḥ kāraṇa ātmanā eva kāraṇe sattvam avara kālīnasya kāryasya śrūyate  sat eva somya idam agre āsīt chā
translated: Because before creation, the existence of the future effect is heard to be in the form of the cause itself, in the cause.🔽'This world existed in the form of Being alone, O dear one, in the beginning.' Chandogya Upanishad

analyzed: ātmā vai idam ekaḥ eva agre āsīt
translated: 'This world was the Self alone, one only, in the beginning.' Aitareya Upanishad

analyzed: ityādau idam śabda gṛhītasya kāryasya kāraṇena sāmānādhikaraṇyāt
translated: In such passages as the above, the effect, which is denoted by the word 'this', is spoken of in apposition with the cause.

original: yacca yadātmanā yatra na vartate na tattata utpadyate /
analyzed: yat ca yad ātmanā yatra na vartate na tat tatas utpadyate
translated: And that which does not exist in a certain form in a certain place, is not produced from that place.

analyzed: yathā sikatābhyaḥ tailam
translated: For example, oil is not produced from sand.

analyzed: tasmāt prāk utpatteḥ ananya tvāt utpannam api ananyat eva kāraṇāt kāryam iti avagamyate
translated: Therefore, because it is non-different before production, it is understood that even when produced, the effect is non-different from the cause.

original: yathāca kāraṇaṃ brahma triṣu kāleṣu sattvaṃ na vyabhicaratyevaṃ kāryamapi jagattriṣu kāleṣu sattvaṃ na vyabhicarati /
analyzed: yathā ca kāraṇam brahma triṣu kāleṣu sattvam na vyabhicarati evam kāryam api jagat triṣu kāleṣu sattvam na vyabhicarati
translated: And just as the cause, Brahman, does not deviate from existence in the three times, so also the effect, the world, does not deviate from existence in the three times.

analyzed: ekam ca punar sattvam atas pi ananyatvam kāraṇāt kāryasya
translated: And existence is one only. Therefore, the effect is non-different from the cause.

original: asadvyapadeśān neti cen na dharmāntareṇa vākyaśeṣāt / / / /
analyzed: asat vyapadeśāt na iti ced na dharma antareṇa vākyaśeṣāt
translated: If it be said that it is not so because of the designation of non-existence, it is not so, because of another attribute, as is declared in the remainder of the passage.

original: nanu kvacidasattvamapi prāgutpatteḥ kāryasya vyapadiśati śrutiḥ 'asadevedamagra āsīt chā / / /
analyzed: nanu kvacid asattvam api prāk utpatteḥ kāryasya vyapadiśati śrutiḥ asat eva idam agre āsīt chā
translated: But, it may be said, somewhere the scripture declares non-existence even before the production of the effect: 'This universe was in the beginning, verily, non-being' (Ch. Up.

original: iti / 'asadvā idamagra āsīt' tai / / / iti ca /
analyzed: iti asat vai idam agre āsīt tai iti ca
translated: 'Or this was in the beginning, non-being' (Tai. Up.

analyzed: tasmāt asat vyapadeśāt na prāk utpatteḥ kāryasya sattvam iti ced
translated: Therefore, because of the designation of non-existence, the effect does not exist before production.

analyzed: na iti brūmaḥ
translated: To this we reply: No.

analyzed: na hi ayam atyanta asatva abhiprāyeṇa prāk utpatteḥ kāryasya asat vyapadeśaḥ
translated: For this declaration of the effect as non-existent before its origination is not meant to convey the idea of its absolute non-existence.

original: kiṃ tarhi vyākṛtanāmarūpatvāddharmādavyākṛtanāmarūpatvaṃ dharmāntaraṃ tena dharmāntareṇāyamasadvyapadeśaḥ prāgutpatteḥ sata eva kāryasya kāraṇarūpeṇānanyasya
analyzed: kim tarhi vyākṛta nāma rūpa tvāt dharmāt avyākṛta nāma rūpa tvam dharma antaram tena dharma antareṇa ayam asat vyapadeśaḥ prāk utpatteḥ sataḥ eva kāryasya kāraṇa rūpeṇa ananyasya
translated: What then? The state of having its name and form manifested is a different dharma from the state of having its name and form unmanifested. By that different dharma, this declaration of non-existence before origination is of the existent effect itself, which is not different from the form of the cause.

analyzed: katham etat avagamyate
translated: How is this understood?

analyzed: vākya śeṣāt
translated: From the remainder of the sentence.

analyzed: yad upakrame saṃdigdha artham vākyam tat śeṣāt niścīyate
translated: A sentence whose meaning is doubtful at the beginning is ascertained from the remainder.

original: iha ca tāvat 'asadevedamagra āsīt' ityasacchabdenopakrame nirdiṣṭaṃ yattadeva punastacchabdena parāmṛśya saditi viśinaṣṭi 'tatsadāsīt' iti
analyzed: iha ca tāvat asat eva idam agre āsīt iti asat śabdena upakrame nirdiṣṭam yat tat eva punar tad śabdena parāmṛśya sat iti viśinaṣṭi tat sat āsīt iti
translated: And here, what is indicated by the word 'asat' (non-existent) at the beginning as 'asadevedaṃgra āsīt' (this was indeed non-existent), that same thing is referred to again by the word 'tat' (that) and qualified as 'sat' (existent) in 'tadāsīt' (that existed).

analyzed: asataḥ ca pūrva apara kāla asaṃbandhāt āsīt śabda anupapatteḥ ca
translated: And because non-existence cannot be connected with the prior and subsequent times, and because the word 'āsīt' (existed) would be illogical.

original: 'asadvā idamagra āsīt' ityatrāpi 'tadātmānaṃ svayamakuruta' iti vākyaśeṣe viśeṣaṇānnātyantāsattvam /
analyzed: asat vai idam agre āsīt iti atra api tadā ātmānam svayam akuruta iti vākyaśeṣe viśeṣaṇāt na atyanta asattvam
translated: Even in 'asadvā idaṃgra āsīt' (this was indeed non-existent), due to the qualification in the remainder of the sentence 'tadātmanā svayamakuruta' (that made itself), it is not absolute non-existence.

analyzed: tasmāt dharma antareṇa eva ayam asat vyapadeśaḥ prāk utpatteḥ kāryasya
translated: Therefore, this declaration of non-existence before origination of the effect is by a different dharma.

original: nāmarūpavyākṛtaṃ hi vastu sacchabdārhaṃ loke prasiddham /
analyzed: nāma rūpa vyākṛtam hi vastu sat śabda arham loke prasiddham
translated: For in the world, a thing that is manifested by name and form is well known as deserving the word 'sat'.

analyzed: atas prāk nāma rūpa vyākaraṇāt asat iva āsīt iva āsīt iti upacaryate
translated: Therefore, prior to the manifestation of name and form, it is figuratively said to be as if non-existent, as if it were not.

original: FN / agre śūnyamāsīcchūnyādeva jagatabhūditi pūrvaḥ pakṣaḥ /
analyzed: agre śūnyam āsīt śūnyāt eva jagat abhūt iti pūrvaḥ pakṣaḥ
translated: The prima facie view is that before creation, the universe was void, and it originated from the void itself.

original: rāddhānte tu idaṃ jagadagre sṛṣṭeḥ prāgasadavyākṛtanāmarūpatvādasattulyamatisūkṣmaṃ brahmaivāsīt /
analyzed: rāddhānte tu idam jagat agre sṛṣṭeḥ prāk asat avyākṛta nāma rūpa tvāt asat tulyam ati sūkṣmam brahma eva āsīt
translated: But in the final conclusion, this universe, before creation, was Brahman itself, extremely subtle, equal to non-existence, due to being unmanifested name and form, not existing.

analyzed: tatas brahmaṇaḥ sat vyākṛta nāma rūpam jagat ajāyata iti
translated: From that Brahman, the existent universe, manifested by name and form, was born.

analyzed: yukteḥ śabda antarāt ca
translated: By reasoning and by other scriptural passages.

original: yukteśca prāgutpatteḥ kāryasya sattvamananyatvaṃ ca kāraṇādavagamyate /
analyzed: yukteḥ ca prāk utpatteḥ kāryasya sattvam ananyatvam ca kāraṇāt avagamyate
translated: By reasoning, the existence of the effect prior to its origination and its non-difference from the cause are understood.

analyzed: śabda antarāt ca
translated: And by other scriptural passages.

original: yuktistāvadvarṇyate dadhighaṭarucakādyarthibhiḥ pratiniyatāni kāraṇāni kṣīramṛttikāsuvarṇādīnyupādīyamānāni loke dṛśyante /
analyzed: yuktiḥ tāvat varṇyate dadhi ghaṭa rucaka ādi arthibhiḥ pratiniyatāni kāraṇāni kṣīra mṛttikā suvarṇa ādīni upādīyamānāni loke dṛśyante
translated: Reasoning is stated first. In the world, people are seen to employ specific causes like milk, clay, gold, etc. for the purposes of curd, pot, gold ornament, etc.

original: nahi dadhyarthibhirmṛttikopādīyate na ghaṭārthibhiḥ kṣīraṃ tadasatkāryavāde nopapadyeta /
analyzed: nahi dadhi arthibhiḥ mṛttikā upādīyate na ghaṭa arthibhiḥ kṣīram tat asatkārya vāde nā upapadyeta
translated: For the sake of curd, clay is not employed, for the sake of a pot, milk is not employed. That would not be possible in the doctrine of non-existent effect.

original: aviśiṣṭe hi prāgutpatteḥ sarvasya sarvatrāsatve kasmātkṣīrādeva dadhyutpadyate na mṛttikāyāḥ mṛttikāyā eva ca ghaṭa utpadyate na kṣīrāt /
analyzed: aviśiṣṭe hi prāk utpatteḥ sarvasya sarvatra asatve kasmāt kṣīrāt eva dadhi utpadyate na mṛttikāyāḥ mṛttikāyāḥ eva ca ghaṭaḥ utpadyate na kṣīrāt
translated: For if there is no difference in the non-existence of everything in everything prior to origination, why is curd produced only from milk and not from clay, and a pot only from clay and not from milk?

original: athāviśiṣṭe 'pi prāgasattve kṣīra eva dadhnaḥ kaścidatiśayo na mṛttikāyāṃ /
analyzed: atha aviśiṣṭe pi prāc asattve kṣīre eva dadhnaḥ kaścid atiśayaḥ na mṛttikāyām
translated: If it is said that even in the non-existence prior to origination, there is some peculiarity in curd only in milk, not in clay,

original: mṛttikāyāmeva ca ghaṭasya kaścidatiśayo na kṣīra ityucyeta /
analyzed: mṛttikāyām eva ca ghaṭasya kaścid atiśayaḥ na kṣīre iti ucyeta
translated: and in clay itself there is some peculiarity in a pot, not in milk,

analyzed: tarhi atiśayavat tvāt prāc avasthāyāḥ asatkārya vāda hāniḥ satkārya vāda siddhiḥ ca
translated: then, because of having a peculiarity, the doctrine of non-existence of effect is lost and the doctrine of existence of effect is established in the prior state.

original: śaktiśca kāraṇasya kāryaniyamārthā kalpamānā nānyāsatī vā kāryaṃ niyacchet /
analyzed: śaktiḥ ca kāraṇasya kārya niyama arthā kalpamānā na anyā asatī vā kāryam niyacchet
translated: And the potency of the cause, which is imagined for the purpose of restricting the effect, would not restrict an effect that is different or non-existent.

analyzed: asattva aviśeṣāt anyatva aviśeṣāt ca
translated: Because of the non-difference in non-existence and the non-difference in being different.

analyzed: tasmāt kāraṇasya ātma bhūtā śaktiḥ śakteḥ ca ātma bhūtam kāryam
translated: Therefore, the potency is of the nature of the cause, and the effect is of the nature of the potency.

analyzed: api ca kārya kāraṇayoḥ dravya guṇa ādīnām ca aśva mahiṣa vat bheda buddhi abhāvāt tādātmyam abhyupagantavyam
translated: Moreover, the identity of cause and effect and of substance and quality, etc. should be accepted because there is no cognition of difference like that of a horse and a buffalo.

original: samavāyakalpanāyāmapi samavāyasya samavāyibhiḥ saṃbandhe 'bhyupagamyamāne tasya tasyānyonyaḥ saṃbandhaḥ kalpayitavya ityanavasthāprasaṅgaḥ
analyzed: samavāya kalpanāyām api samavāyasya samavāyibhiḥ saṃbandhe bhyupagamyamāne tasya tasya anyonyaḥ saṃbandhaḥ kalpayitavyaḥ iti anavasthā prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Even if the assumption of inherence is made, if the inherence of inherence is accepted to be related to the inherent things, then the relation of each to the other would have to be imagined, leading to an infinite regress.

original: anabhyupagamyamāne ca vicchedaprasaṅgaḥ /🔽atha samavāyaḥ svayaṃ saṃbandharūpatvādanapekṣyaivāparaṃ saṃbandhaṃ saṃbadhyate /
analyzed: an abhyupagamyamāne ca viccheda prasaṅgaḥ  atha samavāyaḥ svayam saṃbandha rūpa tvāt an apekṣya eva aparam saṃbandham saṃbadhyate
translated: And if it is not accepted, there would be the undesirable consequence of disconnection.🔽But if inherence, being itself of the nature of relation, is related without depending on another relation,

original: saṃyogo 'pi tarhi svayaṃ saṃbandharūpatvādanapekṣyaiva samavāyaṃ saṃbadhyeta /
analyzed: saṃyogaḥ pi tarhi svayam saṃbandha rūpa tvāt an apekṣya eva samavāyam saṃbadhyeta
translated: then conjunction also, being itself of the nature of relation, would be related without depending on inherence.

analyzed: tādātmya pratīteḥ ca dravya guṇa ādīnām samavāya kalpanā ānarthakyam
translated: And because of the cognition of identity, the postulation of inherence for substance, quality, etc. is pointless.

original: kathaṃ ca kāryamavayavidravyaṃ kāraṇeṣvavayavadravyeṣu vartamānaṃ vartate /
analyzed: katham ca kāryam avayavi dravyam kāraṇeṣu avayava dravyeṣu vartamānam vartate
translated: How does the effect, the composite substance, which inheres in the causes, the component substances, inhere?

analyzed: kim samasteṣu avayaveṣu varteta uta pratyavayavam
translated: Does it inhere in all the components or in each component?

analyzed: yadi tāvat samasteṣu varteta tatas vayavi anupalabdhiḥ prasajyeta
translated: If it inheres in all, then the non-apprehension of the composite would result.

analyzed: samasta avayava samanikarṣasya aśakya tvāt
translated: Because the simultaneous contact of all the components is impossible.

original: nahi bahutvaṃ samasteṣvāśrayeṣu vartamānaṃ vyastāśrayagrahaṇena gṛhyate /
analyzed: nahi bahu tvam samasteṣu āśrayeṣu vartamānam vyasta āśraya grahaṇena gṛhyate
translated: For plurality, which exists in all the substrates, is not grasped by the apprehension of the separate substrates.

analyzed: atha avayavaśas samasteṣu varteta tadā api arambhaka avayava vyatirekeṇa avayavinaḥ vayavāḥ
translated: If it existed in all [substrates] by way of parts, then parts of the whole would have to be imagined, apart from the constituent parts,

original: kalpyeran yairārambhakeṣvavayaveṣvavayavaśo 'vayavī varteta kośāvayavavyatiriktairhyavayavairasiḥ kośaṃ vyāpnoti /
analyzed: kalpyeran yaiḥ ārambhakeṣu avayaveṣu avayavaśas vayavī varteta kośa avayava vyatiriktaiḥ hi avayavaiḥ asiḥ kośam vyāpnoti
translated: by which the whole would exist by way of parts in the constituent parts. For the sword pervades the scabbard with parts other than the parts of the scabbard.

analyzed: anavasthā ca evam prasajyeta
translated: And in this way, an infinite regress would ensue.

analyzed: teṣu teṣu ayavayaveṣu vartayitum anyeṣām avayavānām kalpanīya tvāt
translated: Because in order to make it exist in those and those parts, other parts would have to be imagined.

original: atha pratyavayavaṃ varteta tadaikatra vyāpāre /'nyatrāvyāpāraḥ syāt /
analyzed: atha pratyavayavam varteta tadā ekatra syāt
translated: Or if it existed by way of each part, then in the operation in one place, there would be no operation in another place.

original: nahi devadattaḥ snughne saṃnidhīyamānastadahareva pāṭaliputre 'pi saṃnidhīyeta /
analyzed: nahi devadattaḥ snughne saṃnidhīyamānaḥ tat ahar eva pāṭaliputre saṃnidhīyeta
translated: For Devadatta, being present in Srughna, would not be present on the same day in Pataliputra either.

analyzed: yugapad anekatra vṛttau aneka tva prasaṅgaḥ syāt
translated: If it existed in many places simultaneously, the fault of multiplicity would ensue.

analyzed: devadatta yajñadattayoḥ iva srughnā pāṭaliputra nivāsinoḥ
translated: Like Devadatta and Yajnadatta, who reside in Srughna and Pataliputra respectively.

original: gotvādivatpratyekaṃ parisamāpterna doṣa iti cet / na /
analyzed: go tva ādi vat pratyekam parisamāpteḥ na doṣaḥ iti ced na
translated: If you say there is no fault because it is complete in each individual, like cowness, that is not so.

analyzed: tathā pratīti abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no such cognition.

original: yadi gotvādivatpratyekaṃ parisamāpto 'vayavī syādyathā gotvaṃ prativyakti pratyakṣaṃ gṛhyata evamavayavyapi pratyavayavaṃ pratyakṣaṃ gṛhyeta
analyzed: yadi go tva ādi vat pratyekam parisamāptaḥ vayavī syāt yathā go tvam prati vyakti pratyakṣam gṛhyate evam avayavī api prati avayavam pratyakṣam gṛhyeta
translated: If the whole were complete in each part, like cowness, then just as cowness is perceived in each individual cow, so the whole would be perceived in each part.

analyzed: na ca evam niyatam gṛhyate
translated: But it is not perceived in this way.

original: pratyekaparisamāptau cāvayavinaḥ kāryeṇādhikārāttasya caikatvācchṛṅgeṇāpi stanakāryaṃ kuryādurasā ca pṛṣṭhakāryam /
analyzed: pratyeka parisamāptau ca avayavinaḥ kāryeṇa adhikārāt tasya ca ekatvāt śṛṅgeṇa api stana kāryam kuryāt urasā ca pṛṣṭha kāryam
translated: And if the whole were complete in each part, then since the whole would be engaged in the function of each part, and that function is one, the horn would also perform the function of the udder, and the chest the function of the back.

analyzed: na ca evam dṛśyate
translated: But it is not seen in this way.

original: prāgutpatteśca kāryasyāsattva utpattirakartṛkā nirātmikā ca syāt /
analyzed: prāk utpatteḥ ca kāryasya asattve utpattiḥ akartṛkā nirātmikā ca syāt
translated: And if the effect does not exist prior to its production, then production would be without an agent and without a self.

analyzed: utpacattiḥ ca nāma kriyā
translated: And production is an action.

analyzed: sā sa kartṛkā eva bhavitum arhati gati ādi vat
translated: It can only be said to have an agent, like going and so on.

original: kriyā ca nāma syādakartṛkā ceti vipratiṣidhyeta /🔽ghaṭasya cetpattirucyamānā na ghaṭakartṛkā kiṃ tarihyanyakartṛketi kalpyā syāt /
analyzed: kriyā ca nāma syāt akartṛkā ca iti vipratiṣidhyeta  ghaṭasya ced utpattiḥ ucyamānā na ghaṭa kartṛkā kim tarihi anya kartṛkā iti kalpyā syāt
translated: And it would be contradictory to say that an action is without an agent.🔽And if it is said that the production of the pot is not by the pot itself, but rather by something else, then it would have to be imagined that way.

analyzed: tathā kapāla ādīnām api utpattiḥ ucyamānā anya kartṛkā eva kalpyeta
translated: In the same way, if it is said that the production of the potsherds and so on is not by themselves, but rather by something else, it would have to be imagined that way.

original: tathāca sati ghaṭa utpadyata ityukte kulālādīnāmapyutpadyamānatā pratīyate /
analyzed: tathā ca sati ghaṭaḥ utpadyate iti ukte kulāla ādīnām api utpadyamānatā pratīyate
translated: And if that were so, then when it is said that the pot is produced, it would be understood that the potter and so on are also being produced.

analyzed: utpanna tā pratīteḥ ca
translated: And because of the cognition of the state of having arisen.

analyzed: atha sva kāraṇa sattā saṃbandhe evā utpattiḥ ātmalābhaḥ ca kāryasya iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the arising of an effect is just the relation of its existence to its own cause, and the acquisition of its own nature,

analyzed: katham alabdha ātmakam saṃbadhyeta iti vaktavyam
translated: it must be said how something that has not yet acquired its own nature can be related.

original: satorhi dvayoḥ saṃbandhaḥ saṃbhavati na sadasatorasatorvā /
analyzed: satoḥ hi dvayoḥ saṃbandhaḥ saṃbhavati na sat asatoḥ asatoḥ vā
translated: For the relation of two existent things is possible, not of an existent and a non-existent, or of two non-existent things.

analyzed: abhāvasya ca nirupākhya tvāt prāc utpatteḥ iti maryādā karaṇam anupapannam
translated: And because non-existence is indescribable, the setting of limits before arising is illogical.

original: satāṃ hi loke kṣetragṛhādīnāṃ maryādā dṛṣṭā nābhāvasya /
analyzed: satām hi loke kṣetra gṛha ādīnām maryādā dṛṣṭā na abhāvasya
translated: For in the world, limits of existent things like fields and houses are seen, not of non-existence.

original: nahi vandhyāputro rājā babhūva prākpūrṇavarmaṇo 'bhiṣekādityevañjātīyakena maryādākāraṇena
analyzed: nahi vandhyāputraḥ rājā babhūva prāk pūrṇavarmaṇaḥ bhiṣekāt iti evañjātīyakena maryādā kāraṇena
translated: For it is not the case that the son of a barren woman was a king before the anointment of Pūrṇavarman, by such a setting of limits.

analyzed: nirupākhyaḥ vandhyāputraḥ rājā babhūva prāk pūrṇavarmaṇaḥ bhiṣekāt iti evañjātīyakena
translated: By such a setting of limits, the indescribable son of a barren woman is specified as was a king before the anointment of Pūrṇavarman,

original: maryādākaraṇena nirupākhyo vandhyaputro rājā babhūva bhavati bhaviṣyatīti vā viśeṣyate /
analyzed: maryādā karaṇena nirupākhyaḥ vandhya putraḥ rājā babhūva bhavati bhaviṣyati iti vā viśeṣyate
translated: is, or will be.

original: yadi ca vandyāputro 'pi kārakavyāpārādūrdhvamabhaviṣyattata idamapyupātsyata kāryābhāvo 'pi kārakavyāpārādūrdhvaṃ bhaviṣyatīti /🔽vayaṃ tu paśyāmo vandyāputrasya kāryābhāvasya cābhāvatvāviśeṣādyathā vandhyāputraḥ kārakavyāpārādūrdhvaṃ na bhaviṣyatyevaṃ kāryābhāvo 'pi kārakavyāpārādūrdhvaṃ
analyzed: yadi ca kāraka vyāpārāt ūrdhvam abhaviṣyat tatas idam api upātsyata kārya abhāvaḥ pi kāraka vyāpārāt ūrdhvam bhaviṣyati iti  vayam tu paśyāmaḥ vandyā putrasya kārya abhāvasya ca abhāva tva aviśeṣāt yathā vandhyā putraḥ kāraka vyāpārāt ūrdhvam na bhaviṣyati evam kārya abhāvaḥ pi kāraka vyāpārāt ūrdhvam
translated: And if the son of a barren woman would exist after the operation of the causes, then this would also be accepted: the non-existence of the effect would exist after the operation of the causes.

analyzed: na bhaviṣyati iti
translated: But we see that, because there is no difference in the non-existence of the son of a barren woman and the non-existence of the effect, just as the son of a barren woman will not exist after the operation of the causes, so also the non-existence of the effect will not exist after the operation of the causes.

original: nanvevaṃ sati kārakavyāpāro 'narthakaḥ prasajyeta /🔽yathaiva hi prāksiddhatvātkāraṇasvarūpasiddhaye na kaścidvyāpriyate /
analyzed: nanu evam sati kāraka vyāpāraḥ narthakaḥ prasajyeta  yathā eva hi prāk siddhatvāt kāraṇa svarūpa siddhaye na kaścid vyāpriyate
translated: In that case, is it not that the operation of the causes becomes purposeless?🔽Just as no one acts for the sake of establishing the nature of the cause, because it is already established beforehand,

original: evaṃ prāksiddhatvāttadananyatvācca kāryasya svarūpasiddhaye 'pi na kaścidvyāpriyeta /
analyzed: evam prāk siddha tvāt tad ananya tvāt ca kāryasya svarūpa siddhaye na kaścid vyāpriyeta
translated: in the same way, no one would act for the sake of establishing the nature of the effect, because it is already established beforehand and is not different from that [cause].

analyzed: vyāpriyate ca
translated: But one does act.

analyzed: atas kāraka vyāpāra arthavat tvāya manyāmahe prāk utpatteḥ abhāva
translated: Therefore, for the sake of the purposefulness of the operation of the causes, we think that the effect does not exist before its origination.

analyzed: kāryasya iti
translated: This is the meaning.

analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ
translated: This is not a fault.

analyzed: yatas kāryākāreṇa kāraṇam vyavastāpayataḥ kāraka vyāpārasya arthavat tvam apapadyate
translated: Because the purposefulness of the operation of the causes is established when the cause is established in the form of the effect.

analyzed: kārya ākāraḥ pi kāraṇasya ātma bhūtaḥ eva an ātma bhūtasya an ārabhya tvāt iti abhāṇi
translated: And it has been said that the form of the effect is not something different from the cause, because what is not a part of the cause cannot be taken up.

analyzed: na ca viśeṣa darśana mātreṇa vastu anya tvam bhavati
translated: And mere perception of difference does not make a thing different.

original: nahi devadattaḥ saṃkocitahastapādaḥ prasāritahastapādaśca viśeṣaṇa dṛśyamāno 'pi vastvanyatvaṃ gacchati /
analyzed: nahi devadattaḥ saṃkocita hasta pādaḥ prasārita hasta pādaḥ ca vastu anya tvam gacchati
translated: For Devadatta, when seen with contracted hands and feet and then with outstretched hands and feet, does not become a different thing,

analyzed: saḥ eva iti pratyabhijñānāt
translated: because he is recognized as the same.

original: tathā pratidinamanekasaṃsthānānāmapi pitrādīnāṃ na vastvanyatvaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tathā pratidinam aneka saṃsthānānām api pitṛ ādīnām na vastu anya tvam bhavati
translated: Similarly, the father and others, even though having many different postures every day, do not become different things.

original: mama pitā mama bhrātā mama putra iti pratyabhijñānāt /
analyzed: mama pitā mama bhrātā mama putraḥ iti pratyabhijñānāt
translated: Because he is recognized as my father, my brother, my son.

analyzed: janma uccheda anantarita tvāt tatra yuktam na anyatra iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it is proper there [in the case of Devadatta] but not elsewhere because [his different states] are not separated by birth and destruction, that is not so.

analyzed: kṣīra ādīnām api dadhi ādi ākāra saṃsthānasya pratyakṣa tvāt
translated: Because the form and arrangement of milk etc. as curd etc. is directly perceived.

original: adṛśyamānānāmapi vaṭadhānādīnāṃ samānajātīyāvayavāntaropacitānāmaṅ kurādibhāvena darśanagocaratāpattau janmasaṃjñā /
analyzed: adṛśyamānānām api vaṭa dhānā ādīnām samāna jātīya avayava antara upacitānām aṅ kura ādi bhāvena darśana gocara tā āpattau janma saṃjñā
translated: Even though invisible, the seeds of the banyan tree etc., when they attain the state of being seen as sprouts etc. by the accumulation of similar parts, are designated as born.

analyzed: teṣām eva āyavānām apacaya vaśāt adarśana āpattau uccheda saṃjñā
translated: And when they attain the state of being unseen due to the loss of those very parts, they are designated as destroyed.

original: tatredṛgjanmocchedāntaritatvāccedasataḥ sattvapattistathā sati garbhavāsina uttānaśāyinaśca bhedaprasaṅgaḥ /🔽tathāca bālyayauvanasthāvireṣvapi bhedaprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: tatra īdṛś janma uccheda antarita tvāt ced asataḥ sattva pattiḥ tathā sati garbha vāsinaḥ uttāna śāyinaḥ ca bheda prasaṅgaḥ  tathā ca bālya yauvana sthāvireṣu api bheda prasaṅgaḥ
translated: If, on the other hand, the non-existent becomes existent by being separated from a different birth, then there would be a difference between the fetus and the newborn baby.🔽And so there would be a difference between the child, the youth, and the old man.

analyzed: pitṛ ādi vyavahāra lopa prasaṅgaḥ ca
translated: And there would be the absurdity of the cessation of the usage of father, etc.

analyzed: etena kṣaṇabhaṅga vādaḥ prativaditavyaḥ
translated: By this, the doctrine of momentariness should be refuted.

original: yasyapunaḥ prāgutpatterasatkāryaṃ tasya nirviṣayaḥ kārakavyāpāraḥ syāt /
analyzed: yasya punar prāc utpatteḥ asatkāryam tasya nirviṣayaḥ kāraka vyāpāraḥ syāt
translated: But for one for whom the effect is non-existent before production, the operation of the cause would be objectless.

analyzed: abhāvasya viṣaya tva anupapatteḥ ākāśa hanana prayojana khaḍga ādi aneka āyudha prayukti vat
translated: Because an absence cannot be an object, like the use of many weapons such as a sword, etc. for the purpose of killing space.

analyzed: samavāyi kāraṇa viṣayaḥ kāraka vyāpāraḥ syāt iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the operation of the cause would have the inherent cause as its object, that is not so.

analyzed: anya viṣayeṇa kāraka vyāpāreṇa anya niṣpatteḥ atiprasaṅgāt

original: tasmātkṣīrādīnyeva dravyāṇi dadhyādibhāvenāvatiṣṭhamānāni kāryākhyāṃ labhanta iti na kāraṇādanyatkāryaṃ varṣaśatenāpi śakyaṃ niścetum /

original: tatredaṃśabdavācyasya kāryasya prāgutpatteḥ sacchabdavācyena kāraṇena sāmānādhikaraṇyasya śrūyamāṇatvātsattvānanyatve prasiddhyataḥ /

original: yathā caikapṛthivīvyapāśrayāṇāmapi bījānāṃ bahuvidhaṃ patrapuṣpaphalagandharasādivaicitryaṃ candanakiṃpākādiṣūpalakṣyate /
analyzed: yathā ca eka pṛthivī vyapāśrayāṇām api bījānām bahuvidham patra puṣpa phala gandha rasa ādi vaicitryam candana kiṃpāka ādiṣu upalakṣyate
translated: And just as, even though the seeds depend on the one earth, a manifold diversity of leaves, flowers, fruits, scents, tastes, etc. is observed in sandal trees, betel trees, etc.

original: yathā caikasyāpyannarasasya lohitādīni keśalomādīni ca vicitrāṇi kāryāṇi bhavanti /
analyzed: yathā ca ekasya api anna rasasya lohita ādīni keśa loma ādīni ca vicitrāṇi kāryāṇi bhavanti
translated: And just as, even from one food substance, diverse effects like blood, hair, etc. come about.

original: evamekasyāpi brahmaṇo jīvaprājñapṛthaktvaṃ kāryavaicitryaṃ copapadyata ityastadanupapattiḥ /
analyzed: evam ekasya api brahmaṇaḥ jīva prājña pṛthaktvam kārya vaicitryam ca upapadyate
translated: In the same way, even for the one Brahman, the difference between the individual soul and the wise one and the diversity of effects are possible. Thus there is no non-applicability.

analyzed: para parikalpita doṣa anupapattiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the non-applicability of the faults imagined by others is not possible.

analyzed: śruteḥ ca prāmāṇyāt vikārasya ca vācā ārambhaṇa mātra tvāt svapna dṛśya bhāva vaicitrya vat ca iti abhyuccayaḥ   🔽kiṃpākaḥ mahātāla phalam
translated: And because of the authoritativeness of the scriptures and because of the mere verbal origination of the modification, like the diversity of things seen in a dream, this is a further argument.

analyzed: upasaṃhāra darśana adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on the teaching of the conclusion. Sutra.

original: upasaṃhāradarśanān neti cen na kṣīravad dhi / / / /
analyzed: upasaṃhāra darśanāt na iti ced na kṣīravat hi
translated: If it is argued that it is not so because of the teaching of the conclusion, it is not so, because like milk, indeed.

original: cetanaṃ brahmaikamadvitīyaṃ jagataḥ kāraṇamiti yaduktaṃ tannopapadyate /
analyzed: cetanam brahma ekam advitīyam jagataḥ kāraṇam iti yat uktam tat na upapadyate
translated: What has been said that the intelligent Brahman alone, without a second, is the cause of the world, that is not reasonable.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

analyzed: upasaṃhāra darśanāt
translated: Because of the teaching of the conclusion.

original: iha hi loke kulālādayo ghaṭapaṭādīnāṃ kartāro mṛddaṇḍacakrasūtrādyanekakārakopasaṃhāreṇa saṃgṛhītasādhanāḥ santastattatkāryaṃ kurvāṇā dṛśyante
analyzed: iha hi loke kulāla ādayaḥ ghaṭa paṭa ādīnām kartāraḥ mṛd daṇḍa cakra sūtra ādi aneka kāraka upasaṃhāreṇa saṃgṛhīta sādhanāḥ santaḥ tat tat kāryam kurvāṇāḥ dṛśyante
translated: For in this world, potters and others, the makers of pots, cloth, etc., are seen to make those effects by assembling the means consisting of many factors such as clay, stick, wheel, thread, etc.

original: brahma cāsahāyaṃ tavābhipretaṃ tasya sādhanāntarānupasaṃgrahe sati kathaṃ sraṣṭṛtvamupapadyeta /
analyzed: brahma ca asahāyam tava abhipretam tasya sādhana antara an upasaṃgrahe sati katham sraṣṭṛ tvam upapadyeta
translated: And Brahman, according to you, is without a companion. If it does not assemble other means, how can its creatorship be reasonable?

analyzed: tasmāt na brahma jagat kāraṇam iti ced
translated: Therefore, Brahman is not the cause of the world, if this is argued.

analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ  yatas kṣīravat dravya svabhāva viśeṣāt upapadyate
translated: This is not a fault.🔽Because it is possible due to the special nature of the substance, like milk.

original: yathā hi loke kṣīraṃ jalaṃ vā svayameva dadhihimabhāvena pariṇamate 'napekṣya bāhyaṃ sādhanaṃ tathehāpi bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: yathā hi loke kṣīram jalam vā svayam eva dadhi hima bhāvena pariṇamate na apekṣya bāhyam sādhanam tathā iha api bhaviṣyati
translated: For just as in the world, milk or water itself undergoes transformation into curd or ice, without depending on external means, so it will be here also.

original: nanu kṣīrādyapi dadhyādibhāvena pariṇāmamānapekṣata eva bāhyaṃ sādhanamauṣṇyādikaṃ kathamucyate kṣīravaddhīti /
analyzed: nanu kṣīrādi api dadhi ādi bhāvena pariṇāmam ān apekṣate eva bāhyam sādhanam auṣṇya ādikam katham ucyate kṣīra vat hi iti
translated: But even milk requires an external means, such as heat, etc., in order to transform itself into curd, etc. How then can it be said that the intellect is like milk?

analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ
translated: This is not a fault.

original: svayamapi hi kṣīraṃ yāṃ ca yāvatīṃ ca pariṇāmamātramanubhavati tāvatyeva tvāryate tvauṣṇyādinā dadhibhāvāya /
analyzed: svayam api hi kṣīram yām ca yāvatīm ca pariṇāma mātram anubhavati tāvatī eva tu āryate tu auṣṇya ādinā dadhi bhāvāya
translated: For as far and as much as milk itself experiences a mere transformation, to that extent and no more is it impelled by heat, etc., to the state of curd.

original: yadi ca svayaṃ dadhibhāvaśīlatā na syānnaivauṣṇyādināpi balāddadhibhāvamāpadyeta /
analyzed: yadi ca svayam dadhi bhāva śīla tā na syāt na eva auṣṇya ādinā api balāt dadhi bhāvam āpadyeta
translated: And if it did not have the nature of becoming curd by itself, it would not be forced into the state of curd even by heat, etc.

analyzed: nahi vāyuḥ ākāśaḥ balāt dadhi bhāvam āpadyate
translated: For air or space is not forced into the state of curd by heat, etc.

analyzed: sādana sāmagryā ca tasya pūrṇa tā saṃpādyate
translated: And by the complete collection of the means of curd-production, its completeness is accomplished.

analyzed: paripūrṇa śaktikam tu brahma
translated: But Brahman has complete power.

analyzed: na tasya anyena kenacid pūrṇa tā saṃpādayitavyā
translated: Its completeness is not to be accomplished by anything else.

original: śrutiśca bhavati 'na tasya kāryaṃ kāraṇaṃ ca vidyate na tatsamaścābhyadhikaśca dṛśyate /
analyzed: śrutiḥ ca bhavati na tasya kāryam kāraṇam ca vidyate na tad samaḥ ca abhyadhikaḥ ca dṛśyate
translated: And there is the Vedic text: 'For it there is neither effect nor cause, nor is anything seen equal or superior to it.

original: parāsya śaktirvividhaiva śrūyate svābhāvikī jñānabalakriyā ca //
analyzed: parā asya śaktiḥ vividhā eva śrūyate svābhāvikī jñāna bala kriyā ca
translated: The power of that is declared to be manifold, natural, consisting of knowledge, strength, and action.'

analyzed: śve iti
translated: Thus it is said.

analyzed: tasmāt ekasya api brahmaṇaḥ vicitra śakti yogāt kṣīra ādi vat vicitra pariṇāmaḥ upapadyate
translated: Therefore, even for Brahman alone, due to the connection with diverse powers, diverse modifications are possible, just as in milk and so on.

analyzed: kārakāṇām upasaṃhāraḥ melanam
translated: The bringing together of the instrumental causes is their combination.

analyzed: tvāryate śaighryam kāryate kṣīram dadhi bhāvam auṣṇya ādinā
translated: Milk is caused to be made into curd by heat and so on.

analyzed: deva ādi vat api loke  /
translated: Even like gods and so on in the world.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

original: upapadyate kṣīrādīnāmacetanānāmanapekṣyāpi bāhyaṃ sādhanaṃ dadhyādibhāvaḥ / dṛṣṭatvāt /
analyzed: upapadyate kṣīra ādīnām acetanānām an apekṣya api bāhyam sādhanam dadhi ādi bhāvaḥ dṛṣṭa tvāt
translated: The transformation of unconscious things like milk into curd, etc., without external means is possible, because it is seen.

original: cetanāḥ punaḥ kulālādayaḥ sādhanasāmagrīmapekṣyaiva tasmai kāryāya pravartamānā dṛśyante /
analyzed: cetanāḥ punar kulāla ādayaḥ sādhana sāmagrīm apekṣya eva tasmai kāryāya pravartamānāḥ dṛśyante
translated: But conscious potters, etc., are seen to engage in that action only in dependence on the collection of means.

analyzed: katham brahma cetanam sat asahāyam pravarteta iti
translated: How can Brahman, though conscious, engage in that without a helper?

analyzed: deva ādi vat iti brūmaḥ
translated: We say: like gods and so on.

original: yathā loke devāḥ pitara ṛṣaya ityevamādayo mahāprabhāvāścetanā api santo 'napekṣyaiva
analyzed: yathā loke devāḥ pitaraḥ ṛṣayaḥ iti evamādayaḥ mahā prabhāvāḥ cetanāḥ api santaḥ na apekṣya eva
translated: Just as in the world, gods, ancestors, sages, and so on, though powerful and conscious, without depending on

analyzed: kiñcid bāhyam sādhanam aiśvarya viśeṣa yogāt abhidhyāna mātreṇa svatas eva bahūni nānā saṃsthāni
translated: any external means, by the mere act of thinking, due to the connection with a special kind of power, they themselves produce many objects of various shapes and sizes,

original: śarīrīṇi prāsādādīni ca rathādīni ca nirmimāṇā upalabhyante mantrārthavādetihāsapurāṇaprāmāṇyāt /
analyzed: śarīrīṇi prāsāda ādīni ca ratha ādīni ca nirmimāṇāḥ upalabhyante mantra arthavāda itihāsa purāṇa prāmāṇyāt
translated: And it is observed that bodies, palaces, etc., and chariots, etc., are created. This is known from the authority of mantras, arthavadas, itihāsas, and purāṇas.

analyzed: tantunābhaḥ ca svatas eva tantūn sṛjati
translated: And the spider creates threads from itself.

analyzed: balākā ca antareṇa eva śukram garbham dhatte
translated: And the female cuckoo conceives a young one without any semen.

analyzed: padminī ca an apekṣya kiñcid prastāna sādhanam saraḥ ntarāt saraḥ ntaram pratiṣṭhate
translated: And the lotus plant moves from one lake to another without any means of conveyance.

original: evaṃ cetanamapi brahmānapekṣya bāhyaṃ sādhanaṃ svata eva jagatsrakṣyati /
analyzed: evam cetanam api brahma an apekṣya bāhyam sādhanam svatas eva jagat srakṣyati
translated: In the same way, the conscious Brahman will create the world from itself alone, without depending on any external means.

original: sa yadi brūyādya ete devādayo brahmaṇo dṛṣṭāntā upāttāste dārṣṭrāntikena brahmaṇā na samānā bhavanti /
analyzed: sa yadi brūyāt ye ete deva ādayaḥ brahmaṇaḥ dṛṣṭāntāḥ upāttāḥ te dārṣṭrāntikena brahmaṇā na samānāḥ bhavanti
translated: If he says: The examples of Brahman, such as the gods, that are mentioned, do not become the same as the Brahman to be inferred.

original: śarīrameva hyacetanaṃ devādīnāṃ śarīrāntarādivibhūtyutpādana upādānaṃ natu cetana ātmā /🔽tantunābhyā ca kṣudratarajantubhakṣaṇāllālā kaṭhinatāmāpadyamānā tanturbhavati /
analyzed: śarīram eva hi acetanam deva ādīnām śarīra antara ādi vibhūti utpādane upādānam na tu cetanaḥ ātmā  tantu nābhyā ca kṣudratara jantu bhakṣaṇāt lālā kaṭhina tām āpadyamānā tantuḥ bhavati
translated: For the body alone, which is insentient, is the material cause for the gods, etc., in the production of various manifestations within the body, not the conscious Self.🔽And the spider's saliva becomes thread as it hardens from eating tiny creatures.

analyzed: balākā ca stanayitnu rava śravaṇāt garbham dhatte
translated: And the female cuckoo conceives a young one from hearing the sound of thunder.

original: padminī ca cetanaprayuktā satyacetanevaiva śarīreṇa sarontaropasarpaṇe vyāpriyate /
analyzed: padminī ca cetana prayuktā satī acetanā iva eva śarīreṇa saraḥ ntara upasarpaṇe vyāpriyate
translated: And the lotus, though really insentient, is seen to act in approaching the lake through the impulse of an intelligent being.

analyzed: tasmāt na ete brahmaṇaḥ dṛṣṭāntāḥ iti
translated: Therefore these are the examples of Brahman.

analyzed: tam prati brūyāt na ayam doṣaḥ
translated: To him we would say: This is not a fault.

analyzed: kulāla ādi dṛṣṭānta vailakṣaṇya mātrasya vivakṣita tvāt iti
translated: Because the mere difference from the examples of the potter, etc. is intended.

original: yathā hi kulālādīnāṃ devādīnāṃ ca samāne cetanatve kulālādayaḥ kāryārambhe bāhyaṃ sādhanamapekṣante na devādayaḥ /
analyzed: yathā hi kulāla ādīnām deva ādīnām ca samāne cetana tve kulāla ādayaḥ kārya ārambhe bāhyam sādhanam apekṣante na deva ādayaḥ
translated: For just as the potters, etc. and the gods, etc. are the same in being conscious, the potters, etc. require external means in the beginning of their work, not the gods, etc.

original: tathā brahma cetanamapi na bāhyaṃ sādhanamapekṣiṣyata ityetadvākyaṃ devādyudāharaṇena vivakṣyāmaḥ /
analyzed: tathā brahma cetanam api na bāhyam sādhanam apekṣiṣyate iti etat vākyam deva ādi udāharaṇena vivakṣyāmaḥ
translated: Similarly, Brahman, though conscious, will not require external means. This is what we intend to say by the example of the gods, etc.

original: tasmādyathaikasya sāmarthyaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ tathā sarveṣāmeva bhavitumarhatīti nāstyekānta ityabhiprāyaḥ // //
analyzed: tasmāt yathā ekasya sāmarthyam dṛṣṭam tathā sarveṣām eva bhavitum arhati iti na asti ekāntaḥ iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: Therefore, just as the capacity of one is seen, so it should be for all. There is no absolute rule, this is the intention.

original: FN / lokyate jñāyater'thoneneti loko mantrārthavādādiśāstraṃ vṛddhavyavahāraśca /
analyzed: lokyate jñāyate ṛtha ūna iti lokaḥ mantra arthavāda ādi śāstram vṛddha vyavahāraḥ ca
translated: The world is that by which the meaning is seen, known. The sacred teaching such as mantra, arthavada, etc. and the usage of the elders.

analyzed: abhidhyānam saṃkalpaḥ
translated: Meditation is resolve.

original: yathā bhārate śrīkṛṣṇasya saṃkalpamātreṇa draupadyāḥ paṭaparamparotpattiḥ tathā asahāyasyāpi brahmaṇaḥ kāraṇatvam /
analyzed: yathā bhārate śrī kṛṣṇasya saṃkalpa mātreṇa draupadyāḥ paṭa paramparā utpattiḥ tathā asahāyasya api brahmaṇaḥ kāraṇa tvam
translated: Just as in the Mahābhārata, by the mere will of Śrī Kṛṣṇa, a series of cloths were produced from Draupadī, so also Brahman, though without a helper, is the cause.

analyzed: kṛtsna prasakti adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on the connection of the whole. Sūtra.

analyzed: kṛtsna prasaktiḥ niravayava tva śabda kopaḥ vā
translated: The connection of the whole, or the contradiction of the non-composite nature.

original: cetanamekamadvitīyaṃ brahma kṣīrādivaddevādivaccānapekṣya bāhyasādhanaṃ svayaṃ pariṇamamānaṃ jagataḥ kāraṇamiti sthitam /
analyzed: cetanam ekam advitīyam brahma kṣīra ādi vat deva ādi vat ca an apekṣya bāhya sādhanam svayam pariṇamamānam jagataḥ kāraṇam iti sthitam
translated: It has been established that the one conscious Brahman, without a second, like milk etc. and like God etc., transforming itself without depending on external means, is the cause of the world.

analyzed: śāstra artha pariśuddhaye tu punar ākṣipati
translated: But in order to purify the meaning of the scriptures, it is again raised.

original: kṛtsnaprasaktiḥ kṛtsnasya brahmaṇaḥ kāryarūpeṇa pariṇāmaḥ prāpnoti /
analyzed: kṛtsna prasaktiḥ kṛtsnasya brahmaṇaḥ kārya rūpeṇa pariṇāmaḥ prāpnoti
translated: The connection of the whole, the transformation of the entire Brahman into the form of an effect, would follow.

analyzed: niravayava tvāt
translated: Because it is non-composite.

analyzed: yadi brahma pathivī ādi vat sa avayavam abhaviṣyat tatas sya eka deśaḥ paryaṇaṃsyat eka deśaḥ ca avāsthāsyat
translated: If Brahman would have parts like earth etc., then one part of it would transform and another part would remain.

original: niravayavaṃ tu brahma śrutibhyo 'vagamyate 'niṣkalaṃ niṣkriyaṃ śāntaṃ niravadyaṃ nirañjanam' śve / /
analyzed: niravayavam tu brahma śrutibhyaḥ vagamyate niṣkalam niṣkriyam śāntam niravadyam nirañjanam
translated: But Brahman is understood from the scriptures to be non-composite: Without parts, without action, peaceful, faultless, unstained (Śve. 5.11).

analyzed: divyaḥ hi amūrtaḥ puruṣaḥ sa bāhya abhyantaraḥ hi ajaḥ
translated: For the divine, indeed, is the formless person, who is both internal and external, and is unborn (Mu. 1.1.9).

analyzed: idam mahat bhūtam anantam apāram vijñāna ghane eva bṛ
translated: 'This great Being is infinite, boundless, a mass of pure knowledge' (Br. 1.4.16).

analyzed: saḥ eṣa na iti na iti ātmā bṛ

analyzed: a sthūlam an aṇu bṛ
translated: 'Not gross, not subtle' (Br. 3.8.8).

analyzed: ityādyābhyaḥ sarva viśeṣa pratiṣedhinībhyaḥ
translated: Thus by these and other passages that deny all distinctions.

analyzed: tatas ca eka deśa pariṇāma saṃbhavāt kṛtsna pariṇāma prasaktau satyām mūla ucchedaḥ prasajyeta
translated: And then, because the transformation of a part is possible, when there is the contingency of the transformation of the whole, there would be the cutting off of the root.

analyzed: draṣṭavya tā upadeśa ānarthakyam ca āpannam ayatna draṣṭa tvāt kāryasya

translated: And because Brahman is not possible apart from that, there is the contradiction of the words 'unborn' etc.

original: athaitaddoṣaparijihīrṣayā sāvayavameva brahmābhyupagamyeta tathāpi ye niravayavatvasya pratipādakāḥ śabdā udāhṛtāste prakuṣyeyuḥ /
analyzed: atha etad doṣa parijihīrṣayā sāvayavam eva brahma abhyupagamyeta tathā api ye niravayava tvasya pratipādakāḥ śabdāḥ udāhṛtāḥ te prakuṣyeyuḥ
translated: Now, even if Brahman is accepted as having parts, with the desire to avoid these faults, even then the passages quoted as teaching that it is partless would be contradicted.

analyzed: sāvayava tve ca anitya tva prasaṅgaḥ iti
translated: And if it has parts, it would follow that it is non-eternal.

analyzed: eka deśaḥ ca avasthāsyat apariṇataḥ bhaviṣyat

analyzed: śruteḥ tu śabda mūla tvāt

analyzed: na tāvat kṛtsna prasaktiḥ asti

analyzed: kutas

analyzed: yathā eva hi brahmaṇaḥ jagat utpattiḥ śrūyate evam vikāra vyatirekeṇa api brahmaṇaḥ vastānam śrūyate
translated: Just as the origin of the world from Brahman is heard, so also the existence of Brahman apart from its modifications is heard.

translated: And the beginninglessness of transmigration is perceived in the scriptures and the traditions.🔽In the scriptures, in the beginning of the creation, he shows that transmigration is beginningless by addressing the embodied Self with the word jīva (living being), which is based on the retention of life.

original: iti sargapramukhe śārīramātmānaṃ jīvaśabdena prāṇadhāraṇanimittenābhilapannanādiḥ saṃsāra iti darśayati /
analyzed: iti sarga pramukhe śārīram ātmānam jīva śabdena prāṇa dhāraṇa nimittena abhilapan anādiḥ saṃsāraḥ iti darśayati
translated: By this living Self (Ch. U. 6.3.2).

original: ādimattve tu prāganavadhāritaprāṇaḥ san kathaṃ prāṇādadhāraṇanimittena jīvaśabdena sargapramukhe 'bhilapyeta /
analyzed: ādimattve tu prāk anavadhārita prāṇaḥ san katham prāṇāt adhāraṇa nimittena jīva śabdena sarga pramukhe bhilapyeta
translated: But if it had a beginning, how could it be addressed at the beginning of creation with the word jīva, which is based on the retention of life, when life was not yet determined?

analyzed: na ca dhārayiṣyati iti atas bhilapyeta
translated: Nor could it be addressed because it will retain [life].

analyzed: anāgatāt hi saṃndhāt atītaḥ saṃbandhaḥ balavān bhavati
translated: For a past connection is stronger than a future connection.

analyzed: abhiniṣpanna tvāt
translated: Because it is accomplished.

analyzed: sūryācandramasau dhātā yathāpūrvam akalpayat ṛsam
translated: And the text of a mantra also shows that there was a former Kalpa:

analyzed: iti ca mantra varṇaḥ pūrva kalpa sadbhāvam darśayati
translated: As the creator has arranged the sun and moon as before.🔽And in the Smṛti also the beginninglessness of the world is perceived:

original: smṛtāvapyanāditvaṃ saṃsārasyopalabhyate 'na rūpamasyeha tathopalabhyate nānto na cādirna ca saṃpratiṣṭhā' gī / / iti /
analyzed: smṛtau api anādi tvam saṃsārasya upalabhyate na rūpam asya iha tathā upalabhyate na antaḥ na ca ādiḥ na ca saṃpratiṣṭhā iti
translated: No form of this is perceived here, no end, no beginning, no foundation.

original: purāṇe cātītānāgatānāṃ ca kalpanāṃ na parimāṇamastīti sthāpitam // //
analyzed: purāṇe ca atīta anāgatānām ca kalpanām na parimāṇam asti iti sthāpitam
translated: And in the Purāṇa it is established that there is no limit to the past and future Kalpas.

analyzed: sarva dharma upapatti adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on the possibility of all things. Sutra.

analyzed: sarva dharma upapatteḥ ca
translated: And because all things are possible.

original: cetanaṃ brahma jagataḥ kāraṇaṃ prakṛtiścetyasminnavadhārite vedārthe parairupakṣiptānvilakṣaṇatvādīndoṣānparyahārṣīdācāryaḥ /
analyzed: cetanam brahma jagataḥ kāraṇam prakṛtiḥ ca iti asmin avadhārite veda arthe paraiḥ upakṣiptān vilakṣaṇa tva ādīn doṣān paryahārṣīt ācāryaḥ
translated: When the meaning of the Veda has been ascertained by others that intelligent Brahman is the cause and material cause of the world, the teacher has refuted the objections raised by others such as the defect of difference.

original: idānīṃ parapakṣapratiṣedhapradhānaṃ prakaraṇaṃ prāripsamāṇaḥ svapakṣaparigrahapradhānaṃ prakaraṇamupasaṃharati /
analyzed: idānīm parapakṣa pratiṣedha pradhānam prakaraṇam prāripsamāṇaḥ sva pakṣa parigraha pradhānam prakaraṇam upasaṃharati
translated: Now, beginning a section that is mainly concerned with the refutation of the opponent's view, he concludes a section that is mainly concerned with the acceptance of his own view.

original: yasmādasminbrahmaṇi kāraṇe parigṛhyamāṇe pradarśitena prakāreṇa sarve kāraṇadharmā upapadyante 'sarvajñaṃ sarvaśakti mahāmāyaṃ ca brahma' iti /
analyzed: yasmāt asmin brahmaṇi kāraṇe parigṛhyamāṇe pradarśitena prakāreṇa sarve kāraṇa dharmāḥ upapadyante sarvajñam sarva śakti mahā māyam ca brahma iti
translated: Because, when this Brahman is accepted as the cause, all the attributes of a cause are possible in the manner shown, that Brahman is omniscient, omnipotent, and of great illusion.

analyzed: tasmāt an atiśaṅkanīyam idam aupaniṣadam darśanam iti
translated: Therefore, this Upanisadic doctrine is beyond doubt.

original: iti śrīgovindabhagavatpūjyapādaśiṣyaśaṅkarabhagavatpūjyapādakṛtau śārīrakamīmāṃsābhāṣye dvitīyādhyāyasya prathamaḥ pādaḥ samāptaḥ // //
analyzed: iti śrī govinda bhagavat pūjya pāda śiṣya śaṅkara bhagavat pūjya pāda kṛtau śārīraka mīmāṃsā bhāṣye dvitīya adhyāyasya prathamaḥ pādaḥ samāptaḥ  /
translated: Thus ends the first chapter of the second section of the commentary on the Vedanta Sutras by the venerable Sankaracharya.

original: racanānupapatteś ca nānumānaṃ / / / /🔽yadyapīdaṃ vedāntavākyānāmaidaṃparyaṃ nirūpayituṃ śāstraṃ pravṛttaṃ na tarkśāstravat devalābhir yuktibhiḥ kaṃcit siddhāntaṃ sādhayituṃ dūṣayituṃ
analyzed: racanā anupapatteḥ ca na anumānam  yadi api idam vedānta vākyānām aidaṃparyam nirūpayitum śāstram pravṛttam na tarka śāstra vat devalābhiḥ yuktibhiḥ kaṃcid siddhāntam sādhayitum dūṣayitum
translated: And because of the impossibility of arrangement, there is no inference.

analyzed: vā pravṛttam
translated: Although this treatise is engaged in determining the purport of the Vedanta passages, it is not engaged in establishing or refuting some conclusion by means of logical arguments like a treatise on logic.

original: tathāpi vedāntavākyam api vyācakṣāṇaiḥ samyagdarśanapratipakṣabhūtāni sāṃkhyādidarśanāni nirākaraṇīyāṇīti tadarthaḥ paraḥ pādaḥ pravartate
analyzed: tathā api vedānta vākyam api vyācakṣāṇaiḥ samyak darśana pratipakṣa bhūtāni sāṃkhya ādi darśanāni nirākaraṇīyāṇi iti tad arthaḥ paraḥ pādaḥ pravartate
translated: Nevertheless, those who explain the Vedanta passages must refute the Samkhya and other systems that are opposed to the true doctrine. For that purpose, the next section begins.

original: vedāntārthanirṇayasya ca samyagdarśanārthatvāt tannirṇayena svapakṣasthāpanaṃ prathamaṃ kṛtaṃ taddyabhyarhitaṃ parapakṣapratyākhyānād iti /
analyzed: vedānta artha nirṇayasya ca samyak darśana artha tvāt tad nirṇayena sva pakṣa sthāpanam prathamam kṛtam tat di abhyarhitam para pakṣa pratyākhyānāt iti
translated: And since the ascertainment of the meaning of the Vedanta is for the sake of right knowledge, the establishment of one's own position by that ascertainment was done first, as that is more important than the refutation of the opponent's position.

original: nanu mumukṣūṇāṃ mokṣasādhanatvena samyagdarśananirūpaṇāya svapakṣasthāpanam eva kevalaṃ kartuṃ yuktaṃ kiṃ parapakṣanirākaraṇena paradveṣakareṇa
analyzed: nanu mumukṣūṇām mokṣa sādhana tvena samyak darśana nirūpaṇāya sva pakṣa sthāpanam eva kevalam kartum yuktam kim para pakṣa nirākaraṇena para dveṣa kareṇa
translated: But it is proper to establish one's own position alone for the purpose of describing right knowledge as the means of liberation for those who desire liberation. What is the use of refuting the opponent's position, which causes hatred towards others?

analyzed: bāḍham evam
translated: Indeed, it is so.

original: tathāpi mahājanaparigṛhītāni mahānti sāṃkhyāditantrāṇi samyagdarśanāpadeśena pravṛttānyupalabhya bhavet keṣāṃcin mandamatīnām etāny api samyagdarśanāyopadeyānītyapekṣā
analyzed: tathā api mahājana parigṛhītāni mahānti sāṃkhya ādi tantrāṇi samyak darśana apadeśena pravṛttāni upalabhya bhavet keṣāṃcid manda matīnām etāni api samyak darśanāya upadeyāni iti apekṣā
translated: Nevertheless, seeing that the great systems of Sankhya and others, accepted by the masses, are found to be engaged in the teaching of right knowledge, some slow-witted people might expect that these should also be taught for the sake of right knowledge.

original: tathā yuktagāḍhatvasaṃbhavena sarvajñabhāṣitatvācca śraddhā ca teṣvityatastadasāratopapādanāya prayatyate /
analyzed: tathā yukta gāḍha tva saṃbhavena sarvajña bhāṣita tvāt ca śraddhā ca teṣu iti atas tad asāra tā upapādanāya prayatyate
translated: And since they are capable of being deeply understood in that way, and are also spoken by the Omniscient One, there is faith in them. Therefore, an effort is made to establish their worthlessness.

analyzed: nanu īkṣateḥ na aśabdam brasū
translated: But is it not so that 'not from non-word, because of seeing'? Brahmasutra

analyzed: kāmāt ca na anumāna apekṣā brasū
translated: And 'because of desire, there is no need for inference'? Brahmasutra

analyzed: etena sarve vyākhyātāḥ vyākhyātāḥ brasū
translated: 'By this, all are explained, are explained'? Brahmasutra

analyzed: iti ca pūrvatra api sāṃkhya ādi pakṣa pratikṣepaḥ kṛtaḥ
translated: Thus, the views of the Sāṃkhyas and others have already been refuted.

analyzed: kim punar kṛta karaṇena iti
translated: What is the use of doing it again?

original: taducyate sāṃkhyādayaḥ svapakṣasthāpanāya vedāntavākyānyapyudāhṛtya svapakṣānuguṇenaiva yojayanto vyācakṣate /
analyzed: tat ucyate sāṃkhya ādayaḥ sva pakṣa sthāpanāya vedānta vākyāni api udāhṛtya sva pakṣa anuguṇena eva yojayantaḥ vyācakṣate
translated: It is said that the Sāṃkhyas and others, in order to establish their own views, quote even the Vedānta passages, and explain them by connecting them only with their own views.

original: teṣāṃ yadvyākhyānaṃ tadvyākhyanābhāsaṃ na samyagvyakhyānamityetāvatpūrvaṃ kṛtam /
analyzed: teṣām yat vyākhyānam tat vyākhyana ābhāsam na samyak vyakhyānam iti etāvat pūrvam kṛtam
translated: The explanation given by them is a mere semblance of explanation, not a correct explanation - this much has been done before.

original: iha tu vākyanirapekṣaḥ svatantrastadyuktipratiṣedhaḥ kriyata ityeṣa viśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: iha tu vākya nirapekṣaḥ svatantraḥ tad yukti pratiṣedhaḥ kriyate iti eṣa viśeṣaḥ
translated: But here the refutation of their arguments is done independently, without regard to the statements. This is the difference.

original: tatra sāṃkhyā manyante yathā ghaṭaśarāvādayo bhedā mṛdātmanānvīyamānā mṛdātmakasāmānyapūrvakā loke dṛṣṭāḥ /
analyzed: tatra sāṃkhyāḥ manyante yathā ghaṭa śarāva ādayaḥ bhedāḥ mṛd ātmanā anvīyamānāḥ mṛd ātmaka sāmānya pūrvakāḥ loke dṛṣṭāḥ
translated: There the Sāṃkhyas think that just as the various things like pots, plates, etc., which are found to be of the nature of clay, must have as their antecedent a universal which is of the nature of clay,

original: tathā sarva eva bāhyādhyātmikā bhedāḥ sukhaduḥkhamohātmatayānvīyamānāḥ sukhaduḥkhamohātmakasāmānyapūrvikā bhavitumarhanti /
analyzed: tathā sarve eva bāhya ādhyātmikāḥ bhedāḥ sukha duḥkha moha ātma tayā anvīyamānāḥ sukha duḥkha moha ātmaka sāmānya pūrvikāḥ bhavitum arhanti
translated: in the same way all the external and internal things, which are found to be of the nature of pleasure, pain, and delusion, must have as their antecedent a universal which is of the nature of pleasure, pain, and delusion.

original: yattatsukhaduḥkhamohātmakaṃ sāmānyaṃ tatttriguṇaṃ pradhānaṃ mṛdvadacetanaṃ cetanasya puruṣārthaṃ sādhayituṃ svabhāvenaiva vicitreṇa vikārātmanā 🔽vivartata iti /
analyzed: yat tat sukha duḥkha moha ātmakam sāmānyam tat triguṇam pradhānam mṛd vat acetanam cetanasya puruṣa artham sādhayitum svabhāvena eva vicitreṇa vikāra ātmanā  vivartate iti
translated: That which is the common nature consisting of pleasure, pain, and delusion, that is the three qualities, the pradhāna, which is insentient like clay, and by its own nature, which is variegated, it evolves into the form of modifications in order to accomplish the purpose of the conscious [puruṣa].

analyzed: tathā pariṇāma ādibhiḥ api liṅgaiḥ tat eva pradhānam anuminute
translated: Thus, by the indications of evolution and so on, he infers that very pradhāna.

analyzed: tatra vadāmaḥ yadi dṛṣṭānta balena eva etat nirūpyeta
translated: To that we say: If this were to be determined solely by the force of examples,

analyzed: na acetanam loke cetanā anadhiṣṭhitam svatantram kiñcid viśiṣṭa puruṣa artha nirvartana samarthān vikārān viracayat dṛṣṭam
translated: then it would be seen that in the world, nothing insentient, independent, not controlled by a conscious [being], creates modifications capable of accomplishing the specific purpose of a superior [being].

original: gehaprāsādaśayanāsanavihārabhūmyādayo hi loke prajñāvadbhiḥ śilpibhiryathākālaṃ sukhaduḥkhaprāptiparihārayogyā racitā dṛśyante /
analyzed: geha prāsāda śayana āsana vihāra bhūmi ādayaḥ hi loke prajñāvadbhiḥ śilpibhiḥ yathākālam sukha duḥkha prāpti parihāra yogyāḥ racitāḥ dṛśyante
translated: For in the world, houses, palaces, beds, seats, pleasure grounds, and so on are seen to be constructed by wise craftsmen at the right time, suitable for the attainment of pleasure and the avoidance of pain.

analyzed: tathā idam jagat akhilam pṛthivī ādi nānā karma phala upabhoga yogyam bāhyam
translated: In the same way, this entire world, consisting of earth and so on, is external, suitable for the enjoyment of the fruits of various actions,

analyzed: ādhyatmikam ca śarīra ādi nānā jāti anvitam pratiniyata avayava vinyāsam aneka karma phala anubhava adhiṣṭhānam
translated: and internal, consisting of the body and so on, associated with various species, with the arrangement of its parts determined, the basis for the experience of the fruits of many actions,

analyzed: dṛśyamānam prajñāvadbhiḥ saṃbhāvitatamaiḥ śilpibhiḥ manasā api ālocayitum aśakyam sat
translated: That which is incapable of being even conceived by the most intelligent and skilled craftsmen, when they see it.

analyzed: katham acetanam pradhānam racayet
translated: How can the insentient pradhāna create it?

analyzed: loṣṭa pāṣāṇa ādiṣu adṛṣṭa tvāt
translated: Because it is not seen in clods of earth, stones, etc.

original: mṛdādiṣvapi kumabhakārādyadhiṣṭhiteṣu viśiṣṭākārā racanā dṛśyate tadvatpradhānasyāpi cetanāntarādiṣṭhitatvaprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: mṛd ādiṣu api viśiṣṭa ākārā racanā dṛśyate tadvat pradhānasya api cetanā antarāt iṣṭhita tva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Even in clay, etc., when controlled by a potter, etc., a special arrangement is seen. Similarly, pradhāna would also be controlled by another sentient being.

original: naca mṛdādyupādānasvarūpavyapāśrayeṇaiva dharmeṇa mūlakāraṇamavadhāraṇīyaṃ na bāhyakumbhakārādivyapāśrayeṇeti kiñcinniyāmakamasti /
analyzed: na ca mṛd ādi upādāna svarūpa vyapāśrayeṇa eva dharmeṇa mūla kāraṇam avadhāraṇīyam na bāhya kumbhakāra ādi vyapāśrayeṇa iti kiñcid niyāmakam asti
translated: And there is no restriction that the primary cause should be determined only on the basis of the nature of the material cause like clay, etc., and not on the basis of external factors like the potter, etc.

analyzed: na ca evam sati kiñcid virudhyate
translated: And nothing is contradicted if it is so.

analyzed: pratyuta śrutiḥ anugṛhyate cetana kāraṇa samarpaṇāt
translated: Rather, the śruti is favored by the assertion of a sentient cause.

analyzed: atas racanā anupapatteḥ ca hetoḥ na acetanam jagat kāraṇam anumantavyam bhavati
translated: Therefore, due to the reason of the impossibility of arrangement, the insentient cannot be inferred as the cause of the world.

analyzed: anvaya ādi anupapatteḥ ca iti caśabdena hetoḥ asiddhim samuccinoti
translated: And due to the impossibility of inherence, etc., the word ca includes the non-establishment of the reason.

analyzed: nahi bāhya ādhyātmikānām bhedānām sukha duḥkha moha ātmaka tayā anvayaḥ upapadyate
translated: For the inherence of external and internal differences in the nature of pleasure, pain, and delusion is not possible.

analyzed: sukha ādīnām ca antara tva pratīteḥ
translated: And because pleasure, etc., are felt as internal.

analyzed: śabda ādīnām ca a tad rūpa tva pratīteḥ
translated: And because sound, etc., are felt as having a different nature.

analyzed: tad nimitta tva pratīteḥ ca
translated: And because they are felt to be caused by that [internal self].

analyzed: śabda ādi aviśeṣe ca bhāvanā viśeṣāt sukha ādi viśeṣa upalabdheḥ
translated: And because, even when there is no difference in sound, etc., a difference in pleasure, etc., is observed due to the difference in the mental disposition.

original: tathā parimitānāṃ bhedānāṃ mūlāṅ kurādīnāṃ saṃsargapūrvakatvaṃ dṛṣṭvā bāhyādhyātmikānāṃ
analyzed: tathā parimitānām bhedānām mūla aṅ kura ādīnām saṃsarga pūrvaka tvam dṛṣṭvā bāhya ādhyātmikānām
translated: Having seen that the limited differences, such as root, sprout, etc., are preceded by a combination, inferring that the external and internal differences

analyzed: bhedānām parimita tvāt saṃsarga pūrvakatvam anumimānasya sattva rajaḥ tamasām api saṃsarga pīrvakatva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: are preceded by a combination due to their limited nature, there would be the undesirable consequence that even sattva, rajas, and tamas are preceded by a combination.

analyzed: parimita tva viśeṣāt
translated: Because of the specific limitation.

original: kāryakāraṇabhāvastu prekṣāpūrvakanirmitānāṃ śayanāsanādīnāṃ dṛṣṭa iti na kāryakāraṇabhāvādbāhyādhyātmikānāṃ bhedānāmacetanapūrvakatvaṃ śakyaṃ
analyzed: kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ tu prekṣā pūrvaka nirmitānām śayana āsana ādīnām dṛṣṭaḥ iti na kārya kāraṇa bhāvāt bāhya ādhyātmikānām bhedānām acetana pūrvaka tvam śakyam
translated: But since the relation of cause and effect is seen in the case of beds, seats, etc., which are created with foresight, it is not possible to imagine that the external and internal differences are preceded by a non-sentient [cause] due to the relation of cause and effect.

analyzed: kalpayitum  apadeśena vyājena
translated: ...🔽By a pretext, by a pretense.

analyzed: pravṛtteḥ ca
translated: And because of activity.

analyzed: āstām tāvat iyam racanā
translated: Let this creation be for the time being.🔽...

original: tatsiddhyarthā yā pravṛttiḥ sāmyāvasthānātpracyutiḥ sattvarajastamasāmaṅgāṅgibhāvarūpāpattirviśiṣṭakāryābhimukhapravṛttitā sāpi nācetanasya
analyzed: tad siddhi arthāḥ yā pravṛttiḥ sāmya avasthānāt pracyutiḥ sattva rajaḥ tamasām aṅga aṅgi bhāva rūpa āpattiḥ viśiṣṭa kārya abhimukha pravṛtti tā sā api na acetanasya
