analyzed: api ca aṇavaḥ pravṛtti svabhāvāḥ vā nivṛtti svabhāvāḥ vā ubhaya svabhāvāḥ vā anubhaya svabhāvāḥ vā abhyupagamyante gati antara abhāvāt
translated: Moreover, atoms are accepted as having the nature of activity, or the nature of cessation, or both natures, or neither nature, because there is no other alternative.

analyzed: caturdhā api na upapadyate  pravṛtti svabhāva tve nityam eva pravṛtteḥ bhāvāt pralaya abhāva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: But in no case is it logically possible.🔽If they have the nature of activity, then because of the eternality of activity, the consequence is that there is no dissolution.

analyzed: nivṛtti svabhāva tve pi nityam eva nivṛtteḥ bhāvāt sarga abhāva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: If they have the nature of cessation, then because of the eternality of cessation, the consequence is that there is no creation.

analyzed: ubhaya svabhāva tvam ca virodhāt asamañjasam
translated: And the doctrine that they have both natures is unreasonable because of contradiction.

analyzed: anubhaya svabhāva tve tu nimitta vaśāt pravṛtti nivṛttyoḥ abhyupagamyamānayoḥ adṛṣṭa ādeḥ nimittasya nitya saṃnidhānāt nitya pravṛtti prasaṅgāt
translated: But if they have neither nature, then activity and cessation are accepted as being due to a cause. And because of the constant presence of the cause, such as unseen force, there would be the consequence of constant activity.

analyzed: atantra tve pi adṛṣṭa ādeḥ anitya apravṛtti prasaṅgāt
translated: And even if unseen force, etc. were not the cause, there would be the consequence of occasional activity.

analyzed: tasmāt api anupapannaḥ paramāṇu kāraṇa vādaḥ
translated: Therefore, the doctrine of atoms as the ultimate cause is also unestablished.

analyzed: rūpa ādimat tvāt ca viparyayaḥ darśanāt
translated: And because of having form, etc., there is a contradiction, as seen.

original: sāvayavānāṃ dravyāṇāmavayavavaśo vibhajyamānānāṃ yataḥ paro vibhāgo na saṃbhavati
analyzed: sa avayavānām dravyāṇām avayava vaśas vibhajyamānānām yatas paraḥ vibhāgaḥ na saṃbhavati
translated: For divisible substances, when divided by their parts, there is no further division possible.

original: te caturvidhā rūpādimantaḥ paramāṇavaścaturvidhasya rūpādimato bhūtabhautikasyārambhakā
analyzed: te caturvidhāḥ rūpa ādimantaḥ paramāṇavaḥ caturvidhasya rūpa ādimataḥ bhūtabhautikasya ārambhakā
translated: And those atoms, which have form, etc., are of four kinds, and are the causes of the four kinds of form, etc., which are elemental and elemental derivatives.

original: nityāśceti yadvaiśeṣikā abhyupagacchanti sa teṣāmabhyupagamo nirālambana eva /
analyzed: nityāḥ ca iti yat vaiśeṣikāḥ abhyupagacchanti sa teṣām abhyupagamaḥ nirālambanaḥ eva
translated: And they are eternal, as the Vaiśeṣikas accept. That acceptance of theirs is indeed baseless.

analyzed: yatas rūpa ādimat tvāt paramāṇūnām aṇu tva nitya tva viparyayaḥ prasajyeta
translated: Because of having form, etc., there would result the contradiction of atoms being small and eternal.

analyzed: parama kāraṇa apekṣayā sthūla tvam anitya tvam ca teṣām abhipreta viparītam āpadyeta iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that what they intend as being large and non-eternal in relation to the ultimate cause, becomes the opposite.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why is it so?

analyzed: evam loke dṛṣṭa tvāt
translated: Because it is seen thus in the world.

original: yadi loke rūpādimadvastu tatsvakāraṇāpekṣayā sthūlamanityaṃ ca dṛṣṭam /
analyzed: yadi loke rūpa ādimat vastu tat sva kāraṇa apekṣayā sthūlam anityam ca dṛṣṭam
translated: If in the world, a thing with form, etc., is seen as large and non-eternal in relation to its cause,

original: tadyathā paṭastantūnapekṣya sthūle 'nityaśca bhavati tantavaścaṃśūnapekṣya sthūlā anityāśca bhavanti /
analyzed: tat yathā paṭaḥ tantūn apekṣya sthūle nityaḥ ca bhavati tantavaḥ ca aṃśūn apekṣya sthūlāḥ anityāḥ ca bhavanti
translated: just as a cloth, in relation to the threads, becomes large and non-eternal, and the threads, in relation to the parts, become large and non-eternal.

analyzed: tathā ca amī paramāṇavaḥ rūpa ādimantaḥ taiḥ abhyupagamyante
translated: And thus those atoms are admitted by them to be possessed of color, etc.

analyzed: tasmāt te pi kāraṇavantaḥ tad apekṣayā sthūlāḥ anityāḥ ca prāpnuvanti
translated: Therefore, they also, being possessed of a cause, must be gross and non-eternal in relation to that [cause].

original: yacca nityatve kāraṇaṃ tairuktam 'sadakāraṇavannityam' vai / sū / / / iti /
analyzed: yat ca nitya tve kāraṇam taiḥ uktam sat akāraṇavat nityam vai iti
translated: And the reason which they state for their eternality, 'The existent, being without a cause, is eternal' [Vai. Sū. 1. 1. 10],

analyzed: tat api evam sati aṇuṣu na saṃbhavati
translated: that also is not possible in the case of atoms,

analyzed: uktena prakāreṇa aṇūnām api kāraṇavat tva upapatteḥ
translated: because it is possible to conclude that even atoms have a cause, in the manner stated.

original: yadapi nityatve dvitīyaṃ kāraṇamuktam 'anityamiti ca viśeṣataḥ pratiṣedhābhāvaḥ' vai / sū / / / iti /
analyzed: yat api nitya tve dvitīyam kāraṇam uktam anityam iti ca viśeṣataḥ pratiṣedha abhāvaḥ vai iti
translated: And that second reason which is stated for eternality, 'And there is no absence of the negation in the particular form of non-eternality' [Vai. Sū. 1. 1. 11],

analyzed: tat api na avaśyam paramāṇūnām nitya tvam sādhayati
translated: that also does not necessarily prove the eternality of atoms.

original: asati hi yasminkasmiṃścinnitye vastuni nityaśabdena nañaḥ samāso nopapadyate /
analyzed: asati hi yasmin kasmiṃścid nitye vastuni nitya śabdena nañaḥ samāsaḥ nā upapadyate
translated: For, in the absence of any eternal substance, the compound of the negative with the word 'eternal' is not possible.

analyzed: na punar paramāṇu nitya tvam eva apekṣyate
translated: It is not that the eternality of atoms alone is required.

original: taccāstyeva nityaṃ paramakāraṇaṃ brahma /🔽naca śabdārthavyavahāramātreṇa kasyacidarthasya prasiddhirbhavati /
analyzed: tat ca asti eva nityam parama kāraṇam brahma  na ca śabda artha vyavahāra mātreṇa kasyacid arthasya prasiddhiḥ bhavati
translated: And that eternal supreme cause, Brahman, does exist.🔽And the well-known existence of a thing is not by mere usage of the meaning of a word.

analyzed: pramāṇa antara siddhayoḥ śabda arthayoḥ vyavahāra avatārāt
translated: For, the usage of words is only when the meaning of the words is established by other means of knowledge.

original: yadapi nityatve tṛtīyaṃ kāraṇamuktam 'avidyā ca' vai / sū / / /
analyzed: yat api nitya tve tṛtīyam kāraṇam uktam avidyā ca vai
translated: And the third reason stated for permanence, 'and ignorance,'

original: iti / tadyadyevaṃ vivrīyate satāṃ paridṛśyamānakāryāṇāṃ kāraṇānāṃ pratyakṣeṇāgrahaṇamavidyeti /
analyzed: iti tat yadi evam satām paridṛśyamāna kāryāṇām kāraṇānām pratyakṣeṇa agrahaṇam avidyā iti
translated: if it is explained thus: 'the non-perception by perception of the causes of the existing and manifest effects is ignorance,'

analyzed: tatas dvi aṇuka nitya tā api āpadyeta
translated: then the permanence of dyads would also follow.

analyzed: atha a dravya tve sati iti viśeṣyeta tathā api akāraṇavat tvam eva nitya tā nimittam ādyeta
translated: If it is qualified as 'being non-substance,' then only the absence of being a cause would be stated as the reason for permanence.

original: tasya ca prāgevoktatvāt 'avidyā ca' iti punaruktaṃ syāt /
analyzed: tasya ca prāk eva ukta tvāt avidyā ca iti punaruktam syāt
translated: And since that has already been stated earlier, 'and ignorance' would be a repetition.

original: athāpi kāraṇavibhāgātkāraṇavināśāccanyasya tṛtīyasya vināśahetorasaṃbhavo 'vidyā sā paramāṇūnāṃ nityatvaṃ khyapayatīti vyākhyāyeta /
analyzed: atha api kāraṇa vibhāgāt kāraṇa vināśāt canyasya tṛtīyasya vināśa hetoḥ asaṃbhavaḥ vidyā sā paramāṇūnām nitya tvam khyapayati iti vyākhyāyeta
translated: Now, if it is explained thus: 'The impossibility of a third cause of destruction other than the separation of causes and the destruction of causes is ignorance, and that proves the permanence of atoms,'

original: nāvaśyaṃ vinaśyadvastu dvābhyāmeva hetubhyāṃ vinaṣṭumarhatiti niyamo 'sti /
analyzed: na avaśyam vinaśyat vastu dvābhyām eva hetubhyām vinaṣṭum arhati iti niyamaḥ sti
translated: there is no rule that a thing being destroyed must necessarily be destroyed by only two causes.

original: saṃyogasacive hyanekasmiṃśca dravye dravyāntarasyārambhake 'bhyupagamyamāna etadevaṃ syāt /
analyzed: saṃyoga sacive hi anekasmin ca dravye dravya antarasya ārambhake bhyupagamyamāne etat evam syāt
translated: For this would be so if it were accepted that in a substance consisting of many things accompanied by conjunction, another substance is a cause.

analyzed: yadā tu apāsta viśeṣam sāmānya ātmakam kāraṇam viśeṣa vat avasthā antaram āpadyamānam ārambhakam abhyupagamyate tadā ghṛta kāṭhinya vilayana vat mūrti avasthā vilayanena api
translated: But when a cause consisting of a universal, devoid of particularities, is accepted as the originative material, assuming a state with particularities, then, like the melting of the hardness of ghee, by the melting of the state of corporeality,

analyzed: vināśaḥ upapadyate  tasmāt rūpa ādimat tvāt syāt abhipreta viparyayaḥ paramāṇūnām
translated: But when a cause consisting of a universal, devoid of particularities, is admitted to be productive, when it assumes a different state characterized by particularities, then destruction is possible even by the dissolution of the state of corporeality, like the melting of the hardness of ghee.🔽Therefore, due to having form and other qualities, the opposite of what is intended would occur for the atoms.

analyzed: tasmāt api anupapannaḥ paramāṇu kāraṇa vādaḥ
translated: Therefore, the theory of atoms as the cause is also not logically possible.

analyzed: ubhayathā ca doṣāt  gandha rasa rūpa sparśa guṇā sthūlā pṛthivī
translated: And because of the fault in both cases.🔽Earth is gross, having the qualities of smell, taste, form, and touch.

analyzed: rūpa rasa sparśa guṇāḥ sūkṣmāḥ āpaḥ
translated: Water is subtler, having the qualities of form, taste, and touch.

analyzed: rūpa sparśa guṇam sūkṣmataram tejaḥ
translated: Fire is subtler still, having the qualities of form and touch.

original: sparśaguṇaḥ sūkṣmatamo vāyurityevametāni catvāri bhūtānyupacitāpacitaguṇāni sthūlasūkṣmatarasūkṣmatamatāratamyopetāni ca loke lakṣyante /
analyzed: sparśa guṇaḥ sūkṣmatamaḥ vāyuḥ iti evam etāni catvāri bhūtāni upacita apacita guṇāni sthūla sūkṣmatara sūkṣmatama tāratamya upetāni ca loke lakṣyante
translated: Air is subtlest, having the quality of touch. Thus, these four elements are observed in the world to have increasing and decreasing qualities, with degrees of grossness, subtler, and subtlest.

analyzed: tadvat paramāṇavaḥ pi upacita apacita guṇāḥ kalpyeran na vā
translated: In the same way, atoms could be postulated as having increasing and decreasing qualities, or not.

analyzed: ubhayathā api ca doṣa anuṣaṅgaḥ parihāryaḥ eva syāt
translated: And in both cases, the fault would be unavoidable.

analyzed: kalpyamāne tāvat upacita apacita guṇa tve upacita guṇānām mūrti upacayāt aparamāṇu tva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: If qualities are assumed to increase and decrease, then due to the increase of qualities, there would be the undesirable consequence of composite wholes not being atoms.

analyzed: na ca antareṇa api mūrti upacayam guṇa upacayaḥ bhavati iti ucyate
translated: And it is not said that the increase of qualities occurs without the increase of substance.

analyzed: kāryeṣu bhūteṣu guṇa upacaye mūrti upacaya darśanāt
translated: Because in the effects, the elements, the increase of qualities is seen to be accompanied by the increase of substance.

original: akalpyamāne tūpacitāpacitaguṇatve paramāṇutvasāmyaprasiddhaye yadi tāvatsarvaṃ ekaikaguṇā eva kalpyeraṃstatastejasi sparśasyopalabdhirna syāt /🔽apsu rūpasparśayoḥ /
analyzed: a kalpyamāne tu upacita apacita guṇa tve paramāṇu tva sāmya prasiddhaye yadi tāvat sarvam ekaika guṇāḥ eva kalpyeran tatas tejasi sparśasya upalabdhiḥ na syāt  apsu rūpa sparśayoḥ
translated: If, on the other hand, the increase and decrease of qualities is not assumed, in order to establish the equality of atoms, if they are all assumed to have only one quality each, then the tactile quality would not be perceived in fire.🔽And the visual and tactile qualities in water.

analyzed: pṛthivyām ca rasa rūpa sparśānām
translated: And the gustatory, visual, and tactile qualities in earth.

analyzed: kāraṇa guṇa pūrvaka tvāt kārya guṇānām
translated: Because the qualities of the effect are preceded by the qualities of the cause.

analyzed: atha sarve caturguṇāḥ eva kalpyetan
translated: If, on the other hand, they are all assumed to have four qualities each,

analyzed: tatas u psu api gandhasya upalabdhiḥ syāt  tejasi gandha rasayoḥ
translated: then the olfactory quality would also be perceived in water.🔽And the gustatory and olfactory qualities in fire.

analyzed: vāyau gandha rūpa rasānām
translated: And the gustatory, visual, and olfactory qualities in air.

analyzed: na ca evam dṛśyate
translated: But this is not seen.

analyzed: tasmāt api anupapannaḥ paramāṇu kāraṇa vādaḥ
translated: Therefore, the theory of atoms as the cause is also logically untenable.

analyzed: mūrti upacayāt sthaulyāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: due to the increase of substance, i.e., grossness.

analyzed: aparigrahāt ca atyantam anapekṣā
translated: And due to the non-acceptance, there is complete non-dependence.

analyzed: pradhāna kāraṇa vādaḥ veda vidbhiḥ api kaiścid manu ādibhiḥ satkārya tva ādi aṃśa upajīvana abhiprāyeṇa upanibaddhaḥ
translated: The doctrine of the primordial substance as the cause of the world has been accepted by some Vedāntins also, such as Manu and others, with the intention of accepting the part of the doctrine which teaches that the effect exists in the cause.

original: ayaṃ tu paramāṇukāraṇavādo na kaiścidapi śiṣṭaiḥ kenacidapyaṃśena parigṛhīta ityatyantamevānādaraṇīyo vedavādibhiḥ /
analyzed: ayam tu paramāṇu kāraṇa vādaḥ na kaiścid api śiṣṭaiḥ kenacid api aṃśena parigṛhītaḥ iti atyantam eva an ādaraṇīyaḥ veda vādibhiḥ
translated: But this doctrine of the atoms as the cause of the world has not been accepted by any of the cultured people in any of its parts. Therefore it is to be rejected altogether by the followers of the Veda.

analyzed: apica vaiśeṣikāḥ tantra artha bhūtān ṣaṣ padārthān dravya guṇa karma sāmānya viśeṣa samavāya ākhyān atyanta bhinnān bhinna lakṣaṇān abhyupagacchanti
translated: Moreover, the Vaiśeṣikas accept the six categories, substance, quality, action, universality, particularity, and inherence, which are the subject-matter of their system, as absolutely different from one another, having different characteristics.

analyzed: yathā manuṣyaḥ śvas śaśe iti
translated: Just as a man, a horse, and a hare are different from one another.

analyzed: tathātvam ca abhyupagamya tad viruddham dravya adhīna tvam śeṣāṇam abhyupagacchanti
translated: And accepting this, they contradict it by accepting that the remaining categories are dependent on substance.

analyzed: tat na upapadyate
translated: This is not tenable.

analyzed: katham
translated: How so?

original: yathā hi loke śaśakuśapalāśaprabhṛtīnāmatyantabhinnānāṃ satāṃ netaretarādhīnatvaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: yathā hi loke śaśa kuśa palāśa prabhṛtīnām atyanta bhinnānām satām na itaretara adhīna tvam bhavati
translated: Just as in the world, the hare, the kuśa grass, and the palāśa tree, which are absolutely different from one another, are not dependent on one another,

analyzed: evam dravya ādīnām atyanta bhinna tvāt na eva dravya adhīna tvam guṇa ādīnām bhavitum arhati
translated: in the same way, because substance and the other categories are absolutely different, the qualities and the other categories cannot be dependent on substance.

original: atha bhavati dravyādhīnatvaṃ guṇādīnāṃ tato dravyabhāve bhāvāddravyābhāve 'bhāvāddravyameva saṃsthānādibhedādanekaśabdapratyayabhāgbhavati
analyzed: atha bhavati dravya adhīna tvam guṇa ādīnām tatas dravya bhāve bhāvāt dravya abhāve bhāvāt dravyam eva saṃsthāna ādi bhedāt aneka śabda pratyaya bhāj bhavati
translated: If it be said that the qualities, etc. are dependent on substance, then, because they exist when substance exists and do not exist when substance does not exist, substance alone becomes the basis of multiple words and concepts due to differences in shape, etc.

analyzed: yathā devadattaḥ ekaḥ eva san avasthā antara yogāt aneka śabda pratyaya bhāj bhavati tadvat
translated: Just as Devadatta himself, though one, becomes the basis of multiple words and concepts due to being in different states.

analyzed: tathā sati sāṃkhya siddhānta prasaṅgaḥ sva siddhānta virodhaḥ ca āpadyeyātām
translated: If that were so, the Sankhya doctrine would be entailed and one's own doctrine would be contradicted.

analyzed: nanu agneḥ anyasya api sataḥ dhūmasya agni adhīna tvam dṛśyate
translated: Isn't it seen that smoke, though existing separately from fire, is dependent on fire?

analyzed: satyam dṛśyate
translated: It is indeed seen.

analyzed: bheda pratīteḥ tu tatra agni dhūmayoḥ anya tvam niścīyate
translated: But due to the cognition of difference, the otherness of fire and smoke is ascertained there.

original: iha tu śuklaḥ kambalo rohiṇī dhenurnīlamutpalamiti dravyasyaiva tasya tasya tena tena viśeṣeṇa pratīyamānatvānnaiva dravyaguṇayoragnidhūmayoriva 🔽bhedapratītirasti /
analyzed: iha tu śuklaḥ kambalaḥ rohiṇī dhenuḥ nīlam utpalam iti dravyasya eva tasya tasya tena tena viśeṣeṇa pratīyamāna tvāt na eva dravya guṇayoḥ agni dhūmayoḥ iva  bheda pratītiḥ asti
translated: But here, in expressions like the white blanket, the red cow, and the blue lotus, the very same substance is cognized as having that particular quality, so there is no cognition of difference between substance and quality, as there is between fire and smoke.

analyzed: tasmāt dravya ātmaka tā guṇasya
translated: Therefore, the quality has the nature of substance.

analyzed: etena karma sāmānya viśeṣa samavāyānām dravya ātmaka tā vyākhyātā
translated: By this, the nature of action, universal, particular, and inherence as substances is explained.

analyzed: guṇa ādīnām dravya adhīna tvam dravya guṇayoḥ ayuta siddha tvāt iti yat ucyeta
translated: If it be said that the qualities, etc., are dependent on substance, because substance and quality are not-separately-ascertained.

analyzed: tat punar ayuta siddha tvam apṛthak deśa tvam vā syāt apṛthak kāla tvam vā apṛthak svabhāva tvam vā
translated: And this not-separately-ascertainedness may be non-different-in-place, non-different-in-time, or non-different-in-nature.

analyzed: sarvathā api na upapadyate
translated: But in any case it is not tenable.

analyzed: a pṛthak agdeśa tve tāvat sva abhyupagamaḥ virudhyeta
translated: First of all, if they are non-different-in-place, it contradicts your own admission.

analyzed: katham
translated: How so?

analyzed: tantu ārabdhaḥ hi paṭaḥ ṭantu deśaḥ bhyupagamyate na paṭa deśaḥ
translated: A cloth is admitted to be in the place of the threads, not in the place of the cloth.

original: paṭasya tu guṇāḥ śuklatvādayaḥ paṭadeśā abhyupagamyante na tantudeśāḥ /
analyzed: paṭasya tu guṇāḥ śukla tva ādayaḥ paṭa deśāḥ abhyupagamyante na tantu deśāḥ
translated: But the qualities of the cloth, such as whiteness, are admitted to be in the place of the cloth, not in the place of the threads.

original: tathācāhuḥ 'dravyāṇi dravyāntaramārabhante guṇāśca guṇāntaram' vai / sū / / / iti /
analyzed: tathā ca āhuḥ dravyāṇi dravya antaram ārabhante guṇāḥ ca guṇa antaram vai iti
translated: And thus they say: Substances produce another substance, and qualities another quality.

original: tantavo hi kāraṇadravyāṇi kāryadravyaṃ paṭamārabhante /🔽tantugatāśca guṇāḥ śuklādayaḥ kāryadravye paṭe śuklādiguṇāntaramārabhanta iti hi te 'bhyupagacchanti /
analyzed: tantavaḥ hi kāraṇa dravyāṇi kārya dravyam paṭam ārabhante  tantu gatāḥ ca guṇāḥ śukla ādayaḥ kārya dravye paṭe śukla ādi guṇa antaram ārabhante iti hi te bhyupagacchanti
translated: For the causal substances, the threads, produce the effect-substance, the cloth.🔽And the qualities of the threads, such as whiteness, produce another quality, such as whiteness, in the effect-substance, the cloth. Thus they admit.

analyzed: saḥ bhyupagamaḥ dravya guṇayoḥ apṛthak deśa tve bhyupagamyamāne bādhyeta
translated: That admission would be contradicted if substance and quality were admitted to be non-different-in-place.

analyzed: atha apṛthak kāla tvam ayuta sidda tvam ucyeta
translated: If, on the other hand, non-simultaneity is said to be non-simultaneous existence,

analyzed: savya dakṣiṇayoḥ api go viṣāṇayoḥ ayuta siddha tvam prasajyeta
translated: then the horns on the right and left of a cow would also be non-simultaneously existent.

analyzed: tathā apṛthak svabhāva tve tu ayuta siddha tvena dravya guṇayoḥ ātma bhedaḥ saṃbhavati
translated: Similarly, if they have different natures, the difference between substance and quality can be due to non-simultaneous existence.

analyzed: tasya tādātmyena eva pratīyamāna tvāt
translated: Because that is perceived only as identical with them.

original: yutasiddhayoḥ saṃbandhaḥ saṃyogo 'pyutasiddhayostu samavāya ityayamabhyupagamo mṛṣaiva teṣāṃ /
analyzed: yuta siddhayoḥ saṃbandhaḥ saṃyogaḥ u pi uta siddhayoḥ tu samavāyaḥ iti ayam abhyupagamaḥ mṛṣā eva teṣām
translated: Their acceptance that the relation between simultaneously existent things is conjunction, and the relation between non-simultaneously existent things is inherence, is false.

analyzed: prāk siddhasya kāryāt kāraṇasya ayuta siddha tva anupapatteḥ
translated: Because it is not possible for a cause that exists before its effect to be non-simultaneously existent with it.

original: athānyatarāpekṣa evāyamabhyupagamaḥ syādayutasiddhasya kāryasya kāraṇena saṃbandhaḥ samavāya iti /
analyzed: atha anyatara apekṣaḥ eva ayam abhyupagamaḥ syāt ayuta siddhasya kāryasya kāraṇena saṃbandhaḥ samavāyaḥ iti
translated: If this acceptance were made with reference to one of the two, namely that the relation of an effect that is non-simultaneously existent with its cause is inherence,

original: evamapi prāgsiddhasyālabdhātmakasya kāryasya kāraṇena saṃbandho nopapadyate dvayāyattatvātsaṃbandhasya /
analyzed: evam api prāk siddhasya alabdha ātmakasya kāryasya kāraṇena saṃbandhaḥ na upapadyate dvaya āyatta tvāt saṃbandhasya
translated: even so, the relation of an effect that exists before its cause, which does not have its own nature, is not possible, because a relation depends on two [terms].

analyzed: siddham bhūtvā saṃbadhyate iti ced
translated: If it is argued that it [the effect] becomes related after it has come into existence,

original: prākkāraṇasaṃbandhātkāryasya siddhāvabhyupagamyamānāyāmayutasiddhyabhāvātkāryakāraṇayoḥ saṃyogavibhāgau na vidyete itīdaṃ duruktaṃ syāt /
analyzed: prāk kāraṇa saṃbandhāt kāryasya siddhau abhyupagamyamānāyām ayuta siddhi abhāvāt kārya kāraṇayoḥ saṃyoga vibhāgau na vidyete iti idam duruktam syāt
translated: If it be admitted that the effect exists prior to its relation with the cause, then, there being no non-co-existence of the cause and effect, it would be wrong to say that there is no conjunction or disjunction of the cause and effect.

analyzed: yathā ced panna mātrasya akriyasya kārya dravyasya vibhubhiḥ ākāśa ādibhiḥ dravya antaraiḥ saṃbandhaḥ
translated: And just as the relation of the effect, which is an inert substance, as soon as it comes into existence, with other all-pervading substances like space,

original: saṃyoga evābhyupagamyate na samavāya evaṃ kāraṇadravyeṇāpi saṃbandhaḥ saṃyoga eva syānna samavāyaḥ /
analyzed: saṃyogaḥ eva abhyupagamyate na samavāyaḥ evam kāraṇa dravyeṇa api saṃbandhaḥ saṃyogaḥ eva syāt na samavāyaḥ
translated: is admitted to be mere conjunction, not inherence, so the relation with the causal substance also would be mere conjunction, not inherence.

original: nāpi saṃyogasya samavāyasya vā saṃbandhavyatirekeṇāstitve kiñcitpramāṇamasti /
analyzed: nā api saṃyogasya samavāyasya vā saṃbandha vyatirekeṇa astitve kiñcid pramāṇam asti
translated: Nor is there any proof at all for the existence of either conjunction or inherence apart from the relation.

analyzed: saṃbandha śabda pratyaya vyatirekeṇa saṃyoga samavāya śabda pratyaya darśanāt tayoḥ astitvam iti ced na  eka tve pi sva rūpa bāhya rūpa apekṣayā aneka śabda pratyaya darśanāt
translated: If it be argued that their existence is inferred from the observation of the terms 'conjunction' and 'inherence', which are different from the terms 'relation', that is not so.🔽Even in identity, there is the observation of many terms and concepts based on the distinction of the intrinsic form and the external form.

original: yathaiko 'pi san devadatto loke svarūpaṃ saṃbandhirūpaṃ cāpekṣyānekaśabdapratyayabhāgbhavati /
analyzed: yathā ekaḥ pi san devadattaḥ loke sva rūpam saṃbandhi rūpam ca apekṣya aneka śabda pratyaya bhāj bhavati
translated: For instance, Devadatta, though one, becomes the substratum of many terms and concepts by considering his intrinsic form and his external form as related.

original: manuṣyo brāhmaṇaḥ śrotriyo vadānyo bālo yuvā sthaviraḥ pitā putraḥ pautro bhrātā jāmāteti /
analyzed: manuṣyaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ śrotriyaḥ vadānyaḥ bālaḥ yuvā sthaviraḥ pitā putraḥ pautraḥ bhrātā jāmātā iti
translated: A human being, a Brahmin, a learned person, a generous person, a child, a youth, an elder, a father, a son, a grandson, a brother, a son-in-law.

analyzed: yathā ca ekā api satī rekhā sthānāt nya tvena niviśamānā eka daśa śata sahasra ādi śabda pratyaya bhedam anubhavati
translated: And just as a single line, when placed in different positions, experiences the difference in words and concepts such as one, ten, hundred, thousand, etc.,

analyzed: tathā asaṃbandhinoḥ eva saṃbandha śabda pratyaya vyatirekeṇa saṃyoga samavāya śabda pratyaya arha tvam na vyatirikta vastu astitvena
translated: in the same way, only the relata deserve the words and concepts of conjunction and inherence, not the existence of a separate entity apart from the words and concepts of relation.

analyzed: iti upalabdi lakṣaṇa prāptasya anupalabdheḥ abhāvaḥ vastu antarasya
translated: Thus, the non-existence of a separate entity is due to the non-apprehension of what is fit to be apprehended by the means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: nā api saṃbandha dhi viṣaya tve saṃbandha śabda pratyayayoḥ saṃtata bhāva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Nor is there the contingence of the constant existence of the words and concepts of relation when they have relation as their object,

analyzed: svarūpa āhya rūpa apekṣayā iti ukta uttara tvāt
translated: because it has been answered that it depends on the form and formlessness.

analyzed: tathā aṇu ātma manasām apradeśa tvāt na saṃyogaḥ saṃbhavati
translated: Similarly, because atoms, self, and mind are not spatially extended, conjunction is not possible for them.

analyzed: pradeśavataḥ dravyasya pradeśavatā dravya antareṇa saṃyoga darśanāt
translated: Because the conjunction of an extended substance with another extended substance is seen.

original: kalpitāḥ pradeśā aṇvātmamanasāṃ bhaviṣyantīti cet / na /
analyzed: kalpitāḥ pradeśāḥ aṇu ātma manasām bhaviṣyanti iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the spatially extended parts of atoms, self, and mind will be imagined, it is not so.

analyzed: avidyā māna artha kalpanāyām sarva artha siddhi prasaṅgāt
translated: Because if one imagines a nonexistent object, all objects would be established.

original: iyānevāvidyamāno viruddho 'viruddho vārthaḥ kalpanīyo nāto 'dhika iti niyamahetvabhāvāt /
analyzed: iyān eva a vidyamānaḥ viruddhaḥ viruddhaḥ vā arthaḥ kalpanīyaḥ na atas dhikaḥ iti niyama hetu abhāvāt
translated: This much and no more of a nonexistent, contradictory or non-contradictory object should be imagined. Because there is no cause for a rule that it should not be more than this.

analyzed: kalpanāyāḥ ca sva āyatta tvāt prabhūta tva saṃbhavāt ca
translated: And because imagination is independent and can occur in abundance.

original: naca vaiśeṣikaiḥ kalpitebhyaḥ ṣaḍbhyaḥ padārthebhyo 'nye 'dhikāḥ śataṃ sahasraṃ vārthā na kalpayitavyā iti nivārako heturasti /
analyzed: na ca vaiśeṣikaiḥ kalpitebhyaḥ ṣaḍbhyaḥ padārthebhyaḥ nye dhikāḥ śatam sahasram vā arthāḥ na kalpayitavyāḥ iti nivārakaḥ hetuḥ asti
translated: And the Vaiśeṣikas have no reason to prevent the imagination of more than six categories, such as a hundred or a thousand objects other than the six categories they imagine.

analyzed: tasmāt yasmai yasmai yat yat rocate tat tat siddhyet
translated: Therefore, whatever is imagined by whomever, that would be established.

original: kaścitkṛpāluḥ prāṇināṃ duḥkhabahulaṃ saṃsāra eva mābhūditi kalpayet /
analyzed: kaścid kṛpāluḥ prāṇinām duḥkha bahulam saṃsāraḥ eva mā abhūt iti kalpayet
translated: Some compassionate person might imagine that this world, which is full of suffering for living beings, should not exist at all.

original: anyo vā vyasanī muktānāmapi punarutpattiṃ kalpayet /
analyzed: anyaḥ vā vyasanī muktānām api punarutpattim kalpayet
translated: Or some afflicted person might imagine rebirth even for the liberated.

analyzed: kaḥ tayoḥ nivārakaḥ syāt
translated: What would prevent them?

analyzed: kiñca anyat
translated: And furthermore,

original: dvābhyāṃ paramāṇubhyāṃ niravayavābhyāṃ sāvayavasya dvyaṇukasyākāśeneva saṃśleṣānupapattiḥ /
analyzed: dvābhyām paramāṇubhyām niravayavābhyām sa avayavasya dvyaṇukasya ākāśena iva saṃśleṣa anupapattiḥ
translated: it is impossible for a dyad, which has parts, to be in conjunction with two partless atoms, like space.

analyzed: na hi ākāśasya pṛthivī ādīnām ca jatu kāṣṭha vat saṃśleṣaḥ sti
translated: For there is no conjunction of space and earth, etc., like that of lac and wood.

original: kāryakāraṇadravyayorāśritāśrayabhāvo 'nyathā nopapadyata ityavaśyaṃ kalpyaḥ samavāya iti cet / na /
analyzed: kārya kāraṇa dravyayoḥ āśrita āśraya bhāvaḥ nyathā na upapadyate iti avaśyam kalpyaḥ samavāyaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it be said that the relation of container and contained between the effect and the cause is not possible without the relation of inherence, we deny this;

analyzed: itaretara āśraya tvāt
translated: because the two relations would be reciprocal.

analyzed: kārya kāraṇayoḥ hi bheda siddhau āśrita āśraya bhāva siddhiḥ āśrita āśraya bhāva siddhau ca tayoḥ bheda siddhiḥ kuṇḍa badara vat itaretara āśraya tā syāt
translated: For the relation of container and contained is established only if the difference of the two terms is established; and the difference of the two terms is established only if the relation of container and contained is established; so that the two relations would be reciprocal, like the relation of the pot and the jujube fruit.

analyzed: nahi kārya kāraṇayoḥ bhedaḥ āśrita āśraya bhāvaḥ vā vedānta vādibhiḥ abhyupagamyate
translated: The Vedāntins, on the other hand, do not admit either the difference of the effect from the cause or the relation of container and contained.

analyzed: kāraṇasya eva saṃsthāna mātram kāryam iti abhyupagamāt
translated: For they maintain that the effect is merely a modification of the cause.

analyzed: kiñca anyat
translated: Moreover,

original: paramāṇūnāṃ paricchinnatvādyāvatyo diśaḥ ṣaḍaṣṭau daśa vā tāvadbhiravayavaiḥ sāvayavāste syuḥ sāvayavatvādanityāśceti nityatvaniravayavatvābhyupagamo 🔽bādhyeta /
analyzed: paramāṇūnām paricchinna tvāt yāvatyaḥ diśaḥ ṣaṣ aṣṭau daśa vā tāvadbhiḥ avayavaiḥ sa avayavāḥ te syuḥ sa avayava tvāt anityāḥ ca iti nitya tva niravayava tva abhyupagamaḥ  bādhyeta
translated: the atoms being limited in size, they would have as many parts as there are directions, six, eight, or ten, and would thus be extended, and being extended, they would be noneternal; and this would contradict the doctrine of the atoms being eternal and partless.

original: yāṃstvaṃ digbhedabhedino 'vayavānkalpayasi ta eva paramāṇava iti cet / na /
analyzed: yān tvam diś bheda bhedinaḥ vayavān kalpayasi te eva paramāṇavaḥ iti ced na
translated: If you should say that the parts of the atoms which you assume to be divided according to the different directions are just the atoms themselves, we deny this;

analyzed: sthūla sūkṣma tāratamya krameṇa aparama kāraṇāt vināśa upapatteḥ
translated: because it is possible to account for the destruction of the world by a gradual process of becoming finer and finer, without assuming a highest cause.

original: yathā pṛthivī dvyaṇukādyapekṣayā sthūlatamā vastubhūtāpi vinaśyati /
analyzed: yathā pṛthivī dvyaṇuka ādi apekṣayā sthūlatamā vastu bhūtā api vinaśyati
translated: For example, earth, which is the grossest substance in relation to binary compounds and so on, is destroyed.

original: tataḥ sūkṣmaṃ sūkṣmataraṃ ca pṛthivyekajātīyakaṃ vinaśyati /
analyzed: tatas sūkṣmam sūkṣmataram ca pṛthivī eka jātīyakam vinaśyati
translated: Then the earth of the same type becomes more and more subtle and is destroyed.

analyzed: tatas dvyaṇukam
translated: Then the binary compound.

analyzed: tathā paramāṇavaḥ pi pṛthivī eka jātīyaka tvāt vinaśyeyuḥ
translated: In the same way, atoms would also be destroyed, because they are of the same type as earth.

analyzed: vinaśyantaḥ upi avayava vibhāgena eva vinaśyanti iti ced
translated: If it is argued that they are destroyed only by the division of their parts,

analyzed: na ayam doṣaḥ
translated: this is not a fault.

analyzed: yatas ghṛta kāṭhinya vilayana vat api vināśa upapattim avocāma
translated: Because we have stated that destruction is possible even without the division of parts, like the melting of ghee's solidity.

analyzed: yathā hi ghṛta suvarṇa ādīnām avibhajyamāna avayavānām api agni saṃyogāt drava bhāva āpattyā kāṭhanya vināśaḥ bhavati
translated: For just as ghee, gold, and so on, even though their parts are not divided, the destruction of solidity occurs by the attainment of the liquid state due to contact with fire.

analyzed: evam paramāṇūnām api parama kāraṇa bhāva āpattyā mūrti ādi vināśaḥ bhaviṣyati
translated: In the same way, the destruction of form and so on will occur for atoms by the attainment of the state of ultimate cause.

analyzed: tathā kārya rambhaḥ u pi na avayava saṃyogena eva kevalena bhavati
translated: Similarly, the production of an effect does not occur only by the conjunction of parts.

analyzed: kṣīra jala ādīnām antareṇa api avayava saṃyoga antaram dadhi hima ādi kārya ārambha darśanāt
translated: Because the production of effects like curd and ice is seen even without the conjunction of other parts, in the case of milk and water and so on.

analyzed: tat evam asāratara tarka saṃdṛbdha tvāt īśvara kāraṇa śruti viruddha tvāt śruti pravaṇaiḥ ca
translated: Thus, because it is contradicted by the scriptures that declare God as the cause, and because it is opposed by those who are devoted to the scriptures,

analyzed: śiṣṭaiḥ manu ādibhiḥ aparigṛhīta tvāt atyantam eva anapekṣā asmin paramāṇu kāraṇa vāde kāryā śreyaḥ ūrthibhiḥ iti vākyaśeṣaḥ
translated: Thus, this doctrine of atoms as the cause of the world, being contradicted by the scriptures which declare God as the cause, and being rejected by the wise who are devoted to the scriptures, such as Manu and others, should be entirely disregarded by those who seek the highest good. This is the conclusion of the sentence.

analyzed: tathātvam atyanta bhinna tvam  grāhyaḥ
translated: Thusness means absolute difference.🔽Here, the Vedantin should be taken.

analyzed: yat vā kāpilasya api tādātmya siddhānte iti sāṃkhya grahaṇam
translated: Or, the mention of Sāṃkhya is because even the followers of Kapila have the doctrine of identity.

analyzed: prabhūta tva saṃbhavāt niravadhi tva saṃbhavāt
translated: Because of the possibility of abundance and the possibility of infinity.

analyzed: saṃśleṣaḥ saṃgrahaḥ eka ākarṣaṇena apara ākarṣaṇam tasya anupapattiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The non-occurrence of the connection, i.e., the non-attraction of the other by the attraction of one, is not possible. This is the meaning.

analyzed: samudāya adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on the whole. Sutra.

analyzed: samudāyaḥ ubhaya hetuke tad aprāptiḥ  vaiśeṣika rāddhāntaḥ duryukti yogāt veda virodhāt śiṣṭa aparigrahāt ca na apekṣitavyaḥ iti uktam
translated: Even in the case of the whole being caused by both, there is non-attainment of that.🔽It has been said that the Vaiśeṣika doctrine should not be considered because it is connected with bad reasoning, contradicts the Vedas, and is not accepted by the wise.

analyzed: saḥ ūrdhva vaināśikaḥ iti vaināśika tva sāmyāt sarva vaināśika rāddhāntaḥ natarām apekṣitavyaḥ iti idam idānīm upapādayāmaḥ
translated: He is half a nihilist, so all the nihilist doctrines should not be considered at all because they are similar to nihilism. This is what we are explaining now.

analyzed: sa ca bahu prakāraḥ pratipatti bhedāt vineya bhedāt vā
translated: And that is of many kinds, due to the difference in practice or the difference in those to be trained.

analyzed: tatra ete trayaḥ vādinaḥ bhavanti kecid sarva astitva vādinaḥ
translated: Among them, there are three kinds of proponents: some are proponents of the existence of everything,

analyzed: kecid vijñāna astitva mātra vādinaḥ
translated: some are proponents of the existence of consciousness only,

analyzed: anye punar sarva śūnyatva vādinaḥ iti
translated: and others are proponents of the emptiness of everything.

original: tatra te sarvāstitvavādino bāhyamāntaraṃ ca vastvabhyupagacchanti bhūtaṃ bhautikaṃ ca cittaṃ caittaṃ ca /
analyzed: tatra te sarva astitva vādinaḥ bāhyam āntaram ca vastu abhyupagacchanti bhūtam bhautikam ca cittam caittam ca
translated: Among them, those proponents of the existence of everything accept external and internal things, the elements and the derivatives of the elements, mind and mental factors.

analyzed: tān tāvat pratibrūmaḥ
translated: We will refute them.

analyzed: tatra bhūtam pṛthivī dhātu ādayaḥ
translated: Among them, the elements are the earth element, etc.

analyzed: bhautikam rūpa ādayaḥ cakṣuḥ ādayaḥ ca
translated: The derivatives of the elements are form, etc., and the eyes, etc.

original: catuṣṭaye ca pṛthivyādiparamāṇavaḥ svarasnehoṣṇasvabhāvāste pṛthivyādibhāvena saṃhanyanta iti manyante /
analyzed: catuṣṭaye ca pṛthivī ādi paramāṇavaḥ svara sneha uṣṇa svabhāvāḥ te pṛthivī ādi bhāvena saṃhanyante iti manyante
translated: And they think that the atoms of earth, etc., which are of four kinds, having the nature of solidity, fluidity, heat, and motion, combine to form the nature of earth, etc.

analyzed: tathā rūpa vijñāna vedanā saṃjñā saṃskāra saṃjñakāḥ pañca skandhāḥ
translated: Similarly, there are five aggregates called form, consciousness, feeling, perception, and formations.

analyzed: te pi adhyātmam sarva vyavahāra āspada bhāvena saṃhanyante iti manyante
translated: They also think that those combine to form the basis for all conventional usage internally.

analyzed: tatra idam abhidhīyate yaḥ yam ubhaya hetukaḥ ubhaya prakāraḥ samudāyaḥ pareṣām
translated: Here it is said: This combination, which is accepted by others as having two causes and two aspects,

analyzed: ṇu hetukaḥ ca bhūta bhautika saṃhati rūpaḥ skandha hetukaḥ ca pañca skandhī rūpaḥ tasmin ubhaya hetuke
translated: The aggregate of elements and elemental evolutes is the cause of the atom, and the aggregate of five aggregates is the cause of the aggregate. Even in that aggregate which is the cause of both,

analyzed: pi samudāye bhipreyamāṇe tad aprāptiḥ syāt samudāya aprāptiḥ
translated: if the collection is intended, there would be non-attainment of that, non-attainment of the collection.

analyzed: samudāya bhāva anupapattiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: the collection does not arise.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

analyzed: samudāyinām acetana tvāt
translated: Because the components are insentient.

analyzed: citta abhid jvalanasya ca samudāya siddhi adhīna tvāt
translated: And because the manifestation of mind depends on the establishment of the collection.

original: anyasya ca kasyaciccetanasya bhoktuḥ praśāsiturvā sthirasya saṃhanturanabhyupagamāt nirapekṣapravṛttyabhyupagame ca pravṛttyanuparamaprasaṅgāt
analyzed: anyasya ca kasyacid cetanasya bhoktuḥ praśāsituḥ vā sthirasya saṃhantuḥ anabhyupagamāt nirapekṣa pravṛtti abhyupagame ca pravṛtti anuparama prasaṅgāt
translated: And because no other permanent experiencer, ruler, or controller is accepted. And if independent activity is accepted, there would be the consequence of activity without cessation.

analyzed: āśayasya api anyatva ananyatvābhyām anirūpya tvāt
translated: And because intention cannot be determined as either the same as or different from [mind].

analyzed: kṣaṇika tva abhyupagamāt ca nirvyāpāra tvāt pravṛtti anupapatteḥ
translated: And because momentary existence is accepted, there is no function, so activity is not possible.

analyzed: tasmāt samudāya anupapattiḥ
translated: Therefore, the collection is not possible.

analyzed: samudāya anupapattau ca tad āśrayā lokayātrā lupyeta  /
translated: And if the collection is not possible, then the worldly life based on it would be destroyed.

analyzed: bhūte bhautikam bāhyam
translated: The external is the elemental evolute of the elements.

analyzed: cittam caittam ca kāma ādi antaram iti vibhāgaḥ
translated: Mind and mental factors are internal, beginning with desire. This is the division.

analyzed: catuṣṭaye caturvidhāḥ
translated: And in the four, there are four kinds.

analyzed: svarāḥ kaṭhināḥ pārthivāḥ paramāṇavaḥ
translated: The elements are hard, earthy atoms.

analyzed: snigdhāḥ āpyāḥ
translated: The moist are watery.

analyzed: uṣṇaḥ taijasāḥ
translated: The hot are fiery.

analyzed: īraṇam calanam svabhāvaḥ vāyavyānām iti
translated: The moving, which is motion, is the nature of the airy.
The form aggregate is the sense faculties with their specific objects.

analyzed: aham aham iti ālayavijñāna pravāhaḥ vijñāna skandhaḥ
translated: The consciousness aggregate is the stream of the store consciousness, which is the I and mine consciousness.
The feeling aggregate is the experience of pleasure, etc.

analyzed: gauḥ aśvaḥ iti evaṃnāma viśiṣṭa sa vikalpa pratyayaḥ saṃjñā skandhaḥ  rāga dveṣa moha dharmāḥ saṃskāra skandhaḥ
translated: The perception aggregate is the determinate perception distinguished by the name cow, horse, etc.🔽The formation aggregate is the dharmas of passion, hatred, and delusion.

analyzed: āśerate smin rāga ādayaḥ iti āśayaḥ saṃtānaḥ
translated: The store is the stream in which passion, etc. abide.

analyzed: itaretara pratyaya tvāt iti ced na utpatti mātra nimitta tvāt
translated: If it is argued that it is because they are reciprocal conditions, that is not so, because they are the cause of mere origination.

original: yadyapi bhoktā praśāsitā vā kaściccetanaḥ saṃhantā sthiro nābhyupagamyate tathāpyavidyādīnāmitaretarakāraṇatvādupapadyate lokayātrā /
analyzed: yadi api bhoktā praśāsitā vā kaścid cetanaḥ saṃhantā sthiraḥ nā abhyupagamyate tathā api avidyā ādīnām itaretara kāraṇa tvāt upapadyate lokayātrā
translated: Even though no conscious enjoyer or controller or any such permanent combiner is accepted, still the course of the world is possible due to the mutual causality of ignorance, etc.

analyzed: tasyām ca upapadyamānāyām vā kiñcid aparam apekṣitavyam asti
translated: And when that is possible, nothing else is needed.

original: te cāvidyādayo 'vidyā saṃskāro vijñānaṃ nāma rūpaṃ ṣaḍāyatanaṃ sparśā vedanā tṛṣṇā
analyzed: te ca avidyā ādayaḥ vidyā saṃskāraḥ vijñānam nāma rūpam ṣaṣ āyatanam sparśāḥ vedanā tṛṣṇā
translated: And those ignorance, etc. are ignorance, formations, consciousness, name-and-form, six sense bases, contact, feeling, craving,

original: upādānaṃ bhavo jātirjarā maraṇaṃ śokaḥ paridevanā duḥkhaṃ durmanastetyevañjātīyakā
analyzed: upādānam bhavaḥ jātiḥ jarā maraṇam śokaḥ paridevanā duḥkham durmanaḥ tā iti evañjātīyakā
translated: Clinging, becoming, birth, old age, death, grief, lamentation, pain, mental anguish, and despair—these and other such things,

original: itaretarahetukāḥ saugate samaye kvacitsaṃkṣiptā nirdiṣṭāḥ kvacitprapañcitāḥ /
analyzed: itaretara hetukāḥ saugate samaye kvacid saṃkṣiptāḥ nirdiṣṭāḥ kvacid prapañcitāḥ
translated: are mutually causal in the Buddhist scriptures, sometimes taught concisely and sometimes elaborately.

analyzed: sarveṣām api ayam avidyā ādi kalāpaḥ pratyākhyeyaḥ
translated: But this entire group beginning with ignorance cannot be rejected.

original: tadevamavidyādikalāpe parasparanimittanaimittikabhāvena ghaṭīyantravadaniśamāvartamāner'thākṣipta upapannaḥ saṃghāta iti cet /🔽tanna /
analyzed: tat evam avidyā ādi kalāpe paraspara nimitta naimittika bhāvena ghaṭīyantra vat aniśam āvartamāna irtha ākṣiptaḥ upapannaḥ saṃghātaḥ iti ced  tat na
translated: If it is argued that the aggregate is logically implied and arises when this group beginning with ignorance revolves incessantly like a wheel, with each being the cause and the other the effect,🔽that is not so.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

analyzed: utpatti mātra nimitta tvāt
translated: Because it is only the cause of mere origination.

analyzed: bhavet upapannaḥ saṃghātaḥ yadi saṃghātasya kiñcid nimittam avagamyeta
translated: The aggregate would be logically implied if some cause of the aggregate were understood.

analyzed: na tu avagamyate
translated: But it is not understood.

original: yata itaretarapratyayatve 'pyavidyādīnāṃ pūrvapūrvamuttarottarasyotpattimātranimittaṃ bhavedbhavenna tu saṃghātotpatteḥ kiñcinnimittaṃ saṃbhavati
analyzed: yatas itaretara pratyaya tve pi avidyā ādīnām pūrva pūrvam uttara uttarasya utpatti mātra nimittam bhavet bhavet na tu saṃghāta utpatteḥ kiñcid nimittam saṃbhavati
translated: Because even in the mutual conditioning of ignorance and so on, the earlier one would be only the cause of the origination of the later one, not any cause of the origination of the aggregate.

analyzed: nanu avidyā ādibhiḥ arthāt ākṣipyate saṃghātaḥ iti uktam
translated: Isn't it said that the aggregate is logically implied and arises from ignorance and so on?

original: atrocyate yadi tāvadayamabhiprāyo 'vidyādayaḥ saṃghātamantareṇātmānamalabhamānā apekṣante saṃghātamiti /
analyzed: atra ucyate yadi tāvat ayam abhiprāyaḥ vidyā ādayaḥ saṃghātam antareṇa ātmānam alabhamānāḥ apekṣante saṃghātam iti
translated: To this we reply: If this is the intention: “Ignorance, etc., not finding their own nature apart from the aggregate, depend on the aggregate,”

analyzed: tatas tasya saṃghātasya nimittam vaktavyam
translated: then the cause of that aggregate must be stated.

original: tacca nityeṣvapyaṇuṣvabhyupagamyamāneṣvāśrayāśrayibhūteṣu ca bhokteṣu satsu na saṃbhavatītyuktaṃ vaiśeṣikaparīkṣāyām /
analyzed: tat ca nityeṣu api aṇuṣu abhyupagamyamāneṣu āśraya āśrayi bhūteṣu ca bhokteṣu satsu na saṃbhavati iti uktam vaiśeṣika parīkṣāyām
translated: And that is not possible even if eternal atoms are accepted, or if enjoyers are accepted as the basis and the based. This has been stated in the examination of the Vaiśeṣika [school].

original: kimaṅga punaḥ kṣaṇikeṣvapyaṇuṣu bhoktṛrahiteṣvāśrayiśūnyeṣu vābhyupagamyamāneṣu saṃbhavet /
analyzed: kim aṅga punar kṣaṇikeṣu api aṇuṣu bhoktṛ rahiteṣu āśrayi śūnyeṣu vā abhyupagamyamāneṣu saṃbhavet
translated: So how much less possible is it if momentary atoms are accepted, either devoid of an enjoyer or empty of a basis?

analyzed: atha ayam abhiprāyaḥ vidyā ādayaḥ eva saṃghātasya nimittam iti
translated: But if this is the intention: “Ignorance, etc. are the cause of the aggregate,”

analyzed: katham tam eva āśritya ātmānam labhamānāḥ tasya eva nimittam syuḥ
translated: how could they, depending on that very [aggregate] and finding their own nature, be the cause of that very [aggregate]?

original: atha manyase saṃghātā evānādau saṃsāre saṃtatyānuvartante tadāśrayāścāvidyādaya iti /
analyzed: atha manyase saṃghātāḥ eva anādau saṃsāre saṃtatya anuvartante tad āśrayāḥ ca avidyā ādayaḥ iti
translated: Or if you think that only the aggregates continue in a series in beginningless saṃsāra, and ignorance, etc. are based on them,

analyzed: tat api saṃdhātāt saṃghāta antaram utpadyamānam  niyamena vā sadṛśam eva utpadyeta
translated: then that aggregate arising from one aggregate to another aggregate,🔽would necessarily arise as exactly similar,

analyzed: aniyamena vā sadṛśam visadṛśam vā utpadyeta
translated: or it would arise as similar or dissimilar without restriction.

analyzed: niyama abhyupagame manuṣya pudgalasya deva tiryagyoni nāraka prāpti abhāvaḥ prāpnuyāt
translated: If you accept the rule, then it would follow that a human person could not be reborn as a god, animal, or hell being.

original: aniyamābhyupagame 'pi manuṣyapudgalaḥ kadācitkṣaṇena hastī bhūtvā devo vā punarmanuṣyo vā bhavediti prāpnuyāt /
analyzed: aniyama abhyupagame manuṣya pudgalaḥ kadācid kṣaṇena hastī bhūtvā devaḥ vā punar manuṣyaḥ vā bhavet iti prāpnuyāt
translated: If you accept the exception, then it would follow that a human person could sometimes become an elephant in the next moment, or be reborn as a god or human.

analyzed: ubhayam api abhyupagama viruddham
translated: Both of these are contradictory to your acceptance.

original: apica yadbhogārthaḥ saṃghātaḥ syātsa nāsti sthiro bhokteti tavābhyupagamaḥ /
analyzed: apica yad bhoga arthaḥ saṃghātaḥ syāt sa nā asti sthiraḥ bhoktā iti tava abhyupagamaḥ
translated: Moreover, it is your acceptance that the aggregate exists for the purpose of experience, but there is no stable experiencer.

original: tataśca bhogo bhogārtha eva sa nānyena prārthanīyaḥ /
analyzed: tatas ca bhogaḥ bhoga arthaḥ eva sa na anyena prārthanīyaḥ
translated: Therefore, experience should be sought only for the sake of experience, not by anything else.

original: tathā mokṣo mokṣārthaṃ eveti mumukṣuṇā nānyena bhavitavyam /
analyzed: tathā mokṣaḥ mokṣa artham eva iti mumukṣuṇā na anyena bhavitavyam
translated: Similarly, liberation should be sought only for the sake of liberation, so one who desires liberation should not be anything else.

analyzed: anyena ced prārthyeta ubhayam bhoga mokṣa kāla avasthāyinā tena bhavitavyam
translated: If both are sought by something else that remains during the time of experience and liberation, then it must be something permanent.

original: avasthāyitve kṣaṇikatvābhyupagamavirodhaḥ /🔽tasmāditaretarotpattimātranimittatvamavidyādīnāṃ yadi bhavedbhavatu nāma natu saṃghātaḥ siddhyet /
analyzed: tasmāt itaretara utpatti mātra nimitta tvam avidyā ādīnām yadi bhavet bhavatu nāma na tu saṃghātaḥ siddhyet
translated: If it is permanent, then it contradicts the acceptance of momentariness.🔽Therefore, if ignorance, etc. were merely the causes of each other's arising, let it be so, but the aggregate would not be established.

analyzed: bhoktṛ abhāvāt iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: The intention is that there would be no experiencer.

original: FN / kāryaṃ prati ayate gacchatīti pratyayaḥ kāraṇam /
analyzed: kāryam prati gacchati iti pratyayaḥ kāraṇam
translated: A pratyaya is that which goes (ayate) towards (prati) an effect.

original: vijñānaṃ pṛthivyādicatuṣṭayaṃ rūpaṃ ceti ṣaḍāyatanāni yasyendriyajātasya tatṣaḍāyatanam /
analyzed: vijñānam pṛthivī ādi catuṣṭayam rūpam ca iti ṣaḍ āyatanāni yasya indriya jātasya tat ṣaḍāyatanam
translated: That collection of sense faculties which has six bases, namely consciousness, the four beginning with earth, and form.

analyzed: tṛṣṇyāḥ vāc kāya ceṣṭā upādānam
translated: Craving is grasping, which is the activity of speech and body.

analyzed: hā putra tāta ityādi pralāpaḥ paridevanā
translated: Lamentation is the utterance Alas, son! Alas, father! and so on.

analyzed: āśraya ityādi bhoktṛ viśeṣaṇam adṛṣṭa āśrayeṣu iti arthaḥ
translated: Having an unseen substratum and so on are qualifications of the experiencer, meaning having an unseen substratum.

analyzed: uttara utpāde ca pūrva nirodhāt
translated: And because the previous [moment] ceases when the subsequent [moment] arises.

analyzed: uktam etat avidyā ādīnām utpatti mātra nimitta tvāt na saṃghāta siddhiḥ asti iti
translated: It has been said that the establishment of the aggregate is not possible because ignorance and so on are only the causes of mere arising.

analyzed: tat api tu utpatti mātra nimitta tvam na saṃbhavati iti idam idānīm upapādyate
translated: But that mere being the cause of arising is also not possible, so this is now being established.

original: kṣaṇabhaṅgavādino 'yamabhyupagama uttarasminkṣaṇa utpadyamāne pūrvaḥ kṣaṇo nirudhyata iti /
analyzed: kṣaṇabhaṅga vādinaḥ yam abhyupagamaḥ uttarasmin kṣaṇe utpadyamāne pūrvaḥ kṣaṇaḥ nirudhyate iti
translated: For one who advocates momentariness, there is the acceptance that when the subsequent moment is arising, the previous moment ceases.

analyzed: na ca evam abhyupagacchatā pūrva uttarayoḥ kṣaṇayoḥ hetu phala bhāvaḥ śakyate saṃpādayitum
translated: And for one who accepts this, the relation of cause and effect between the previous and subsequent moments cannot be accomplished.

analyzed: nirudhyamānasya niruddhasya vā pūrva kṣaṇasya abhāva grasta tvāt uttara kṣaṇa hetu tva anupapatteḥ
translated: Because the previous moment, whether ceasing or having ceased, is already non-existent, it cannot be the cause of the subsequent moment.

original: atha bhāvabhūtaḥ pariniṣpannāvasthaḥ pūrvakṣaṇa uttarakṣaṇasya heturityabhiprāyastathāpi nopapadyate /
analyzed: atha bhāva bhūtaḥ pariniṣpanna avasthaḥ pūrva kṣaṇaḥ uttara kṣaṇasya hetuḥ iti abhiprāyaḥ tathā api na upapadyate
translated: Now, if the intended meaning is that the perfected state, which is an existent, is the cause of the subsequent moment, even so it is not tenable.

analyzed: bhāva bhūtasya punar vyāpāra kalpanāyām kṣaṇa antara saṃbandha prasaṅgāt
translated: For if the existent is imagined to have activity, it would follow that it is connected with another moment.

original: atha bhāva evāsya vyāpāra ityabhiprāyastathāpi naivopapadyate /
analyzed: atha bhāvaḥ eva asya vyāpāraḥ iti abhiprāyaḥ tathā api na evā upapadyate
translated: But if the intended meaning is that his activity is just the existent itself, even so it is not tenable.

analyzed: hetu svabhāva an uparaktasya phalasya itpatti asaṃbhavāt
translated: Because it is impossible for a result to arise that is not connected with the nature of the cause.

original: svabhāvoparāgābhyupagame ca hetusvabhāvasya phalakālāvasthāyitve sati kṣaṇabhaṅgābhyupagamatyāgaprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: svabhāva uparāga abhyupagame ca hetu svabhāvasya phala kāla avasthāyi tve sati kṣaṇa bhaṅga abhyupagama tyāga prasaṅgaḥ
translated: And if the connection with its own nature is accepted, and the nature of the cause persists at the time of the result, it follows that the acceptance of momentariness is abandoned.

original: vinaiva vā svabhāvoparāgeṇa hetu phalabhāvamabhyupagacchataḥ sarvatra tatprāpteratiprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: vinā eva vā svabhāva uparāgeṇa hetu phala bhāvam abhyupagacchataḥ sarvatra tad prāpteḥ atiprasaṅgaḥ
translated: Or if one accepts the relation of cause and effect without any connection with one's own nature, it follows that it is attained everywhere, which is absurd.

original: apicotpādanirodhau nāma vastunaḥ svarūpameva vā syātāmavasthāntaraṃ vā vastvantarameva vā /
analyzed: api ca utpāda nirodhau nāma vastunaḥ svarūpam eva vā syātām avasthā antaram vā vastu antaram eva vā
translated: Moreover, origination and cessation would be either the very nature of a thing, or a different state, or a completely different thing.

analyzed: sarvathā api na upapadyate
translated: In no way is it tenable.

original: yadi tāvadvastunaḥ svarūpamevotpādanirodhau syātāṃ tato vastuśabda utpādanirodhaśabdau ca paryāyāḥ prāpnuyuḥ /
analyzed: yadi tāvat vastunaḥ svarūpam eva utpāda nirodhau syātām tatas vastu śabdaḥ utpāda nirodha śabdau ca paryāyāḥ prāpnuyuḥ
translated: If, on the other hand, the very nature of the entity were to be its origination and cessation, then the words 'entity', 'origination', and 'cessation' would become synonyms.

original: asthāsti kaścidviśeṣa iti manyetotpādanirodhaśabdābhyāṃ madhyavartino vastuna ādyantākhye avasthe abhilapyete iti /
analyzed: asthā asti kaścid viśeṣaḥ iti manyeta utpāda nirodha śabdābhyām madhya vartinaḥ vastunaḥ ādi anta ākhye avasthe abhilapyete iti
translated: If one thinks that there is some difference, one might think that the words 'origination' and 'cessation' refer to the initial and final states of the entity existing in the middle.

analyzed: evam api ādya anta madhya kṣaṇa traya saṃbandhi tvāt vastunaḥ kṣaṇikatva abhyupagama hāniḥ
translated: Even so, because the entity is related to the three moments of the beginning, end, and middle, there is a loss of the acceptance of momentariness.🔽If, on the other hand, origination and cessation were to be absolutely distinct from the entity, like a horse and a buffalo,

original: athātyantavyatiriktāvevotpādanirodhau vastunaḥ syātāmaśvamahiṣavat /🔽tato vastu utpādanirodhābhyāmasaṃsṛṣṭamiti vastunaḥ śāśvatatvaprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: atha atyanta vyatiriktau eva utpāda nirodhau vastunaḥ syātām aśva mahiṣa vat  tatas vastu utpāda nirodhābhyām asaṃsṛṣṭam iti vastunaḥ śāśvata tva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: then the entity would not be mixed with origination and cessation, and there would be the consequence of the eternality of the entity.

original: yadi ca darśanādarśane vastuna utpādanirodhau syātām /🔽evamapi draṣṭṛdharmau tau na vastudharmāviti vastunaḥ śāśvatatvaprasaṅga eva /
analyzed: yadi ca darśana adarśane vastunaḥ utpāda nirodhau syātām  evam api draṣṭṛ dharmau tau na vastu dharmau iti vastunaḥ śāśvata tva prasaṅgaḥ eva
translated: And if origination and cessation of the entity were to be its being seen and not being seen,🔽even so, those two would be properties of the seer, not properties of the entity, and there would be the same consequence of the eternality of the entity.

analyzed: tasmāt api asaṃgatam saugatam matam    nirudhyamāna tvam vināśaka sāṃnidhyam
translated: Therefore, the view of the Buddhists is also incoherent.🔽The state of being in the process of ceasing is the presence of the cause of destruction.

analyzed: niruddha tvam atīta tvam
translated: The state of having ceased is the past state.

analyzed: asati pratijñā uparodhaḥ yaugapadyam anyathā
translated: If there is no [cause], there is contradiction with the thesis, simultaneity [of cause and effect], and [the effect] would not be produced.

analyzed: kṣaṇabhaṅga vāde pūrva kṣaṇaḥ nirodha grasta tvāt na uttarasya kṣaṇasya hetuḥ bhavati iti uktam
translated: It has been said that in the doctrine of momentariness, the previous moment, being destroyed by cessation, does not become the cause of the subsequent moment.

analyzed: atha asati eva hetau phala utpattim brūyāt
translated: If one were to say that the effect arises even without a cause,

analyzed: tatas pratijñā uparodhaḥ syāt
translated: then there would be a contradiction with the thesis.

original: caturvidhānhetūnpratītya cittacaittā utpadyanta itīyaṃ pratijñā hīyeta /
analyzed: caturvidhān hetūn pratītya citta caittāḥ utpadyante iti iyam pratijñā hīyeta
translated: The thesis that mind and mental factors arise in dependence on four kinds of causes would be abandoned.

analyzed: nirhetukāyām ca utpattau apratibandhāt sarvam sarvatra utpadyeta
translated: And if there were production without a cause, everything would arise everywhere, because there would be no obstruction.

original: athottarakṣaṇotpattiryāvattāvadavatiṣṭhate pūrvakṣaṇa iti brūyāttato yaugapadyaṃ hetuphalayoḥ syāt /
analyzed: atha uttara kṣaṇa utpattiḥ yāvat tāvat avatiṣṭhate pūrva kṣaṇe iti brūyāt tatas yaugapadyam hetu phalayoḥ syāt
translated: If one were to say that the previous moment endures as long as the arising of the subsequent moment, then there would be simultaneity of cause and effect.

analyzed: tathā api pratijñā uparodhaḥ eva syāt
translated: Even so, there would be only a contradiction with the thesis.

analyzed: kṣaṇikāḥ sarve saṃskārāḥ iti iyam pratijñā uparudhyeta  /
translated: The thesis that all conditioned things are momentary would be abandoned.

analyzed: pratisaṃkhyā pratisaṃkhyā nirodha aprāptiḥ avicchedāt
translated: The attainment of cessation through deliberation and cessation without deliberation would not be due to disconnection.

original: apica vaināśikāḥ kalpayanti buddhibodhyaṃ trayādanyatsaṃskṛtaṃ kṣaṇikaṃ ceti /
analyzed: apica vaināśikāḥ kalpayanti buddhi bodhyam trayāt anyat saṃskṛtam kṣaṇikam ca iti
translated: Moreover, the nihilists imagine that what is cognized by the intellect is conditioned and momentary, other than the three [unconditioned things].

analyzed: tat api ca kṣayam pratisaṃkhyā pratisaṃkhāya a nirodha avakāśam ca iti ācakṣate
translated: And that is also called the opportunity for the cessation due to deliberation and the cessation not due to deliberation.

analyzed: trayam api ca etat avastu abhāva mātram nirupākhyam iti manyante
translated: And they consider that all three are mere non-existence of a thing, without any designation.

original: buddhipūrvakaḥ kila vināśo bhāvānāṃ pratisaṃkhyānirodho nāma bhāṣyate /
analyzed: buddhi pūrvakaḥ kila vināśaḥ bhāvānām pratisaṃkhyā nirodhaḥ nāma bhāṣyate
translated: It is said that the destruction of things preceded by cognition is called the cessation due to deliberation.

analyzed: tad viparītaḥ pratisaṃkhyā nirodhaḥ āvaraṇa bhāva mātram ākāśam iti
translated: The opposite of that is the cessation not due to deliberation. Space is merely the state of obstruction.

analyzed: teṣām ākāśam parastāt pratyākhyāsyati  nirodha dvayam idānīm pratyācaṣṭe
translated: He will refute their space later.🔽Now he refutes the two cessations.

analyzed: pratisaṃkhyā pratisaṃkhyā nirodhayoḥ aprāptiḥ
translated: The non-attainment of the cessation due to deliberation and the cessation not due to deliberation.

analyzed: asaṃbhavaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is impossibility.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

analyzed: a vicchedāt
translated: Because there is no interruption.

original: etau hi pratisaṃkhyāpratisaṃkhyānirodhau saṃtānagocarau vā syātāṃ bhāvagocarau vā /
analyzed: etau hi pratisaṃkhyā pratisaṃkhyā nirodhau saṃtāna gocarau vā syātām bhāva gocarau vā
translated: For these two, the cessation due to deliberation and the cessation not due to deliberation, would either have a continuum as their domain or a thing as their domain.

analyzed: na tāvat saṃtāna gocarau saṃbhavataḥ
translated: First, they cannot possibly have a continuum as their domain.

analyzed: sarveṣu api saṃtāneṣu saṃtāninām avicchinnena hetu phala bhāvena saṃtāna vicchedasya asaṃbhavāt
translated: Because the interruption of a continuum is impossible due to the uninterrupted causal relationship of all continua.

analyzed: na api bhāva gocarau saṃbhavataḥ
translated: Nor can they possibly have a thing as their domain.

original: nahi bhāvānāṃ niranvayo nirupākhyo vināśaḥ saṃbhavati /
analyzed: nahi bhāvānām niranvayaḥ nirupākhyaḥ vināśaḥ saṃbhavati
translated: For destruction, which is devoid of a substratum and is inexistent, is not possible for existent things.

analyzed: sarvāsu api avasthāsu pratyabhijñāna balena anvayi aviccheda darśanāt
translated: Because in all states, the non-interruption of the substratum is seen by the power of recognition.

analyzed: aspaṣṭa pratyabhijñānāsu api avasthāsu kvacid dṛṣṭena anvayi avicchedena anyatra api tad anumānāt
translated: And in states where recognition is not clear, the non-interruption of the substratum is seen somewhere, and from that, it is inferred elsewhere.

analyzed: tasmāt para parikalpitasya nirodha dvayasya anupapattiḥ
translated: Therefore, the two kinds of cessation postulated by others are not logically possible.

analyzed: nirupākhyam niḥsvarūpam
translated: The inexistent, i.e., that which has no form.

original: pratīpā pratukūlaḥ saṃkhyā santaṃ bhāvamasantaṃ karomītyevaṃrūpā buddhiḥ pratisaṃkhyā tayā nirodhaḥ /
analyzed: pratīpā pratukūlaḥ saṃkhyā santam bhāvam asantam karomi iti evaṃrūpā buddhiḥ pratisaṃkhyā tayā nirodhaḥ
translated: The intellect that is opposed, i.e., adverse, in the form I make an existent thing non-existent, is called pratisamkhyā. Cessation is by that.

analyzed: ubhayathā ca doṣāt
translated: And because there is a fault in both cases.

analyzed: yaḥ yama vidyā ādi nirodhaḥ pratisaṃkhyā nirodha antaḥpātī para parikalpitaḥ
translated: This cessation of ignorance, etc., which is included within pratisamkhyā-nirodha and is postulated by others,

analyzed: sa samyak jñānāt vā sa parikarāt syāt svayam eva vā
translated: would be by perfect knowledge along with its auxiliaries, or by itself.

analyzed: pūrvasmin vikalpe nihartuka vināśa abhyupagama hāni prasaṅgaḥ
translated: In the former case, there would be the undesirable consequence of abandoning the acceptance of the destruction of the object to be abandoned.

analyzed: uttarasmin tu mārga upadeśa ānarthakya prasaṅgaḥ
translated: In the latter case, there would be the undesirable consequence of the futility of teaching the path.

analyzed: evam ubhayathā api doṣa prasaṅgāt asamañjasam idam darśanam
translated: Thus, because there is the undesirable consequence of a fault in both cases, this view is not logically coherent.

analyzed: parikarāḥ yama niyama ādayaḥ tad sahitāt
translated: The means are the restraints, observances, etc., together with that.

analyzed: sarvam duḥkham kṣaṇikam iti bhāvanā upadeśaḥ mārga upadeśaḥ
translated: The teaching of meditation on all suffering as momentary is the teaching of the path.

original: ākāśe cāviśeṣāt / / / /🔽yacca teṣāmevābhipretaṃ nirodhadvayamākāśaṃ ca nirupākhyamiti /
analyzed: ākāśe ca aviśeṣāt  yat ca teṣām eva abhipretam nirodha dvayam ākāśam ca nirupākhyam iti
translated: And in space, because there is no difference,🔽And what they accept as the two cessations and space as non-existent,

analyzed: tatra nirodha dvayasya nirupākhya tvam purastāt nirākṛtam
translated: There, the non-existence of the two cessations has been refuted earlier.

analyzed: ākāśasya idānīm nirākriyate
translated: Now space is being refuted.

analyzed: ākāśe ca ayuktaḥ nirupākhya tva abhyupagamaḥ
translated: And in space, the acceptance of non-existence is not proper.

analyzed: pratisaṃkhyā pratisaṃkhyā nirodhayoḥ iva vastu tva pratipatteḥ aviśeṣāt  āgama prāmāṇyāt tāvat ātmanaḥ ākāśaḥ saṃbhūtaḥ
translated: Because there is no difference in the understanding of substantiality, like in the case of analytical and non-analytical cessations.🔽First, by the authority of scripture, from the Vedic statement Space is born from the Self,

analyzed: ityādi śrutibhyaḥ ākāśasya ca vastu tva prāptiḥ
translated: Space is established as a substance.

analyzed: vipratipannān prati tu śabda guṇa anumeya tvam vaktavyam
translated: But for those who disagree, it should be said that it is to be inferred from the quality of sound.

analyzed: gandha ādīnām guṇānām pṛthivī ādi vastu āśraya tva darśanāt
translated: Because smell and other qualities are seen to be based on substances like earth, etc.

analyzed: api ca āvaraṇa abhāva mātram ākāśam icchatām ekasmin suparṇe patati āvaraṇasya vidyamāna tvāt suparṇa antarasya utpitsataḥ na avakāśa tva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Moreover, for those who consider space to be merely the absence of obstruction, when one bird is flying, since there is an obstruction, it follows that there is no opportunity for another bird to attempt to fly there.

analyzed: yatra āvaraṇa abhāvaḥ tatra patiṣyati iti ced
translated: If it is argued that it will fly where there is no obstruction,

original: yenāvaraṇabhāvo viśeṣyate tattarhi vastubhūtamevākāśaṃ manyamānasya saugatasya svābhyupagamavirodhaḥ prasajyeta /
analyzed: yena āvaraṇa bhāvaḥ viśeṣyate tat tarhi vastu bhūtam eva ākāśam manyamānasya saugatasya sva abhyupagama virodhaḥ prasajyeta
translated: then for one who considers space to be a real entity, qualified by the absence of obstruction, there would arise the fault of contradicting one's own accepted doctrine.

original: saugate hi samaye 'pṛthivī bhagavaḥ kiṃsaṃniścayā' ityasminprativacanapravāhe pṛthivyādīnāmante
analyzed: saugate hi samaye pṛthivī bhagavaḥ kiṃsaṃniścayā iti asmin prativacana pravāhe pṛthivī ādīnām ante
translated: For in the Sautrāntika system, in the series of answers beginning with Earth, Blessed One, is determined by what? at the end of the discussion of earth, etc.,

original: vāyuḥ 'kiṃsaṃniścayaḥ' ityasya praśnasya prativacanaṃ bhavati 'vāyurākāśasaṃniścayaḥ' iti /
analyzed: vāyuḥ kiṃsaṃniścayaḥ iti asya praśnasya prativacanam bhavati vāyuḥ ākāśa saṃniścayaḥ iti
translated: the answer to the question What is wind determined by? is Wind is determined by space.

analyzed: tat ākāśasya avastu tve na samañjasam syāt
translated: If space were unreal, that would not be coherent.

analyzed: tasmāt api ayuktam ākāśasya avastu tvam
translated: Therefore, it is also unreasonable for space to be unreal.

original: apica nirodhadvayamākāśaṃ ca trayamapyetannirūpākhyamavastu nityaṃ ceti vipratiṣiddham /
analyzed: apica nirodha dvayam ākāśam ca trayam api etat nirūpa ākhyam avastu nityam ca iti vipratiṣiddham
translated: Moreover, it is contradictory to call these three - the two cessations and space - both unobservable and unreal, and also permanent.

analyzed: na hi avastunaḥ nitya tvam anitya tvam vā saṃbhavati
translated: For an unreal thing cannot be either permanent or impermanent.

analyzed: vastu āśraya tvāt dharma dharmi vyavahārasya
translated: Because the usage of substance and attribute is based on substance.

analyzed: dharma dharmi bhāve hi ghaṭa ādi vat vastu tvam eva syāt na nirupākhya tvam
translated: For if there were the relation of substance and attribute, it would be a substance like a pot, not a non-entity.

analyzed: patiṣyati saṃcariṣyati iti arthaḥ
translated: Will fall, will move, is the meaning.

original: kiṃ samyak niścaya āśrayo 'syā iti kiṃ saṃniścayā /
analyzed: kim samyak syāḥ iti
translated: What is the correct ascertainment that is the basis of this? Thus, what is the ascertainment?

analyzed: anusmṛteḥ ca
translated: And because of recollection.

original: apica vaināśikaḥ sarvasya vastunaḥ kṣaṇikatāmabhyupayannupalabdhurapi kṣaṇikatāmabhyupeyāt /
analyzed: apica vaināśikaḥ sarvasya vastunaḥ kṣaṇikatām abhyupayan upalabdhuḥ api kṣaṇikatām abhyupeyāt
translated: Moreover, the annihilationist, accepting the momentariness of all things, would have to accept the momentariness of the perceiver as well.

analyzed: na ca sā saṃbhavati
translated: But that is not possible.

analyzed: anusmṛteḥ anubhavam upalabdhim anūtpadyamānam smaraṇam eva anusmṛtiḥ
translated: Because of recollection. Recollection is the memory that arises following the experience, the perception.

analyzed: sā ca upalabdhi eka kartṛkā satī saṃbhavati
translated: And that is possible only when it has the same agent as the perception.

analyzed: puruṣa antara upalabdhi viṣaye puruṣa antarasya smṛti adarśanāt
translated: Because memory is not seen in one person with regard to the object of perception of another person.

original: kathaṃ hyahamado 'drākṣamidaṃ paśyāmīti ca pūrvottaradarśinyekasminnasati pratyayaḥ syāt /
analyzed: katham hi aham adaḥ drākṣam idam paśyāmi iti ca pūrva uttara darśini ekasmin asati pratyayaḥ syāt
translated: For how could there be the idea I saw this before and I see this now if there were not one who sees both before and after?

original: apica darśanasmaraṇayoḥ kartaryekasminpratyakṣaḥ pratyabhijñāpratyayaḥ sarvasya lokasya prasiddho 'hamado 'drākṣamidaṃ paśyāmīti /
analyzed: api ca darśana smaraṇayoḥ kartari ekasmin pratyakṣaḥ pratyabhijñā pratyayaḥ sarvasya lokasya prasiddhaḥ ham adaḥ drākṣam idam paśyāmi iti
translated: Moreover, in the case of perception and memory, the subject is the same, as is well-known to all people, as is evident from the cognition of recognition, 'I saw that, I see this'.

original: yadi hi tayorbhinnaḥ kartā syāttato 'haṃ smārāmyadrākṣīdanya iti pratīyāt /
analyzed: yadi hi tayoḥ bhinnaḥ kartā syāt tatas ham smārāmi adrākṣīt anyaḥ iti pratīyāt
translated: If the subject were different in the two cases, then one would cognize, 'I remember, but someone else saw'.

analyzed: na tu evam pratyeti kaścid
translated: But no one cognizes in this way.

analyzed: yatra evam pratyayaḥ tatra darśana smaraṇayoḥ bhinnam eva kartāram sarva lokaḥ vagacchati
translated: Where there is such a cognition, all people understand that the subject is different in the two cases of perception and memory.

analyzed: smarāmi aham asau adaḥ drākṣīt iti
translated: 'I remember, but he saw.'

analyzed: iha tu aham adaḥ drākṣam iti darśana smaraṇayoḥ u pi ātmānam eva ekam kartāram avagacchati
translated: But here, even the annihilationist understands himself alone as the subject in the two cases of perception and memory, 'I saw that, I see this'.

original: na nāhamityātmano darśanaṃ nirvṛttaṃ nihnute yathāgniranuṣṇo 'prakāśa iti vā /
analyzed: na na aham iti ātmanaḥ darśanam nirvṛttam nihnute yathā agniḥ an uṣṇaḥ prakāśaḥ iti vā
translated: He does not deny the perception of the self as 'I', just as one does not say 'fire is not hot, not illuminating'.

original: tatraivaṃ satyekasya darśanasmaraṇalakṣaṇadvayasaṃbandhe kṣaṇikatvābhyupagamahāniraparihāryā vaināśikasya syāt /
analyzed: tatra evam sati ekasya darśana smaraṇa lakṣaṇa dvaya saṃbandhe kṣaṇika tva abhyupagama hāniḥ aparihāryā vaināśikasya syāt
translated: In that case, for the annihilationist, who accepts momentariness, the undesirable consequence of abandoning that very doctrine would be unavoidable, if one thing were related to two things, perception and memory, in the way described.

analyzed: tathā anantaram anantarām ātmanaḥ eva pratipattim pratyabhijānan eka kartṛ kāma uttamāt ucchvāsāt atītāḥ ca
translated: Similarly, immediately after that, recognizing the very same cognition of himself, desiring a single agent from the best exhalation, and recollecting the past

original: pratipattīrā janmana ātmaikakartṛkāḥ pratisaṃdadhānaḥ kathaṃ kṣaṇabhaṅgavādī vaināśiko
analyzed: pratipat tīrāḥ janmanaḥ ātma eka kartṛkāḥ pratisaṃdadhānaḥ katham kṣaṇa bhaṅga vādī vaināśikaḥ
translated: cognitions from birth as having the self as the single agent, how can the annihilationist who advocates momentariness

analyzed: na apapeta sa yadi brūyāt sādṛśyāt etat samapatsyate iti
translated: not be refuted? If he were to say that this would be accomplished by similarity,

analyzed: tam pratibrūyāt
translated: he should be replied to as follows.

analyzed: tena idam sadṛśam iti dvaya āyatta tvāt sādṛśyasya
translated: Because similarity depends on two things, saying this is similar to that.

analyzed: kṣaṇabhaṅga vādinaḥ sadṛśayoḥ dvayoḥ vastunoḥ grahītuḥ ekasya abhāvāt
translated: For the proponent of momentariness, there is no single apprehender of two similar things.

analyzed: sādṛśya nimittam pratisaṃdhānam iti mithyā pralāpaḥ eva syāt
translated: Therefore, the recollection based on similarity would be mere false talk.

analyzed: syāt ced pūrva uttarayoḥ kṣaṇayoḥ sādṛśyasya grahītā ekaḥ
translated: If it were said that there is a single apprehender of the similarity between the prior and subsequent moments,

original: tathāsatyekasya pīḍyeta /🔽tenedaṃ sadṛśamiti pratyayāntaramevedaṃ na pūrvottarakṣaṇadvayagrahaṇanimittamiticet / na /
analyzed: tathā asati ekasya pīḍyeta  tena idam sadṛśam iti pratyaya antaram eva idam na pūrva uttara kṣaṇa dvaya grahaṇa nimittam iti ced na
translated: then in that case, one would be contradicted.

analyzed: tena idam iti
translated: If it is said that this is a different cognition, not based on the apprehension of the pair of prior and subsequent moments, saying this is similar to that, no.

analyzed: bhinna padārtha upādānāt
translated: Because of the inclusion of different word meanings in this is similar to that.

original: pratyayāntarameva cetsādṛśyaviṣayaṃ syāttenedaṃ sadṛśamiti vākyaprayogo 'narthakaḥ syāt /
analyzed: pratyaya antaram eva ced sādṛśya viṣayam syāt tena idam sadṛśam iti vākya prayogaḥ narthakaḥ syāt
translated: If, on the other hand, it were a different cognition, having similarity as its object, then the use of the sentence This is similar to that would be meaningless.

original: sādṛśyamityeva prayogaḥ prāpnuyāt /🔽yadā hi lokaprasiddhaḥ padārthaḥ parīkṣakairna parigṛhyate tadā svapakṣasiddhiḥ parapakṣadoṣo vobhayamapyucyamānaṃ parīkṣakāṇāmātmanaśca yathārthatvena
analyzed: sādṛśyam iti eva prayogaḥ prāpnuyāt  yadā hi loka prasiddhaḥ padārthaḥ parīkṣakaiḥ na parigṛhyate tadā sva pakṣa siddhiḥ para pakṣa doṣaḥ vā ubhayam api ucyamānam parīkṣakāṇām ātmanaḥ ca yathārtha tvena
translated: The usage should be Similarity alone.🔽When a well-known object in the world is not accepted by the investigators, then the establishment of one's own position and the fault of the opponent's position, both when stated, do not properly

analyzed: na buddhi saṃtānam ārohati
translated: enter the mind-stream of the investigators and oneself.

analyzed: evam eva eṣa ṛthaḥ iti niścitam yat tat eva vaktavyam
translated: It should be stated that this is the meaning just as it is.

analyzed: tatas bahu pralāpi tvam ātmanaḥ kevalam prakhyāpayet
translated: Anything else stated would only proclaim one's own excessive prattle.

analyzed: na ca ayam sādṛśyāt saṃvyavahāraḥ yuktaḥ
translated: And this usage through similarity is not appropriate.

analyzed: tad bhāva avagamāt tad sadṛśa bhāva anavagamāt ca
translated: Because of the ascertainment of its existence and the non-ascertainment of the existence of what is similar to it.

original: bhavedapi kadācidbāhyavastuni vipralambhasaṃbhavāttadevedaṃ syāttatsadṛśaṃ veti saṃdehaḥ /
analyzed: bhavet api kadācid bāhya vastuni vipralambha saṃbhavāt tat eva idam syāt tat sadṛśam vā iti saṃdehaḥ
translated: It might happen that due to the possibility of deception regarding an external object, there would be doubt as to whether this is that itself or similar to that.

original: upalabdhari tu saṃdeho 'pi na kadācidbhavati sa evāhaṃ syāṃ tatsadṛśo veti /
analyzed: upalabdhari tu na kadācid bhavati saḥ eva aham syām tad sadṛśaḥ vā iti
translated: But in the case of the perceiver, doubt never arises as to whether one is that or similar to that.

original: ya evāhaṃpūrvedyuradrākṣaṃ sa evāhamadya smarāmīti niścitatadbhāvopalambhāt /
analyzed: yaḥ eva aham pūrvedyus adrākṣam saḥ eva aham adya smarāmi iti niścita tad bhāva upalambhāt
translated: Because the definite cognition of the same thing is produced by the thought, ‘I who saw it yesterday, I remember it today.’

analyzed: tasmāt api anupapannaḥ vaināśika samayaḥ
translated: Therefore, the doctrine of the annihilationists is not logically possible.

analyzed: na asataḥ dṛṣṭa tvāt  /
translated: Because non-existence is not seen.

analyzed: itas ca anupapannaḥ vaināśika samayaḥ
translated: And for this reason also, the doctrine of the annihilationists is not logically possible.

analyzed: yatas sthiram anuyāyi kāraṇam an abhyupagacchatām abhāvāt bhāva utpattiḥ iti etat āpadyate
translated: For those who do not accept a permanent, continuous cause, it follows that existence arises from non-existence.

analyzed: darśayanti ca abhāvāt bhāva utpattim na an upamṛdya prādurbhāvāt iti
translated: And they show that existence arises from non-existence, saying, ‘Because there is no manifestation without destruction.’

analyzed: vinaṣṭāt hi kila bījāt aṅ kuraḥ utpadyate
