translated: For indeed, the sprout is produced from a destroyed seed.

analyzed: tathā vinaṣṭāt kṣīrāt dadhi
translated: Similarly, curd from destroyed milk.

analyzed: mṛd piṇḍāt ca ghaṭaḥ
translated: And a pot from a lump of clay.

analyzed: kūṭastāt ced kāraṇāt kāryam utpadyeta aviśeṣāt sarvam sarvatas utpadyeta
translated: If an effect were produced from a destroyed cause, then everything would be produced from everything, because there would be no distinction.

analyzed: tasmāt abhāva grastebhyaḥ bīja ādibhyaḥ kura ādīnām utpadyamāna tvāt abhāvāt bhāva utpattiḥ iti manyante
translated: Therefore, they think that existence arises from non-existence, because sprouts and so on are produced from seeds and so on that are seized by non-existence.

analyzed: tatra idam ucyate na asataḥ dṛṣṭa tvāt iti
translated: To that, this is said: ‘Because non-existence is not seen.’

analyzed: na abhāvāt bhāvaḥ utpadyate
translated: Existence is not produced from non-existence.

analyzed: yadi abhāvāt bhāvaḥ utpadyeta abhāva tva aviśeṣāt kāraṇa viśeṣa abhyupagamaḥ narthakaḥ syāt
translated: If an existent thing were produced from a non-existent thing, then, because of the non-distinction of non-existence, the acceptance of a particular cause would be meaningless.

original: nahi bījādīnāmupamṛditānāṃ yo 'bhāvastasyābhāvasya śaśaviṣāṇādīnāṃ ca niḥsvabhāvatvāviśeṣādabhāvatve kaścidviśeṣo 'sti /🔽yena bījādevāṅ kuro jāyate kṣīrādeva dadhītyevañjātīyakaḥ kāraṇiśeṣaṇādibhyupagamor'thavānsyāt /
analyzed: nahi bīja ādīnām upamṛditānām yaḥ bhāvaḥ tasya abhāvasya śaśaviṣāṇa ādīnām ca niḥsvabhāva tva aviśeṣāt abhāva tve kaścid viśeṣaḥ sti  yena bījāt eva aṅ kuraḥ jāyate kṣīrāt eva dadhi iti evañjātīyakaḥ kāraṇi śeṣaṇa āt ibhyupagama ūrthavān syāt
translated: For there is no distinction in the non-existence of seeds etc. that have been destroyed, and the non-existence of the horns of a rabbit, because of the non-distinction of their naturelessness.🔽By what [distinction] would the acceptance of a particular cause, such as 'only a sprout is produced from a seed', 'only curd is produced from milk', be meaningful?

original: nirviśeṣasya tvabhāvasya kāraṇatvābhyupagame śaśaviṣāṇādibhyo 'pyaṅ kurādayo jāyeran /
analyzed: nirviśeṣasya tu abhāvasya kāraṇa tva abhyupagame śaśaviṣāṇa ādibhyaḥ pi aṅ kura ādayaḥ jāyeran
translated: But if the non-distinction of non-existence is accepted as the cause, then sprouts etc. would be produced even from the horns of a rabbit.

analyzed: na ca evam dṛśyate
translated: And it is not seen that way.

original: yadi punarabhāvasyāpi viśeṣo 'bhyupagamyetotpalādīnāmiva nīlatvādistato viśeṣavattvādevābhāvasya bhāvatvamutpalādivatprasajyeta /
analyzed: yadi punar abhāvasya api viśeṣaḥ bhyupagamyeta utpala ādīnām iva nīla tva ādiḥ tatas viśeṣavat tvāt eva abhāvasya bhāva tvam utpala ādi vat prasajyeta
translated: If, on the other hand, a distinction in non-existence is accepted, like blueness etc. in lotuses etc., then because of having a distinction, non-existence would be a thing, like a lotus etc.

analyzed: na api abhāvaḥ kasyacid utpatti hetuḥ syāt
translated: Nor would non-existence be the cause of the production of anything.

analyzed: abhāva tvāt eva
translated: Because of being non-existence itself.

analyzed: śaśaviṣāṇa ādi vat
translated: Like the horns of a rabbit.

analyzed: ābhāvāt ca bhāva utpattau abhāva anvitam eva sarvam kāryam syāt
translated: And if an existent thing were produced from non-existence, then the entire effect would be connected with non-existence.

analyzed: na ca evam dṛśyate
translated: And it is not seen that way.

original: sarvasya ca vastunaḥ svena svena rūpeṇa bhāvātmanaivopalabhyamānatvāt /
analyzed: sarvasya ca vastunaḥ svena svena rūpeṇa bhāva ātmanā eva upalabhyamāna tvāt
translated: And because every object is perceived as having the nature of its own form.

analyzed: na ca mṛdā anvitāḥ śarāva ādayaḥ bhāvaḥ tantu ādi vikārāḥ kenacid abhyupagamyante
translated: And no one accepts that such things as pots, which contain clay, are the modifications of threads, etc.

analyzed: mṛd vikārān eva tu mṛdā anvitān bhāvān lokaḥ pratyeti
translated: But people think that things which contain clay are modifications of clay.

analyzed: yat tu uktam svarūpa upamardam antareṇa kasyacid kūṭasthasya vastunaḥ kāraṇa tvām upapatteḥ abhāvāt bhāva utpattiḥ bhavitum arhati iti
translated: But it was said that since it is not possible for any immutable substance to be a cause without destroying its own form, existence must be produced.

original: tadduruktam /🔽sthirasvabhāvānāmeva suvarṇādīnāṃ pratyabhijñāyamānānāṃ rucakādikāryakāraṇabhāvadarśanāt /🔽yeṣvapi bījādiṣu svarūpopamarde lakṣyate teṣvarapi nāsāvupamṛdyamānā pūrvāvasthottarāvasthāyāḥ kāraṇamabhyupagamyate /
analyzed: tat duruktam  sthira svabhāvānām eva suvarṇa ādīnām pratyabhijñāyamānānām rucaka ādi kārya kāraṇa bhāva darśanāt  yeṣu api bīja ādiṣu sva rūpa upamarde lakṣyate na asau upamṛdyamānā pūrva avasthā uttara avasthāyāḥ kāraṇam abhyupagamyate
translated: That is a poor statement.🔽Because it is recognized that gold, etc., which have a stable nature, are the cause and effect of such things as ornaments, etc.🔽Even in those cases where the destruction of form is observed in seeds, etc., it is not accepted that what is being destroyed is the cause of the subsequent state.

analyzed: an upamṛdyamānām eva anuyāyinām bīja ādi avayavānām aṅ kura ādi kāraṇa bhāva abhyupagamāt
translated: Because it is accepted that the continuing parts of seeds, etc., which are not being destroyed, are the cause of sprouts, etc.

analyzed: tasmāt asadbhyaḥ śaśaviṣāṇa ādibhyaḥ sat utpatti adarśanāt sadbhyaḥ ca suvarṇa ādibhyaḥ sat utpatti darśanāt anupapannaḥ yama bhāvāt bhāva utpatti abhyupagamaḥ
translated: Therefore, since the origination of an existent from a non-existent, such as a hare's horn, is not seen, and the origination of an existent from an existent, such as gold, is seen, this acceptance of the origination of an existent from a non-existent is illogical.

analyzed: api ca caturbhiḥ citta caittāḥ utpadyante
translated: Moreover, mind and mental factors arise from four [conditions].

original: paramāṇubhyaśca bhūtabhautikalakṣaṇaḥ samudāya utpadyata ityabhyupagamya punarabhāvādbhāvotpattiṃ kalpayadbhirabhyupagatamapahnuvānairvaināśikaiḥ
analyzed: paramāṇubhyaḥ ca bhūta bhautika lakṣaṇaḥ samudāyaḥ utpadyate iti abhyupagamya punar abhāvāt bhāva utpattim kalpayadbhiḥ abhyupagatam apahnuvānaiḥ vaināśikaiḥ
translated: Accepting that a collection characterized by elements and derivatives arises from atoms, and then imagining the origination of an existent from a non-existent, the nihilists, by denying what is accepted,

analyzed: sarvaḥ lokaḥ ākulīkriyate  /
translated: make the whole world confused.

analyzed: udāsīnānām api ca evam siddhiḥ
translated: And in this way, even the neutral ones are established.

analyzed: yadi ca abhāvāt bhāva utpattiḥ abhyupagamyeta
translated: And if the origination of an existent from a non-existent were accepted,

analyzed: evaṃsati udāsīnānām anīhamānānām api janānām abhimata siddhiḥ syāt
translated: in that case, even for the neutral ones who do not strive, the accomplishment of what is desired would occur.

analyzed: abhāvasya sulabha tvāt  kṛṣīvalasya kṣetra karmaṇi aprayatamānasya api sasya niṣpattiḥ syāt
translated: Because a non-existent is easy to obtain.🔽Even for a farmer who does not exert himself in field work, the harvest would be accomplished.

analyzed: kulālasya ca mṛd saṃskriyāyām aprayatamānasya api amatra utpattiḥ
translated: And for a potter who does not exert himself in shaping the clay, the production of a pot would occur.

original: tantuvāyasyāpi tantūnatanvānasyāpi tanvānasyeva vastralābhaḥ /🔽svargāpavargayośca na kaścitkathañcitsamīheta /
analyzed: tantuvāyasya api tantūn a tanvānasya api tanvānasya iva vastra lābhaḥ  svarga apavargayoḥ ca na kaścid kathañcid samīheta
translated: Even for a weaver who is weaving threads, there is gain of cloth, as if he were weaving.🔽And no one could ever desire heaven or liberation in any way.

analyzed: na ca etat yujyate bhyupagamyate vā kenacid
translated: And this is not accepted by anyone as reasonable.

analyzed: tasmāt api anupapannaḥ yama bhāvāt bhāva utpatti abhyupagamaḥ
translated: Therefore, this acceptance of the origination of existence from non-existence is also illogical.

analyzed: an īhamānānām prayatna śūnyānām
translated: Those who are not making an effort, who are devoid of exertion.

analyzed: amatram ghaṭa ādi pātram
translated: A vessel is a pot or other container.

analyzed: abhāva adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on non-existence. Sutra.

analyzed: na abhāvaḥ upalabdheḥ
translated: Not due to the non-apprehension of non-existence.

original: evaṃ bāhyārtavādamāśritya samudāyāprāptyādiṣu dūṣaṇeṣūdbhāviteṣu vijñānavādī bauddha idānīṃ pratyavatiṣṭhite /
analyzed: evam bāhya ārta vādam āśritya samudāya aprāpti ādiṣu dūṣaṇeṣu udbhāviteṣu vijñāna vādī bauddhaḥ idānīm pratyavatiṣṭhite
translated: Thus, when objections such as the non-attainment of the whole have been raised regarding the theory of external objects, the Buddhist who is a proponent of consciousness now responds.

original: keṣāñcitkila bāhye vastunyabhiniveśamālakṣya tadanurodhena bāhyārthavādaprakriyeyaṃ virocitā /
analyzed: keṣāñcid kila bāhye vastuni abhiniveśam ālakṣya tad anurodhena bāhya artha vāda prakriyā iyam virocitā
translated: It seems that, noticing the attachment of some to external things, he has illuminated this theory of external objects in accordance with their approval.

analyzed: na asau sugata abhiprāyaḥ  tasya tu vijñāna eka skandha vādaḥ eva abhipretaḥ
translated: That is not the intention of the Blessed One.🔽But his intention is indeed the doctrine of consciousness alone as the only aggregate.

original: tasmiṃśca vijñānavāde buddhyārūḍhena rūpeṇāntastha eva pramāṇaprameyavyavahāraḥ sarva upapadyate /
analyzed: tasmin ca vijñāna vāde buddhi ārūḍhena rūpeṇa antasthaḥ eva pramāṇa prameya vyavahāraḥ sarvaḥ upapadyate
translated: And in that doctrine of consciousness, all the usage of means of knowledge and objects of knowledge is logically possible only within the mind, in the form that appears there.

analyzed: sati api bāhya ṛthe buddhi āroham antareṇa pramāṇa prameya phala vyavahāra anavatārāt
translated: Even if there is an external object, because without being reflected in the cognition, the usage of means of knowledge, object of knowledge, and result is not possible.

original: kathaṃ punaravagamyate 'ntastha evāyaṃ sarvavyavahāro na vijñānavyatirikto bāhyor'tho 'stīti /
analyzed: katham punar avagamyate eva ayam sarva vyavahāraḥ na vijñāna vyatiriktaḥ asti iti
translated: How is it known that all this usage is only internal, and there is no external object apart from consciousness?

analyzed: tad asaṃbhavāt iti āha
translated: He says it is because it is impossible.

original: sa hi bāhyortho 'bhyupagamyamānaḥ paramāṇavo vā syustatsamūhā vā stambhādayaḥ syuḥ /
analyzed: sa hi bāhyaḥ ṛthaḥ abhyupagamyamānaḥ paramāṇavaḥ vā syuḥ tad samūhāḥ vā stambha ādayaḥ syuḥ
translated: If an external object is accepted, it would either be atoms or collections of atoms like pillars, etc.

original: tatra na tāvatparamāṇavaḥ stambhādipratyayaparicchedyā bhavitumarhanti paramāṇvābhāsajñānānutpatteḥ /
analyzed: tatra na tāvat paramāṇavaḥ stambha ādi pratyaya paricchedyāḥ bhavitum arhanti paramāṇu ābhāsa jñāna anutpatteḥ
translated: Among them, atoms cannot be what is discerned by the cognition of pillars, etc., because the cognition appearing as atoms does not arise.

analyzed: na api tad samūhāḥ stambha ādayaḥ
translated: Nor are collections of atoms like pillars, etc.

analyzed: teṣām paramāṇubhyaḥ nya tva ananya tvābhyām nirūpayitum aśakya tvāt
translated: Because they cannot be defined as different or non-different from atoms.

analyzed: evam jāti ādīn api pratyakṣīta
translated: In the same way, universals, etc. should also be examined by perception.

original: apicānubhāvamātreṇa sādhāraṇātmano jñānasya jāyamānasya yo 'yaṃ prativiṣayaṃ pakṣapātaḥ stambhajñānaṃ kuḍyajñānaṃ ghaṭajñānaṃ paṭajñānamiti /
analyzed: api ca anubhāva mātreṇa sādhāraṇa ātmanaḥ jñānasya jāyamānasya yaḥ yam prati viṣayam pakṣapātaḥ stambha jñānam kuḍya jñānam ghaṭa jñānam paṭa jñānam iti
translated: Moreover, the cognition that arises with a common nature through mere manifestation, this partiality towards each object - the cognition of a pillar, the cognition of a wall, the cognition of a pot, the cognition of a cloth,

analyzed: na asau jñāna gata viśeṣam antareṇa upapadyate iti avaśyam viṣaya sārūpyam jñānasya aṅgīkartavyam
translated: This is not possible without a difference in the cognition. Therefore, the cognition must necessarily be admitted to have the form of the object.

analyzed: aṅgīkṛte ca tasmin viṣaya ākārasya jñānena eva avaruddha tvāt apārthikā bāhya artha sadbhāva kalpanā
translated: And when that is admitted, since the form of the object is restricted by the cognition itself, the postulation of the existence of external objects is pointless.

analyzed: api ca saha upalambha niyamāt abhedaḥ viṣaya vijñānayoḥ āpatati
translated: Moreover, the non-difference of the object and cognition follows from the rule of simultaneous apprehension.

analyzed: nahi anayoḥ ekasya anupalambhe nyasya upalambhaḥ sti
translated: For when one of these two is not apprehended, the other is not apprehended either.

analyzed: na ca etat svabhāva viveke yuktam
translated: And this is not reasonable in the case of different natures.

analyzed: pratibandha kāraṇa abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no cause for restriction.

analyzed: tasmāt api artha abhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, the external object does not exist.

analyzed: svapna ādi vat ca idam draṣṭavyam
translated: And this should be seen as like dreams, etc.

analyzed: yathā hi svapna māyā marīci udaka gandharvanagara ādi pratyayāḥ vinā eva bāhyena arthena grāhya grāhaka ākārāḥ bhavanti
translated: For just as in dreams, illusions, mirages, water, and gandharva cities, etc., cognitions arise in the form of grasped and grasper without any external object,

analyzed: evam jāgarita gocarāḥ api stambha ādi pratyayāḥ bhavitum arhanti iti avagamyate
translated: in the same way, the cognitions of pillars, etc., in the waking state are also capable of arising. This is understood.

analyzed: pratyaya tva aviśeṣāt
translated: Because there is no difference in being a cognition.

analyzed: katham punar asati bāhya arthe pratyaya vaicitryam upapadyate
translated: But how is the variety of cognitions possible in the absence of an external object?

analyzed: vāsanā vaicitryāt iti āha
translated: It is said that it is due to the variety of impressions.

original: anādau hi saṃsāre bījāṅ kuravadvijñānānāṃ vāsanānāṃ cānyonyanimittanaimittikabhāvena vaicitryaṃ na vipratiṣidhyate /
analyzed: anādau hi saṃsāre bīja aṅ kura vat vijñānānām vāsanānām ca anyonya nimitta naimittika bhāvena vaicitryam na vipratiṣidhyate
translated: For in beginningless saṃsāra, the diversity of cognitions and impressions is not contradicted as being mutually cause and effect, like a seed and a sprout.

analyzed: api ca anvaya vyatirekābhyām vāsanā nimittam eva jñāna vaicitryam iti avagamyate
translated: Moreover, it is understood that the diversity of cognitions is caused by impressions alone, by positive and negative concomitance.

analyzed: svapna ādiṣu antareṇa api artham vāsanā nimittasya jñāna vaicitryasya ubhābhyām api āvābhyām abhyupagamyamāna tvāt
translated: Because in dreams and so on, the diversity of cognitions caused by impressions is accepted by both of us, even without an external object.

analyzed: antareṇa tu vāsanām artha nimittasya jñāna vaicitryasya mayā an abhyupagamyamāna tvāt
translated: But the diversity of cognitions caused by an external object without impressions is not accepted by me.

analyzed: tasmāt api abhāvaḥ bāhya arthasya iti
translated: Therefore, the external object does not exist.

analyzed: evam prāpte brūmaḥ na abhāvaḥ upalabdheḥ iti
translated: When this is the case, we say: Not the non-existence of the object, because of perception.

analyzed: na khalu abhāvaḥ bāhyasya arthasya adhyavasātum śakyate
translated: Indeed, the non-existence of the external object cannot be ascertained.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

analyzed: upalabdheḥ
translated: Because of perception.

original: upalabhyate hi pratipratyayaṃ bāhyor'thaḥ stambhaḥ kuḍyaṃ ghaṭaḥ paṭa iti /
analyzed: upalabhyate hi prati pratyayam bāhyaḥ ṛthaḥ stambhaḥ kuḍyam ghaṭaḥ paṭaḥ iti
translated: For the external object is perceived in each case, as a pillar, a wall, a pot, a cloth.

analyzed: na ca upalabhyamānasya eva abhāvaḥ bhavitum arhati
translated: And what is perceived cannot be non-existent.

original: yathā hi kaścidbhuñjāno bhujitasādhyāyāṃ tṛptau svayamanubhūyamānāyāmevaṃ brūyānnāhaṃ bhuñje na vā tṛpyāmīti /
analyzed: yathā hi kaścid bhuñjānaḥ bhujita sādhyāyām tṛptau svayam anubhūyamānāyām evam brūyāt na aham bhuñje na vā tṛpyāmi iti
translated: For example, suppose someone eating were to say, I am not eating, nor am I satisfied, even though satisfaction, which is accomplished by eating, is being experienced by himself.

original: tadvadindriyasaṃnikarṣeṇa svayamupalabhamāna eva bāhyamarthaṃ nāhamupalabhe naca so 'stīti bruvankathamupādeyavacanaḥ syāt /
analyzed: tadvat indriya saṃnikarṣeṇa svayam upalabhamānaḥ eva bāhyam artham na aham upalabhe na ca saḥ sti iti bruvan katham upādeya vacanaḥ syāt
translated: In the same way, if one were to say, I do not perceive the external object at all, nor does it exist, even though it is being perceived by himself through contact with the sense organ, how could his words be accepted?

original: nanu nāhamahaṃ bravīmi na kañcidarthamupalabha iti kiṃ tūpalabdhivyatiriktaṃ nopalabha iti bravīmi /
analyzed: nanu na aham aham bravīmi na kañcid artham upalabhe iti kim tu upalabdhi vyatiriktam na upalabhe iti bravīmi
translated: But I do not say that I do not perceive any object at all. Rather, I say that I do not perceive anything apart from perception.

analyzed: bāḍham evam bravīṣi niraṅ kuśa tvāt te tuṇḍasya
translated: Indeed, you do say this, because your mouth is unrestrained.

analyzed: na tu yakti upetam bravīṣi
translated: But you do not speak what is reasonable.

analyzed: yatas upalabdhi vyatirekaḥ u pi balāt arthasya abhyupagantavyaḥ upalabdheḥ eva
translated: For even the distinction from perception must be accepted as belonging to the object by force of perception itself.

analyzed: nahi kaścid upalabdhim eva stambhaḥ kuḍyam ca iti upalabhate
translated: For no one perceives perception itself as a pillar or a wall.🔽But all worldly people perceive pillars, walls, etc. only as the objects of perception, even when denying them. Those who deny external objects also explain them as external,

original: upalabdhiviṣayatvenaiva tu stambhakuḍyādīnsarve laukikā upalabhante yatpratyācakṣāṇā api bāhyārthameva vyācakṣate yadantarjñeyarūpaṃ tadbahirvadavabhāsata 🔽iti /
analyzed: upalabdhi viṣaya tvena eva tu stambha kuḍya ādīn sarve laukikāḥ upalabhante yat pratyācakṣāṇāḥ api bāhya artham eva vyācakṣate yat antar jñeya rūpam tat bahis vat avabhāsata 🔽iti
translated: saying, That which is the form of the knowable within appears as if external.

original: te 'pi sarvalokaprasiddhāṃ bahiravabhāsamānāṃ saṃvidaṃ pratilabhamānāḥ pratyākhyātukāmāśca bāhyamarthaṃ bahirvadati vatkāraṃ kurvanti /
analyzed: te pi sarva loka prasiddhām bahis avabhāsamānām saṃvidam pratilabhamānāḥ pratyākhyātu kāmāḥ ca bāhyam artham bahis vadati vatkāram kurvanti
translated: They also, who are desirous of denying the external object, though they admit the consciousness which appears as external and is well known to all people, say that it appears as external.

analyzed: itarathā hi kasmāt bahis vadati brūyuḥ
translated: Otherwise, why should they say that it appears as external?

original: nahi viṣṇumitro vandhyāputravadavabhāsata iti kaścidācakṣīta /🔽tasmādyathānubhavaṃ tattvamabhyupagacchadbhirbahirevāvabhāsata iti yuktamabhyupagantuṃ natu bahirvadavabhāsata iti /🔽nanu bāhyārthasyāsaṃbhavādbahirvadavabhāsata ityadhyavasitam /
analyzed: nahi viṣṇu mitraḥ vandhyā putra vat avabhāsate iti kaścid ācakṣīta  tasmāt yathānubhavam tattvam abhyupagacchadbhiḥ bahis eva avabhāsate iti yuktam abhyupagantum na tu bahis vat avabhāsate iti  nanu bāhya arthasya asaṃbhavāt bahis vat avabhāsate iti adhyavasitam
translated: For no one would say that Viṣṇumitra appears like the son of a barren woman.🔽Therefore, those who accept things as they are experienced, it is proper for them to accept that it appears as external, not that it appears as if external.🔽But it has been concluded that it appears as external because the external object is impossible.

original: nāyaṃ sādhuradhyavasāyo yataḥ pramāṇapravṛttyapravṛttipūrvakau saṃbavāsaṃbhavāvavadhāryete na punaḥ saṃbhavāsaṃbhavapūrvike pramāṇapravṛttyapravṛttī
analyzed: na ayam sādhuḥ adhyavasāyaḥ yatas pramāṇa pravṛtti apravṛtti pūrvakau saṃbava asaṃbhavau avadhāryete na punar saṃbhava asaṃbhava pūrvike pramāṇa pravṛtti apravṛttī
translated: This conclusion is not good, because existence and non-existence are determined on the basis of the occurrence and non-occurrence of valid cognition, and not vice versa.

analyzed: yat hi pratyakṣa ādīnām anyatamena api pramāṇena upalabhyate tat saṃbhavati
translated: That which is perceived by any one of the means of valid cognition such as perception, etc. is possible.

original: yattu na kenacidapi pramāṇenopalabhyate tanna saṃbhavati /
analyzed: yat tu na kenacid api pramāṇena upalabhyate tat na saṃbhavati
translated: But that which is not perceived by any means of valid cognition is not possible.

original: iha tu yathāsvaṃ sarvaireva pramāṇairbāhyor'tha upalabhyamānaḥ kathaṃ vyatirekāvyatirekādivikalpairna saṃbhavatītyucyetopalabdhereva /
analyzed: iha tu yathāsvam sarvaiḥ eva pramāṇaiḥ bāhyaḥ ṛthaḥ upalabhyamānaḥ katham vyatireka avyatireka ādi vikalpaiḥ na saṃbhavati iti ucyeta upalabdheḥ eva
translated: But here, the external object being perceived by all the means of valid knowledge in their own way, how can it be said that it is not possible by the alternatives of identity, difference, etc.? Because of perception itself.

analyzed: na ca jñānasya viṣaya sārūpyāt viṣaya nāśaḥ bhavati
translated: And the object is not destroyed by the knowledge taking on the form of the object.

analyzed: asati viṣaye viṣaya sārūpya anupapatteḥ
translated: Because in the absence of the object, the taking on of its form is not possible.

analyzed: bahis upalabdheḥ ca viṣayasya
translated: And because the object is perceived externally.

original: ata eva sahopalambhaniyamo 'pi pratyayaviṣayayorupāyopeyabhāvahetuko nābhedahetuka ityabyupagantavyam /
analyzed: atas eva saha upalambha niyamaḥ pi pratyaya viṣayayoḥ upāya upeya bhāva hetukaḥ na abheda hetukaḥ iti abyupagantavyam
translated: For this very reason, the rule of simultaneous perception should be accepted as being due to the relation of means and object between the cognition and the object, not as being due to non-difference.

original: apica ghaṭajñānaṃ paṭajñānamiti viśeṣaṇayoreva ghaṭapaṭayorbhedo na viśeṣyasya jñānasya /
analyzed: apica ghaṭa jñānam paṭa jñānam iti viśeṣaṇayoḥ eva ghaṭa paṭayoḥ bhedaḥ na viśeṣyasya jñānasya
translated: Moreover, the difference is between the qualified things themselves, the cognition of the pot and the cognition of the cloth, not between the qualified things, the cognition.

original: dvābhyāṃ ca bheda etasya siddho bhavatyekasmācca dvayoḥ /
analyzed: dvābhyām ca bhedaḥ etasya siddhaḥ bhavati ekasmāt ca dvayoḥ
translated: And the difference of this [cognition] is established by both [the pot and the cloth], and by one [the cognition] of the two [the pot and the cloth].

analyzed: tasmāt artha jñānayoḥ bhedaḥ
translated: Therefore, there is a difference between the object and cognition.

analyzed: tathā ghaṭa darśanam ghaṭa smaraṇam iti atra api pratipattavyam
translated: Similarly, it should be understood in the case of 'the seeing of the pot' and 'the remembering of the pot'.

original: atrāpi hi viśeṣyayoreva darśanasmaraṇayorbhedo na viśeṣaṇas ghaṭasya /
analyzed: atra api hi viśeṣyayoḥ eva darśana smaraṇayoḥ bhedaḥ na viśeṣaṇaḥ ghaṭasya
translated: For here also, the difference is between the qualified things themselves, the seeing and the remembering, not between the qualified thing, the pot.

original: yathā kṣīragandhaḥ kṣīrarasa iti viśeṣyayoreva gandharasayorbhedo na viśeṣaṇasya kṣīrasya tadvat /
analyzed: yathā kṣīra gandhaḥ kṣīra rasaḥ iti viśeṣyayoḥ eva gandha rasayoḥ bhedaḥ na viśeṣaṇasya kṣīrasya tadvat
translated: Just as the smell of milk and the taste of milk are different only in the two qualities, smell and taste, not in the qualified milk.

analyzed: apica dvayoḥ vijñānayoḥ pūrva uttara kālayoḥ sva saṃvedanena eva upakṣīṇayoḥ itaretara grāhya grāhaka tva anupapattiḥ
translated: Moreover, the two cognitions, past and future, being exhausted by self-awareness itself, cannot be the apprehended object and apprehending subject of each other.

analyzed: tatas ca vijñāna bheda pratijñā kṣaṇika tva ādi dharma pratijñā sva lakṣaṇa sāmānya lakṣaṇa vāsya vāsaka tva avidyā upaplava sat asat dharma bandha mokṣa ādi pratijñāḥ ca
translated: And therefore, the promise of the difference of consciousness, the promise of momentary nature and other properties, the nature of being the characterized and the characteristic, the bondage and liberation due to the affliction of ignorance and good and bad dharmas, etc.,

analyzed: sva śāstra gatāḥ tāḥ hīyeran
translated: which are found in one's own scriptures, would be lost.

original: kiñcānyat /🔽vijñānaṃ vijñānamityabhyupagacchatā bāhyorthaḥ stambhaḥ kuḍyamityevañjātīyakaḥ tasmānnābhyupagamyata eveti yuktamabhyupagantum /
analyzed: kiñca anyat  vijñānam vijñānam iti abhyupagacchatā bāhyaḥ ṛthaḥ stambhaḥ kuḍyam iti evañjātīyakaḥ tasmāt na abhyupagamyate eva iti yuktam abhyupagantum
translated: And furthermore,🔽one who accepts consciousness as consciousness should rightly accept that an external object such as a pillar or a wall is not accepted in the same way as that [consciousness].

original: atha vijñānaṃ prakāśātmakatvātpradīpavatsvayamevānubhūyate na tathā bāhyo 'pyartha iti cet /
analyzed: atha vijñānam prakāśa ātmaka tvāt pradīpa vat svayam eva anubhūyate na tathā
translated: If it is argued that consciousness is experienced by itself like a lamp because it has the nature of illumination, but an external object is not so [experienced],

analyzed: atyanta viruddhām svātmani kriyām abhyupagacchasi agniḥ ātmānam dahati iti vat
translated: one would be accepting an action upon itself, which is utterly contradictory, like saying fire burns itself.

original: aviruddhaṃ tu lokaprasiddhaṃ svātmavyatiriktena vijñānena bāhyor'thonubhūyata iti necchāsyaho pāṇḍityaṃ mahaddarśitam /
analyzed: aviruddham tu loka prasiddham sva ātma vyatiriktena vijñānena bāhyaḥ ṛthaḥ anubhūyate iti na icchāsi aho pāṇḍityam mahat darśitam
translated: But what is not opposed to common experience is this: that the external object is experienced by a consciousness different from one’s own self. Oh, how great is the learning displayed by him who does not accept this!

analyzed: na ca artha avyatiriktam api vijñānam svayam eva anubhūyate
translated: And consciousness, even though not different from the object, is not itself experienced.

analyzed: sva ātmani kriyā virodhāt eva
translated: Because action with regard to itself is contradictory.

original: nanu vijñānasya svarūpavyatiriktagrāhyatve tadapyanena grāhyaṃ tadapyanyenetyanavasthā prāpnoti /
analyzed: nanu vijñānasya svarūpa vyatirikta grāhya tve tat api anena grāhyam tat api anyena iti anavasthā prāpnoti
translated: If consciousness were to be apprehended by something different from its own form, then that [apprehending consciousness] also would have to be apprehended by something else, and so on ad infinitum.

original: apica pradīpavadavabhāsātmakatvājjñānasya jñānāntaraṃ kalpayataḥ samatvādavabhāsyāvabhāsakabhāvānupapatteḥ kalpanānarthakyamiti /
analyzed: apica pradīpa vat avabhāsa ātmaka tvāt jñānasya jñāna antaram kalpayataḥ sama tvāt avabhāsya avabhāsaka bhāva anupapatteḥ kalpanā ānarthakyam iti
translated: Moreover, if you imagine another consciousness because consciousness, like a lamp, has the nature of illumination, then, since the two are equal, the relation of the illuminated and the illuminator is not possible, and so the imagination is pointless.

analyzed: tat ubhayam api asat
translated: Both of these are false.

analyzed: vijñāna grahaṇa mātre eva vijñāna sākṣiṇaḥ grahaṇa ākāṅkṣā anutpāda ādāna vasta āśaṅkā anupapatteḥ  sākṣi pratyayayoḥ ca svabhāva vaiṣamyāt upalabdhṛ upalabhya bhāva upapatteḥ
translated: Because, in the mere apprehension of consciousness, there is no production of the desire to apprehend the witness of consciousness, so the fear of an infinite regress is not possible.🔽And because of the difference in nature between the witness and the object of cognition, the relation of the apprehender and the apprehended is possible.

analyzed: svayam siddhasya ca sākṣiṇaḥ pratyākhyeya tvāt
translated: And because the self-established witness cannot be denied.🔽Moreover,

analyzed: kiñca anyat
translated: what else?

original: pradīpavadvijñānamavabhāsakāntaranirapekṣaṃ svayameva prathata iti bruvatāpramāṇagamyaṃ vijñānamanavagantṛkamityuktaṃ syāt /
analyzed: pradīpa vat vijñānam avabhāsaka antara nirapekṣam svayam eva prathate iti bruvatā apramāṇa gamyam vijñānam anavagantṛkam iti uktam syāt
translated: By saying that consciousness shines by itself, independently of any other illuminator, like a lamp, you would be saying that consciousness is known by non-perception, i.e., without a knower.

analyzed: śilā ghana madhya stha pradīpa sahasra prathana vat
translated: Like the shining of a thousand lamps in the middle of a rock cave.

analyzed: bāḍham evam
translated: Very well, it is so.

original: anubhavarūpatvāttu vijñānasyeṣṭo naḥ pakṣastvayānujñāyata iti cet / na /
analyzed: anubhava rūpa tvāt tu vijñānasya iṣṭaḥ naḥ pakṣaḥ tvayā anujñāyate iti ced na
translated: If you say that our view is accepted by you because consciousness is of the nature of experience, no.

analyzed: anyasya avagantuḥ cakṣuḥ sādhanasya pradīpa ādi prathana darśanāt
translated: Because we see the shining of a lamp, etc., which is the means of knowledge for another knower.

analyzed: atas vijñānasya api avabhāsya tva aviśeṣāt sati eva anyasmin avagantari prathanam pradīpa vat iti avagamyate
translated: Therefore, because consciousness is not different from being illuminated, it is understood that its shining is like a lamp, only when there is another knower.

original: sākṣiṇo 'vagantuḥ svayaṃsiddhatāmupakṣipatā svayaṃ prathate vijñānamityeṣa eva mama pakṣastvayā vācoyuktyantareṇāśrita iti cet / na /
analyzed: sākṣiṇaḥ vagantuḥ svayam siddha tām upakṣipatā svayam prathate vijñānam iti eṣaḥ eva mama pakṣaḥ tvayā vācoyukti antareṇa āśritaḥ iti ced na
translated: If you argue that the witness, the knower, is self-established, and that you have adopted the view that consciousness shines by itself using different words, no.

analyzed: vijñānasya utpatti pradhvaṃsa aneka tva ādi viśeṣavat tva abhyupagamāt
translated: Because consciousness is accepted as having attributes like origination, destruction, and plurality.

analyzed: atas pradīpa vat vijñānasya api vyatirikta avagamya tvam asmābhiḥ prasādhitam
translated: Therefore, we have established that consciousness, like a lamp, is known by something else.

analyzed: pakṣapātaḥ viṣaya viśeṣa vaiśiṣṭya vyavahāraḥ
translated: Paksapatas is the usage of distinguishing a particular object.

analyzed: avidyā upaplavaḥ vidyā saṃsargaḥ
translated: The disturbance of ignorance is the association with ignorance.

analyzed: vaidharmyāt ca na svapna ādi vat
translated: And because of the difference in properties, it is not like in a dream, etc.

original: yaduktaṃ bāhyārthapalāyinā svapnādipratyayavajijāgaritagocarā api stambhādipratyayā vinaiva bāhyenārthena bhaveyuḥ pratyayatvāviśeṣāditi /
analyzed: yat uktam bāhya artha palāyinā svapna ādi pratyaya vajijāgarita gocarāḥ api stambha ādi pratyayāḥ vinā eva bāhyena arthena bhaveyuḥ pratyaya tva aviśeṣāt iti
translated: What was said by the one who denies external objects - Like the perceptions in a dream, the perceptions in the waking state, such as of a pillar, etc., could occur without an external object, because there is no difference in being a perception.

analyzed: tat prativaktavyam
translated: That should be responded to.

analyzed: atra ucyate na svapna ādi pratyaya vat jāgrat pratyayāḥ bhavitum arhanti
translated: Here it is said: The perceptions in the waking state should not be like the perceptions in a dream, etc.

analyzed: kasmāt  vaidharmyāt
translated: Why?🔽Because of the difference in properties.

analyzed: vaidharmyam hi bhavati svapna jāgaritayoḥ
translated: There is a difference in properties between a dream and the waking state.

analyzed: kim punar vaidharmyam
translated: What, then, is the difference in properties?

original: bādhābādhāviti brūmaḥ /🔽bādhyate hi svapnopalabdhaṃ vastu pratibuddhasya mithyā mayopalabdho mahājanasamāgama iti /
analyzed: bādhā bādhau iti brūmaḥ  bādhyate hi svapna upalabdham vastu pratibuddhasya mithyā mayā upalabdhaḥ mahājana samāgamaḥ iti
translated: We say: obstruction and non-obstruction.🔽For the object perceived in a dream is obstructed by the awakened one, thinking I perceived a great gathering of people falsely.

original: nahyasti mama mahājanasamāgamo nidrālagnaṃ tu me mano babhūva tenaiṣā bhrāntirudbabhūveti /
analyzed: na hi asti mama mahā jana samāgamaḥ nidrā lagnam tu me manaḥ babhūva tena eṣā bhrāntiḥ udbabhūva iti
translated: I do not have a great gathering of people, but my mind was attached to sleep, therefore this error arose.

analyzed: evam māyā ādiṣu api bhavati yatāvidham bādhaḥ
translated: Thus, there is obstruction in various ways in the case of illusions, etc. as well.

original: naivaṃ jāgaritopalabdhaṃ vastu stambhādikaṃ kasyāñcidapyavasthāyāṃ bādhyate /
analyzed: na evam jāgarita upalabdham vastu stambha ādikam kasyāñcid api avasthāyām bādhyate
translated: The object perceived in the waking state, such as a pillar, is never contradicted at any time.

analyzed: apica samṛtiḥ eṣā yat svapna darśanam
translated: Moreover, the perception of a dream is a memory,

analyzed: upalabdhiḥ tu jāgarita darśanam
translated: while the perception in the waking state is a direct perception.

original: smṛtyupalabdhayośca pratyakṣamantaraṃ svayamanubhūyater'thaviprayogasaṃyogātmakamiṣṭaṃ putraṃ smarāmi nopalabha upalabdhumicchāmīti /
analyzed: smṛti upalabdhayoḥ ca pratyakṣam antaram svayam anubhūyate irtha viprayoga saṃyoga ātmakam iṣṭam putram smarāmi na upalabhe upalabdhum icchāmi iti
translated: The difference between memory and perception is experienced by oneself as consisting in the connection and disconnection with the object. One says, I remember my son, who is dear to me, but I do not perceive him; I wish to perceive him.

original: tatraivaṃsati na śakyate vaktuṃ mithyā jāgaritopalabdhirūpalabdhitvātsvapnopalabdhivadityubhayorantaraṃ svayamanubhavatā /
analyzed: tatra evam sati na śakyate vaktum mithyā jāgarita upalabdhiḥ ūpalabdhi tvāt svapna upalabdhi vat iti ubhayoḥ antaram svayam anubhavatā
translated: In this case, it cannot be said that the perception in the waking state is false, because it is a perception, like the perception in a dream, for one who experiences the difference between the two.

analyzed: na ca sva anubhava apalāpaḥ prājña mānibhiḥ yuktaḥ kartum
translated: And it is not proper for the wise to deny their own experience.

analyzed: api ca anubhava virodha prasaṅgāt jāgarita pratyayānām svatas nirālambana tām vaktum aśaknuvatā svapna pratyaya sādharmyāt vaktum iṣyate
translated: Moreover, because it would lead to the contradiction of experience, one who is unable to say that the perceptions in the waking state are inherently without an external object, wishes to say so by the similarity of the perceptions in a dream.

original: naca yo yasya svato dharmo na saṃbhavati so 'nyasya sādharmyāttasya saṃbhaviṣyati /
analyzed: na ca yaḥ yasya svatas dharmaḥ na saṃbhavati saḥ nyasya sādharmyāt tasya saṃbhaviṣyati
translated: And what cannot be a property of something by itself cannot be made to be so by the similarity of another.

analyzed: na hi agniḥ uṣṇaḥ nubhūyamānaḥ udaka sādharmyāt śītaḥ bhaviṣyati
translated: For fire, when experienced as hot, will not become cold due to the similarity of water.

analyzed: darśitam tu vaidharmyam svapna jāgaritayoḥ
translated: But the dissimilarity between sleep and waking has been shown.

original: FN / nidrālagnimiti karaṇadoṣābhidhānam /🔽saṃskāramātrajaṃ hi vijñānaṃ samṛtiḥ /
analyzed: nidrā lagnim iti karaṇa doṣa abhidhānam  saṃskāra mātra jam hi vijñānam samṛtiḥ
translated: The statement affected by sleep indicates a fault of the instrument.🔽For memory is consciousness produced merely by impressions.
Experience is the apprehension produced by a means of valid knowledge.

original: na bhāvo 'nupalabdheḥ / / / /🔽yadapyuktaṃ vināpyarthena jñānavaicitryaṃ vāsanāvaicitryādevāvakalpyata iti /
analyzed: na bhāvaḥ n upalabdheḥ  yat api uktam vinā api arthena jñāna vaicitryam vāsanā vaicitryāt eva avakalpyate iti
translated: An entity does not exist because it is not apprehended.

analyzed: tat prativaktavyam
translated: What was said - that the variety of cognitions is possible even without external objects, just from the variety of impressions - that should be refuted.

analyzed: atrā ucyate na bhāvaḥ vāsanānām upapadyeta tvad pakṣe n upalabdheḥ bāhyānām arthānām
translated: In response to that, it is said: Impressions would not be possible in your view, because external objects are not apprehended.

original: arthopalabdhinimittā hi pratyarthaṃ nānārūpā vāsanā bhavanti /
analyzed: artha upalabdhi nimittāḥ hi pratyartham nānā rūpāḥ vāsanāḥ bhavanti
translated: For impressions, which have different forms for each object, arise as the cause for the perception of objects.

original: anupalabhyamāneṣu tvartheṣu kiṃnimittā vicitrā vāsanā bhaveyuḥ /
analyzed: an upalabhyamāneṣu tu artheṣu kiṃnimittāḥ vicitrāḥ vāsanāḥ bhaveyuḥ
translated: But when objects are not perceived, what would be the cause for various impressions to arise?

analyzed: anādi tve pi andha paraṃparā nyāyena apratiṣṭhā evā anavasthā vyavahāra lopinī syāt na abhiprāya siddhiḥ
translated: Even if [impressions] are beginningless, like the analogy of a series of blind people, the regress would be unestablished and would destroy worldly conventions, not establish the intended meaning.

analyzed: yau api anya vyatirekau artha apalāpinā upanyastau vāsanā nimittam eva idam jñāna jātam na artha nimittam iti
translated: Even the other two reasons, non-apprehension of the object and the production of cognition even without the object, which are stated by the opponent to prove that this group of cognitions has only impressions as its cause, not the object,

analyzed: tau api evaṃsati pratyuktau draṣṭavyau
translated: should be seen as refuted in the same way.

analyzed: vinā artha upalabdhyā vāsanā anupapatteḥ
translated: Because impressions are not possible without the apprehension of the object.🔽Moreover, even without accepting the production of impressions without the apprehension of the object, the existence of the object is established by the two reasons of positive and negative concomitance,

analyzed: apica vinā api vāsanābhiḥ artha upalabdhi upagamāt vinā tu artha upalabdhyā vāsanā utpatti anabhyupagamāt artha sadbhāvam eva anvaya vyatirekau api pratiṣṭhāpayataḥ
translated: because the apprehension of the object is accepted even without impressions.

analyzed: apica vāsanāḥ nāma saṃskāra viśeṣāḥ
translated: Moreover, impressions are a particular kind of latent impression.

analyzed: saṃskārāḥ ca na āśrayam antareṇa avakalpyante
translated: And latent impressions are not possible without a substratum,

analyzed: evam loke dṛṣṭa tvāt
translated: because they are seen to be so in the world.

analyzed: na ca tava vāsanā āśrayaḥ kaścid asti pramāṇataḥ n upalabdheḥ
translated: And for you, there is no substratum of impressions, because it is not apprehended by any means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: bhāvaḥ utpattiḥ sattā vā
translated: The existence is either origination or being.

original: kṣaṇikatvāc ca / / / /🔽yadapyālayavijñānaṃ nāma vāsanāśrayatvena parikalpitaṃ tadapi kṣaṇikatvābhyupagamādanavasthitasvarūpaṃ satpravṛttivijñānavanna vāsanānāmadhikaraṇaṃ
analyzed: kṣaṇika tvāt ca  yat api ālayavijñānam nāma vāsanā āśraya tvena parikalpitam tat api kṣaṇika tva abhyupagamāt anavasthita svarūpam sat pravṛtti vijñāna vat na vāsanānām adhikaraṇam
translated: And because of momentariness.

analyzed: bhavitum arhati
translated: And that which is imagined as the substratum of impressions, called the store-consciousness, that also, because it is accepted as momentary, being of an unstable nature like the active consciousness, is not fit to be the substratum of impressions.

analyzed: nahi kāla traya saṃbandhini ekasmin anvayini asati kūṭasthe vā sarva artha darśini
translated: For, in the absence of a single, all-pervading, unchanging, and all-knowing entity connected with the three times,

analyzed: deśa kāla nimitta apekṣa vāsanā ādhāna smṛti pratisaṃdhāna ādi vyavahāraḥ saṃbhavati
translated: For without something permanent, something all-pervading, something that sees all things, there can be no such notions as the connection of the three times, the laying of impressions in dependence on place, time, and occasion, the reuniting of memory, etc.

analyzed: sthira svarūpa tve tu ālayavijñānasya siddhānta hāniḥ
translated: But if the ālaya-vijñāna has a stable nature, then the doctrine of the Yogācāras is undermined.

original: apica vijñānavāde 'pi kṣaṇikatvābhyupagamasya samānatvādyāni bāhyārthavāde kṣaṇikatvanibandhanāni
analyzed: apica vijñāna vāde pi kṣaṇikatva abhyupagamasya samāna tva ādyāni bāhya artha vāde kṣaṇikatva nibandhanāni
translated: Moreover, in the doctrine of consciousness, the acceptance of momentariness is the same, so the objections raised in the doctrine of external objects,

analyzed: dūṣaṇāni udbhāvitāni uttara utpāde ca pūrva nirodhāt iti evamādīni tāni iha api anusaṃdhātavyāni
translated: such as Because the later arises while the previous ceases, should be applied here as well.

original: evametau dvāvapi vaināśikapakṣau nirākṛtau bāhyārthavādipakṣo vijñānavādipakṣaśca /
analyzed: evam etau dvau api vaināśika pakṣau nirākṛtau bāhya artha vādi pakṣaḥ vijñāna vādi pakṣaḥ ca
translated: Thus, both of these nihilistic positions are refuted, the position of external objects and the position of consciousness.

original: śūnyavādipakṣastu sarvapramāṇavipratiṣiddha iti tannirākaraṇāya nādaraḥ kriyate /
analyzed: śūnyavādi pakṣaḥ tu sarva pramāṇa vipratiṣiddhaḥ iti tad nirākaraṇāya na ādaraḥ kriyate
translated: But the position of the proponents of emptiness is contradicted by all means of valid cognition, so no effort is made to refute it.

analyzed: na hi ayam sarva pramāṇa prasiddhaḥ lokavyavahāraḥ nyat tattvam an adhigamya śakyate pahnotum apavāda abhāvaḥ utsarga prasiddheḥ  /
translated: For this well-known worldly practice, established by all means of valid cognition, cannot be denied without understanding another truth, because of the absence of refutation and the establishment of the general rule.

original: FN / nādaraḥ kriyate sūtrāntarāṇi na racyanta etānyevāvṛttyā yojayante /
analyzed: na ādaraḥ kriyate sūtrāntarāṇi na racyante etāni eva āvṛttyā yojayante
translated: No regard is paid to other sūtras; they are not composed; these very [sūtras] are repeated and applied.

analyzed: sarvathā anupapatteḥ ca
translated: And also because of impossibility in every way.

analyzed: kim bahunā
translated: What more needs to be said?

original: sarvaprakāreṇa yathāyathāyaṃ vaināśikasamaya upapattimattvāya parīkṣyate tathātathā sikatākūpavadvidīryata eva /
analyzed: sarva prakāreṇa yathā yathā ayam vaināśika samayaḥ upapattimat tvāya parīkṣyate tathā tathā sikatā kūpa vat vidīryate eva
translated: In whatever way this doctrine of annihilation is examined for the sake of having a sound basis, in that very way it crumbles like sand in a hole.

analyzed: na kāñcid api atra upapattim paśyāmaḥ
translated: We do not see any sound basis here at all.

analyzed: atas ca anupapannaḥ vaināśika tantra vyavahāraḥ
translated: And therefore the usage of the doctrine of annihilation is unsound.

analyzed: apica bāhya artha vijñāna śūnya vāda trayam itaretara viruddham upadiśatā sugatena spaṣṭīkṛtam ātmanaḥ saṃbaddha pralāpi tvam
translated: Moreover, by teaching the three doctrines of the emptiness of external objects, consciousness, and both, which are mutually contradictory, the Sugata has clearly made known his own incoherent prattle.

original: pradveṣo vā prajāsu viruddhārthapratipattyā vimuhyeyurimāḥ prajā iti /
analyzed: pradveṣaḥ vā prajāsu viruddha artha pratipattyā vimuhyeyuḥ imāḥ prajāḥ iti
translated: Or he hates the people, thinking By learning contradictory meanings, these people will be confused.

analyzed: sarvathā api an ādaraṇīyaḥ yam sugata samayaḥ śreyaskāmaiḥ iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: The intention is that this doctrine of the Sugata should in no way be respected by those who desire what is good.

original: FN / vedabāhyā atra prajā grāhyāḥ /🔽ekasminnasaṃbhavādhikaraṇam / sū /
analyzed: veda bāhyāḥ atra prajāḥ grāhyāḥ  ekasmin asaṃbhava adhikaraṇam sū
translated: Here the people who are outside the Vedas should be understood.🔽The section on the impossibility of one. The sūtra.

analyzed: na ekasmin asaṃbhavāt  /
translated: Not in one, because of impossibility.

analyzed: nirastaḥ sugata samayaḥ
translated: The doctrine of the Sugata is refuted.

analyzed: vivasana samayaḥ idānīm nirasyate
translated: Now the time of nakedness is rejected.

original: sapta caiṣāṃ padārthāḥ saṃmatā jīvājīvāsravasaṃvaranirjarabandhamokṣā nāma /
analyzed: sapta ca eṣām padārthāḥ saṃmatāḥ jīva ajīva āsrava saṃvara nirjara bandha mokṣāḥ nāma
translated: And their seven topics are accepted: the living soul, the non-living, the inflow, the restraint, the purification, the bondage, and liberation.

analyzed: saṃkṣepataḥ tu dvau eva padārthau jīva ajīva ākhyau
translated: But in brief, there are only two topics, called the living soul and the non-living.

analyzed: yathāyogam tayoḥ eva itara antarbhāvāt iti manyante
translated: They consider that the others are included in these two, as appropriate.

original: tayorimamaparaṃ prapañcamācakṣate pañcāstikāyā nāma jīvāstikāyaḥ pudgalāstikāyo dharmāstikāyo 'dharmāstikāya ākāśāstikāyaśceti /
analyzed: tayoḥ imam aparam prapañcam ācakṣate pañca astikāyāḥ nāma jīva astikāyaḥ pudgala astikāyaḥ dharma astikāyaḥ dharma astikāyaḥ ākāśa astikāyaḥ ca iti
translated: They describe another elaboration of these two, called the five substances: the substance of the living soul, the substance of the individual, the substance of dharma, the substance of adharma, and the substance of space.

analyzed: sarveṣām api eṣām avāntara prabhedān bahuvidhān sva samaya parikalpitān varṇayanti
translated: They also describe many different subdivisions of all of these, imagined in their own doctrines.

original: sarvatra cemaṃ saptabhaṅgīnayaṃ nāma nyāyamavatārayanti /🔽syādasti / syānnāsti /
analyzed: sarvatra ca imam saptabhaṅgīnayam nāma nyāyam avatārayanti  syāt asti syāt na asti
translated: And everywhere they introduce this principle called the seven-fold mode.

analyzed: syāt asti ca na asti ca
translated: It may be that it exists. It may be that it does not exist.🔽It may be that it both exists and does not exist.

analyzed: syāt avaktavyaḥ  syāt asti ca avaktavyaḥ ca  syāt na asti ca avaktavyaḥ ca
translated: It may be that it is inexpressible.🔽It may be that it both exists and is inexpressible.🔽It may be that it both does not exist and is inexpressible.

analyzed: syāt asti ca na asti ca avaktavyaḥ ca iti
translated: It may be that it both exists, does not exist, and is inexpressible.

analyzed: evam eva ekatva nitya tva ādiṣu api imam sapta bhaṅgī nayam yojayanti
translated: In the same way, they apply this seven-fold mode to oneness, permanence, and so on.

analyzed: atra ācakṣmahe na ayam abhyupagamaḥ yuktaḥ iti kutas
translated: We reply: This assumption is not proper. Why?

analyzed: ekasmin asaṃbhavāt
translated: Because it is impossible in one thing.

analyzed: na hi ekasmin dharmiṇi yugapad sat asat tva ādi viruddha dharma samāveśaḥ saṃbhavati śīta uṣṇa vat
translated: For it is impossible for contradictory properties such as existence and non-existence to inhere simultaneously in one thing, just as cold and heat [cannot inhere in the same place].

original: ya ete saptapadārthā nirdhāritā etāvanta evaṃrūpāśceti te tathaiva vā syurnaiva vā tathā syuḥ /🔽itarathā hi tathā vā syuratathā vetyanirdhāritarūpaṃ jñānaṃ saṃśayajñānavadapramāṇameva syāt /
analyzed: ye ete sapta padārthāḥ nirdhāritāḥ etāvantaḥ evaṃrūpāḥ ca iti te tathā eva vā syuḥ na eva vā tathā syuḥ  itarathā hi tathā vā syuḥ atathā vā iti anirdhārita rūpam jñānam saṃśaya jñāna vat apramāṇam eva syāt
translated: Either these seven categories determined as just so many and of just this nature must be just so, or they must not be so at all.🔽For if it were otherwise, then the cognition which is undetermined in form, 'It is so or it is not so', would be a mere doubt, and like a cognition of doubt would not be a valid means of knowledge.

original: nanvanekātmakaṃ vastviti nirdhāritarūpameva jñānamutpadyamānaṃ saṃśayajñānavannāpramāṇaṃ bhavitumarhati /
analyzed: nanu aneka ātmakam vastu iti nirdhārita rūpam eva jñānam utpadyamānam saṃśaya jñāna vat na apramāṇam bhavitum arhati
translated: But an arising cognition which is determined in form, 'The thing is manifold', cannot be a non-valid means of knowledge, just as the cognition of doubt is not.

analyzed: na iti brūmaḥ
translated: We say: No.

original: niraṅ kuśaṃ hyanekāntatvaṃ sarvavastuṣu pratijānānasya nirdhāraṇasyāpi vastutvaviśeṣātsyāditi syānavnāstītyādivikalpopanipātādinirdhāraṇātmakataiva 🔽syāt /
analyzed: niraṅ kuśam hi anekānta tvam sarva vastuṣu pratijānānasya nirdhāraṇasya api vastu tva viśeṣāt syāt iti  syāt
translated: For one who asserts unrestricted non-restriction in all things, even the determination would have the nature of a thing, and so would be subject to the alternatives 'It is' or 'It is not', etc., and so would not be of the nature of determination.

original: evaṃ nirdhārayiturnirdhāraṇaphalasya ca syātpakṣe 'stitā syācca pakṣe nāstīti /
analyzed: evam nirdhārayituḥ nirdhāraṇa phalasya ca syāt pakṣe stitā syāt ca pakṣe na asti iti
translated: Thus, for the determiner and the result of determination, there would be existence in one case and non-existence in another case.

analyzed: evaṃsati katham pramāṇa bhūtaḥ san tīrthakaraḥ pramāṇa prameya pramātṛ pramitaṣu anirdhāritāsu upadeṣṭum śaknuyāt
translated: If this be so, how can a teacher, who is a reliable authority, teach the four categories, which are themselves unreliable?

analyzed: katham vā tad abhiprāya anusāriṇaḥ tad upadiṣṭa irthe nirdhārita rūpe pravarteran
translated: Or how can people, who follow his teachings, engage in the performance of the rites, the nature of which is not well ascertained?

original: aikāntikaphalatvanirdhāraṇe hi sati tatsādhanānuṣṭhānāya sarvo loko 'nākulaḥ pravartate nānyathā /
analyzed: aikāntika phala tva nirdhāraṇe hi sati tad sādhana anuṣṭhānāya sarvaḥ lokaḥ na ākulaḥ pravartate na anyathā
translated: For, if the result of the rite is ascertained to be certain, then all people, without confusion, engage in the performance of the rite for the attainment of that result; not otherwise.

analyzed: atas ca anirdhārta artham śāstram praṇayat matta unmatta vat anupādeya vacanaḥ syāt
translated: And, therefore, one who composes a treatise whose meaning is not ascertained, would be a person whose words are not to be accepted, like a madman.

original: tathā pañcānāmastikāyānāṃ pañcatvasaṃkhyāsti vā nāsti veti vikalpyamānā syāttāvadekasminpakṣe /
analyzed: tathā pañcānām astikāyānām pañcatva saṃkhyā asti vā na asti vā iti vikalpyamānā syāt tāvat ekasmin pakṣe
translated: Similarly, the number five of the five kinds of atheists would be sometimes, when considered, either existent or non-existent, in one case.

original: pakṣāntare tu na syādityato nyūnasaṃkhyātvamadhikasaṃkhyātvaṃ vā prāpnuyāt /
analyzed: pakṣa antare tu na syāt iti atas nyūna saṃkhyā tvam adhika saṃkhyā tvam vā prāpnuyāt
translated: But in the other case, it would not be, and so it would either be less than the number or more than the number.

analyzed: na ca eṣām padārthānām avaktavya tvam saṃbhavati  a vaktavyāḥ ced na ucyeran  ucyante ca avaktavyāḥ ca iti vipratiṣiddham
translated: And it is not possible for these things to be inexpressible.🔽And if they are inexpressible, they would not be spoken of.🔽And it is contradictory to say that they are spoken of and also inexpressible.

analyzed: ucyamānāḥ ca tathā eva avadhāryante na avadhāryante iti ca
translated: And when they are spoken of, they are ascertained as such, and also not ascertained.

original: tathā tadavadhāraṇaphalaṃ samyagdarśanamasti vā nāsti vā /
analyzed: tathā tad avadhāraṇa phalam samyak darśanam asti vā na asti vā
translated: Similarly, whether the result of that ascertainment, viz., right knowledge, exists or not,

original: evaṃ tadviparītamasamyagdarśanamapyasti vā nāsti veti pralapanmattonmattapakṣasyaiva syānna pratyāyitavyapakṣasya /
analyzed: evam tad viparītam asamyak darśanam api asti vā na asti vā iti pralapat matta unmatta pakṣasya eva syāt na pratyāyitavya pakṣasya
translated: so also whether the opposite of that, viz., wrong knowledge, exists or not, is mere prattle, belonging only to the side of the insane and deluded, not to the side of the one to be convinced.

original: svargāpavargayośca pakṣe bhāvaḥ pakṣe cābhāvastathā pakṣe nityatā pakṣe cānityatetyanavadhāraṇāyāṃ pravṛttyanupapattiḥ /
analyzed: svarga apavargayoḥ ca pakṣe bhāvaḥ pakṣe ca abhāvaḥ tathā pakṣe nitya tā pakṣe ca anitya tā iti anavadhāraṇāyām pravṛtti anupapattiḥ
translated: And in the case of heaven and final beatitude, existence in one case and non-existence in another case, so also permanence in one case and impermanence in another case, when there is no ascertainment, there is no possibility of activity.

analyzed: anādisiddha jīva prabhṛtīnām ca sva śāstra avadhṛta svabhāvānām ayathā avadhṛta svabhāva tva prasaṅgaḥ  evam jīva ādiṣu padārtheṣu ekasmin dharmiṇi sattva asattvayoḥ viruddhayoḥ dharmayoḥ asaṃbhavāt sattve
translated: And it would follow that the soul, etc., which are established from beginningless time, and whose nature is ascertained by their own scriptures, would not have the nature as ascertained.🔽Thus, in the case of things like the soul, in one substratum, existence and non-existence, which are contradictory properties, are not possible. And in the case of existence,

analyzed: ca ekasmin dharme sattvasya dharma antarasya asaṃbhavāt asattve ca evam sattvasya asaṃbhavāt asaṃgatam idam ārhatam matam
translated: in one property, non-existence, which is another property, is not possible. And in the case of non-existence, existence is not possible. Thus, this doctrine of the Jains is irrelevant.

analyzed: etena eka aneka nitya anitya vyatirikta avyatirikta ādi anekānta abhyupagamāḥ nirākṛtāḥ mantavyāḥ
translated: By this, the acceptance of many alternatives such as one and many, permanent and impermanent, different and non-different, etc., should be understood to be refuted.

original: yattu pudgalasaṃjñakebhyo 'ṇubhyaḥ saṃgātāḥ saṃbhavantīti kalpayanti tatpūrveṇaivāṇuvādanirākaraṇena nirākṛtaṃ bhavatītyato na pṛthaktannirākaraṇāya 🔽prayatyate // //
analyzed: yat tu pudgala saṃjñakebhyaḥ ṇubhyaḥ saṃgātāḥ saṃbhavanti iti kalpayanti tat pūrveṇa eva aṇu vāda nirākaraṇena nirākṛtam bhavati iti atas na pṛthak tad nirākaraṇāya  prayatyate
translated: But what they imagine, that they originate from atoms designated as pudgala, that is refuted by the previous refutation of the doctrine of atoms. Therefore, no effort is made separately to refute that.

analyzed: jīva ajīvau bhoktṛ bhogyau  viṣaya ābhimukhyena in idriyāṇām pravṛttiḥ āsravaḥ
translated: Jiva and ajiva are the enjoyer and the object of enjoyment.🔽The activity of the senses towards objects is asrava.

analyzed: tām saṃvṛṇoti iti saṃvaraḥ yama niyama ādiḥ
translated: It is restraint because it covers that. It is yama, niyama, etc.

analyzed: nirjarayati nāśayati kalmaṣam iti nirjaraḥ tapta śilā rohaṇa ādiḥ
translated: It destroys, i.e., removes, sin. It is nirjara, i.e., tapas, shila-arohana, etc.

analyzed: bandhaḥ karma
translated: Bondage is karma.

analyzed: mokṣaḥ karma pāśa nāśe satya loka ākāśa praviṣṭasya satata ūrdhva gamanam
translated: Liberation is the upward movement of one who has entered the world-space after the destruction of the bonds of karma.

analyzed: astikāya śabdaḥ sāṃketikaḥ padārtha vācī
translated: The word asti-kaya is a conventional word denoting a meaning.

analyzed: jīvaḥ ca asau astikāyaḥ ca iti vigrahaḥ
translated: The analysis is: it is jiva and it is asti-kaya.

analyzed: pūryante ganti iti pudgalāḥ paramāṇu saṃghāḥ kāyāḥ
translated: Pudgalas are aggregates of atoms, bodies, because they are filled and go.

original: saptānāṃstitvādīnāṃ bhaṅgānāṃ samāhāraḥ saptabhaṅgī tasyā nayo nyāyaḥ /
analyzed: sapta anāṃstitva ādīnām bhaṅgānām samāhāraḥ saptabhaṅgī tasyāḥ nayaḥ nyāyaḥ
translated: The system of the seven modes is the method of the collection of the seven modes beginning with existence.

analyzed: evam ca ātma akārtsnyam
translated: And thus the soul is incomplete.

original: yathaikasmindharmiṇi viruddhadharmāsaṃbhavo doṣaḥ syādvāde prasakta evamātmano 'pi jīvasyākārtsnyamaparo doṣaḥ prasajyeta /
analyzed: yathā ekasmin dharmiṇi viruddha dharma asaṃbhavaḥ doṣaḥ syāt vāde prasakte evam ātmanaḥ api jīvasya akārtsnyam aparaḥ doṣaḥ prasajyeta
translated: Just as the fact that contradictory properties cannot inhere in the same thing is a fault in the doctrine of the Vaiśeṣikas, so the doctrine of the Ājīvikas is open to the further fault that the individual soul is not all-pervading.

analyzed: katham
translated: How so?

analyzed: śarīra paramātmāṇaḥ hi jīvaḥ iti ārhatāḥ manyante
translated: The Ājīvikas think that the individual soul is the same as the body and the highest Self.

original: śarīraparimāṇatāyāṃ ca satyāmakṛtsno 'sarvagataḥ paricchinna ātmetyato ghaṭādivadanityatvamātmanaḥ prasajyeta /🔽śarīrīṇāṃ cānavasthitaparimāṇatvānmanuṣyajīvo manuṣyaśarīraparimāṇo bhūtvā punaḥ kenacitkarmavipākena hastijanma prāpnuvanna kṛtsnaṃ hastiśarīraṃ
analyzed: śarīra parimāṇa tāyām ca satyām akṛtsnaḥ sarva gataḥ paricchinnaḥ ātmā iti atas ghaṭa ādi vat anitya tvam ātmanaḥ prasajyeta  śarīrīṇām ca anavasthita parimāṇa tvāt manuṣya jīvaḥ manuṣya śarīra parimāṇaḥ bhūtvā punar kenacid karma vipākena hasti janma prāpnuvan na kṛtsnam hasti śarīram
translated: And if the soul is of the same size as the body, it is not all-pervading, not all-embracing, limited, and therefore, like a jar, it follows that the soul is non-eternal.

analyzed: vyāpnuyāt
translated: And since the size of embodied souls is not fixed, the individual soul of a human being, having become of the size of a human body, would again, through the ripening of some karma, obtain birth as an elephant and would not pervade the entire body of the elephant.

original: puttikājanma ca prāpmuvanna kṛtsnaḥ puttikāśarīre saṃmīyeta /
analyzed: puttikā janma ca kṛtsnaḥ puttikā śarīre saṃmīyeta
translated: And obtaining birth as a small insect, it would not be contained in the entire body of the small insect.

original: samāna eṣa ekasminnapi janmani kaumārayauvanasthavireṣu doṣaḥ /
analyzed: samānaḥ eṣaḥ ekasmin api janmani kaumāra yauvana sthavireṣu doṣaḥ
translated: The same fault applies even in a single birth, to childhood, youth, and old age.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

original: antāvayavo jīvastasya ta evāvayavā alpe śarīre saṃkuceyurmahati ca vikuceyuriti /
analyzed: anta avayavaḥ jīvaḥ tasya te eva avayavāḥ alpe śarīre saṃkuceyuḥ mahati ca vikuceyuḥ iti
translated: The individual soul is a part of the whole soul. Its parts contract in a small body and expand in a large body.

original: teṣāṃ punaranantānāṃ jīvāvayavānāṃ samānadeśatvaṃ pratihanyate vā naveti vaktavyam /
analyzed: teṣām punar anantānām jīva avayavānām samāna deśa tvam pratihanyate vā na vā iti vaktavyam
translated: Moreover, it must be stated whether the infinite parts of the soul are obstructed or not obstructed in occupying the same space.

analyzed: pratighāte tāvat na ananta avayavāḥ paricchinne deśe saṃmīyeran
translated: If they are obstructed, the infinite parts cannot be combined in a limited space.

analyzed: apratighāte pi eka avayava deśa tva upapatteḥ sarveṣām avayavānām prathima anupapatteḥ jīvasya aṇu mātra tva prasaṅgaḥ syāt
translated: If they are not obstructed, since all parts would occupy the same space, the soul would be reduced to the size of an atom.

analyzed: apica śarīra mātra paricchinnānām jīva avayavānām ānantyam na utprekṣitum api śakyam  /
translated: Moreover, the infinity of the soul's parts, which are limited to the body alone, cannot even be imagined.

analyzed: karma vipākaḥ karmaṇām abhivyaktiḥ
translated: The ripening of karma is the manifestation of actions.

original: atha prayāyeṇa bṛhaccharīrapratipattau kecijjīvāvayavā upagacchanti tanuśarīrapratipattau ca kecidapagacchantītyucyeta tatrāpyucyate
analyzed: atha prayāyeṇa bṛhat śarīra pratipattau kecid jīva avayavāḥ upagacchanti tanu śarīra pratipattau ca kecid apagacchanti iti ucyeta tatra api ucyate
translated: If it is said that when a large body is attained, some soul parts come together, and when a small body is attained, some depart, then in response to that it is said:

original: na ca paryāyād apy avirodho vikārādibhyaḥ / / / /
analyzed: na ca paryāyāt api avirodhaḥ vikāra ādibhyaḥ
translated: And even by succession, there is no non-contradiction due to modification and so on.

analyzed: na ca paryāyeṇa api avayava upagama apagamābhyām etat deha parimāṇa tvam jīvasya avirodhena upapādayitum śakyate
translated: And even by succession, this finiteness of the soul's body cannot be reasonably explained without contradiction by the coming and going of parts.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

analyzed: vikāra ādi doṣa prasaṅgāt
translated: Because the faults of modification and so on are entailed.

original: avayavopagamāpagamābhyāṃ hyaniśamāpūryamāṇasyāpakṣīyamāṇasya ca jīvasya vikriyāvattvaṃ tāvadaparihāryam /
analyzed: avayava upagama apagamābhyām hi aniśam āpūryamāṇasya apakṣīyamāṇasya ca jīvasya vikriyāvat tvam tāvat aparihāryam
translated: For the individual soul, which is being constantly filled and emptied by the coming and going of its parts, must necessarily be subject to change.

analyzed: vikriyāvat tve ca carma ādi vat anityam prasajyeta
translated: And if it is subject to change, it follows that it is non-eternal, like skin and other parts of the body.

original: tataśca bandhamokṣābhyupagamo bādhyeta karmāṣṭakapariveṣṭitasya jīvasyālābuvatsaṃsārasāgare nimagnasya bandhanocchedādūrdhvagāmitvaṃ bhavatīti
analyzed: tatas ca bandha mokṣa abhyupagamaḥ bādhyeta karma aṣṭaka pariveṣṭitasya jīvasya alābu vat saṃsāra sāgare nimagnasya bandhana ucchedāt ūrdhvagāmi tvam bhavati iti
translated: And then the acceptance of bondage and liberation would be contradicted, for the individual soul, enveloped by the eight classes of matter, immersed in the ocean of worldly existence like a gourd, would become a goer upwards by the cutting off of its bonds.

analyzed: kiñca anyat
translated: Moreover,

analyzed: āgacchatām apagacchatām ca avayavānām āgama apāya dharmavat tvāt evānām ātvam śarīra ādi vat
translated: the individual soul, being subject to the properties of coming and going of its parts, must be non-eternal like the body and other parts.

analyzed: tatas ca avasthitaḥ kaścid avayavaḥ ātmā iti syāt
translated: And then it would follow that some part of the soul remains fixed.

analyzed: na ca sa nirūpayitum śakyate yam asau iti
translated: And it cannot be determined which one it is.

analyzed: kiñca anyat
translated: Moreover,

original: āgacchantaścaite jīvāvayavāḥ kutaḥ prādurbhavantyapagacchantaśca kva vā līyanta iti vaktavyam /
analyzed: āgacchantaḥ ca ete jīva avayavāḥ kutas prādurbhavanti apagacchantaḥ ca kva vā līyante iti vaktavyam
translated: it must be said from where the coming individual soul-parts arise and where they dissolve when they go away.

analyzed: nahi bhūtebhyaḥ prādurbhaveyuḥ bhūteṣu ca nilīyeran
translated: They cannot arise from the elements and dissolve into the elements,

analyzed: abhautika tvāt jīvasya
translated: because the individual soul is not made of elements.

original: nāpi kaścidanyaḥ sādhāraṇo 'sādhāraṇo vā jīvānāmavayavādhāro nirūpyate pramāṇābhāvāt /
analyzed: nā api kaścid anyaḥ sādhāraṇaḥ sādhāraṇaḥ vā jīvānām avayava ādhāraḥ nirūpyate pramāṇa abhāvāt
translated: Nor is any other common or uncommon substratum of the individual souls determined, because there is no evidence.

analyzed: kiñca anyat
translated: Moreover,

analyzed: an avadhṛta svarūpaḥ ca evam sati ātmā syāt
translated: in that case, the self would have an undetermined nature.

analyzed: āgacchatām apagacchatām ca avayavānām aniyata parimāṇa tvāt
translated: Because the incoming and outgoing parts have an undetermined size.

analyzed: atas evamādi doṣa prasaṅgāt na paryāyeṇa api avayava upagama apagamau ātmanaḥ āśrayitum śakyate
translated: For this very reason, because of the occurrence of faults such as these, it is not possible to accept the coming and going of parts even in turn for the self.

analyzed: athavā pūrveṇa sūtreṇa śarīra parimāṇasya ātmanaḥ upacita apacita śarīra antara pratipattau akārtsnya prasañjana dvāreṇa anitya tāyām
translated: Or, in the previous aphorism, the impermanence of the self whose size is that of the body, due to the possibility of incompleteness in the attainment of other bodies with increased or decreased size,

original: coditāyāṃ punaḥ paryāyeṇa parimāṇānavasthāne 'pi srotaḥsaṃtānanityatānyāyenātmano nityatā syāt /
analyzed: coditāyām punar paryāyeṇa parimāṇa anavasthāne srotaḥ saṃtāna nitya tā nyāyena ātmanaḥ nitya tā syāt
translated: having been urged, again, even in the absence of the stability of size in turn, the self would be permanent by the principle of the permanence of the continuum of the stream.

original: yathā raktapaṭānāṃ vijñānānavasthāne 'pi tatsaṃtānanityatā tadvaddhisicāmapītyāśaṅkyānena sūtreṇottaramucyate /
analyzed: yathā rakta paṭānām vijñāna anavasthāne tad saṃtāna nitya tā tadvat hi sicām api iti āśaṅkya anena sūtreṇa uttaram ucyate
translated: Just as, even in the absence of the stability of consciousness, there is the permanence of its continuum, so it is for the individual souls also. Thus, suspecting this, the reply is given by this aphorism.

analyzed: saṃtānasya tāvat avastu tve nairātmya vāda prasaṅgaḥ
translated: If the continuum is not a real entity, there is the undesirable consequence of the doctrine of selflessness.

analyzed: vastu tve pi ātmanaḥ vikāra ādi doṣa prasaṅgāt asya pakṣasya anupapattiḥ iti
translated: Even if the soul were a substance, this view is untenable, because it would involve the undesirable contingency of the soul being subject to modifications, etc.

analyzed: dehabhedena parimāṇasya ātmanaḥ ca anavasthāne pi nāśe pi srotaḥ pravāhaḥ
translated: Even though the soul and its size are not subject to destruction or non-existence due to the difference in bodies, there is a continuity of the stream.

analyzed: vigatam sic vastram visicaḥ digambarāḥ teṣām iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that they are naked, with their clothes removed.

analyzed: antya avasthiteḥ ca ubhaya nitya tvāt aviśeṣaḥ
translated: And because of the permanence of the last, there is no distinction due to the permanence of both.

analyzed: api ca antyasya mokṣa avasthā bhāvinaḥ jīva parimāṇasya nitya tvam iṣyate jainaiḥ
translated: Moreover, the Jains accept the permanence of the final size of the soul, which occurs in the state of liberation.

analyzed: tadvat pūrvayoḥ api avidya madhyamayoḥ jīva parimāṇayoḥ nitya tva prasaṅgāt aviśeṣa prasaṅgaḥ syāt
translated: Due to the undesirable consequence of the permanence of the two previous sizes of the soul, which occur during ignorance, there would be the undesirable consequence of no distinction.

analyzed: eka śarīra parimāṇa tā eva syāt na upacita apacita śarīra antara prāptiḥ
translated: There would be only the size of one body, and there would be no attainment of other bodies that are increased or decreased.

analyzed: athavā antyasya jīva parimāṇasya avasthita tvāt pūrvayoḥ api avasthayoḥ avasthita parimāṇaḥ eva jīvaḥ syāt
translated: Or, because of the stability of the final size of the soul, the soul would have a stable size in the two previous states as well.

analyzed: tatas ca aviśeṣeṇa sarvadā eva aṇuḥ mahān vā jīvaḥ bhyupagantavyaḥ na śarīra parimāṇaḥ
translated: And from that, without distinction, the soul would always have to be accepted as atomic or large, not as the size of the body.

analyzed: atas ca saugata vat ārhatam api matam asaṃgatam iti upekṣitavyam
translated: Therefore, the doctrine of the Arhat, like that of the Buddhist, is to be disregarded as untenable.

analyzed: pati adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The chapter on the Lord.

analyzed: patyuḥ asāmañjasyāt  /
translated: Because the Lord is not tenable.

analyzed: idānīm kevala adhiṣṭhātṛ īśvara kāraṇa vādaḥ pratiṣidhyate
translated: Now the doctrine that the Lord is the sole governing cause is being refuted.

analyzed: tat katham avagamyate  prakṛtiḥ ca pratijñā dṛṣṭānta an uparodhāt abhidhyā upadeśāt ca
translated: How is this understood?

analyzed: iti atra prakṛti bhāvena adhiṣṭhātṛ bhāvena ca ubhaya svabhāvasya īśvarasya svayam eva ācāryeṇa pratiṣṭhāpita tvāt
translated: In And primordial matter, because it does not contradict the thesis and the example, and And because of the teaching of desire, the teacher himself has established the Lord as having both natures, as primordial matter and as the governing.

original: yadi punaraviśeṣeṇeśvarakāraṇavādamātramiha pratiṣidhyeta pūrvottaravirodhādvyāhatābhivyāhāraḥ sūtrakāra ityetadāpadyeta /
analyzed: yadi punar aviśeṣeṇa īśvara kāraṇa vāda mātram iha pratiṣidhyeta pūrva uttara virodhāt vyāhata abhivyāhāraḥ sūtrakāraḥ iti etat āpadyeta
translated: If, on the other hand, the doctrine of the Lord as cause were being refuted here without distinction, it would follow that the author of the aphorisms would be guilty of a contradiction, speaking what is contradicted, because of the contradiction between the earlier and later [parts of the aphorisms].

original: tasmādaprakṛtiradhiṣṭhātā kevalaṃ nimittakāraṇamīśvara ityeṣa pakṣo vedāntavihitabrahmaikatvapratipakṣatvādyatnenātra pratiṣidhyate /
analyzed: tasmāt aprakṛtiḥ adhiṣṭhātā kevalam nimitta kāraṇam īśvaraḥ iti eṣa pakṣaḥ vedānta vihita brahma ekatva pratipakṣa tvāt yatnena atra pratiṣidhyate
translated: Therefore, this view that the Lord is not primordial matter, is the governing cause only, and is the sole instrumental cause, is being strenuously refuted here because it is opposed to the doctrine of the oneness of Brahman taught by the Vedanta.

analyzed: sā ca iyam veda bāhya īśvara kalpanā aneka prakārā
translated: And this conception of the Lord outside the Veda is of many kinds.

original: kecittāvatsāṃkhyayogavyapāśrayāḥ kalpayanti pradhānapuruṣayoradhiṣṭhātā kevalaṃ nimittakāraṇamīśvara itaretaravilakṣaṇāḥ pradhānapuruṣeśvarā 🔽iti /
analyzed: kecid tāvat sāṃkhya yoga vyapāśrayāḥ kalpayanti pradhāna puruṣayoḥ adhiṣṭhātā kevalam nimitta kāraṇam īśvaraḥ itaretara vilakṣaṇāḥ pradhāna puruṣa īśvarāḥ  iti
translated: Some, relying on Sāṃkhya and Yoga, imagine that Īśvara is only the controlling cause of Pradhāna and Puruṣa, and that Pradhāna, Puruṣa, and Īśvara are mutually different.

original: māheśvarāstu manyante kāryakāraṇayogavidhiduḥkhāntāḥ pañca padārthāḥ paśupatineśvareṇa paśupāśavimokṣaṇāyopadiṣṭāḥ paśupatirīśvaro nimittakāraṇamiti 🔽varṇayanti /
analyzed: māheśvarāḥ tu manyante kārya kāraṇa yoga vidhi duḥkhāntāḥ pañca padārthāḥ paśupatinā īśvareṇa paśu pāśa vimokṣaṇāya upadiṣṭāḥ paśupatiḥ īśvaraḥ nimitta kāraṇam iti  varṇayanti
translated: The Mīmāṃsakas, however, consider that the five categories of effect, cause, yoga, injunction, and pain are taught by Īśvara, the Lord of beings, for the liberation of beings from bondage. They describe Īśvara as the instrumental cause.

original: tathā vaiśeṣikādayo 'pi kecitkathañcitsvaprakriyānusāreṇa nimittakāraṇamīśvara iti varṇayanti /
analyzed: tathā vaiśeṣika ādayaḥ api kecid kathañcid sva prakriyā anusāreṇa nimittakāraṇam īśvaraḥ iti varṇayanti
translated: Similarly, some Vaiśeṣikas and others describe Īśvara as the instrumental cause in some way, in accordance with their own doctrines.

analyzed: atas uttaram ucyate patyuḥ asāmañjasyāt iti
translated: Therefore, the answer is given: Because of the inconsistency of the controller.

analyzed: patyuḥ īśvarasya pradhāna puruṣayoḥ adhiṣṭhātṛ tvena jagat kāraṇatvam na upapadyate
translated: The state of being the cause of the world as the controller of Pradhāna and Puruṣa is not possible for Īśvara, the Lord.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

analyzed: a sāmañsyāt
translated: Because of inconsistency.

analyzed: kim punar asāmañjasyam
translated: What is the inconsistency?

analyzed: hīna madhyama uttama bhāvena hi prāṇi bhedān vidadhataḥ īśvarasya rāga dveṣa ādi doṣa prasakteḥ asmat ādi vat anīśvara tvam prasajyeta
translated: For if Īśvara, in creating the various kinds of beings with inferior, middling, and superior states, were to be subject to faults such as attachment and hatred, he would be not-Īśvara, like us and others.

analyzed: prāṇi karma apekṣita tvāt adoṣaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it be said that there is no fault, because the Lord is dependent on the actions of the souls, we say no.

analyzed: karma īśvarayoḥ pravartya pravartayitṛ tve itaretara āśraya doṣa prasaṅgāt
translated: For if the Lord and the souls were the instigators and the instigated, the fault of mutual dependence would follow.

analyzed: na anādi tvāt iti ced na
translated: If it be said that there is no fault, because the world has no beginning, we say no.

analyzed: vartamāna kāla vat atīteṣu api kāleṣu itaretara āśraya doṣa aviśeṣāt andha paramparā nyāya āpatteḥ  apica pravartanā lakṣaṇāḥ doṣāḥ
translated: For the same fault of mutual dependence would apply to the past times as to the present time; and the absurdity would follow that there would be an infinite regress of blind men.

analyzed: iti nyāya vid samayaḥ
translated: Moreover, it is a maxim of the logicians that “faults are of the nature of instigation.”

original: nahi kaścidadoṣaprayuktaḥ svārthe parārthe vā pravartamāno dṛśyate /
analyzed: nahi kaścid adoṣa prayuktaḥ sva arthe para arthe vā pravartamānaḥ dṛśyate
translated: For no one is seen to be engaged in his own interest or in the interest of another without being instigated by a fault.

original: svārthaprayukta eva ca sarvo janaḥ parārthe 'pi pravartata ityevamapyasāmañjasyaṃ /🔽svārthavattvādīśvarasyānīśvaratvaprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: sva artha prayuktaḥ eva ca sarvaḥ janaḥ para arthe pravartate iti evam api asāmañjasyam  svārthavat tvāt īśvarasya anīśvara tva prasaṅgāt
translated: And all men are engaged in the interest of another only because they are engaged in their own interest. Thus also there is inconsistency.🔽For if God has an object of His own, it follows that He is not God.

analyzed: puruṣa viśeṣa tva abhyupagamāt ca īśvarasya puruṣasya ca audāsīnya abhyupagamāt asāmañjasyam
translated: And there is inconsistency also because the Sāṅkhyas admit that God is a particular soul, and because they admit that the soul is indifferent.

analyzed: sāṃkhya yoga vyapāśrayāḥ hiraṇyagarbha patañjali prabhṛtayaḥ
translated: The Sāṅkhyas and the Yogas are the followers of Hiraṇyagarbha, Patañjali, and others.

analyzed: māheśvarāḥ catvāraḥ śaivāḥ
translated: The Mīmāṃsakas are fourfold, the Śaivas,

analyzed: pāśupatāḥ  kāruṇika siddhāntinaḥ
translated: the Pāśupatas,🔽the followers of the doctrine of the compassionate one,

analyzed: kāpālikāḥ ca iti
translated: and the Kāpālikas.

analyzed: paśavaḥ jīvāḥ teṣām pāśaḥ bandhaḥ tad nāśāya iti arthaḥ
translated: The living beings are the animals; the bond of them is the fetter; for the destruction of that, is the meaning.

analyzed: saṃbandha anupapatteḥ ca
translated: And also because of the impossibility of the relation.

analyzed: punar api asmāñjasyam eva
translated: Again, the same objection.

analyzed: nahi pradhāna puruṣa vyatiriktaḥ īśvaraḥ ntareṇa saṃbandham pradhāna puruṣayoḥ īśitā
translated: For, apart from the relation, God, who is different from the primordial matter and the souls, cannot be the ruler of the primordial matter and the souls.

analyzed: na tāvat saṃyoga lakṣaṇaḥ saṃbandhaḥ saṃbhavati
translated: Nor is the relation possible in the form of conjunction.

analyzed: pradhāna puruṣa īśvarāṇām sarvagata tvāt niravayava tvāt ca
translated: Because the primordial matter, the souls, and God are all-pervading and partless.

analyzed: na api samavāya lakṣaṇaḥ saṃbandhaḥ
translated: Nor is the relation in the form of inherence.

analyzed: āśraya āśrayi bhāva a nirūpaṇāt
translated: Because the relation of container and contained cannot be determined.

analyzed: na api anyaḥ kaścid kārya gamyaḥ saṃbandhaḥ śakyate kalpayitum
translated: Nor can any other relation, which is known through its effect, be imagined.

analyzed: kārya kāraṇa bhāvasya eva adya api asiddha tvāt
translated: Because the relation of cause and effect itself is not yet established.

analyzed: brahma vādinaḥ katham iti ced na
translated: If it be asked how is it for the Vedāntins? No.

analyzed: tasya tādātmya lakṣaṇa saṃbandha upapatteḥ
translated: Because the relation in the form of identity is possible for them.

original: apicāgamabalena brahmavādī kāraṇādisvarūpaṃ nirūpayatīti nāvaśyaṃ tasya yathādṛṣṭameva sarvamabhyupagantavyamiti niyamo 'sti /
analyzed: api ca āgama balena brahma vādī kāraṇa ādi svarūpam nirūpayati iti na avaśyam tasya yathādṛṣṭam eva sarvam abhyupagantavyam iti
translated: Moreover, the Vedāntin determines the nature of the cause, etc., on the strength of the scriptures; so it is not necessary for him to accept everything just as it is seen.

original: parasya tu dṛṣṭāntabalena kāraṇādisvarūpaṃ nirūpayato yathādṛṣṭameva sarvamabhyupagantavyamityayamastyatiśayaḥ /
analyzed: parasya tu dṛṣṭānta balena kāraṇa ādi svarūpam nirūpayataḥ yathādṛṣṭam eva sarvam abhyupagantavyam iti ayam asti atiśayaḥ
translated: But when the opponent, on the strength of examples, determines the nature of the cause, etc., he must accept everything just as it is seen. This is the difference.

analyzed: parasya api sarvajña praṇīta āgama sadbhāvāt samānam āgama balam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the opponent also has the same strength of scripture because of the existence of a scripture composed by an omniscient being, it is not so.

analyzed: itaretara āśraya tva prasaṅgāt āgama pratyaya tvāt sarvajña tva siddhiḥ sarvajña pratyayāt ca āgama siddhiḥ iti
