translated: Because of the mutual dependence, the establishment of omniscience is due to the belief in scripture, and the establishment of scripture is due to omniscience.

analyzed: tasmāt anupapannā sāṃkhya yoga vādinām īśvara kalpanā
translated: Therefore, the conception of God by the Sāṃkhya and Yoga proponents is illogical.

analyzed: evam anyāsu api yathāsaṃbhavam asāmañjasyam yojayitavyam
translated: Similarly, in other conceptions of God in the Vedas and Upaniṣads, inconsistency should be shown as appropriate.

analyzed: adhiṣṭhāna anupapatteḥ ca
translated: And because of the impossibility of a substratum.

analyzed: itas ca anupapattiḥ tārkika parikalpitasya īśvarasya
translated: And for this reason also, the conception of God imagined by the logicians is illogical.

original: sa hi parikalpyamānaḥ kumabhakāra iva mṛdādīni pradhānādīnyadhiṣṭhāya pravartayet /
analyzed: sa hi parikalpyamānaḥ kumabhakāraḥ iva mṛd ādīni pradhāna ādīni adhiṣṭhāya pravartayet
translated: For, when imagined, he would operate by controlling the primordial matter, etc., like a potter controlling the clay, etc.

analyzed: na ca evam upapadyate
translated: But this is not possible.

original: nahyapratyakṣaṃ rūpādihīnaṃ ca pradhānamīśvarasyādhiṣṭheyaṃ saṃbhavati mṛdādivailakṣaṇyāt // //
analyzed: na hi apratyakṣam rūpa ādi hīnam ca pradhānam īśvarasya adhiṣṭheyam saṃbhavati mṛd ādi vailakṣaṇyāt  /
translated: For, primordial matter, which is not perceptible and devoid of form, etc., cannot be the substratum of God, because it is different from clay, etc.

analyzed: karaṇavat ced na bhoga ādibhyaḥ
translated: If it be said that (the Lord is related to the pradhāna) as the senses are (to the soul), (we say) no, because (the pradhāna) is not an object of experience, etc.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

original: yathā karaṇagrāmaṃ cakṣurādikamapratyakṣaṃ rūpādihīnaṃ ca puruṣo 'dhitiṣṭhatyevaṃ pradhānamapīśvaro 'dhiṣṭhāsyatīti /
analyzed: yathā karaṇa grāmam cakṣuḥ ādikam apratyakṣam rūpa ādi hīnam ca puruṣaḥ dhitiṣṭhati evam pradhānam api īśvaraḥ dhiṣṭhāsyati iti
translated: Just as the soul presides over the group of senses, the eye, etc., which are not perceived and which are devoid of colour, etc., in the same way the Lord will preside over the pradhāna.

analyzed: tathā api na upapadyate
translated: Even so, it is not tenable.

analyzed: bhoga ādi darśanāt hi karaṇa grāmasya adhiṣṭhita tvam gamyate
translated: For the fact that the group of senses is presided over is inferred from the fact that it is an object of experience, etc.

analyzed: na ca atra bhoga ādayaḥ dṛśyante
translated: And here, experience, etc., are not seen.

analyzed: karaṇa grāma sāmye vā abhyupagamyamāne saṃsāriṇām iva īśvarasya api bhoga ādayaḥ prasajyeran
translated: Or, if it is admitted that the pradhāna is similar to the group of senses, then the Lord also would be subject to experience, etc., like transmigrating beings.

analyzed: anyathā vā sūtra dvayam vyākhyāyate adhiṣṭhāna anupapatteḥ ca itas ca anupapattiḥ tārkika parikalpi sya īśvarasya
translated: Or the two aphorisms are explained in another way: And because a substratum is not possible. For this reason also the existence of God imagined by the logicians is not possible.

original: sādhiṣṭhāno hi loke saśarīro rājā rāṣṭrasyeśvaro dṛśyate na niradhiṣṭhānaḥ /
analyzed: sa adhiṣṭhānaḥ hi loke sa śarīraḥ rājā rāṣṭrasya īśvaraḥ dṛśyate na niradhiṣṭhānaḥ
translated: For in the world, a king with a body, who has a substratum, is seen to be the lord of the kingdom, not one without a substratum.

original: ataśca taddṛṣṭāntavaśenādṛṣṭamīśvaraṃ kalpayitumicchata īśvarasyapi kiñciccharīraṃ karaṇāyatanaṃ varṇayitavyaṃ syāt /
analyzed: atas ca tad dṛṣṭānta vaśena adṛṣṭam īśvaram kalpayitum icchataḥ īśvarasi api kiñcid śarīram karaṇa āyatanam varṇayitavyam syāt
translated: And therefore, one who wishes to imagine God, who is not perceived, on the basis of that analogy, would have to describe some kind of body for God, as the seat of the senses.

analyzed: na ca tat varṇayitum śakyate
translated: But that cannot be described.

analyzed: sṛṣṭi uttara kāla bhāvi tvāt śarīrasya prāk sṛṣṭeḥ tad anupapatteḥ
translated: Because the body exists after creation, it is not possible before creation.

analyzed: niradhiṣṭhāna tve ca īśvarasya pravartaka tva anupapattiḥ
translated: And if God were without a substratum, He could not be an active agent,

analyzed: evam loke dṛṣṭa tvāt
translated: because that is seen in the world.

analyzed: karaṇavat ced na bhoga ādibhyaḥ
translated: If it be said that He is like one with organs, no; because of experience, etc.

original: atha lokadarśanānusāreṇeśvarasyāpi kiñcitkāraṇānāmāyatanaṃ śarīraṃ kāmena kalpyeta /
analyzed: atha loka darśana anusāreṇa īśvarasya api kiñcid kāraṇānām āyatanam śarīram kāmena kalpyeta
translated: If, in accordance with the view of the world, a body were hypothetically assumed for God as the abode of some of the causes,

analyzed: evam api na upapadyate
translated: even so it is not possible.

analyzed: sa śarīra tve hi sati saṃsāri vat bhoga ādi prasaṅgāt īśvarasya api anīśvara tvam prasajyeta  /
translated: For if He had a body, then, like one subject to transmigration, He would be liable to experience, etc., and thus God would be subject to imperfection.

analyzed: bhogaḥ sukha duḥkha anubhavaḥ  ādi padāt viṣaya anubhava grahaḥ
translated: Experience is the feeling of pleasure and pain.🔽The word 'etc.' includes the experience of objects.

analyzed: karaṇāni atra santi iti karaṇavat śarīram
translated: The body is like one with organs, because organs are present there.

analyzed: antavat tvam asarvajña tā vā
translated: It would have an end, or it would not be omniscient.

analyzed: itas ca anupapattiḥ tārkika parikalpitasya īśvarasya
translated: And for this reason also the God postulated by the logicians is not possible.

analyzed: sa hi sarvajñaḥ taiḥ abhyupagamyate nantaḥ ca
translated: For He is accepted by them as omniscient and infinite.

original: anantaṃ ca pradhānamanantāśca puruṣā mitho bhinnā abhyupagamyate /
analyzed: anantam ca pradhānam anantāḥ ca puruṣāḥ mithas bhinnāḥ abhyupagamyate
translated: And the primordial matter is accepted as infinite, and the souls as infinite and mutually different.🔽And if God is the cause of the world, then He would be the cause of what is non-eternal, of what is mixed with pain, of what is liable to destruction, and of what is other than Brahman.

original: tatra sarvajñeśvareṇa pradhānasya puruṣāṇāmātmanaśceyattā paricchidyeta vā na vā paricchidyeta /
analyzed: tatra sarvajña īśvareṇa pradhānasya puruṣāṇām ātmanaḥ ca iyattā paricchidyeta vā na vā paricchidyeta
translated: There, by the omniscient Lord, the extent of the primordial matter, the souls, and of himself would be either determined or not determined.

analyzed: ubhayathā api doṣaḥ nuṣaktaḥ eva
translated: In both cases, the fault is certainly attached.

analyzed: katham
translated: How?

analyzed: pūrvasmin tāvat vikalpe iyat tā paricchinna tvāt pradhāna puruṣa īśvarāṇām antavat tvam avaśyam bhāvi evam loke dṛṣṭa tvāt
translated: First, in the case of the option, because of being limited in extent, the primordial matter, souls, and Lord must necessarily be finite, because it is seen thus in the world.

original: yaddhi loka iyattāparicchinnaṃ vastu paṭādi tadantavaddṛṣṭaṃ tathā pradhānapuruṣeśvaratrayamapīyattāparicchinnatvādantavatsyāt /
analyzed: yat hi loke iyattā paricchinnam vastu paṭa ādi tat antavat dṛṣṭam tathā pradhāna puruṣa īśvara trayam api iyattā paricchinna tvāt antavat syāt
translated: Whatever thing in the world is limited in extent, like a cloth, is seen to be finite. Similarly, the triad of primordial matter, souls, and Lord would also be finite, because of being limited in extent.

analyzed: saṃkhyā parimāṇam tāvat pradhāna puruṣa īśvara traya rūpeṇa paricchinnam
translated: The extent in terms of number is certainly limited in the form of the triad of primordial matter, souls, and Lord.

analyzed: sva rūpa parimāṇam api tad gatam īśvareṇa paricchidyeta iti
translated: The extent in terms of intrinsic nature is also determined by the Lord with regard to them.

analyzed: puruṣa gatā ca mahā saṃkhyā
translated: And the great number is with regard to the souls.

original: tataśceyattāparicchinnānāṃ madhye ye saṃsāriṇaḥ saṃsārānmucyante teṣāṃ saṃsāro 'ntavānsaṃsāritvaṃ ca teṣāmantavat /
analyzed: tatas ca iyattā paricchinnānām madhye ye saṃsāriṇaḥ saṃsārāt mucyante teṣām saṃsāraḥ ntavān saṃsāri tvam ca teṣām antavat
translated: And then, among those limited in extent, those who are transmigrating and are liberated from transmigration, their transmigration is finite, and their state of being transmigrating is also finite.

original: evamitareṣvapi krameṇa mucyamāneṣu saṃsārasya saṃsāriṇāṃ cāntavattvaṃ syāt /
analyzed: evam itareṣu api krameṇa mucyamāneṣu saṃsārasya saṃsāriṇām ca antavat tvam syāt
translated: In the same way, if the other (principles) are also liberated in due order, the world and the transmigrating souls would have an end.

original: pradhānaṃ ca savikāraṃ puruṣārthamīśvarasyādhiṣṭheyaṃ saṃsāritvenābhimataṃ tacchūnyatāyāmīśvaraḥ kimadhitiṣṭhet /
analyzed: pradhānam ca sa vikāram puruṣa artham īśvarasya adhiṣṭheyam saṃsāri tvena abhimatam tat śūnyatāyām īśvaraḥ kim adhitiṣṭhet
translated: And the pradhāna with its evolutes, which is accepted as the object of the Lord's control in the form of transmigration for the sake of the souls, if that were empty, what would the Lord control?

analyzed: kiṃviṣaye vā sarvajña tā īśvara te syātām
translated: Or what would be the object of omniscience and lordship?

analyzed: pradhāna puruṣa īśvarāṇām ca evam antavat tve satya ādimat tva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: And if the pradhāna, the souls, and the Lord were thus finite, it would follow that they have a beginning.

analyzed: ādi antavat tve ca śūnyavāda prasaṅgaḥ
translated: And if they had a beginning and an end, it would lead to the doctrine of nihilism.

original: atha mā bhūdeṣa doṣa ityuttaro vikalpo 'bhyupagamyeta na pradhānasya puruṣāṇāmātmanaśceyatteśvareṇa paricchidyata iti /
analyzed: atha mā bhūt eṣa doṣaḥ iti uttaraḥ vikalpaḥ bhyupagamyeta na pradhānasya puruṣāṇām ātmanaḥ ca iyattā īśvareṇa paricchidyate iti
translated: Now, if this fault is not to be, the latter alternative may be accepted, that the finiteness of the pradhāna, the souls, and the self is not determined by the Lord.

analyzed: tatas īśvarasya sarvajña tva abhyupagama hāniḥ aparaḥ doṣaḥ prasajyeta
translated: Then, there would be the other fault of abandoning the accepted doctrine of the omniscience of the Lord.

analyzed: tasmāt api asaṃgataḥ tārkika parigṛhītaḥ īśvara kāraṇa vādaḥ
translated: Therefore, the doctrine of God as the cause, accepted by the logicians, is also incoherent for this reason.

analyzed: saṃkhyā vā parimāṇam vā iyattā
translated: The finiteness is either number or dimension.

analyzed: utpatti asaṃbhava adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The chapter on the impossibility of origination. Sutra.

analyzed: utpatti asaṃbhavāt
translated: Because origination is impossible.

analyzed: yeṣām aprakṛtiḥ adhiṣṭhātā kevala nimitta kāraṇam īśvaraḥ bhimataḥ teṣām pakṣaḥ pratyākhyātaḥ
translated: The view of those who consider God as the mere instrumental cause, without any material cause, has been refuted.

original: yeṣāṃ punaḥ prakṛtiścādhiṣṭhātā cobhayātmakaṃ kāraṇamīśvaro 'bhimatasteṣāṃ pakṣaḥ pratyākhyāyayate /
analyzed: yeṣām punar prakṛtiḥ ca adhiṣṭhātā ca ubhaya ātmakam kāraṇam īśvaraḥ bhimataḥ teṣām pakṣaḥ
translated: Now the view of those who consider God as the material cause and the controller, as the cause having both aspects, is being refuted.

original: nanu śrutisamāśrayaṇenāpyevaṃrūpa eveśvaraḥ prāṅnirdhāritaḥ prakṛtiścādhiṣṭhātā ceti /
analyzed: nanu śruti samāśrayaṇena api evaṃrūpaḥ eva īśvaraḥ prāk nirdhāritaḥ prakṛtiḥ ca adhiṣṭhātā ca iti
translated: But wasn't such a God, with both aspects of material cause and controller, already determined earlier by relying on the scriptures?

analyzed: śruti anusāriṇī ca smṛtiḥ pramāṇam iti sthitiḥ
translated: And it is established that smrti is a means of valid knowledge only when it accords with the scriptures.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ eṣa pakṣaḥ pratyācikhyāsitaḥ iti
translated: Then why is this view being refuted?

analyzed: ucyate yadi api eva jātīyaka oṃśaḥ samāna tvāt na visaṃvāda gocaraḥ bhavatti astitu aṃśa antaram visaṃvāda sthānam iti atas tad pratyākhyānāya āramabhaḥ
translated: It is said: Although this part is similar and not subject to contradiction, there is another part about existence that is the basis of contradiction. Therefore, the argument is presented to refute that.

analyzed: tatra bhāgavatāḥ manyante
translated: In that regard, the Bhagavatas think:

analyzed: bhagavān eva ekaḥ vāsudevaḥ nirañjana jñāna svarūpaḥ paramārtha tattvam
translated: The Lord alone, Vāsudeva, whose nature is non-dual knowledge, is the ultimate reality.

original: sa caturdhātmānaṃ pravibhajya pratiṣṭhito vāsudevavyūharūpeṇa saṃkarṣaṇavyūharūpeṇa pradyumnavyūharūpeṇāniruddhavyūharūpeṇa ca /

translated: Regarding this, first of all, what is said - that Narayana, who is known as supreme, beyond the unmanifest, the supreme Self, the Self of all, that Self, having divided Himself into many forms, abides -

original: yatpunaridamucyate vāsudevātsaṃkarṣaṇa utpadyate saṃkarṣaṇācca pradyumnaḥ pradyumnāccāniruddha iti /

translated: But as for what is said, that Saṅkarṣaṇa is produced from Vāsudeva, and Pradyumna from Saṅkarṣaṇa, and Aniruddha from Pradyumna,

analyzed: vyūhaḥ mūrtiḥ

analyzed: svādhyāyaḥ ṣṭa akṣara ādi japaḥ

translated: It created that light.

analyzed: iti sakṛt śrutasya sraṣṭuḥ sraṣṭavya dvayena saṃbandha anupapatteḥ  tat tejaḥ sṛjata
translated: Because it is not possible for the creator mentioned once to be connected with two things to be created.🔽It created that light.

analyzed: tat ākāśam asṛjata iti
translated: It created that space.

original: nanu sakṛcchrutasyāpi kartuḥ kartavyadvayena saṃbandho dṛśyate /
analyzed: nanu sakṛt śrutasya api kartuḥ kartavya dvayena saṃbandhaḥ dṛśyate
translated: Isn't it seen that a creator mentioned once can be connected with two things to be created?

analyzed: yathā sūpam paktvā odanam pacati iti
translated: For example, having cooked the soup, he cooks the rice.

analyzed: evam tat ākāśam sṛṣṭvā tat tejaḥ sṛjati iti yojayiṣyāmi
translated: Similarly, having created space then, it created that light. I will connect it like this.

analyzed: na evam yujyate
translated: It is not proper like this.

original: prathamajatvaṃ hi chāndogye tejaso 'vagamyate taittirīyake cākāśasya /
analyzed: prathama ja tvam hi chāndogye tejasaḥ vagamyate taittirīyake ca ākāśasya
translated: For in the Chāndogya, the primacy of light is understood, and in the Taittirīya, of space.

analyzed: na ca ubhayoḥ prathama ja tvam saṃbhavati
translated: And the primacy of both is not possible.

analyzed: etena itara śruti akṣara virodhaḥ vyākhyātaḥ
translated: By this, the contradiction with the words of the other scriptures is also explained.

analyzed: tasmāt vai etasmāt ātmanaḥ ākāśaḥ saṃbhūtaḥ
translated: From that Self indeed, space was produced.

original: ityatrāpi tasmādākāśaḥ saṃbhūtastasmāttejaḥ saṃbhūtamiti sakṛcchrutasyāpādānasya saṃbhavanasya ca viyattejobhyāṃ yugapatsaṃbandhānupapatteḥ
analyzed: iti atra api tasmāt ākāśaḥ saṃbhūtaḥ tasmāt tejaḥ saṃbhūtam iti sakṛt śrutasya apādānasya saṃbhavanasya ca viyat tejobhyām yugapad saṃbandha anupapatteḥ
translated: Here also, from that, space was produced, from that, light was produced. Because it is not possible for the once-mentioned source and production to be simultaneously connected with space and light,

analyzed: vāyoḥ agniḥ te
translated: And From Vāyu, Agni (Taitt. Up. 2. 1).

analyzed: iti ca pṛthak āmnānāt
translated: And because of the separate mention.

analyzed: asmin vipratiṣedhe kaścid āha
translated: In this contradiction, someone says:

analyzed: gauṇī asaṃbhavāt  na asti viyataḥ utpattiḥ aśruteḥ eva
translated: Because the secondary meaning is impossible.🔽There is no origination from space, simply because it is not heard.

original: yā tvitarā viyadutpattivādinī śrutirudāhṛtā sā gauṇī bhavitumarhati /🔽kasmāt /
analyzed: yā tu itarā viyat utpatti vādinī śrutiḥ udāhṛtā sā gauṇī bhavitum arhati  kasmāt
translated: But the other scriptural passage that states the origination of space should be taken as secondary.🔽Why?

analyzed: asaṃbhavāt
translated: Because it is impossible.

analyzed: nahi ākāśasya utpattiḥ saṃbhāvayitum śakyā śrīmat kaṇabhuj abhiprāya anusāriṣu jīvatsu
translated: For as long as the illustrious followers of Kaṇabhaṭṭa are alive, the origination of space cannot be imagined.

analyzed: te hi kāraṇa sāmāgrya saṃbhavāt akāśasya utpattim vārayanti
translated: They, indeed, deny the origination of space because the totality of causes is not possible.

analyzed: samavāyi asamavāyi nimitta kāraṇebhyaḥ hi kila sarvam utpadyamānam samutpadyate
translated: For everything that originates, it is said, originates from inhering, non-inhering, and instrumental causes.

original: dravyasya caikajātīyakamanekaṃ ca dravyaṃ samavāyikāraṇaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: dravyasya ca eka jātīyakam anekam ca dravyam samavāyi kāraṇam bhavati
translated: And for a substance, a plurality of substances of the same class is the inhering cause.

analyzed: na ca ākāśasya eka jātīyakam anekam ca dravyam ārambhakam asti
translated: But there is no plurality of substances of the same class that is the origin of space.

original: yasminsamavāyikāraṇe satyasamavāyikāraṇe ca tatsaṃyoga ākāśa utpadyeta /
analyzed: yasmin samavāyi kāraṇe sati asamavāyi kāraṇe ca tad saṃyogaḥ ākāśaḥ utpadyeta
translated: In which inhering cause and non-inhering cause, that conjunction would be the origin of space.

analyzed: tad abhāvāt tu tad anugraha pravṛttam nimitta kāraṇam dūra apetam eva ākāśasya bhavati
translated: But since this is not the case, the causal condition, which operates by favouring the effect, is far removed from Ākāśa

original: utpattimatāṃ ca tejaḥprabhṛtīnāṃ pūrvottarakāyorviśeṣaḥ saṃbhāvyate prāgutpatteḥ prakāśādikāryaṃ na babhūva paścācca bhavatīti /
analyzed: utpattimatām ca tejaḥ prabhṛtīnām pūrva uttara kāyoḥ viśeṣaḥ saṃbhāvyate prāk utpatteḥ prakāśa ādi kāryam na babhūva paścāt ca bhavati iti
translated: In the case of fire and the other elements, which are produced, it is possible to conceive a difference between their previous and subsequent states, the difference, namely, that before their origination they did not perform their functions of illuminating, &c, while afterwards they do so

analyzed: ākāśasya punar na pūrva uttara kālayoḥ viśeṣaḥ saṃbhāvayitum śakyate
translated: But in the case of Ākāśa it is impossible to conceive any difference between its previous and subsequent states

analyzed: kim hi prāk utpatteḥ anavakāśam a suṣiram acchidram babhūva iti śakyate dhī avasātum
translated: For how can it be determined that before its origination it was without any interstices, without any holes?

analyzed: pṛthivī ādi vaidharmyāt ca vibhu tva ādi lakṣaṇāt ākāśasya aja tva siddhiḥ
translated: And on account of the difference of Ākāśa from earth and the other elements, which latter are characterized by extension, &c, it is proved that Ākāśa is unproduced

original: tasmādyathā loka ākāśaṃ kurvākāśo jāta ityevañjātīyako gauṇaḥ prayogo bhavati /
analyzed: tasmāt yathā loke ākāśam kuru ākāśaḥ jātaḥ iti evañjātīyakaḥ gauṇaḥ prayogaḥ bhavati
translated: Hence, just as in ordinary life the expression, He makes Ākāśa, Ākāśa is produced, is used in a secondary sense,

original: yathāca ghaṭākāśaḥ karakākāśo gṛhākāśa ityekasyāpyākāśasyaivañjātīyako bhedavyapadeśo gauṇo bhavati /🔽vede 'pi 'āraṇyānākāśeṣvālabheran' iti /
analyzed: yathā ca ghaṭa ākāśaḥ karaka ākāśaḥ gṛha ākāśaḥ iti ekasya api ākāśasya evañjātīyakaḥ bheda vyapadeśaḥ gauṇaḥ bhavati  vede pi āraṇyān ākāśeṣu ālabheran iti
translated: and just as the different designations of the one Ākāśa, Ākāśa of the pot, Ākāśa of the jar, Ākāśa of the house, are used in a secondary sense,🔽so also in the Veda, where it is said, They are to offer sacrifice to the Ākāśa in the forest,

analyzed: evam utpatti śrutiḥ api gauṇī draṣṭavyā
translated: we must understand the passage as referring to the elements, and the word Ākāśa must be taken in a secondary sense

analyzed: śabdāt ca
translated: And on account of the word

analyzed: śabdaḥ khalu ākāśasya aja tvam khyāpayati
translated: Sound, indeed, proclaims the unbornness of space.

analyzed: yatas āha vāyuḥ ca antarikṣam ca etat amṛtam bṛ iti
translated: For it is said, 'This wind and space are immortal' (Tai. 2.1).

analyzed: na hi amṛtasya utpattiḥ upapadyate
translated: For the origin of the immortal is not possible.

original: ākāśavatsarvagataśca nityaḥ iti cākāśena brahma sarvagatatvanityatvābhyāṃ dharmābhyāmupamimāna ākāśasyāpi tau dharmau sūcayati /
analyzed: ākāśa vat sarva gataḥ ca nityaḥ iti ca ākāśena brahma sarva gata tva nitya tvābhyām dharmābhyām upamimānaḥ ākāśasya api tau dharmau sūcayati
translated: And the text comparing Brahman with space by the two attributes of being all-pervading and eternal, indicates those two attributes of space also.

analyzed: na ca tādṛśasya utpattiḥ upapadyate
translated: And for such a one, origin is not possible.

original: 'sa yathānanto 'yamākāśa evamananta ātmā veditavyaḥ' iti codāharaṇam /
analyzed: sa yathā anantaḥ yam ākāśaḥ evam anantaḥ ātmā veditavyaḥ iti ca udāharaṇam
translated: And the example, 'As this space is endless, so the Self is to be known as endless' (Tai. 2.1),

analyzed: ākāśa śarīram brahma taiḥ
translated: 'Brahman has space as its body' (Tai. 2.1),

analyzed: ākāśa ātmā tai iti ca
translated: 'Space is the Self' (Tai. 1.6),

analyzed: na hi ākāśasya utpattimat tve brahmaṇaḥ tena viśeṣeṇa saṃbhavati nīlena iva utpalasya
translated: for when space has origin, Brahman cannot have that particular attribute, just as a lotus cannot have the attribute of blueness.

analyzed: tasmāt nityam eva ākāśena sādhāraṇam brahma iti gamyate  /
translated: Therefore, it is understood that Brahman is eternal, common with space.

analyzed: syāt ca ekasya brahma śabda vat
translated: And there may be oneness, like the word Brahman.

analyzed: idam pada uttaram sūtram
translated: This is the next aphorism.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said.

original: kathaṃ punarekasya saṃbhūtaśabdasya 'tasmādvā etasmādātmana ākāśaḥ saṃbhūtaḥ' tai /
analyzed: katham punar ekasya saṃbhūta śabdasya tasmāt vai etasmāt ātmanaḥ ākāśaḥ saṃbhūtaḥ
translated: How then is the word 'sambhūta' (arisen) of one meaning in 'Therefore, from this Self, space has arisen' (Tai. 2.1),

original: ityasminnadhikāre pareṣu tejaḥprabhṛtiṣvanuvartamānasya mukhyatvaṃ saṃbhavatyākāśe ca gauṇatvamiti /
analyzed: iti asmin adhikāre pareṣu tejaḥ prabhṛtiṣu anuvartamānasya mukhya tvam saṃbhavati ākāśe ca gauṇa tvam iti
translated: Thus, in this context, it is possible that the primary meaning of the word 'bhūta' applies to the other elements beginning with fire, while the secondary meaning applies to space.

original: ata uttaramucyate syāccaikasyāpi saṃbhūtaśabdasya viṣayaviśeṣavaśādgauṇo mukhyasya prayogo brahmaśabdavat /
analyzed: atas uttaram ucyate syāt ca ekasya api saṃbhūta śabdasya viṣaya viśeṣa vaśāt gauṇaḥ mukhyasya prayogaḥ brahma śabda vat
translated: To this, the following reply is given: Even for the word 'bhūta', which has only one meaning, there may be secondary and primary usage based on the specific subject matter, just as in the case of the word 'Brahman'.

original: yathaikasyāpi brahmaśabdasya 'tapasā brahma vijijñāsasva /🔽tapo brahma' tai / /
analyzed: yathā ekasya api brahma śabdasya tapasā brahma vijijñāsasva  tapaḥ brahma tai
translated: Just as for the word 'Brahman' alone, in the context of 'Inquire about Brahman through austerity.

original: ityasminnadhikāre 'nnādiṣu gauṇaḥ prayoga ānande ca mukhyaḥ /
analyzed: iti asmin adhikāre nna ādiṣu gauṇaḥ prayogaḥ ānande ca mukhyaḥ
translated: Austerity is Brahman' (Tai. 2.1), there is secondary usage in relation to food etc., and primary usage in relation to bliss.

original: yathā ca tapasi brahmavijñānasādhane brahmaśabdo bhaktyā prayujyate 'ñjasā tu vijñeye brahmaṇi tadvat /
analyzed: yathā ca tapasi brahma vijñāna sādhane brahma śabdaḥ bhaktyā prayujyate ñjasā tu vijñeye brahmaṇi tadvat
translated: And just as the word 'Brahman' is used figuratively in relation to austerity, which is the means of knowing Brahman, it is used directly in relation to Brahman, which is to be known.

original: kathaṃ punaranutpattau nabhasaḥ 'ekamevādvitīyam' chā / / /🔽itīyaṃ pratijñā samarthyate /🔽nanu nabhasā dvitīyena sadvitīyaṃ brahma prāpnoti /
analyzed: katham punar anutpattau nabhasaḥ ekam eva advitīyam chā  iti iyam pratijñā samarthyate  nanu nabhasā dvitīyena sa dvitīyam brahma prāpnoti
translated: How then is the assertion 'Brahman is one without a second' (Ch. 6.2.1) justified, if space is not a product?

original: kathaṃ ca brahmaṇi vidite sarvaṃ viditaṃ syāditi /
analyzed: katham ca brahmaṇi vidite sarvam viditam syāt iti
translated: How is it that when Brahman is known, everything is known?

analyzed: tat ucyate ekam eva iti tāvat sva kārya apekṣayā upapadyate
translated: To this it is said: First of all, the statement 'Brahman is one' is justified in relation to its own effect.

original: yathā loke kaścitkumbhakārakule pūrvedyurmṛddaṇḍacakrādīni copalabhyāparedyuśca nānāvidhānyamatrāṇi🔽prasāritānyupalabhya brūyānmṛdevaikākinī pūrvedyurāsīditi sa ca tayāvadhāraṇayā mṛtkāryajātameva
analyzed: yathā loke kaścid kumbhakāra kule pūrvedyus mṛd daṇḍa cakra ādīni ca upalabhya aparedyus ca nānāvidhāni amatrāṇi  prasāritāni upalabhya brūyāt mṛdā iva ekākinī pūrvedyus āsīt iti sa ca tayā avadhāraṇayā mṛd kārya jātam eva
translated: Just as in the world, someone, having perceived clay, stick, wheel, etc. in a potter's family on the previous day, and having perceived various kinds of pots spread out on the next day,

analyzed: pūrvedyus na āsīt iti abhipreyāt na daṇḍa cakra ādi
translated: might say, Clay alone existed on the previous day, and by that determination he would intend that only the class of clay products did not exist on the previous day, not the stick, wheel, etc.

analyzed: tadvat advitīya śrutiḥ adhiṣṭhātrā antaram vārayati
translated: Similarly, the statement of non-duality excludes any other controller.

original: yathā mṛdo 'matraprakṛteḥ kumbhakāro 'dhiṣṭhātā dṛśyate naivaṃ brahmaṇo jagatprakṛteranyo 'dhikṛtāstīti /
analyzed: yathā mṛdaḥ matra prakṛteḥ kumbhakāraḥ dhiṣṭhātā dṛśyate na evam brahmaṇaḥ jagat prakṛteḥ anyaḥ dhikṛtā asti iti
translated: Just as a potter is seen as the controller of clay in the case of a pot, there is no other agent in the case of Brahman and the world.

original: naca nabhasāpi dvitīyena sadvitīyaṃ brahma prasajyate /
analyzed: na ca nabhasā api dvitīyena sa dvitīyam brahma prasajyate
translated: And Brahman is not said to be non-dual with the second, i.e., space.

analyzed: lakṣaṇa anyatva nimittam hi nānātvam
translated: For non-duality is due to the difference in characteristics.

analyzed: na ca prāk utpatteḥ brahma nabhasoḥ lakṣaṇa anyatvam asti kṣīra udakayoḥ iva saṃsṛṣṭyoḥ vyāpi tva amūrta tva didharma sāmānyāt
translated: And there is no difference in characteristics of Brahman and space before creation, like that of milk and water when mixed, due to the commonality of properties such as all-pervasiveness and incorporeality.

original: sargakāle tu brahma jagadutpādayituṃ yatate stimitamitaravattiṣṭati /
analyzed: sarga kāle tu brahma jagat utpādayitum yatate stimitam itara vat tiṣṭati
translated: But at the time of creation, Brahman strives to produce the world, and remains inert like the other [i.e., space].

analyzed: tena anya tvam avasīyate
translated: Therefore, non-duality is ascertained.

analyzed: tathā ca ākāśa śarīram brahma
translated: And so also in the Taittirīya Upaniṣad (2.1), 'Brahman has the ether for its body.'🔽🔽

analyzed: ityādi śrutibhyaḥ pi brahma ākāśayoḥ abheda upacāra siddhiḥ
translated: And so, from the scriptures such as Brahman has the sky as its body (Tai. 2.1), the establishment of the figurative identification of non-difference between Brahman and the sky is accomplished.

analyzed: atas eva ca brahma vijñānena sarva vijñāna siddhiḥ
translated: And for this very reason, the establishment of the knowledge of all things by the knowledge of Brahman is accomplished.

analyzed: apica sarvam kāryam utpadyamānam ākāśena a vyatirikta deśa kālam eva utpadyate
translated: Moreover, all effects, while being produced, are produced with a place and time that are non-different from the sky.

analyzed: brahmaṇā ca a vyatirikta deśa kālam eva ākāśam bhavati iti
translated: And the sky exists with a place and time that are non-different from Brahman.

original: ato brahmaṇā tatkāryeṇa ca vijñātena sahavijñātamevākāśaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: atas brahmaṇā tad kāryeṇa ca vijñātena saha vijñātam eva ākāśam bhavati
translated: Therefore, the sky becomes known along with Brahman and its effects when they are known.

original: yathā kṣīrapūrṇe ghaṭe katicidabbindavaḥ prakṣiptāḥ santaḥ kṣīragrahaṇenaiva gṛhītā bhavanti /
analyzed: yathā kṣīra pūrṇe ghaṭe katicid ap bindavaḥ prakṣiptāḥ santaḥ kṣīra grahaṇena eva gṛhītāḥ bhavanti
translated: Just as when a few drops of water are poured into a pot full of milk, they become grasped by the mere grasping of the milk.

analyzed: nahi kṣīra prahaṇāt ap bindu vu grahaṇam pariśiṣyate
translated: For after the grasping of the milk, the grasping of the drops of water is not left over.

analyzed: evam brahmaṇā tad kāryaiḥ ca avyatirikta deśa kāla tvāt gṛhītam eva brahma grahaṇena nabhaḥ bhavati
translated: In the same way, the sky becomes grasped by the grasping of Brahman, because it has a place and time that are non-different from Brahman and its effects.

analyzed: tasmāt bhāktam nabhasaḥ saṃbhava śravaṇam iti
translated: Therefore, the statement about the origin of the sky is figurative.

analyzed: abheda upacāraḥ bhaktiḥ
translated: The figurative identification is the figurative usage.

analyzed: kulam gṛham
translated: A family is a house.

analyzed: amatrāṇi ghaṭa ādīni
translated: Vessels are pots, etc.

analyzed: evam prāptaḥ idam āha
translated: Having reached this conclusion, he says this:

original: pratijñāhānir avyatirekāc chabdebhyaḥ / / / /🔽'yenāśrutaṃ śrutaṃ bhavatyamataṃ matamavijñātaṃ vijñātam' chā / / /
analyzed: pratijñāhāniḥ avyatirekāt śabdebhyaḥ  yena a śrutam śrutam bhavati a matam matam a vijñātam vijñātam chā
translated: The abandonment of the thesis is due to non-difference from the words.🔽By which the unheard is heard, the unknown is known, the unseen is seen.

original: iti / 'ātmani khalvare dṛṣṭe śrute mate vijñāta idaṃ sarvaṃ viditam' bṛ / / /
analyzed: iti ātmani khalvare dṛṣṭe śrute mate vijñāte idam sarvam viditam bṛ
translated: Thus, 'When the Self alone is seen, heard, thought, and known, then all this is known.' Brihadaranyaka Upanishad.

original: iti / 'kasminnu bhagavo vijñāte sarvamidaṃ vijñātaṃ bhavati' muṇḍa / / /
analyzed: iti kasmin nu bhagavaḥ vijñāte sarvam idam vijñātam bhavati muṇḍa
translated: Thus, 'In the knowledge of what, O Blessed One, does all this become known?' Mundaka Upanishad.

original: iti / 'na kācana maddhahirdhā vidyāsti' iti caivaṃrūpā prativedāntaṃ pratijñā vijñāyate /
analyzed: iti na kācana mat hahirdhā vidyā asti iti ca evaṃrūpā prati vedāntam pratijñā vijñāyate
translated: Thus, 'There is no knowledge outside of Me.' Such a thesis is understood in every Vedanta.

original: tasyāḥ pratijñāyā evamahāniranuparodhaḥ syāt /🔽yadyavyatirekaḥ kṛtsnasya vastujātasya vijñeyādbrahmaṇaḥ syāt /
analyzed: tasyāḥ pratijñāyāḥ evam ahāniḥ an uparodhaḥ syāt  yadi a vyatirekaḥ kṛtsnasya vastu jātasya vijñeyāt brahmaṇaḥ syāt
translated: The non-abandonment of that thesis would be non-contradictory.🔽If there were no difference of the entire class of things from Brahman, which is to be known.

original: vyatireke hi satyekavijñānena sarvaṃ vijñāyata itīyaṃ pratijñā hrīyeta /
analyzed: vyatireke hi sati eka vijñānena sarvam vijñāyate iti iyam pratijñā hrīyeta
translated: For if there were difference, this thesis that 'by the knowledge of one all is known' would be contradicted.

original: sa cāvyatireka evamupapadyate yadi kṛtsnaṃ vastujātamekasmādbrahmaṇa utpadyeta /
analyzed: sa ca avyatirekaḥ evam upapadyate yadi kṛtsnam vastu jātam ekasmāt brahmaṇaḥ utpadyeta
translated: And that non-difference is possible only if the entire class of things were produced from the one Brahman.

analyzed: śabdebhyaḥ ca prakṛti vikāra avyatireka nyāyena eva pratijñā siddhiḥ avagamyate
translated: And the establishment of the thesis is understood by the method of the relation of material cause and effect from the words.

original: tathāhi 'yenāśrutaṃ śrutaṃ bhavati' iti pratijñāya mṛdādidṛṣṭāntaiḥ kāryakāraṇābhedapratipādanaparaiḥ pratijñaiṣā samarthyate /
analyzed: tathā hi yena aśrutam śrutam bhavati iti pratijñāya mṛd ādi dṛṣṭāntaiḥ kārya kāraṇa abheda pratipādana paraiḥ pratijñā eṣā samarthyate
translated: For, after the promise, ‘By which the unheard is heard,’ the promise is supported by the examples of clay, etc., which are intended to teach the non-difference of effect and cause.

original: tatsādhanāyaiva cottare śabdāḥ 'sadeva somyedamagra āsīdekamevādvitīyam' chā / / /
analyzed: tad sādhanāya eva ca uttare śabdāḥ sat eva somya idam agre āsīt ekam eva advitīyam chā
translated: For the sake of establishing that, the words beginning with ‘In the beginning, O son of a brāhmaṇa, this was Being only, one, without a second’ (Chānd.

translated: All the three, origin, subsistence, and dissolution, of the elements are declared to depend on Brahman, From him are born these beings, by him when born they live, into him when departing they enter Śve Up ,

original: athavotpatteḥ kramasya śrutatvāpralayasyāpi kramākāṅkṣiṇaḥ sa eva kramaḥ syāditi /🔽evaṃ prāptaṃ tato brūmaḥ viparyayeṇa tu pralayakramo 'ta utpattikramādbhavitumarhati /
analyzed: athavā utpatteḥ kramasya śruta tvāt pralayasya api krama ākāṅkṣiṇaḥ saḥ eva kramaḥ syāt iti  evam prāptam tatas brūmaḥ viparyayeṇa tu utpatti kramāt bhavitum arhati
translated: Now, as no special order is mentioned, the dissolution must be supposed to take place in the same order in which the origin of the elements takes place; or else, if the order of dissolution is to be different from that of origin, it must be the reverse order, because the order of origin is declared in Śruti

original: tathāhi loke dṛśyate yena krameṇa sopānamārūḍhastato viparītena krameṇāvarohatīti /
analyzed: tathā hi loke dṛśyate yena krameṇa sopānam ārūḍhaḥ tatas viparītena krameṇa avarohati iti
translated: To this we make the following reply The order of dissolution is the reverse of the order of origination; for we observe in ordinary experience that a man who has ascended a ladder by one set of steps descends it by the reverse set of steps

original: apica dṛśyate mṛdo jātaṃ ghaṭaśarāvādyapyayakāle mṛdbhāvamapyetyadbhyaśca jātaṃ himakarakādyabbhāvamapyetīti /
analyzed: apica dṛśyate mṛdaḥ jātam ghaṭa śarāva ādi apyaya kāle mṛd bhāvam apyeti adbhyaḥ ca jātam himakaraka ādi ap bhāvam apyeti iti
translated: Moreover, we see that a jar, a dish, and other things which are made of clay, when they are destroyed, pass back into the state of clay, and that hail, rain, and other things which are formed of water, pass back into the state of water

analyzed: atas ca upapadyate etat
translated: From this it follows that the dissolution of the elements takes place in the reverse order of their origination

original: yadpṛthivyadbhyo jātā satī sthitikālavyatikrāntāvapo 'pīyādāpaśca tejaso jātāḥ satyastejo 'pīyuḥ /
analyzed: yat pṛthivī adbhyaḥ jātā satī sthiti kāla vyatikrāntau apaḥ pīyāt āpaḥ ca tejasaḥ jātāḥ satyaḥ tejaḥ pīyuḥ
translated: When the earth, having been produced from water, passes away at the time of dissolution, it returns into the water; and the water, having been produced from fire, returns into fire; and so on, each effect having to return into its cause

original: evaṃ krameṇa sūkṣmaṃ sūkṣmataraṃ cānantaramanantaraṃ kāraṇamapītya sarvaṃ kāryajātaṃ paramakāraṇaṃ paramasūkṣmaṃ ca brahmāpyetīti veditavyam
analyzed: evam krameṇa sūkṣmam sūkṣmataram ca anantaram anantaram kāraṇam apītya sarvam kārya jātam parama kāraṇam parama sūkṣmam ca brahma apyeti iti veditavyam
translated: Thus the whole aggregate of effects has to be known as returning into Brahman, the highest cause and the highest object of knowledge

original: nahi svakāraṇavyatikrameṇa kāraṇakāraṇe kāryāpyayo nyāyyaḥ /🔽smṛtāvapyutpattikramaviparyayeṇaivāpyayakramastatra tatra darśitaḥ 'jagatpratiṣṭhā devarṣe pṛthivyapsu pralīyate /
analyzed: nahi sva kāraṇa vyatikrameṇa kāraṇa kāraṇe kārya apyayaḥ nyāyyaḥ  smṛtau api utpatti krama viparyayeṇa eva apyaya kramaḥ tatra tatra darśitaḥ jagat pratiṣṭhā deva ṛṣe pṛthivī apsu pralīyate
translated: For it would be absurd to suppose that the effect returns into something different from its cause, and that the cause returns into something different from its effect

original: jyotiṣyāpaḥ pralīyante jyotirvāyau pralīyate' ityevamādau /🔽utpattikramastūtpattāveva śrutatvānnāpyaye bhavitumarhati /🔽nacāsāvayogyatvādapyayenākāṅkṣyate /
analyzed: jyotiṣi āpaḥ pralīyante jyotiḥ vāyau pralīyate iti evamādau  utpatti kramaḥ tu utpattau eva śruta tvāt na apyaye bhavitum arhati  na ca asau ayogya tvāt apyayena ākāṅkṣyate
translated: In Smṛti also the order of reabsorption is stated to be the reverse of the order of creation; cp eg Bṛ Up , , 0, 0, The world, O divine sage, dissolves into the earth; the earth into water; water into fire; fire into air; air into ether; ether into the set of eleven; the set of eleven into the set of five; the set of five into the individual soul; the individual soul into the great one; the great one into the notgreater; the notgreater into the supreme Self, which is the highest object of knowledge🔽The order of creation, on the other hand, is not to be adopted in the case of reabsorption, because it is mentioned in the passage referring to creation only

original: nahi kārye dhriyamāṇe kāraṇasyāpyayo yuktaḥ kāraṇāpyaye kāryasyāvasthānānupapatteḥ /
analyzed: nahi kārye dhriyamāṇe kāraṇasya apyayaḥ yuktaḥ kāraṇa apyaye kāryasya avasthāna anupapatteḥ
translated: Nor is it to be desired that the effect should return into the cause, because it is not fit for that; for it is impossible that the effect should continue to exist when the cause has been reabsorbed into itself

original: kāryāpyaye tu kāraṇasyāvasthānaṃ yuktaṃ mṛdādiṣvevaṃ dṛṣṭatvāt // //
analyzed: kārya apyaye tu kāraṇasya avasthānam yuktam mṛd ādiṣu evam dṛṣṭa tvāt
translated: But it is proper that the cause should remain when the effect is destroyed, because it is seen to be so in the case of clay and so on.

analyzed: krameṇa paramparayā
translated: In succession, by a series.

analyzed: antarā vijñāna adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on the consciousness in between. Sutra.

original: antarā vijñānamanasī krameṇa talliṅgād iti cen nāviśeṣāt / / / /
analyzed: antarā vijñāna manasī krameṇa tad liṅgāt iti ced na aviśeṣāt
translated: If it is argued that consciousness and mind arise in between in succession, because of the indication, it is not so, because there is no distinction.

analyzed: bhūtānām utpatti pralayau anuloma pratiloma kramābhyām bhavataḥ iti uktam
translated: It has been said that the origination and dissolution of the elements occur in the order of evolution and involution.

analyzed: ātma ādiḥ utpattiḥ pralayaḥ ca ātma antaḥ iti api uktam
translated: It has also been said that the origination is from the Self and dissolution is into the Self.

original: sendriyasya tu manaso buddheśca sadbhāvaḥ prasiddhaḥ śrutismṛtyoḥ /
analyzed: sa indriyasya tu manasaḥ buddheḥ ca sadbhāvaḥ prasiddhaḥ śruti smṛtyoḥ
translated: But the existence of the mind and intellect along with the senses is well-known from the Vedas and Smritis.

original: 'buddhiṃ tu sārathiṃ viddhi manaḥ pragrahameva ca /
analyzed: buddhim tu sārathim viddhi manaḥ pragraham eva ca
translated: But know the intellect to be the charioteer and the mind to be the reins,

analyzed: indriyāṇi hayān āhuḥ kaṭha
translated: the senses are said to be the horses (Katha Upanishad 1.3.4).

analyzed: ityādi liṅgebhyaḥ
translated: and so on.

analyzed: tayoḥ api kasmiścid antarāle krameṇa utpatti pralayau upasaṃgrāhyau
translated: The origination and dissolution of those two should also be included in some intermediate stage, in succession.

analyzed: sarvasya vastu jātasya brahma ja tva abhyupagamāt
translated: Because the entire class of things is accepted as having Brahman as its cause.

analyzed: api ca atharvaṇaḥ utpatti prakaraṇe bhūtānām ātmanaḥ ca antarāle karaṇāni anukramyante
translated: Moreover, in the section on origination in the Atharva Veda, the organs are enumerated in between the elements and the Self.

analyzed: etasmāt jāyate prāṇaḥ manaḥ sarva indriyāṇi ca
translated: 'From this is born breath, mind, and all the senses.

original: khaṃ vāyurjyotirāpaḥ pṛthivī viśvasya dhāriṇī' muṇaḍa / / / iti /
analyzed: kham vāyuḥ jyotiḥ āpaḥ pṛthivī viśvasya dhāriṇī muṇaḍaḥ iti
translated: Space, air, light, water, and earth, the supporter of all.

analyzed: tasmāt pūrva ukta utpatti pralaya krama bhaṅga prasaṅgaḥ bhūtānām iti ced na
translated: If it be said that on that account there results a confusion of the order of origination and dissolution of the elements, we reply that that is not so,

analyzed: aviśeṣāt
translated: because there is no difference.

original: yadi tāvadbhautikāni karaṇāni tato bhūtotpattipralayābhyāmevaiṣāmutpattipralayau bhavata iti naitayoḥ kramāntaraṃ mṛgyam /
analyzed: yadi tāvat bhautikāni karaṇāni tatas bhūta utpatti pralayābhyām eva eṣām utpatti pralayau bhavataḥ iti na etayoḥ krama antaram mṛgyam
translated: If the organs are material, then their origination and dissolution must take place together with those of the elements; and we need not seek for any other order of their origination and dissolution.

analyzed: bhavati ca bhautika tve liṅgam karaṇānām
translated: There is, moreover, an indication of the organs being material.

original: 'annamayaṃ hi somya mana oṣadhayaḥ prāṇastejomayī vāk' chā / / /
analyzed: anna mayam hi somya manaḥ oṣadhayaḥ prāṇaḥ tejaḥ mayī vāc chā
translated: For it is said, The mind, my dear, consists of food; breath is made of plants; speech is made of light Ch Up , ,

analyzed: iti evajātīyakam
translated: and so on.

original: vyapadeśo 'pi kvacidbhūtānāṃ karaṇānāṃ ca brāhmaṇaparivrājakanyāyena netavyaḥ /🔽atha tvabhautikāni karaṇāni tathāpi bhūtotpattikramo na karaṇairviśeṣyate prathamaṃ karaṇānyutpadyante caramaṃ bhūtāni prathamaṃ vā bhūtānyutpadyante
analyzed: vyapadeśaḥ pi kvacid bhūtānām karaṇānām ca brāhmaṇa parivrājaka nyāyena netavyaḥ  atha tu abhautikāni karaṇāni tathā api bhūta utpatti kramaḥ na karaṇaiḥ viśeṣyate prathamam karaṇāni utpadyante caramam bhūtāni prathamam vā bhūtāni utpadyante  /
translated: And in some places the organs and the elements are spoken of together, as in the case of the Brāhmaṇa and the Parivrājaka.

original: caramaṃ vā karaṇānīti /🔽ātharvaṇe tu samāmnāyakramamātraṃ karaṇānāṃ bhūtānāṃ ca /
analyzed: caramam vā karaṇāni iti 🔽ātharvaṇe tu samāmnāya krama mātram karaṇānām bhūtānām ca
translated: If, on the other hand, the organs are not material, still the order of the origination of the elements is not to be defined by the organs; either the organs originate first and the elements afterwards, or the elements first and the organs afterwards.

analyzed: na tatra utpatti kramaḥ ucyate
translated: The order of origination is not stated there.

original: tathānyatrāpi pṛthageva bhūtakramātkaraṇakrama āmnāyate 'prajāpatirvā idamagra āsītsa ātmānamaikṣata sa mano 'sṛjata tanmana evāsīttadātmānamaikṣata
analyzed: tathā anyatra api pṛthak eva bhūta kramāt karaṇa kramaḥ āmnāyate prajāpatiḥ vai idam agre āsīt saḥ ātmānam aikṣata sa manaḥ sṛjata tat manaḥ eva āsīt tat ātmānam aikṣata  /
translated: Similarly, elsewhere also, the order of the organs is mentioned separately from the order of the elements: 'Prajapati was here in the beginning, he looked upon himself, he created mind. That mind was indeed himself. He looked upon it,

analyzed: tat vācam asṛjata ityādinā
translated: he created speech.' and so on.

analyzed: tasmāt na asti bhūta utpatti kramasya bhaṅgaḥ
translated: Therefore, there is no contradiction of the order of the origin of the elements.

analyzed: anya pare śabdāḥ liṅgāni iti ucyante
translated: FN: Words that have another meaning are called 'indicative'.

original: idaṃ sthūlamutpatteḥ prāk prajāpatiḥ sūtrātmā āsīt /
analyzed: idam sthūlam utpatteḥ prāk prajāpatiḥ sūtra ātmā āsīt
translated: This gross Prajapati existed before creation in the form of a thread-soul.

analyzed: carācara vyapāśraya adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on the basis of the moving and unmoving. Sutra.

original: carācaravyapāśrayas tu syāt tadvyapadeśo bhāktas tadbhāvabhāvitvāt / / / /🔽sto jīvasyāpyutpattipralayau /
analyzed: carācara vyapāśrayaḥ tu syāt tad vyapadeśaḥ bhāktaḥ tad bhāva bhāvi tvāt  staḥ jīvasya api utpatti pralayau
translated: But the designation of him [as Brahman] may be figurative, because he is affected by that [Brahman's] existence.🔽There may be the doubt of some that the individual soul also has origination and dissolution,

original: jāto devadatto mṛto devadatta ityevajātīyakāllaukikavyapadeśāt jātakarmādisaṃskāravidhānācceti syātkasyacdbhrāntistāmapanudāmaḥ /
analyzed: jātaḥ devadattaḥ mṛtaḥ devadattaḥ iti eva jātīyakāt laukika vyapadeśāt jātakarma ādi saṃskāra vidhānāt ca iti syāt kasyacid bhrāntiḥ tām apanudāmaḥ
translated: because of worldly designations such as 'Devadatta is born', 'Devadatta is dead', and because of the injunctions of purificatory rites like the Jatakarma. We remove that doubt.

analyzed: na jīvasya utpatti pralayau staḥ
translated: The individual soul does not have origination and dissolution.

analyzed: śāstra phala saṃbandha upapatteḥ
translated: Because the connection with the fruits of the scriptures is possible.

analyzed: śarīra anuvināśini hi jīve śarīra antaka gata iṣṭa aniṣṭa prāpti parihāra arthau vidhi pratiṣedhau anartakau syātām
translated: For if the soul were subject to destruction with the body, the injunctions and prohibitions would be without effect, as the attainment of the desirable and the avoidance of the undesirable would be impossible after the death of the body.

original: śrūyate ca 'jīvāpetaṃ vāva kiledaṃ mriyate na jīvo mriyate' chā / / / iti /
analyzed: śrūyate ca jīva apetam vāva kila idam mriyate na jīvaḥ mriyate iti
translated: And it is heard: ‘Verily, this (body) dies devoid of life; the living being does not die’ (Chānd. 7.25.2).

analyzed: nanu laukikaḥ janma maraṇa vyapadeśaḥ jīvasya darśitaḥ
translated: But it has been shown that the designation of birth and death applies to the individual soul in the world.

analyzed: satyam darśitaḥ
translated: True, it has been shown.

analyzed: bhāktaḥ tu eṣa jīvasya janma maraṇa vyapadeśaḥ
translated: But this designation of birth and death for the individual soul is figurative.

original: kimāśrayaḥ punarayaṃ mukhyo yadapekṣayā bhākta iti /
analyzed: kimāśrayaḥ punar ayam mukhyaḥ yad apekṣayā bhāktaḥ iti
translated: But what is the primary basis of this, in relation to which it is figurative?

analyzed: ucyate carācara vyapāśrayaḥ  sthāvara jaṅgama śarīra viṣayau janma maraṇa śabdau
translated: It is said: It is based on the moving and unmoving.🔽The words ‘birth’ and ‘death’ refer to the bodies of the moving and unmoving.

original: sthāvarajaṅgamāni hi bhūtāni jāyante ca mriyante cātastadviṣayau janmamaraṇaśabdau mukhyau santau tatsthe jīvātmanyupacaryate /
analyzed: sthāvara jaṅgamāni hi bhūtāni jāyante ca mriyante ca atas tad viṣayau janma maraṇa śabdau mukhyau santau tad sthe jīvātmani upacaryate
translated: For the moving and unmoving beings are born and die; therefore, the words ‘birth’ and ‘death,’ which primarily refer to them, are figuratively applied to the individual soul residing in them.

analyzed: tad bhāva bhāvi tvāt  śarīra prādurbhāva tirobhāvayoḥ hi satoḥ janma maraṇa śabdau bhavataḥ na asatoḥ
translated: Because it exists in their existence.🔽For the words ‘birth’ and ‘death’ apply when there is appearance and disappearance of the body, not when there is no such existence.

original: nahi śarīrasaṃbandhādanyatra jīvo jāto mṛto vā kenacillakṣyate /
analyzed: nahi śarīra saṃbandhāt anyatra jīvaḥ jātaḥ mṛtaḥ vā kenacid lakṣyate
translated: For nowhere is the soul seen to be born or die apart from its connection with the body.

original: 'sa vā ayaṃ puruṣo jāyamānaḥ śarīramabhisaṃpadyamānaḥ sa utkrāman mriyamāṇaḥ bṛ / / /🔽iti ca śarīrasaṃyogaviyoganimittāveva janmamaraṇaśabdau darśayati /
analyzed: sa vai ayam puruṣaḥ jāyamānaḥ śarīram abhisaṃpadyamānaḥ saḥ utkrāman mriyamāṇaḥ bṛ  iti ca śarīra saṃyoga viyoga nimittau eva janma maraṇa śabdau darśayati
translated: And again, 'This person, when being born, enters the body; when departing, he goes out, when dying' (Kaṭha. 2.2.6).🔽Here also the words 'birth' and 'death' are shown to refer to the conjunction with and disjunction from the body.

analyzed: jātakarma ādi vidhānam api deha prādurbhāva apekṣam eva draṣṭavyam
translated: The injunctions regarding the Jātakarma (birth ceremony) and so on should be understood to refer to the appearance of the body.

analyzed: abhāvāt jīva prādurbhāvasya
translated: Because there is no appearance of the individual soul.

original: jīvasya parasmādātmana utpattirviyadādīnāmivāsti nāsti vetyetaduttareṇa sūtreṇa vakṣyati /
analyzed: jīvasya parasmāt ātmanaḥ utpattiḥ viyat ādīnām iva asti na asti vā iti etat uttareṇa sūtreṇa vakṣyati
translated: Whether the individual soul has an origin from the supreme Self like ether and so on, or not, he will explain in the next aphorism.

original: dehāśrayau tāvajjīvasya sthūlāvutpattipralayau na sta ityetadanena sūtreṇāvocat // //
analyzed: deha āśrayau tāvat jīvasya sthūlau utpatti pralayau na staḥ iti etat anena sūtreṇa avocat  /
translated: By this aphorism he has stated that the gross origin and dissolution of the individual soul are not based on the body.

analyzed: jīva apetam jīvena tyaktam idam śarīram
translated: The body devoid of the individual soul, abandoned by the individual soul.

analyzed: ātmā adhiraṇam sū
translated: The chapter on the Self. Aphorism.

analyzed: na ātmā śruteḥ nitya tvāt ca tābhyaḥ
translated: The Self does not exist, because of scripture, and because of eternity.

analyzed: asti ātmā jīva ākhyaḥ śarīra indriya pañjara adhyakṣaḥ karma phala saṃbandhī
translated: There is a Self called the individual soul, the presiding deity of the body and the five senses, connected with the fruits of actions.

original: sa kiṃ vyomādivadutpadyate brahmaṇa āhosvidbrahmavadeva notpadyata iti śrutivipratipatterviśayaḥ /
analyzed: sa kim vyoma ādi vat utpadyate brahmaṇaḥ āhosvit brahma vat eva na utpadyate iti śruti vipratipatteḥ viśayaḥ
translated: Whether it originates from Brahman like ether and so on, or does not originate like Brahman itself, this is the subject of dispute due to conflicting scriptures.

original: kāsucicchrutiṣvagnivisphuliṅgādinidarśanairjīvātmanaḥ parasmādbrahmaṇa utpattirāmnāyate /🔽kāsucittvavikṛtasya parasya brahmaṇaḥ kāryapraveśena jīvabhāvo vijñāyate nacotpattirāmnāyata iti /
analyzed: kāsucid śrutiṣu agni visphuliṅga ādi nidarśanaiḥ jīvātmanaḥ parasmāt brahmaṇaḥ utpattiḥ āmnāyate  kāsucid tu avikṛtasya parasya brahmaṇaḥ kārya praveśena jīva bhāvaḥ vijñāyate na ca utpattiḥ āmnāyate iti
translated: In some Śrutis, the individual soul is declared to be produced from the highest Brahman, by such illustrations as fire and sparks, &c; in others, the individual soul is known to be the highest Brahman unmodified, entering into the state of individual soul by entering into its effects, and no production of it is declared.

analyzed: tatra prāptam tāvat utpadyate jīvaḥ iti  kutas  pratijñā an uparodhāt eva
translated: Here the pūrvapakṣin maintains that the individual soul is produced, because that is the only way of reconciling the declaration of production with the general doctrine of Brahman being the cause of the world

original: ekasminvidite sarvamidaṃ viditam itīyaṃ pratijñā sarvasya vastujātasya brahmaprabhavatve sati noparudhyeta /
analyzed: ekasmin vidite sarvam idam viditam iti iyam pratijñā sarvasya vastu jātasya brahma prabhava tve sati na uparudhyeta
translated: For if the individual soul were not produced, the general assertion, When one thing is known all this is known, would be contradicted, since it would not be true that all this world is produced from Brahman

original: tattvāntaratve tu jīvasya pratijñeyamuparudhyeta /🔽nacāvikṛtaḥ paramātmaiva jīva iti śakyate vijñātuṃ /
analyzed: tattva antara tve tu jīvasya pratijñā iyam uparudhyeta  na ca avikṛtaḥ paramātmā eva jīvaḥ iti śakyate vijñātum
translated: But if the individual soul were a different substance from Brahman, the general assertion would be contradicted

analyzed: lakṣaṇa bhedāt  apahṛta pāpma tva ādi dharmakaḥ hi paramātmā
translated: Nor can it be maintained that the individual soul is the highest Self unmodified; for the two are distinguished by different qualities

analyzed: tad viparītaḥ hi jīvaḥ
translated: The highest Self is declared to be of the nature of being free from all evil, &c; the individual soul, on the other hand, is of a nature contrary to that

analyzed: vibhāgāt ca asya vikāra tva siddhiḥ
translated: Moreover, the individual soul is an effect, because it is divided, ie is divided from the highest Self

original: yāvānhyākāśādiḥ pravibhaktaḥ sa sarvo vikārastasya cākāśāderutpattiḥ samadhigatā /
analyzed: yāvān hi ākāśa ādiḥ pravibhaktaḥ sa sarvaḥ vikāraḥ tasya ca ākāśa ādeḥ utpattiḥ samadhigatā
translated: Whatever is divided, such as ether and so on, is an effect, and the production of ether and so on is admitted

original: jīvātmāpi puṇyāpuṇyakarmā sukhaduḥkhayukpratiśarīraṃ pravibhakta iti tasyāpi prapañcotpattyavasara utpattirbhavitumarhati /🔽apica 'yathāgneḥ kṣudrā visphuliṅgā vyuccārantyevamevāsmādātmanaḥ sarve prāṇāḥ' bṛ / / /

analyzed: nanu kvacid aśravaṇam anyatra śrutam na vārayiti iti uktam

analyzed: ayam ātmā brahma sarva anubhūḥ bṛ

translated: passages of this kind

analyzed: sva śabdena ca asya kvacid aṇu parimāṇa tvam āmnāyate

analyzed: tasya sarvasya an ākula tva upapādānāya ayam ārambhaḥ

analyzed: nahi vibhoḥ calanam avakalpate iti

analyzed: sati ca paricchede śarīra parimāṇa tvasya ārhata parīkṣāyām nirasta tvāt aṇuḥ ātmā iti gamyate  /

analyzed: sva ātmanā ca uttarayoḥ  /

analyzed: utkrāntiḥ grāma svāmya nivṛtti vat deha svāmya nivṛttyā karma kṣayeṇa avakalpeta
translated: The departure may be possible even for one who does not move, just as the cessation of being the lord of a village is possible without moving, on the ground of the exhaustion of the merit on which the lordship depends

analyzed: uttare tu gati āgatī na acalataḥ saṃbhavataḥ

analyzed: sva ātmanā hi tayoḥ saṃbandhaḥ bhavati

analyzed: gameḥ kartṛ stha kriyā tvāt

analyzed: amadhyama parimāṇasya ca gati āgatī aṇu tve eva saṃbhavataḥ

analyzed: satyoḥ ca gati āgatyoḥ utkrāntiḥ api apasṛptiḥ eva dehāt iti pratīyate

analyzed: na hi an apasṛtya dehāt gatya āgatī syātām

analyzed: deha pradeśānām ca utkrāntau apādāna tva vacanāt

original: 'cakṣuṣo vā mūrdhno vānyebhyo vā śarīradeśebhyaḥ' bṛ / / / iti /

analyzed: tasmāt api asya aṇu tva siddhiḥ  apādāna tvam avadhi tvam

analyzed: na aṇuḥ a tad śruteḥ iti ced na itara adhikārāt

analyzed: kasmāt

analyzed: aṇu tva viparīta parimāṇa śravaṇāt iti arthaḥ

analyzed: ākāśa vat sarva gataḥ ca nityaḥ

analyzed: satyam jñānam anantam brahma taiḥ

analyzed: iti evañjātīyakā hi śrutiḥ ātmanaḥ ṇu tve vipratiṣidhyeta iti ced
translated: If it be said that such passages as these contradict the smallness of the soul,

analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why not?

analyzed: itara adhikārāt
translated: Because the subject-matter is different.

analyzed: parasya hi ātmanaḥ prakriyāyām eṣā parimāṇa antara śrutiḥ

analyzed: parasya eva ātmanaḥ prādhānyena vedānteṣu veditavya tvena prakṛta tvāt

original: virajaḥ para ākāśādityevaṃvidhācca parasyaivātmanastatra tatra viśeṣādhikārāt /🔽nanu 'yo 'yaṃ vijñānamayaḥ prāṇeṣu' bṛ / / /
analyzed: virajaḥ paras ākāśāt iti evaṃvidhāt ca parasya eva ātmanaḥ tatra tatra viśeṣa adhikārāt  nanu yaḥ yam vijñāna mayaḥ prāṇeṣu
translated: And on account of such passages as 'The pure one, higher than the high,' 'higher than the sky,' the highest Self is referred to in particular in those passages.

analyzed: iti śārīre eva mahat tva saṃbandhi tvena pratinirdiśyate
translated: But is it not the individual soul that is pointed to as connected with greatness in the passage, 'He who consists of knowledge, who is in the vital airs' (Bṛ.

analyzed: śāstra dṛṣṭyā tu eṣa nirdeśaḥ vāmadeva vat draṣṭavyaḥ
translated: We reply that this direction must be regarded as referring to the highest Self, as in the case of the hymn addressed to Vāmadeva.

analyzed: tasmāt prājña viṣaya tvāt parimāṇa antara śravaṇasya ca jīvasya aṇu tvam virudhyate  /
translated: Therefore the smallness of the individual soul is contradicted by the statement of its other dimension, because that statement refers to the highest Self.

analyzed: itara adhikārāt brahma prakaraṇāt
