analyzed: sva śabda unmānābhyām ca
translated: And because it is mentioned by its own name and because of the impossibility of the other.

original: itaścāṇurātmā yataḥ sākṣādevāsyāṇutvavācī śabdaḥ śrūyate 'eṣo 'ṇurātmā cetasā veditavyo yasminprāṇaḥ pañcadhā saṃviveśa' muṇḍa / / / iti
analyzed: itas ca aṇuḥ ātmā yatas sākṣāt eva asya aṇu tva vācī śabdaḥ śrūyate eṣaḥ ṇuḥ ātmā cetasā veditavyaḥ yasmin prāṇaḥ pañcadhā saṃviveśa muṇḍaḥ iti
translated: And for this reason also the individual soul is atomic, because a word denoting its atomicity is directly heard: 'This soul is to be known by the mind as atomic, in which the life-breath has entered in five ways' (Muṇḍ. 1.2.9).

original: prāṇasaṃbandhācca jīva evāyamaṇurabhihita iti gamyate /🔽tathonmānamapi jīvasyāṇimānaṃ gamayati 'bālāgraśatabhāgasya śatadhā kalpitasya ca /
analyzed: prāṇa saṃbandhāt ca jīvaḥ eva ayam aṇuḥ abhihitaḥ iti gamyate  tathā unmānam api jīvasya aṇimānam gamayati bālāgra śata bhāgasya śatadhā kalpitasya ca
translated: And because of the connection with the life-breath, it is understood that this atomic one referred to is the individual soul.

original: bhāgo jīvaḥ sa vijñeyaḥ' śve / / iti /
analyzed: bhāgaḥ jīvaḥ sa vijñeyaḥ śve iti
translated: Similarly, the measurement also indicates the atomicity of the individual soul: 'The individual soul should be known as a part of a hundredth part of the tip of a hair divided a hundred times' (Śvet. 6.15).

analyzed: ārā agra mātraḥ dṛṣṭaḥ śve
translated: 'For a soul as small as the tip of a hair is seen to enter' (Śvet. 6.16).

analyzed: iti ca unmāna antaram
translated: This is another measurement.

analyzed: nanu aṇu tve sati eka deśa sthasya sakala deha gata upalabdhiḥ virudhyate
translated: If it is atomic, the perception extending to the whole body by one located in a part is contradictory.

original: dṛśyate ca jāhnavīhradanimagnānāṃ sarvāṅgaśaityopalabdhirnidāghasamaye ca sakalaśarīraparitāpopalabdhiriti /
analyzed: dṛśyate ca jāhnavī hrada nimagnānām sarva aṅga śaitya upalabdhiḥ nidāgha samaye ca sakala śarīra paritāpa upalabdhiḥ iti
translated: And the perception of the entire body being cold is seen in those immersed in the waters of the Ganges, and the perception of the entire body being heated is seen in the hot season.

analyzed: uddhṛtyamānam unmānam
translated: The measurement being extracted is unmāna.

analyzed: bālaḥ keśaḥ
translated: Bāla is hair.

original: totraprotāyaḥśalākāgramarāgraṃ tasmāduddhṛtā mātrā mānaṃ yasya sa jīvastathā /
analyzed: totra prota ayaḥ śalākā agram ara agram tasmāt uddhṛtā mātrā mānam yasya sa jīvaḥ tathā
translated: The tip of a hair is the tip of an iron needle threaded by a needle-thread. The measure of that is the measure of which that soul has.

analyzed: atas uttaram paṭhati
translated: To this objection, the next verse is the reply.

analyzed: avirodhaḥ candana vat
translated: And there is no contradiction, like in the case of sandalwood.

original: yathā hi haricandanabinduḥ śarīraikadeśasaṃbaddho 'pi sansakaladehavyapinamāhlādaṃ karotyevamātmāpi dehaikadeśebhyaḥ sakaladehavyāpinīmupalabdhiṃ 🔽kariṣyati /
analyzed: yathā hi haricandana binduḥ śarīra eka deśa saṃbaddhaḥ san sakala deha vyapinam āhlādam karoti evam ātmā api deha eka deśebhyaḥ sakala deha vyāpinīm upalabdhim  kariṣyati
translated: Just as a drop of yellow sandalwood, even when connected to one part of the body, produces a delight that pervades the entire body, in the same way, the self will produce an experience that pervades the entire body from the parts of the body.

analyzed: tvac saṃbandhanāt ca asya sakala śarīra gatā vedanā na virudhyate
translated: And the feeling that occurs throughout the entire body is not contradicted by the connection of the self with the skin.

original: tvagātmanorhi saṃbandhaḥ kṛtsnāyāṃ tvaci vartate tvakca kṛtsnaśarīravyāpinīti // //
analyzed: tvac ātmanoḥ hi saṃbandhaḥ kṛtsnāyām tvaci vartate tvac ca kṛtsna śarīra vyāpinī iti
translated: For the connection between the skin and the self occurs throughout the entire skin, and the skin pervades the entire body.

original: avasthitivaiśeṣyād iti cen nābhyupagamād dhṛdi hi / / / /
analyzed: avasthiti vaiśeṣyāt iti ced na abhyupagamāt hṛdi hi
translated: If it is argued that it is due to the specific nature of the state, no, because of the acceptance, for the self is in the heart.

analyzed: atra āha yat uktam avirodhaḥ candana vat iti
translated: Here it is said: What was said, that there is no contradiction, like in the case of sandalwood,

original: tadayuktaṃ dṛṣṭāntadārṣṭrāntikayoratulyatvāt /🔽siddhe hyātmano dehaikadeśasthatve candanadṛṣṭānto bhavati /
analyzed: tat ayuktam dṛṣṭānta dārṣṭrāntikayoḥ atulya tvāt  siddhe hi ātmanaḥ deha eka deśa stha tve candana dṛṣṭāntaḥ bhavati
translated: is not correct, because the example and the subject do not correspond.🔽For if the self's being located in one part of the body were established, then the sandalwood example would be appropriate.

analyzed: pratyakṣam tu candanasya avasthiti vaiśeṣyam eka deśa stha tvam sakala deha āhlādanam ca
translated: But the specific nature of the state of sandalwood, its being located in one part and its refreshing the entire body, is directly perceived.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ punar sakala deha upalabdhi mātram pratyakṣam na eka deśa varti tvam
translated: But for the self, only the experience of the entire body is directly perceived, not its being located in one part.

analyzed: anumeyam tu tat iti yat api ucyeta
translated: If it be said that it is to be inferred.

analyzed: na ca atra anumānam saṃbhavati
translated: But inference is not possible here.

original: kimātmanaḥ sakalaśarīragatā vedanā tvagindriyasyeva sakaladehavyāpinaḥ sataḥ kiṃvā vibhornabhasa ivāhosviccandanabindorivāṇorekadeśasthasyeti
analyzed: kim ātmanaḥ sakala śarīra gatā vedanā tvac indriyasya iva sakala deha vyāpinaḥ sataḥ kiṃvā vibhoḥ nabhasaḥ iva āhosvit candana bindoḥ iva aṇoḥ eka deśa sthasya iti
translated: Is the feeling of the soul confined to the whole body like the skin sense organ, which pervades the entire body, or is it like the all-pervading ether, or like a small part of the sandal paste, located in one place?

analyzed: saṃśaya anativṛtteḥ iti
translated: Because the doubt does not cease.

analyzed: atra ucyate na ayam doṣaḥ
translated: To this it is said: This is not a fault.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

analyzed: abhyupagamāt
translated: Because it is accepted.

analyzed: abhyupagamyate hi ātmanaḥ pi candanasya iva deha eka deśa vṛtti tvam avasthiti vaiśeṣyam
translated: For it is accepted that the soul, like sandal paste, has the particularity of existing in one part of the body.

analyzed: katham iti ucyate
translated: How is this said?

original: hṛdi hyeṣa ātmā paṭhyate vedāntaṣu /🔽'hṛdi hyeṣa ātmā'
analyzed: hṛdi hi eṣaḥ ātmā paṭhyate vedāntaṣu  hṛdi hi eṣaḥ ātmā
translated: For in the Vedanta texts, this soul is declared to be in the heart.🔽For this soul is in the heart.🔽In the question... He is the self in the heart.

original: praśna / / / 'sa vā eṣa ātmā hṛdi' chā / / /
analyzed: sa vai eṣaḥ ātmā hṛdi chā
translated: He is the self in the heart.

original: 'katama ātmeti yo 'yaṃ vijñānamayaḥ prāṇeṣu hṛdyantarjyotiḥ puruṣaḥ' bṛ / / /
analyzed: katamaḥ ātmā iti yaḥ yam vijñāna mayaḥ prāṇeṣu hṛdi antar jyotiḥ puruṣaḥ
translated: What is the self? He who is made of consciousness, the person in the heart within the breaths.

analyzed: ityādi upadeśebhyaḥ
translated: From such teachings.

analyzed: tasmāt dṛṣṭānta dārṣṭrāntikayoḥ avaiṣamyāt yuktam eva etat avirodhaḥ candana vat iti
translated: Therefore, because there is no inequality between the example and the subject, this is said to be correct and not contradictory, like sandal paste.

analyzed: guṇāt vā loka vat
translated: Or because of the quality, like in the world.

original: caitanyaguṇavyāptervāṇorapi sato jīvasya sakaladehavyāpi kāryaṃ na virudhyate /
analyzed: caitanya guṇa vyāpteḥ vā aṇoḥ api sataḥ jīvasya sakala deha vyāpi kāryam na virudhyate
translated: Or, because the soul, though minute, is pervaded by the quality of consciousness, it is not contradictory for its effect to pervade the entire body.

original: yathā loke maṇipradīpaprabhṛtīnāmapavarakaikadeśavartināmapi prabhāpavarakavyāpinī satī kṛtsne 'pavarake kāryaṃ karoti tadvat /
analyzed: yathā loke maṇi pradīpa prabhṛtīnām apavaraka eka deśa vartinām api prabhā pavaraka vyāpinī satī kṛtsne pavarake kāryam karoti tadvat
translated: Just as in the world, the light of gems, lamps, etc., though located in one part of a room, pervades the entire room and performs its function in the entire room, so is it here.

analyzed: syāt kadācid candanasya sāvayava tvāt sūkṣma avayava visarpaṇena api sakala dehe āhlādayitṛ tvam
translated: And it might be argued that sandal paste, being composed of parts, could delight the entire body by the spread of its subtle parts.

original: va tvaṇorjīvasyāvayavāḥ santi yairayaṃ sakaladehaṃ viprasarpedityāśaṅkya guṇādvā
analyzed: tu aṇoḥ jīvasya avayavāḥ santi yaiḥ ayam sakala deham viprasarpet iti āśaṅkya guṇāt vā
translated: But the soul is atomic, and it has no parts by which it could spread through the entire body.

analyzed: loka vat iti uktam
translated: Fearing such a doubt, the author says or by quality, like in the world.

analyzed: katham punar guṇaḥ guṇi vyatirekeṇa anyatra varteta
translated: How can a quality exist in something else apart from the possessor of the quality?

original: nahi paṭasya śuklo guṇaḥ paṭavyatirekeṇānyatra vartamāno dṛśyate /
analyzed: nahi paṭasya śuklaḥ guṇaḥ paṭa vyatirekeṇa anyatra vartamānaḥ dṛśyate
translated: For the white color of a cloth is not seen to exist in something else apart from the cloth.

analyzed: pradīpa bhāvat bhavet iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it could be like the light of a lamp, that is not so.

original: tasyā api dravyatvābhyupagamāt /🔽nibiḍāvayavaṃ hi tejodravyaṃ pradīpaḥ /
analyzed: tasyāḥ api dravya tva abhyupagamāt  nibiḍa avayavam hi tejaḥ dravyam pradīpaḥ
translated: Because even that is accepted as a substance.🔽A lamp is a mass of fire with closely packed parts.

analyzed: pravirala avayavam tu tejaḥ dravyam eva prabhā iti
translated: But light is a mass of fire with widely spaced parts.

analyzed: atas uttaram paṭhati
translated: Therefore, he replies to this as follows:

analyzed: vyatirekaḥ gandha vat
translated: The difference is like that of smell.

original: yathā guṇasyāpi sato gandhasya gandhavaddravyavyatirekeṇa vṛttirbhavati /
analyzed: yathā guṇasya api sataḥ gandhasya gandhavat dravya vyatirekeṇa vṛttiḥ bhavati
translated: Just as smell, though a quality, exists separately from substances possessing smell,

analyzed: aprāpteṣu api kusuma ādiṣu gandhavatsu kusuma gandha upalabdheḥ
translated: because the smell of flowers is perceived even in distant flowers.

analyzed: evam aṇoḥ api sataḥ jīvasya caitanya guṇa vyatirekaḥ bhaviṣyati
translated: In the same way, even though the soul is small, there will be a difference from the quality of consciousness.

analyzed: atas ca anaikāntikam etad guṇa tvāt rūpa ādi vat āśraya viśleṣa anupapattiḥ iti
translated: And therefore this reason is inconclusive: Because of being a quality, like form, there cannot be separation from the substratum.

analyzed: guṇasya eva sataḥ gandhasya āśraya viśleṣa darśanāt
translated: Because even a quality that exists, like smell, is seen to be separated from its substratum.

original: gandhasyāpi sahaivāśrayeṇa viśleṣa iti cet / na /
analyzed: gandhasya api saha eva āśrayeṇa viśleṣaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that even smell is separated along with its substratum, that is not so.

analyzed: yasmāt mūla dravyāt viśleṣitasya kṣaya prasaṅgāt
translated: Because if it were separated from the original substance, it would be destroyed.

analyzed: a kṣīyamāṇam api tat pūrva avasthātaḥ gamyate
translated: But it is understood to be not destroyed, as it was in its previous state.

analyzed: anyathā tad pūrva avasthaiḥ guru tva ādibhiḥ hīyeta
translated: Otherwise, it would be lacking the heaviness etc. of its previous state.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be argued:

analyzed: gandha āśrayāṇām viśliṣṭānām avayavānām alpa tvāt san api viśeṣaḥ na upalakṣyate
translated: Because the separated parts of the substratum of smell are small, the difference, though present, is not observed.

original: sūkṣmā hi gandhaparamāṇavaḥ sarvato viprasṛptā gandhabuddhimutpādayanti nāsikāpuṭamanupraviśanta iti cet / na /
analyzed: sūkṣmāḥ hi gandha paramāṇavaḥ sarvatas viprasṛptāḥ gandha buddhim utpādayanti nāsikā puṭam anupraviśantaḥ iti ced na
translated: For subtle odor atoms spread out in all directions and produce the cognition of odor. If it is argued that they enter the nostrils, that is not so.

analyzed: atīndriya tvāt paramāṇūnām sphuṭa gandha upalabdheḥ ca nāgakesara ādiṣu
translated: Because atoms are beyond the senses and because of the clear perception of odor in things like camphor.

analyzed: na ca loke pratītiḥ gandhavat dravyam āghrātam iti
translated: And there is no worldly cognition that a fragrant substance is smelled.

original: gandha evāghrāta iti tu laukikāḥ pratīyanti /
analyzed: gandhaḥ eva āghrātaḥ iti tu laukikāḥ pratīyanti
translated: But people are seen to think that only the odor is smelled.

analyzed: rūpa ādiṣu āśraya vyatireka anupalabdheḥ gandhasya api ayuktaḥ āśraya vyatirekaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the separation of odor from its substratum is not proper because the separation of form etc. from their substratum is not perceived, that is not so.

analyzed: pratyakṣa tvāt anumāna apravṛtteḥ
translated: Because of perceptibility, inference does not apply.

analyzed: tasmāt yat yathā loke dṛṣṭam tat tathā eva anumantavyam nirūpakaiḥ na anyathā
translated: Therefore, what is seen in the world should be inferred just as it is by those who investigate, not otherwise.

original: nahi raso guṇo jihvayopalabhyata ityato rūpādayo 'pi guṇā jihvāyaivopalabhyeragniriti niyantuṃ śakyate // //
analyzed: nahi rasaḥ guṇaḥ jihvayā upalabhyate iti atas rūpa ādayaḥ pi guṇāḥ jihvāya eva upalabhyeragniḥ iti niyantum śakyate
translated: For it cannot be determined that just because the quality taste is perceived by the tongue, form etc. qualities should also be perceived only by the tongue.

analyzed: guṇasya dravya vyatirekaḥ āśraya viśleṣaḥ
translated: The separation of a quality from a substance is its dissociation from its substratum.

analyzed: tathā ca darśayati
translated: And he shows it thus.

original: hṛdayāyatanatvamaṇuparimāṇatvaṃ cātmano 'bhidhāya tasyaiva 'ā lomasya ā nakhāgrebhyaḥ' chā / / /
analyzed: hṛdaya āyatana tvam aṇu parimāṇa tvam ca ātmanaḥ bhidhāya tasya eva ā lomasya ā nakha agrebhyaḥ
translated: Having declared that the soul has its abode in the heart and is of atomic size, the text goes on to say that it is to be seen only within the heart, and that it is to be sought for by the aid of the Upaniṣads

analyzed: iti caitanyena guṇena samasta śarīra vyāpi tvam darśayati
translated: Having declared that the soul has its abode in the heart and is of atomic size, the text shows by the passage, He is to be known as enclosed by the skin, and as filling the whole body with his self, that it pervades the whole body by its quality of intelligence

original: pṛthagupadeśāt / / / /🔽'prajñayā śarīraṃ samāruhya' kauṣī / /🔽iti cātmaprajñayoḥ kartṛkaraṇabhāvena pṛthagupadeśāccaitanyaguṇenaivāsya śarīravyāpitā gamyate /🔽'tadeṣāṃ prāṇānāṃ vijñānena vijñānamādāya' bṛ / / /
analyzed: pṛthak upadeśāt  prajñayā śarīram samāruhya kauṣī  iti ca ātma prajñayoḥ kartṛ karaṇa bhāvena pṛthak upadeśāt caitanya guṇena eva asya śarīra vyāpi tā gamyate  tat eṣām prāṇānām vijñānena vijñānam ādāya bṛ
translated: On account of the separate mention of the soul and of the quality of intelligence🔽The passage, Having mounted on the understanding the soul Kau Up , , shows that the soul and the understanding are to be viewed as different, the one being the agent, the other the instrument; from which it follows that the soul pervades the body by its quality of intelligence

analyzed: iti ca kartuḥ etam eva abhiprāyam upodbalayati
translated: The passage, Having taken with its intelligence the intelligence of these vital breaths Bṛ Up , , , teaches that the soul, which is the agent, is different from the intelligence of the body; and thus confirms the above interpretation

analyzed: tasmāt aṇuḥ ātmā iti
translated: Hence the soul is of atomic size

original: FN / vijñānamindriyāṇāṃ jñānaśaktiṃ vijñānena caitanyaguṇenādāya śeta ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: vijñānam indriyāṇām jñāna śaktim vijñānena caitanya guṇena ādāya śete iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the passage is that the soul, having taken with its quality of intelligence the quality of knowledge of the senses, lies in the body

analyzed: evam prāpte brūmaḥ
translated: To this we make the following reply

original: tadguṇasāratvāt tu tadvyapadeśaḥ prājñavat / / / /🔽tuśabdaḥ pakṣaṃ vyavartayati /
analyzed: tad guṇa sāra tvāt tu tad vyapadeśaḥ prājña vat  tuśabdaḥ pakṣam vyavartayati
translated: On account of the soul being the essence of the qualities, it is spoken of as having the qualities, like the wise prajña

analyzed: na etat asti aṇuḥ ātmā iti
translated: The word but sets aside the pūrvapakṣa It is not true that the soul is of atomic size

original: utpattyaśravaṇāddhi parasyaiva tu brahmaṇaḥ praveśaśravaṇāttādātmyopadeśācca parameva brahma jīva ityuktam /
analyzed: utpatti aśravaṇāt hi parasya eva tu brahmaṇaḥ praveśa śravaṇāt tādātmya upadeśāt ca param eva brahma jīvaḥ iti uktam
translated: For the reason already given, that the origin of the individual soul is not declared in the Upaniṣads, while the absorption of the individual soul into Brahman is declared, and for the reason that the Upaniṣads teach the identity of the individual soul with Brahman, we have already shown that the individual soul is the highest Brahman itself

original: parameva cedbrahma jīvastasmādyāvatparaṃ brahma tāvāneva jīvo bhavitumarhati /
analyzed: param eva ced brahma jīvaḥ tasmāt yāvat param brahma tāvān eva jīvaḥ bhavitum arhati
translated: If the individual soul is the highest Brahman, it follows that the individual soul is as great as the highest Brahman

analyzed: parasya ca brahmaṇaḥ vibhu tvam āmnātam
translated: And it is declared that the highest Brahman is allpervading

original: tasmādvibhurjīvaḥ /🔽tathāca 'sa vā eṣa mahānaja ātmā yo 'yaṃ vijñānamayaḥ prāṇeṣu' bṛ / / /
analyzed: tasmāt vibhuḥ jīvaḥ  tathā ca sa vai eṣa mahān ajaḥ ātmā yaḥ yam vijñāna mayaḥ prāṇeṣu
translated: Hence the individual soul is allpervading

original: ityevañjātīyakā jīvaviṣayā vibhutvavādāḥ śrautāḥ smārtāśca samarthitā bhavanti /
analyzed: iti evañjātīyakāḥ jīva viṣayāḥ vibhu tva vādāḥ śrautāḥ smārtāḥ ca samarthitāḥ bhavanti
translated: And thus the scriptural and Smṛti passages which declare the allpervadingness of the individual soul, such as He is this great unborn Self who consists of knowledge and is surrounded by the prāṇas Bṛ Up , , 0, are established

analyzed: na ca aṇoḥ jīvasya sakala śarīra gatā vedanā upapadyate
translated: And it is impossible that the individual soul, which is atomic, should feel the whole body

original: tvaksaṃbandhātsyāditi cet / na /🔽kaṇṭakatodane 'pi sakalaśarīragataiva vedanā prasajyeta /
analyzed: tvak saṃbandhāt syāt iti ced na  kaṇṭaka todane sakala śarīra gatā eva vedanā prasajyeta
translated: If it be said that the soul feels the whole body on account of its connexion with the skin, we deny that

original: tvakkaṇṭakayorhi saṃyogaḥ kṛtsnāyāṃ tvaci vartate tvakca kṛtsnaśarīravyāpinīti /
analyzed: tvakkaṇṭakayoḥ hi saṃyogaḥ kṛtsnāyām tvaci vartate tvac ca kṛtsna śarīra vyāpinī iti
translated: For in that case the soul would feel the whole body even when pricked by a thorn, since the connexion of the skin and the thorn extends over the whole skin, and the skin pervades the whole body

original: pādatala eva tu kaṇṭakanunno vedanāṃ prati labhate /
analyzed: pāda tale eva tu kaṇṭaka nunnaḥ vedanām prati labhate
translated: But the soul feels the prick only in the sole of the foot, not in the whole body

analyzed: na ca aṇoḥ guṇa vyāptiḥ upapadyate
translated: And it is impossible that the quality of allpervadingness should belong to the atomic soul

analyzed: guṇasya guṇi deśa tvāt
translated: Because the quality is located in the substratum of the possessor of the quality.

analyzed: guṇa tvam eva hi guṇinam an āśritya guṇasya hīyeta
translated: For the quality itself would be lost if it did not depend on the possessor of the quality.

analyzed: pradīpa prabhāyāḥ ca dravya antara tvam vyākhyātam
translated: And it has been explained that the light of a lamp is a different substance.

analyzed: gandhaḥ pi guṇa tva abhyupagamāt sa āśrayaḥ eva saṃcaritum arhati
translated: And smell also, because it is accepted as a quality, should move only along with its substratum.

analyzed: anyathā guṇa tva hāni prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be the undesirable consequence of losing its quality.

analyzed: tathā ca uktam dvaipāyanena upalabhya apsu ced gandam kecid brūyuḥ anaipuṇāḥ
translated: And thus it has been said by Dvaipayana: If some ignorant people were to say that they perceive smell in water,

original: pṛthivyāmeva taṃ vidyādapo vāyuṃ ca saṃśritam' iti /
analyzed: pṛthivyām eva tam vidyāt apaḥ vāyum ca saṃśritam iti
translated: one should know that it is on earth, resorting to water and air.

original: yadi ca caitanyaṃ jīvasya samastaṃ śarīraṃ vyāpnuyānnāṇurjīvaḥ syāt /
analyzed: yadi ca caitanyam jīvasya samastam śarīram vyāpnuyāt na aṇuḥ jīvaḥ syāt
translated: And if consciousness pervades the entire body of the individual soul, the individual soul would not be atomic.

analyzed: caitanyam eva hi asya svarūpam agneḥ iva auṣṇya prakāśau
translated: For consciousness itself is its own nature, like heat and light are of fire.

original: nātra guṇaguṇivibhāgo vidyata iti śarīraparimāṇatvaṃ ca pratyākhyātam /
analyzed: na atra guṇa guṇi vibhāgaḥ vidyate iti śarīra parimāṇa tvam ca pratyākhyātam
translated: There is no distinction here between quality and substance. Thus it has been refuted that the individual soul is of the size of the body.

analyzed: pariśeṣāt vibhuḥ jīvaḥ
translated: By elimination, the individual soul is all-pervading.

original: kathaṃ tarhyaṇutvādivyapadeśa ityata āha tad guṇasāratvāttu tadvyapadeśaḥ iti /
analyzed: katham tarhi aṇu tva ādi vyapadeśaḥ iti atas āha tat guṇa sāra tvāt tu tad vyapadeśaḥ iti
translated: Then how is it described as atomic and so on? To this he says: But it is described as such because it is the essence of its qualities.

original: tasyā buddherguṇāstadguṇā icchā dveṣaḥ sukhaṃ duḥkhamityevamādayastadguṇāḥ sāraḥ pradhānaṃ yasyātmanaḥ saṃsāritve saṃbhavati sa tadguṇasārastasya
analyzed: tasyāḥ buddheḥ guṇāḥ tad guṇāḥ icchā dveṣaḥ sukham duḥkham iti evamādayaḥ tad guṇāḥ sāraḥ pradhānam yasya ātmanaḥ saṃsāri tve saṃbhavati sa tad guṇa sāraḥ tasya
translated: The qualities of that buddhi are its qualities, such as desire, aversion, pleasure, pain, etc. That Self which has as its essence those qualities, when it is possible for it to be a transmigrator, is one whose essence is those qualities.

analyzed: bhāvaḥ tad guṇa sāra tvam
translated: The state of that is being one whose essence is those qualities.

analyzed: nahi buddheḥ guṇaiḥ vinā kevalasya ātmanaḥ saṃsāri tvam asti
translated: For the mere Self, without the qualities of buddhi, there is no transmigrating.

original: buddhyupādhirdharmādhyāsanimittaṃ hi kartṛtvabhoktṛtvādilakṣaṇaṃ saṃsāritvamakartṛrabhoktuścāsaṃsāriṇo nityamuktasya sata ātmanaḥ /
analyzed: buddhi upādhiḥ dharma adhyāsa nimittam hi kartṛ tva bhoktṛ tva ādi lakṣaṇam saṃsāri tvam akartṛḥ abhoktuḥ ca asaṃsāriṇaḥ nitya muktasya sataḥ ātmanaḥ
translated: For the state of being a transmigrator, characterized by being an agent and an experiencer, is due to the limiting adjunct of buddhi and the superimposition of its qualities. For the Self, which is not an agent, not an experiencer, and is not a transmigrator, is eternal and liberated.

analyzed: tasmāt tad guṇa sāra tvāt buddhi parimāṇena asya parimāṇa vyapadeśaḥ
translated: Therefore, because it has those qualities as its essence, it is described as having the same size as buddhi.

analyzed: tad utkrānti ādibhiḥ ca asya utkrānti ādi vyapadeśaḥ na svatas
translated: And because of its emergence, etc., its description as having emergence, etc., is due to that, not intrinsically.🔽And so, having stated the minuteness of the individual soul:

original: tathāca 'bālāgraśatabhāgasya śatadhā kalpitasya ca /🔽bhāgo jīvaḥ sa vijñeyaḥ sa cānantyāya kalpate' śve / /
analyzed: tathā ca bālāgra śata bhāgasya śatadhā kalpitasya ca  bhāgaḥ jīvaḥ sa vijñeyaḥ sa ca ānantyāya kalpate śve
translated: A hundredth part of the tip of a hair, divided a hundred times,🔽is the size of the individual soul, and that is considered to lead to infinity.

analyzed: iti aṇu tvam jīvasya uktvā tasya eva punar ānantyam āha
translated: Having stated the minuteness of the individual soul, he then speaks of its infinity.

original: taccaivameva samañjasaṃ syādyadyaupacārikamaṇutvaṃ jīvasya bhavetpāramārthikaṃ cānantyam /
analyzed: tat ca evam eva samañjasam syāt yadi aupacārikam aṇu tvam jīvasya bhavet pāramārthikam ca ānantyam
translated: And this would be quite consistent if the smallness of the individual soul were figurative, and its infinity real.

analyzed: nahi ubhayam mukhyam avakalpeta
translated: For both cannot be taken in their primary sense.

analyzed: na ca ānantyam aupacārikam iti śakyam vijñātum
translated: Nor can it be maintained that the infinity of the soul is figurative only,

original: sarvopaniṣatsu brahmātmabhāvasya pratipādayiṣitatvāt /🔽tathetarasminnapyunmāne 'buddherguṇenātmaguṇena caiva ārāgramātro hyavaro 'pi dṛṣṭaḥ' śve / /
analyzed: sarva upaniṣatsu brahma ātma bhāvasya  tathā itarasmin api unmāne buddheḥ guṇena ātma guṇena ca eva ārā agra mātraḥ hi avaraḥ dṛṣṭaḥ śve
translated: since all the Upaniṣads aim at teaching that Brahman is the Self of the individual soul.

original: iti ca buddhiguṇasaṃbandhenaivārāgramātratāṃ śāsti na svenaivātmanā /
analyzed: iti ca buddhi guṇa saṃbandhena eva ara agra mātra tām śāsti na svena eva ātmanā
translated: In the other passage also, , , , He is to be seen by the mind, by the quality and by the Self, he is of the size of an atom, or smaller than that, or greater than that, the text teaches that the soul is of the size of the point of a goad, only in so far as it is connected with the quality of the understanding, not in itself

original: 'eṣo 'ṇurātmā cetasā veditavyaḥ' muṇḍa / / /🔽ityatrāpi na jīvasyāṇuparimāṇatvaṃ śiṣyate /
analyzed: eṣaḥ ṇuḥ ātmā cetasā veditavyaḥ muṇḍa  iti atra api na jīvasya aṇu parimāṇa tvam śiṣyate
translated: In the passage, This soul is to be known by the mind, Mu Up , , , the smallness of the individual soul is not meant to be taught

analyzed: parasya eva ātmanaḥ cakṣuḥ ādi anavagrāhya tvena jñāna prasāda gamya tvena ca prakṛta tvāt
translated: For the highest Self only is referred to in the passage, on account of its being not apprehended by the eye, &c, and on account of its being to be apprehended by the favour of knowledge

analyzed: jīvasya api ca mukhya aṇu parimāṇa tva anupapatteḥ
translated: Moreover, the individual soul cannot be said to be of the size of an atom in the primary sense of the word

analyzed: tasmāt durjñāna tva abhiprāyam idam aṇu tva vacanam upādhi abhiprāyam vā draṣṭavyam
translated: Therefore the statement as to the soul being of the size of an atom must be viewed either as referring to the difficulty of knowing the soul, or as referring to the limiting adjuncts of the soul

original: tathā 'prajñayā śarīraṃ samāruhya' kauṣī / /🔽ityevañjātīyakeṣvapi bhedopadeśeṣu buddhyauvopādhibhūtayā jīvaḥ śarīraṃ samāruhyetyevaṃ yojayitavyam /🔽vyapadeśamātraṃ vā /
analyzed: tathā prajñayā śarīram samāruhya kauṣī  iti evañjātīyakeṣu api bheda upadeśeṣu buddhyā auvā upādhi bhūtayā jīvaḥ śarīram samāruhya iti evam yojayitavyam  vyapadeśa mātram vā
translated: So also in the passage, Having mounted the chariot by means of the understanding Kauṣ Up , , 0, the difference of the two has to be explained as a difference of the individual soul and the understanding, the individual soul being mounted on the body by means of the understanding which is the instrument of mounting

analyzed: śilāputrakasya śarīram iti avadat
translated: Or else the passage may be explained as a mere designation, the individual soul being compared to a puppet, the body to a machine, and the understanding to a puppeteer

analyzed: na hi atra vidyate iti uktam
translated: For here there is not even a difference of quality and substance, as has been said above

analyzed: hṛdaya āyatana tva vacanam api buddheḥ eva tad āyatana tvāt
translated: The statement that the individual soul has its abode in the heart is to be explained in the same way, the understanding being the abode of the individual soul

original: tathotkrāntyādīnāmapyupādhyāyattatāṃ darśayati 'kasminnvahamutkrānta utkrānto bhaviṣyāmi kasminvā pratiṣṭhite pratiṣṭhāsyāmīti' praśna / /🔽'sa prāṇamasṛjata' pra / / iti /
analyzed: tathā utkrānti ādīnām api upādhyāya tta tām darśayati kasmin u aham utkrāntaḥ utkrāntaḥ bhaviṣyāmi kasmin vā pratiṣṭhite pratiṣṭhāsyāmi iti praśna  sa prāṇam asṛjata pra iti
translated: In the same way the passage, In what shall I depart when I depart? In what shall I abide when I abide? Bṛ Up , , 0, shows that the departure and so on of the individual soul depend on the limiting adjuncts

analyzed: utkrānti abhāve hi gati agatyoḥ api abhāvaḥ vijñāyate
translated: The passage, He sent forth prāṇa Bṛ Up , , 0, shows that the going and coming of the individual soul depend on the limiting adjuncts, for if there were no departure, no going and coming would be possible

analyzed: nahi an apasṛpasya dehāt gati āgatī syātām
translated: For without passing out of the body there can be no going and coming

analyzed: evam upādhi guṇa sāra tvāt jīvasya aṇu tva ādi vyapadeśaḥ prājña vat
translated: In the same way the individual soul is spoken of as being of atomic size, because it is the aggregate of the qualities of its limiting adjuncts, just as the highest Lord is spoken of as being of atomic size

analyzed: yathā prājñasya paramātmanaḥ saguṇeṣu upāsaneṣu upādhi guṇa sāra tvāt aṇīyaḥ tva ādi vyapadeśaḥ aṇīyān vrīheḥ vā yavāt vā chā
translated: Just as the highest Self, which is the object of knowledge, is spoken of as small, &c, on account of its being contained in the qualities of the qualified Brahman, so also the individual soul is spoken of as small, &c, on account of its being contained in the qualities of the buddhi, as we see from such passages as He is smaller than a grain of rice, smaller than a grain of barley, smaller than a grain of mustard, smaller than a grain of millet Ch Up , ,

original: 'manomayaḥ prāṇaśarīraḥ sarvagandhaḥ sarvarasaḥ satyakāmaḥ satyasaṃkalpaḥ' chā / / /
analyzed: manaḥ mayaḥ prāṇa śarīraḥ sarva gandhaḥ sarva rasaḥ satya kāmaḥ satya saṃkalpaḥ chā
translated: He is the Self consisting of mind, having the lifebreath for his body, the essence of all odours, of all tastes, the fulfiller of all desires, the fulfiller of all purposes Ch Up , ,

analyzed: iti evaṃprakāraḥ tadvat  syāt etat yadi buddhi guṇa sāra tvāt ātmanaḥ saṃsāri tvam kalpyeta
translated: and so on

original: tato buddhyātmanorbhinnayoḥ saṃyogāvasānamavaśyaṃbhāvītyato buddhiviyoge satyātmano vibhaktasyānālakṣyatvādasattvamasaṃsāritvaṃ vā prasajyeteti
analyzed: tatas buddhi ātmanoḥ bhinnayoḥ saṃyoga avasānam avaśyaṃbhāvi iti atas buddhi viyoge sati ātmanaḥ vibhaktasya anālakṣya tvāt asattvam asaṃsāri tvam vā prasajyeta iti
translated: But if the individual soul were assumed to be the enjoyer in so far only as it is contained in the qualities of the buddhi, it would follow that the soul and the buddhi being two different things, their connexion must come to an end at some time or other; and then, when the soul is separated from the buddhi, it will be imperceptible and either nonexisting or not subject to the saṃsāra

original: ata uttaraṃ paṭhati🔽yāvadātmabhāvitvāc ca na doṣas taddarśanāt / / / /
analyzed: atas uttaram paṭhati  yāvadātmabhāvi tvāt ca na doṣaḥ tad darśanāt
translated: To this objection the next Sūtra replies🔽On account of the connexion of the soul with the buddhi lasting as long as the soul exists, no such objection is possible; as we see from Śruti

analyzed: na iyam anantara nirdiṣṭa doṣa prāptiḥ āśaṅkanīyā
translated: The objection stated above is not to be raised at all

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

analyzed: yāvadātmabhāvi tvāt buddhi saṃyogasya
translated: On account of the connexion of the soul with the buddhi lasting as long as the soul exists

analyzed: yāvat ayam ātmā saṃsārī bhavati
translated: As long as the soul exists as the enjoyer in the saṃsāra,

analyzed: yāvat asya samyak darśanena saṃsāri tvam na nivartate
translated: as long as its state of being an enjoyer is not put an end to by perfect knowledge,

analyzed: tāvat asya buddhyā saṃyogaḥ na śāmyati
translated: As long as his union with the intellect is not extinguished,

original: yāvadeva cāyaṃ buddhyupādhisaṃbandhastāvajjīvasya jīvatvaṃ saṃsāritvaṃ ca /🔽paramārthatastu na jīvo nāma buddhyupādhisaṃbandhaparikalpitasvarūpavyatirekeṇāsti /
analyzed: yāvat eva ca ayam buddhi upādhi saṃbandhaḥ tāvat jīvasya jīva tvam saṃsāri tvam ca  paramārthataḥ tu na jīvaḥ nāma buddhi upādhi saṃbandha parikalpita svarūpa vyatirekeṇa asti

original: nahi nityamuktasvarūpātsarvajñādīśvarādanyaścetano dhāturdvitīyo vedāntārthanirūpaṇāyāmupalabhyate /🔽'nānyo 'to 'sti draṣṭā śrotā mantā vijñātā' bṛ / / /
analyzed: nahi nitya mukta svarūpāt sarvajñāt īśvarāt anyaḥ cetanaḥ dhātuḥ dvitīyaḥ vedānta artha nirūpaṇāyām upalabhyate  na anyaḥ taḥ sti draṣṭā śrotā mantā vijñātā bṛ
translated: For in the determination of the meaning of the Vedanta, no second element of intelligence is found apart from the Lord, who is of the nature of the eternal and the free, and who is omniscient and so on.🔽'There is no other seer but He, no other hearer but He, no other feeler but He, no other knower but He' (Br. 3.7.23).

analyzed: na anyat atas sti draṣṭṛ śrotṛ mantṛ vijñātṛ chā
translated: 'There is no other seer but He, no other hearer but He, no other feeler but He, no other knower but He' (Ch. 3.14.4).

analyzed: tat tvam asi chā

analyzed: aham brahma asmi bṛ

analyzed: ityādi śrutebhyaḥ

analyzed: katham punar avagamyate yāvat ātma bhāvī buddhi saṃyogaḥ iti

analyzed: bṛ ityādi

analyzed: pradeśa antare vijñāna mayaḥ manaḥ mayaḥ prāṇa mayaḥ cakṣuḥ mayaḥ śrotra mayaḥ iti vijñāna mayasya manaḥ ādibhiḥ saha pāṭhāt
translated: In another place, it is said: ‘Made of consciousness, made of mind, made of life-breath, made of eye, made of ear’ (Chānd.

analyzed: buddhi maya tvam ca tad guṇa sāra tvam eva abhipreyate

translated: And it shows the inseparability of the Self from intelligence even in going to another world, by saying: ‘Being the same, it moves along both worlds’ (Chānd.

analyzed: kena samānaḥ tasya eva buddhyā iti gamyate saṃnidhānāt

analyzed: tat ca darśayati dhyāyati iva lelāyati iva iti

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati na ayam svatas dhyāyati

analyzed: na api calati

original: darśayati ca 'vedāhametaṃ puruṣaṃ mahāntamādityavarṇaṃ tamasaḥ purastāt /

analyzed: tam eva viditvā atimṛtyum eti na anyaḥ panthāḥ vidyate yanāya śve iti

analyzed: vijñāna mayaḥ buddhi pracuraḥ

analyzed: āditya varṇam sva prakāśam

analyzed: kṛtsna vikāra pralaya abhyupagamāt ca

analyzed: tat katham yāvadātmabhāvitvam buddhi saṃbandhasya iti atra ucyate
translated: Then how can the connection of the intellect be as long as the existence of the Self? To this it is said:

analyzed: puṃstva ādi vat tu asya sataḥ abhivyakti yogāt  /

original: yathā loke puṃstvādīni bījātmanā vidyamānānyeva bālyādiṣvanupalabhyamānānyavidyamānavadabhipreyamāṇāni yauvanādiṣvāvirbhavanti /

analyzed: evam hi etat yujyate

analyzed: na hi ākasmikī kasyacid utpattiḥ saṃbhavati

analyzed: atiprasaṅgāt

original: yathāyamātmopalabdhiṃ prati svatantro 'pyaniyameneṣṭamaniṣṭaṃ copalabhata evamaniyamenaiveṣṭamaniṣṭaṃ ca saṃpādayiṣyati /

analyzed: upalabdhau tu an anya apekṣa tvam ātmanaḥ caitanya yogāt

analyzed: na ca sahāya apekṣasya kartuḥ kartṛ tvam nivartate

analyzed: ahaṅkāra pūrvikāyāḥ eva pravṛtteḥ sarvatra darśanāt

original: yo 'pyayamaupaniṣadātmapratipattiprayojanaḥ samādhirupadiṣṭo vedānteṣu 'ātmā vā are draṣṭavyaḥ śrotavyo mantavyo nididhyasitavya so 'nveṣṭavyaḥ
analyzed: yaḥ u pi ayam aupaniṣada ātma pratipatti prayojanaḥ samādhiḥ upadiṣṭaḥ vedānteṣu ātmā vai are draṣṭavyaḥ śrotavyaḥ mantavyaḥ nididhyasitavya saḥ nveṣṭavyaḥ  /

analyzed: yathā ca takṣa ubhayathā

analyzed: tatra etaiḥ eva śāstra arthavat tva ādibhiḥ hetubhiḥ svābhāvikam kartṛ tvam apavāda hetu abhāvāt iti

analyzed: tasmāt samanāḥ eva svapne viharati

translated: And in the same way the Śruti describes the activity of the dream-state as connected with the forms of the waking state: ‘As if rejoicing with women, as if eating, as if beholding terrors’ (Br. 3, 1, 1).

original: laukikā api tathaiva svapnaṃ kathayanti ārukṣamiva giriśṛṅgamadrākṣamiva vanarājimiti /
analyzed: laukikāḥ api tathā eva svapnam kathayanti ārukṣam iva giri śṛṅgam adrākṣam iva vana rājim iti
translated: And people in the world describe their dreams in the same way: ‘As if I climbed the mountain-peak,’ ‘as if I saw the forest-range.’

original: tathopādāne 'pi yadyapi karaṇeṣu karmakaraṇavibhaktinirdeśastathāpi tatsaṃpṛktasyaivātmanaḥ kartṛtvaṃ draṣṭavyam /
analyzed: tathā upādāne pi yadi api karaṇeṣu karma karaṇa vibhakti nirdeśaḥ tathā api tad saṃpṛktasya eva ātmanaḥ kartṛ tvam draṣṭavyam
translated: And in the passage about the ‘upādāna’ (the ‘subjective cause’ of the dream-state), although the instruments of perception are indicated by the objective and instrumental cases, yet the soul in connection with them should be regarded as the agent.

analyzed: kevale kartṛ tva asaṃbhavasya darśita tvāt
translated: For the impossibility of the soul being the agent by itself has been shown.

original: bhavati ca loke 'nekaprakārā vivakṣā yodhā yudhyante yodhai rājā yudhyata iti /
analyzed: bhavati ca loke neka prakārā vivakṣā yodhāḥ yudhyante yodhaiḥ rājā yudhyate iti
translated: And in the world there is seen a variety of modes of expression: ‘The warriors fight,’ ‘The king fights through the warriors.’

original: apicāsminnupādāne karaṇavyāpāroparamamātraṃ vivakṣyate na svātantryaṃ kasyacidabuddhipūrvakasyāpi svāpe karaṇavyāpāroparamasya dṛṣṭatvāt /
analyzed: api ca asmin upādāne karaṇa vyāpāra uparama mātram vivakṣyate na svātantryam kasyacid abuddhi pūrvakasya api svāpe karaṇa vyāpāra uparamasya dṛṣṭa tvāt
translated: Moreover, in this passage about the ‘upādāna’ (the ‘subjective cause’ of the dream-state), the mere cessation of the activity of the instruments of perception is meant to be described, not the independence of anything; for the cessation of the activity of the instruments of perception is seen even in sleep, which is not preceded by the knowledge (of Brahman).

original: yastvayaṃ vyapadeśo darśitaḥ 'vijñānaṃ yajñaṃ tanute' iti /
analyzed: yaḥ tu ayam vyapadeśaḥ darśitaḥ vijñānam yajñam tanute iti
translated: But this designation (of the soul as the agent) which has been shown (in the passage, ‘The knowledge performs the sacrifice’),

analyzed: sa buddheḥ eva kartṛ tvam prāpayati
translated: that leads to the conclusion that the intellect is the agent.

analyzed: vijñāna śabdasya tatra prasiddha tvāt
translated: Because the word 'consciousness' is well-known there.

original: manonantaraṃ pāṭhācca /🔽'tasya śraddhaiva śiraḥ' tai / /🔽iti ca vijñānamayasyātmanaḥ śraddhādyavayavatvasaṃkīrtanāt /
analyzed: manaḥ anantaram pāṭhāt ca  tasya śraddhā eva śiraḥ tai  iti ca vijñāna mayasya ātmanaḥ śraddhā ādi avayava tva saṃkīrtanāt
translated: And because it is mentioned immediately after the mind.🔽And because in the text, 'Faith alone is its head' (Tai. 2.1), the consciousness-sheath is declared to be composed of faith and other qualities.

analyzed: śraddhā ādīnām ca buddhi dharma tva prasiddheḥ
translated: And because faith and other qualities are well-known to be attributes of the intellect.

analyzed: vijñānam devāḥ sarve brahma jyeṣṭham upāsate taiḥ
translated: And because in the remaining text, 'All the gods worship the Brahman, the eldest, through consciousness' (Tai. 2.1),

analyzed: iti ca vākya śeṣāt
translated: it is understood that the sacrifice is accomplished by speech and intellect.

analyzed: jyeṣṭha tvasya ca prathama ja tvam asya buddhau prasiddha tvāt
translated: And because the quality of being the eldest is well-known to belong to the intellect, as the first-born.

original: 'sa eṣa vācaścittasyottarottarakramo yadyajñaḥ' iti ca śrutyantare yajñasya vāgbuddhisādhyatvāvadhāramāt /
analyzed: saḥ eṣa vācaḥ cittasya uttarottara kramaḥ yat yajñaḥ iti ca śruti antare yajñasya vāc buddhi sādhya tva avadhāramāt
translated: And because in another scripture it is stated, 'This sacrifice is the successive order of speech and mind' (Tai. 2.2), it is understood that the sacrifice is accomplished by speech and intellect.

original: naca buddheḥ śaktiviparyayaḥ karaṇānāṃ kartṛtvābhyupagame bhavati /
analyzed: na ca buddheḥ śakti viparyayaḥ karaṇānām kartṛ tva abhyupagame bhavati
translated: And when the instruments are accepted as agents, there is no reversal of the power of the intellect.

analyzed: sarva kārakāṇām eva sva sva vyāpāreṣu kartṛ tvasya avaśyaṃbhāvi tvāt
translated: Because in their respective operations, all the instruments must necessarily be agents.

analyzed: upalabdhi apekṣam tu eṣām karaṇānām karaṇa tvam
translated: But the instrumentality of these instruments depends on apprehension.

analyzed: sā ca ātmanaḥ
translated: And that belongs to the self.

analyzed: na ca tasyām api asya kartṛ tvam asti
translated: And in that also, the self is not an agent.

analyzed: nityaḥ labdhi svarūpa tvāt
translated: Because its nature is eternal apprehension.

analyzed: ahaṅkāra pūrvakam api kartṛ tvam na upalabdhuḥ bhavitum arhati
translated: Even the agency preceded by the sense of I cannot be apprehended.

analyzed: ahaṅkārasya api upalabhyamāna tvāt
translated: Because the sense of I is also apprehended.

analyzed: na ca evam sati karaṇa antara kalpanā prasaṅgaḥ
translated: And in that case, there is no need to postulate another instrument.

analyzed: buddheḥ karaṇa tva abhyupagamāt
translated: Because intelligence is accepted as the instrument.

analyzed: samādhi abhāvaḥ tu parihṛtaḥ
translated: As for the absence of concentration, it is refuted by the very purpose of the scriptures.

analyzed: yathāprāptam eva kartṛ tvam upādāya samādhi vidhānāt
translated: Because concentration is enjoined on the basis of agency as it is obtained.

analyzed: tasmāt kartṛ tvam api ātmanaḥ upādhi nimittam eva iti sthitam
translated: Therefore, it is established that even agency belongs to the self only on account of the limiting adjunct.

analyzed: śoka antaram duḥkha a spṛṣṭam
translated: The other sorrow is that which is not touched by pain.

analyzed: gatiḥ prāpyam
translated: The goal is what is to be attained.

analyzed: lokaḥ bhogyam sukham
translated: The world is the enjoyable pleasure.

analyzed: anyaiḥ a prerya tvam svastha tvam
translated: Being not impelled by others is self-sufficiency.
Absence of mental effort is peace.
Absence of bodily activity is inactivity.

analyzed: saṃprasādaḥ suṣuptiḥ
translated: Tranquility is deep sleep.

analyzed: jakṣat bhuñjānā eva
translated: While eating, while enjoying.

analyzed: parāyatta adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on being dependent on another. Sutra.

analyzed: parāt tu tad śruteḥ
translated: But from the Veda, because it is heard from that.

analyzed: yat idam avidyā avasthāyām upādi nibandhanam kartṛ tvam jīvasya abhihitam
translated: This agency of the individual self, based on the limiting adjunct, which is stated in the state of ignorance,

analyzed: tat kim an apekṣya īśvaram bhavati āhosvit īśvara apekṣam iti bhavati vicāraṇā
translated: Therefore, the question arises whether the soul acts independently of God or in dependence on God.

original: tatra prāptaṃ tāvanneśvaramapekṣate jīvaḥ kartṛtva iti /
analyzed: tatra prāptam tāvat na īśvaram apekṣate jīvaḥ kartṛ tve iti
translated: Here, it is first established that the soul does not depend on God for its agency.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

analyzed: apekṣā prayojana abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no purpose for dependence.

original: ayaṃ hi jīvaḥ svayameva rāgadveṣādidoṣaprayuktaḥ kārakāntarasāmagrīsamapannaḥ kartṛtvamanubhavituṃ śaknoti /
analyzed: ayam hi jīvaḥ svayam eva rāga dveṣa ādi doṣa prayuktaḥ kāraka antara sāmagrī samapannaḥ kartṛ tvam anubhavitum śaknoti
translated: For this soul, being itself affected by faults like attachment and aversion, and being endowed with the assemblage of other causal factors, is capable of experiencing agency.

analyzed: tasya kim īśvaraḥ kariṣyati
translated: What will God do for it?

original: naca loke prasiddhirasti kṛṣyādikāsu kriyāsvanaḍudādivadīśvaro 'paro 'pekṣitavya iti /
analyzed: na ca loke prasiddhiḥ asti kṛṣi ādikāsu kriyāsu anaḍuh ādi vat īśvaraḥ pekṣitavyaḥ iti
translated: And there is no established usage in the world that another God is to be depended on in actions like agriculture, like an ox, etc.

original: kleṣātmakena ca kartṛtvena jantūnsaṃsṛjata īśvarasya nairghṛṇyaṃ prasajyeta /
analyzed: kleṣa ātmakena ca kartṛ tvena jantūn saṃsṛjataḥ īśvarasya nairghṛṇyam prasajyeta
translated: And if God binds beings with agency, which is of the nature of affliction, it would follow that God is merciless.

analyzed: viṣama phalam ca eṣām kartṛ tvam vidadhataḥ vaiṣamyam
translated: And in ordaining for them agency, which is an uneven fruit, He would be uneven.

analyzed: nanu vaiṣamya nairghṛṇye na sāpekṣa tvāt iti uktam
translated: But it has been said, Unevenness and mercilessness do not apply to Him, because He is not dependent on anything else.

analyzed: satyam uktam sati tu īśvarasya sāpekṣa tva saṃbhave
translated: This is true, if it is possible for God to be dependent on something.

original: sāpekṣatvaṃ ceśvarasya saṃbhavati satorjantūnāṃ dharmādharmayostayośca sadbhāvaḥ sati jīvasya kartṛtve /
analyzed: sāpekṣa tvam ca īśvarasya saṃbhavati satoḥ jantūnām dharma adharmayoḥ tayoḥ ca sadbhāvaḥ sati jīvasya kartṛ tve
translated: And God's dependence is possible when the souls and their dharma and adharma exist, and the existence of those two is when the individual soul is an agent.

analyzed: tat eva ced kartṛ tvam īśvara apekṣam syāt kiṃviṣayam īśvarasya sāpekṣa tvam ucyeta
translated: But if that very agency were dependent on God, on what would God's dependence be said to be?

analyzed: a kṛta abhyāgamaḥ ca evam jīvasya prasajyeta
translated: And thus the individual soul would be subject to the arrival of what is not done.

analyzed: tasmāt svatas eva asya kartṛ tvam iti
translated: Therefore, its agency is from itself alone.

original: etāṃ prāptiṃ tuśabdena vyāvartya pratijānīte 'parāt' iti /🔽avidyāvasthāyāṃ kāryakaraṇasaṃghātāvivekadarśino jīvasyāvidyātimirāndhasya sataḥ
analyzed: etām prāptim tuśabdena vyāvartya pratijānīte parāt iti  avidyā avasthāyām kārya karaṇa saṃghāta aviveka darśinaḥ jīvasya avidyā timira andhasya sataḥ
translated: But this conclusion is refuted by the word tu (but) and the proposition is stated as from another.🔽For the individual soul, who in the state of ignorance sees no difference between the aggregate of body and organs, who is blinded by the darkness of ignorance,

analyzed: parasmāt ātmanaḥ karma adhyakṣāt sarva bhūta adhivāsāt sākṣiṇaḥ cetayituḥ īśvarāt tad anujñayā
translated: from the supreme Self, the overseer of actions, the abode of all beings, the witness, the thinker, the Lord, with His permission,

analyzed: kartṛ tva bhoktṛ tva lakṣaṇasya saṃsārasya siddhiḥ
translated: the existence of transmigration characterized by agency and enjoyment is established.

analyzed: tad anugraha hetukena eva ca vijñānena mokṣa siddhiḥ bhavitum arhati
translated: And the attainment of liberation should be by the knowledge caused by His grace alone.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

analyzed: tad śruteḥ
translated: Because it is heard in the scriptures.

analyzed: yadi api doṣa prayuktaḥ sāmagrī saṃpannaḥ ca jīvaḥ
translated: Even though the individual soul is endowed with faults and with the collection of causes,

original: yadyapi ca loke kṛṣyādiṣu karmasu neśvarakāraṇatvaṃ prasiddhaṃ /
analyzed: yadi api ca loke kṛṣi ādiṣu karmasu na īśvara kāraṇa tvam prasiddham
translated: And although in the world the sovereignty of God is not acknowledged as the cause of such actions as agriculture, &c,

original: tathāpi sarvāsveva pravṛttiṣvīśvaro hetukarteti śruteravasīyate /🔽tathāhi śrutirbhavati 'eṣa hyeva sādhu karma kārayati taṃ yamebhyo lokebhya unninīyate /
analyzed: tathā api sarvāsu eva pravṛttiṣu īśvaraḥ hetu kartā iti śruteḥ avasīyate  tathā hi śrutiḥ bhavati eṣa hi eva sādhu karma kārayati tam yam ebhyaḥ lokebhyaḥ unninīyate
translated: nevertheless it is settled on the ground of Scripture that God is the cause of all activity.

original: eṣa hyevāsādhu karma kārayati taṃ yamadho ninīṣate' kauṣī / / iti /
analyzed: eṣa hi eva asādhu karma kārayati tam yam adhas ninīṣate iti
translated: For thus runs Scripture, He makes him do what is good, and then he leads him up to the higher worlds. He makes him do what is evil, and then he leads him down to the lower worlds Kaush Up ,

original: 'ya ātmani tiṣṭhannātmānamantaro yamayati' iti caivañjātīyakā // //🔽nanvevamīśvarasya kārayitṛtve sati vaiṣamyanairghaṇye syātāmakṛtābhyāgamaśca jīvasyeti /🔽netyucyate
analyzed: yaḥ ātmani tiṣṭhan ātmānam antaraḥ yamayati iti ca evañjātīyakā  nanu evam īśvarasya kārayitṛ tve sati vaiṣamya nairghaṇye syātām akṛta abhyāgamaḥ ca jīvasya iti  na iti ucyate
translated: And he who abiding in the Self rules the Self Bṛ Up , ,🔽Now, if it be admitted that God is the maker of all, the objections as to inequality, cruelty, and the like, and the objection as to the soul being charged with what it has not done, will present themselves

analyzed: kṛta prayatna apekṣaḥ tu vihita pratiṣiddha a vaiyarthya ādibhyaḥ
translated: To this we reply that God is the maker of all, but that he makes the soul act only in so far as the latter has itself made previous efforts of a virtuous or vicious nature

original: tuśabdaścoditadoṣavyāvartanārthaḥ /🔽kṛto yaḥ prayatno jīvasya dharmādharmalakṣaṇastadapekṣa evainamīśvaraḥ kārayati /
analyzed: tuśabdaḥ codita doṣa vyāvartana arthaḥ  kṛtaḥ yaḥ prayatnaḥ jīvasya dharma adharma lakṣaṇaḥ tad apekṣaḥ eva enam īśvaraḥ kārayati
translated: The word but is meant to set aside the objections urged above

analyzed: tatas ca ete coditāḥ doṣāḥ na prasajyante
translated: God makes the soul act only in so far as the latter has itself made previous efforts of a virtuous or vicious nature, which are called its works And thus the objections urged above do not apply to our doctrine

original: jīvakṛtadharmādharmavaiṣamyāpekṣa eva tattatphalāni viṣamaṃ vibhajetparjanyavadīśvaro nimittatvamātreṇa /
analyzed: jīva kṛta dharma adharma vaiṣamya apekṣaḥ eva tad tad phalāni viṣamam vibhajet parjanya vat īśvaraḥ nimitta tva mātreṇa
translated: God, like the rain, would distribute the fruits of action unequally, according to the inequality of the merit and demerit produced by the individual souls.

original: yathā loke nānāvidhānāṃ gucchagulmādīnāṃ vrīhiyavādīnāṃ cāsādhāraṇebhyaḥ svasvabījebhyo jāyamānānāṃ sādhāraṇaṃ nimittaṃ bhavati parjanyaḥ /
analyzed: yathā loke nānāvidhānām guccha gulma ādīnām vrīhi yava ādīnām ca a sādhāraṇebhyaḥ sva sva bījebhyaḥ jāyamānānām sādhāraṇam nimittam bhavati parjanyaḥ
translated: Just as in the world, for various clumps, thickets, etc., and for rice, barley, etc., which are born from their own individual seeds, rain is a common cause.

analyzed: na hi asati parjanye rasa paṣpa palāśa ādi vaiṣamyam teṣām jāyate
translated: For without rain, their differences in sap, flowers, leaves, etc. do not occur.

analyzed: na api asatsu sva sva bījeṣu
translated: Nor without their own individual seeds.

original: evaṃ jīvakṛtaprayatnāpekṣa īśvarasteṣāṃ śubhāśubhaṃ vidadhyāditi śliṣyate /
analyzed: evam jīva kṛta prayatna apekṣaḥ īśvaraḥ teṣām śubha aśubham vidadhyāt iti śliṣyate
translated: In the same way, God would bestow good and bad results on them in dependence on the effort produced by the individual souls. This is reasonable.

original: nanu kṛtaprayatnāpekṣatvameva jīvasya parāyatte kartṛtve nopapadyate /
analyzed: nanu kṛta prayatna apekṣa tvam eva jīvasya parāyatte kartṛ tve nā upapadyate
translated: But if the soul's agency is dependent on another, its dependence on previous effort is not possible.

analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ
translated: This is not a fault.

analyzed: parāyatte pi hi kartṛ tve karoti eva jīvaḥ
translated: For even if agency is dependent on another, the soul is the agent.

analyzed: kurvantam hi tam īśvaraḥ kārayati
translated: For God makes him act.

original: apica pūrvaprayatnamapekṣyedānīṃ kārayati pūrvataraṃ ca prayatnamapekṣya pūrvamakārayadityanāditvātsaṃsārasyetyanavadyam /
analyzed: apica pūrva prayatnam apekṣya idānīm kārayati pūrvataram ca prayatnam apekṣya pūrvam akārayat iti anādi tvāt saṃsārasya iti anavadyam
translated: Moreover, depending on a previous effort, he makes him act now; and depending on an earlier effort, he made him act before. Thus, since the cycle of birth and death is beginningless, there is no fault.

analyzed: katham punar avagamyate kṛta pratna apekṣaḥ īśvaraḥ iti
translated: How, again, is it known that God has regard to what has been done and what not done?

original: vihitapratiṣiddhāvaiyarthyādibhya ityāha /🔽evaṃ hi 'svargakāmo yajeta' 'brāhmaṇo na hantavyaḥ' /
analyzed: vihita pratiṣiddha a vaiyarthya ādibhyaḥ iti āha  evam hi svarga kāmaḥ yajeta brāhmaṇaḥ na hantavyaḥ
translated: He says: Because otherwise the injunctions and prohibitions would be meaningless, etc.

analyzed: iti evañjātīyakasya vihitasya pratiṣiddhasya ca a vaiyarthyam bhavati
translated: For thus alone is there sense in injunctions and prohibitions such as, 'One who desires heaven should sacrifice,' 'A Brāhmaṇa should not be killed,' etc.

analyzed: anyathā tat anarthakam syāt
translated: Otherwise they would be meaningless.

analyzed: īśvaraḥ eva vidhi pratiṣedhayoḥ niyujyeta
translated: God alone would be appointed to the injunctions and prohibitions.

analyzed: atyanta paratantra tvāt jīvasya
translated: Because the individual soul is absolutely dependent.

analyzed: tathā vihita kāriṇam api anarthena saṃsṛjet pratiṣiddha kāriṇam api arthena
translated: Thus he would connect even one who acts according to the injunctions with misfortune, and even one who acts contrary to the injunctions with good fortune.

original: tataśca prāmāṇyaṃ vedasyāstamiyāt /🔽īśvarasya cātyantānapekṣatve laukikasyāpi puruṣakārasya vaiyarthyaṃ tathā deśakālanimittānāṃ pūrvoktadoṣaprasaṅgaścetyevañjātīyakaṃ doṣajātamādigrahaṇena
analyzed: tatas ca prāmāṇyam vedasya astam iyāt  īśvarasya ca atyanta anapekṣa tve laukikasya api puruṣakārasya vaiyarthyam tathā deśa kāla nimittānām pūrva ukta doṣa prasaṅgaḥ ca iti evañjātīyakam doṣa jātam ādi grahaṇena
translated: And then the authoritativeness of the Veda would be destroyed.

analyzed: darśayati
translated: And if God were absolutely independent, human effort in the world would be useless, and the previously mentioned faults would apply to place, time, and causes. This kind of fault is shown by the word 'etc.'

analyzed: aṃśa adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on parts. Sutra.

original: aṃśo nānāvyapadeśād anyathā cāpi dāśakitavāditvam adhīyata eke / / / /
analyzed: aṃśaḥ nānā vyapadeśāt anyathā ca api dāśa kitavādi tvam adhīyate eke
translated: The part is different because of different designations, and some study it as the son of Dāsakīrti in another way.

analyzed: jīva īśvarayoḥ upakārya upakāra bhāvaḥ uktaḥ
translated: The relation of being helped and helper is stated to exist between the individual soul and God.

original: sa ca saṃbaddhayoreva loke dṛṣṭo yathā svāmibhṛtyayoryathā vāgnivisphuliṅgayoḥ /
analyzed: sa ca saṃbaddhayoḥ eva loke dṛṣṭaḥ yathā svāmi bhṛtyayoḥ yathā vā agni visphuliṅgayoḥ
translated: And this is seen in the world to exist only between connected things, as between a master and a servant, or as between fire and a spark.

analyzed: tatas ca jīva īśvarayoḥ api upakārya upakāraka bhāva abhyupagamāt kim svāmi bhṛtya vat saṃbandhaḥ āhosvit agni visphuliṅga vat iti asyām vicikitsāyām aniyamaḥ vā
translated: Therefore, since the relation of being helped and helper is accepted to exist between the individual soul and God, the doubt arises as to whether their relation is like that of master and servant or like that of fire and a spark.

analyzed: prāpnoti
translated: In this doubt, there would be no restriction.

original: athavā svāmibhṛtyaprakāreṣveveśitrīśitavyabhāvasya prasiddhatvāttadvidha eva saṃbandha iti prāpnoti /
analyzed: athavā svāmi bhṛtya prakāreṣu eva īśitṛ īśitavya bhāvasya prasiddha tvāt tadvidhaḥ eva saṃbandhaḥ iti prāpnoti
translated: Or, since the relation of being controlled and controller is well-known to exist in the manner of master and servant, the relation would be of that kind.

analyzed: atas bravīti aṃśaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, he says 'part'.

analyzed: jīvaḥ īśvasya aṃśaḥ bhavitum arhati  yathā agneḥ visphuliṅgaḥ
translated: The individual soul should be a part of God.🔽Like a spark of fire.

original: aṃśa ivāṃśo nahi niravayavasya mukhyoṃ'śaḥ saṃbhavati /
analyzed: aṃśaḥ iva aṃśaḥ nahi niravayavasya mukhyaḥ oṃśaḥ saṃbhavati
translated: A part is like a part, because a part of the principal, which is indivisible, is not possible.

analyzed: kasmāt punar niravayava tvāt saḥ eva na bhavati
translated: But why is it not the same because of being indivisible?

analyzed: nānā vyapadeśāt
translated: Because of the designation of difference.

analyzed: saḥ nveṣṭavyaḥ sa vijijñāsitavyaḥ chā
translated: 'He is to be sought, he is to be desired to be known' (Ch. 7.25.2).

original: 'etameva viditvā munirbhavati' ' ya ātmani tiṣṭhannātmānamantaro yamayati' iti caivañjātīyako bhedanirdeśo nāsati bhede yujyate /
analyzed: etam eva viditvā muniḥ bhavati yaḥ ātmani tiṣṭhan ātmānam antaraḥ yamayati iti ca evañjātīyakaḥ bheda nirdeśaḥ na asati bhede yujyate
translated: And the like statements about difference, such as, Knowing him only, the sage becomes calm; he who, abiding in the Self, rules the Self from within, are not tenable if there is no difference.

original: nanu cāyaṃ nānāvyapadeśaḥ sutarāṃ svāmibhṛtyasārūpye yujyata ityata āha anyathā cāpīti /
analyzed: nanu ca ayam nānā vyapadeśaḥ sutarām svāmi bhṛtya sārūpye yujyate iti atas āha anyathā ca api iti
translated: But this manifold designation is more appropriate if there is a relation of master and servant? To this he says, And in another way also, etc.

analyzed: na ca nānā vyapadeśāt eva kevalāt aṃśa tva pratiptiḥ
translated: And the individual soul is not known to be a part merely on the ground of the manifold designation.

original: kiṃ tarhyanyathā cāpi vyapadeśo bhavatyanānātvasya pratipādakaḥ /
analyzed: kim tarhi anyathā ca api vyapadeśaḥ bhavati a nānātvasya pratipādakaḥ
translated: But in another way also, the designation is made, which teaches nondifference.

original: tathāhi eke śākhino dāśakitavādibhāvaṃ brahmaṇa āmanantyātharvaṇikā brahmasūkte 'brahma dāśā brahma dāsā brahmaiveme kitavāḥ' ityādinā /
analyzed: tathā hi eke śākhinaḥ dāśa kitava ādi bhāvam brahmaṇaḥ āmananti ātharvaṇikāḥ brahmasūkte brahma dāśāḥ brahma dāsāḥ brahma eva ime kitavāḥ ityādinā
translated: Thus, some Śākhās, the Ātharvaṇikas, declare in the Brahmasūkta that Brahman is in the condition of a fisherman, etc., Brahman is the fishermen, Brahman are the servants, Brahman are these gamblers, etc.

analyzed: dāśāḥ ye ete kaivartāḥ prasiddhāḥ
translated: The fishermen are those wellknown people who live by fishing.

analyzed: ye ca amī dāsāḥ svāmiṣu ātmānam upakṣapayanti
translated: And the servants are those who offer themselves to their masters.

original: ye cānye kitavā dyūtakṛtaste sarve brahmaiveti hīnajantūdāharaṇena sarveṣāmeva nāmarūpakṛtakāryakaraṇasaṃghātapraviṣṭānāṃ jīvānāṃ brahmatvamāha
analyzed: ye ca anye kitavāḥ dyūta kṛtaḥ te sarve brahmā eva iti hīna jantu udāharaṇena sarveṣām eva nāma rūpa kṛta kārya karaṇa saṃghāta praviṣṭānām jīvānām brahmatvam āha
translated: And the other gamblers are those who play at dice. All these are Brahman. Thus, by the example of the low animals, it declares that all the individual souls, which have entered the aggregates of causes and effects produced by name and form, are Brahman.

original: tathānyatrāpi brahmaprakriyāyāmevāyamarthaḥ prapañcyate 'tvaṃ strī tvaṃ pumānasi tvaṃ kumāra uta vā kumārī /
analyzed: tathā anyatra api brahma prakriyāyām eva ayam arthaḥ prapañcyate tvam strī tvam pumān asi tvam kumāraḥ uta vā kumārī
translated: And in another place also, in the same context of Brahman, this matter is enlarged upon: ‘Thou art the female, thou art the male; thou art the youth, thou art even the virgin.

original: tvaṃ jīrṇo daṇḍena vañcasi tvaṃ jāto bhavasi viśvatomukhaḥ' śve / / iti /
analyzed: tvam jīrṇaḥ daṇḍena vañcasi tvam jātaḥ bhavasi viśvatomukhaḥ śve iti
translated: Thou art old, thou goest with a staff; thou art born again, thou hast a face on every side’ (Śve Up. 1).

original: 'sarvāṇi rūpāṇi vicitya dhīro nāmāni kṛtvābhivadanyadāste' iti ca /🔽'nānyo 'to 'sti draṣṭā' bṛca / /
analyzed: sarvāṇi rūpāṇi vicitya dhīraḥ nāmāni kṛtvā abhivadanyat āste iti ca  na anyaḥ taḥ sti draṣṭā bṛca
translated: And: ‘The wise one, having created all forms, having made all names, sits calling them by their names’ (RV. 10, 90, 3).

analyzed: ityādi śrutibhyaḥ ca asya arthasya siddhiḥ
translated: And from the following scriptural passages the matter is established: ‘There is no other seer but he’ (Br. 1, 4, 10).

analyzed: caitanyam ca aviśiṣṭam jīva īśvarayoḥ yathā agni visphuliṅgayoḥ auṣṇyam
translated: And consciousness is not different in the individual soul and the Lord, as heat is not different in fire and a spark.

analyzed: atas bheda abheda avagamābhyām aṃśa tva avagamaḥ
translated: Therefore, from the cognition of difference and non-difference, the cognition of the individual soul being a part of God is established.

analyzed: kutas ca aṃśa tva avagamaḥ
translated: And from where else is the cognition of the individual soul being a part established?

analyzed: mantra varṇāt ca
translated: And from the words of the mantra.

analyzed: mantra varṇaḥ ca etam artham avagamayati tāvān asya mahimā tatas jyāyān ca puruṣaḥ
translated: And the words of the mantra make this matter known: ‘His greatness is so great; the person is greater than that.

original: pādo 'sya sarvābhūtāni tripādasyāmṛtaṃ divi' chā / / / iti /
analyzed: pādaḥ sya sarvābhūtāni tri pādasya amṛtam divi chā iti
translated: One foot of him are all beings; three feet of him are what is immortal in heaven’ (RV. 10, 90, 3).

analyzed: atra bhūta śabdena jīva pradhānāni sthāvara jaṅgamāni nirdiśati
translated: Here, by the word ‘beings’ he indicates the moving and unmoving, with the individual soul as the chief.

analyzed: a hiṃsan sarva bhūtāni anyatra tīrthebhyaḥ iti prayogāt
translated: And because the text, 'without injuring any creature, except in the case of sacrifices,' shows that the soul is a part of God.

analyzed: aṃśaḥ pādaḥ bhāgaḥ iti anarthāntaram
translated: Part, foot, portion, are synonymous terms.

analyzed: tasmāt api aṃśa tva avagamaḥ
translated: Therefore, the soul is known to be a part of God.

analyzed: kutas ca aṃśa tva avagamaḥ
translated: And from what other source is the soul known to be a part of God?

analyzed: api ca smaryate  /
translated: And it is remembered in the Smritis.

original: īśvaragītāsvapi ceśvaraṃśatvaṃ jīvasya smaryate 'mamaivāṃśo jīvaloke jīvabhūtaḥ sanātanaḥ' / iti /
analyzed: īśvaragītāsu api ca īśvara aṃśa tvam jīvasya smaryate mama eva aṃśaḥ jīva loke jīva bhūtaḥ sanātanaḥ iti
translated: And in the Bhagavad-Gita, the soul is remembered to be a part of God: 'The eternal soul, become a living being in the world of living beings, is a part of Myself.'

analyzed: tasmāt api aṃśa tva avagamaḥ  yat tu uktam svāmi bhṛtya ādiṣu eva īśitṛ īśitavya bhāvaḥ loke prasiddhaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, the soul is known to be a part of God.🔽But it has been said that the relation of ruler and ruled is well known in the world in the case of masters and servants, etc.

analyzed: yadi api eṣā loke prasiddhaḥ tathā api śāstrāt tu atra aṃśa aṃśi tvam īśitṛ īśitavya bhāvaḥ ca niścīyate
translated: Although this is well known in the world, still from the scriptures, the relation of part and whole and that of ruler and ruled is ascertained here.

analyzed: niratiśaya upādhi saṃpannaḥ ca īśvaraḥ nihīna upādhi saṃpannān jīvān praśāsti iti na kiñcid vipratiṣidhyate  /
translated: And God, endowed with incomparable attributes, rules over the souls endowed with inferior attributes. Thus nothing is contradicted.

original: atrāha nanu jīvasyeśvarāṃśatvābhyupagame tadīyena saṃsāraduḥkhopabhogenāṃśina īśvarasyāpi duḥkhitvaṃ syāt /
analyzed: atra āha nanu jīvasya īśvara aṃśa tva abhyupagame tadīyena saṃsāra duḥkha upabhogena aṃśinaḥ īśvarasya api duḥkhi tvam syāt
translated: Here it is said: If the soul is accepted as a part of God, then by the experience of worldly suffering belonging to the soul, God, the possessor of the part, would also be miserable.

original: yathā loke hastapādādyanyatamāṅgagatena duḥkhenāṅgino devadattasya duḥkhitvaṃ tadvat /
analyzed: yathā loke hasta pāda ādi anyatama aṅga gatena duḥkhena aṅginaḥ devadattasya duḥkhi tvam tadvat
translated: Just as in the world, when one part, such as the hand or foot, is pained, the whole body, Devadatta, is pained.

analyzed: tatas ca tad prāptānām mahattaram duḥkham prāpnuyāt
translated: And therefore, those who attain that would attain a much greater suffering.

original: ato varaṃ pūrvāvasthaḥ saṃsāra evāstviti samyagdarśanānarthakyaprasaṅgaḥ syāditi /
analyzed: atas varam pūrva avasthaḥ saṃsāraḥ evā astu iti samyak darśana ānarthakya prasaṅgaḥ syāt iti
translated: Therefore, it would be better to remain in the previous state of saṃsāra itself. Thus, the futility of right knowledge would follow.

analyzed: atrā ucyate
translated: To this it is said:

analyzed: prakāśa ādi vat na evam paraḥ
translated: The Supreme is not like that, like light, etc.

original: yathā jīvaḥ saṃsāraduḥkhamanubhavati naivaṃ para īśvaro 'nubhavatīti pratijānīmahe /
analyzed: yathā jīvaḥ saṃsāra duḥkham anubhavati na evam paraḥ īśvaraḥ nubhavati iti pratijānīmahe
translated: We declare that the Supreme Lord does not experience suffering in the same way that the individual soul experiences the suffering of saṃsāra.

original: jīvo hyavidyāveśavaśāddehādyātmabhāvamiva gatvā tatkṛtena duḥkhena duḥkhyahamityavidyayā kṛtaṃ duḥkhopabhogamabhimanyate /
analyzed: jīvaḥ hi avidyā āveśa vaśāt deha ādi ātma bhāvam iva gatvā tad kṛtena duḥkhena duḥkhī aham iti avidyayā kṛtam duḥkha upabhogam abhimanyate
translated: For the individual soul, under the influence of the power of ignorance, as if having become identified with the body and so on, thinks due to ignorance that it is experiencing the suffering created by that [identification].

analyzed: na evam parameśvarasya deha ādi ātma bhāvaḥ duḥkha abhimānaḥ vā asti
translated: But the Supreme Lord has no real identification with the body and so on or the notion of suffering.

analyzed: jīvasya api avidyā kṛta nāma rūpa nirvṛtta deha indriya ādi upādhya viveka bhrama nimittaḥ eva duḥkha abhimānaḥ na tu pāramārthikaḥ sti
translated: And the individual soul's notion of suffering is due only to the delusion of nondiscrimination regarding the limiting adjuncts such as the body and senses produced by name-and-form created by ignorance, and it is not real.

original: yathāca svadehagatadāhacchedādinimittaṃ duḥkhaṃ tadabhimānabhrāntyānubhavati tathā🔽putramitrādigocaramapi duḥkhaṃ tadabhimānabhrāntyaivānubhavatyahameva putro 'hameva
analyzed: yathā ca sva deha gata dāha cheda ādi nimittam duḥkham tad abhimāna bhrāntyā anubhavati tathā  putra mitra ādi gocaram api duḥkham tad abhimāna bhrāntyā eva anubhavati aham eva putraḥ ham eva
translated: And just as he experiences pain caused by burning, cutting, etc., in his own body, through the error of identifying with it,

analyzed: mitram iti evam sneha vaśena putra mitra ādiṣu abhiniviśamānaḥ
translated: so also he experiences pain having for its object son, friend, etc., through the error of identifying with them, thinking, “I am the son,” “I am the friend,” and so on, thus becoming attached to son, friend, etc., out of affection.

original: tataśca niścitametadavagamyate mithyābhimānabhramanimitta eva duḥkhānubhava iti /
analyzed: tatas ca niścitam etat avagamyate mithyā abhimāna bhrama nimittaḥ eva duḥkha anubhavaḥ iti
translated: And from this it is ascertained with certainty that the experience of pain has for its cause the error of false identification.

original: vyatirekadarśanāccaivamavagamyate /🔽tathāhi putramitrādimatsu bahuṣūpaviṣṭeṣu tatsaṃbandhābhimāniṣvitareṣu ca putro
analyzed: vyatireka darśanāt ca evam avagamyate  tathā hi putra mitra ādimatsu bahuṣu upaviṣṭeṣu tad saṃbandha abhimāniṣu itareṣu ca
translated: And it is understood in this way also from the observation of the absence of pain.

analyzed: mṛtaḥ mitram mṛtam iti evamādi udghoṣite yeṣām eva putra mitra ādimat tva abhimānaḥ teṣām eva
translated: For example, when many people are seated, some of whom have sons, friends, etc., and some of whom do not, and the announcement is made, “The son is dead,” “The friend is dead,” and so on,

analyzed: tad nimittam duḥkham utpadyate na abhimāna hīnānām parivrājaka ādīnām
translated: then pain arises only in those who have the notion of having sons, friends, etc., and not in those who are free from the notion, such as wandering ascetics.

analyzed: atas ca laukikasya api puṃsaḥ samyak darśana arthavat tvam dṛṣṭam
translated: And from this it is seen that even for a worldly person, the purpose of right knowledge is seen.

analyzed: kim uta viṣaya śūnyāt ātmanaḥ nyat vastu antaram apaśyataḥ nitya caitanya mātra svarūpasya iti
translated: How much less so for the Self, which is devoid of objects, which does not see any other thing, and whose nature is eternal consciousness alone?

analyzed: tasmāt nā asti samyak darśana ānarthakya prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Therefore, the objection that the knowledge of Brahman is useless does not arise.

analyzed: prakāśa ādi vat iti nidarśana upanyāsaḥ
translated: The example of light, etc. is stated.

original: yathā prakāśaḥ sauraścāndramaso vā viyadvyāpyavatiṣṭhamāno 'ṅgulyādyupādhisaṃbandhātteṣvṛjuvakrādibhāvaṃ🔽pratipadyamāneṣu tattadbhāvamiva pratipadyamāno 'pi na paramārthatastadbhāvaṃ pratipadyate /
analyzed: yathā prakāśaḥ sauraḥ cāndramasaḥ vā viyat vyāpya avatiṣṭhamānaḥ ṅguli ādi upādhi saṃbandhāt teṣu ṛju vakra ādi bhāvam  pratipadyamāneṣu tad tad bhāvam iva pratipadyamānaḥ pi na paramārthataḥ tad bhāvam pratipadyate
translated: Just as the light, whether solar or lunar, pervading the sky, due to the contact of limiting adjuncts like the finger, appears to have the states of straight, curved, etc.,

original: yathā cākāśo ghaṭādiṣu gacchatsu gacchanniva vibhāvyamāno 'pi na paramārthato gacchati /
analyzed: yathā ca ākāśaḥ ghaṭa ādiṣu gacchatsu gacchan iva vibhāvyamānaḥ na paramārthataḥ gacchati
translated: although it does not really assume those states. And just as the sky, when the pots, etc. are moving, appears to be moving, but does not really move.

original: yathā codaśarāvādikampanāttadgate sūryapratibimbe kampamāne 'pi na tadvānsūryaḥ kampate /
analyzed: yathā ca uda śarāva ādi kampanāt tad gate sūrya pratibimbe kampamāne na tadvān sūryaḥ kampate
translated: And just as when the reflection of the sun in a well, etc. moves due to the shaking of the well, etc., the sun possessing it does not move.

original: evamavidyāpratyupasthāpite buddhyādyupahite jīvākhyeṃ'śe duḥkhāyamāne 'pi na tadvānīśvaro duḥkhāyate /
analyzed: evam avidyā pratyupasthāpite buddhi ādi upahite jīva ākhya iṃśe duḥkhāyamāne na tadvān īśvaraḥ duḥkhāyate
translated: In the same way, when the part called Jiva, which is superimposed by ignorance and limited by intellect, etc., is suffering, the Lord possessing it does not suffer.

analyzed: jīvasya api tu duḥkha prāptiḥ avidyā nimittā eva iti uktam
translated: But it has been said that the Jiva's experience of suffering is also due to ignorance.

original: tathācāvidyānimittajīvabhāvavyudāsena brahmabhāvameva jīvasya pratipādayanti vedāntāḥ 'tattvamasi' ityevamādayaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca avidyā nimitta jīva bhāva vyudāsena brahma bhāvam eva jīvasya pratipādayanti vedāntāḥ tat tvam asi iti evamādayaḥ
translated: And thus the Vedānta texts, such as ‘That thou art,’ teach that the individual soul is Brahman itself, by removing the state of the individual soul which is due to Nescience.

analyzed: tasmāt nā asti jaivena duḥkhena paramātmanaḥ duḥkhi tva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Therefore, there is no occasion for the highest Self to be miserable on account of the misery of the individual soul.

analyzed: itareṣu abhimāna śūnyeṣu
translated: In other words, in those who are devoid of the sense of mineness.

analyzed: smaranti ca
translated: And they remember.

original: smaranti ca vyāsādayo yathā jaivena duḥkhena na paramātmā duḥkhāyata iti /
analyzed: smaranti ca vyāsa ādayaḥ yathā jaivena duḥkhena na paramātmā duḥkhāyate iti
translated: And Vyāsa and others remember that the highest Self is not made miserable by the misery of the individual soul.

original: 'tatra yaḥ paramātmā hi sa nityo nirguṇaḥ smṛtaḥ /
analyzed: tatra yaḥ parama ātmā hi sa nityaḥ nirguṇaḥ smṛtaḥ
translated: ‘There the highest Self is indeed eternal and without qualities, it is remembered.

analyzed: na lipyate phalaiḥ ca api padma patram iva ambhasā
translated: It is not affected by the fruits, like a lotus leaf by water.

original: karmātmā tvaparo yo 'sau mokṣabandhanaiḥ sa yujyate /
analyzed: karma ātmā tu aparaḥ yaḥ sau mokṣa bandhanaiḥ sa yujyate
translated: The other one, the individual soul, is connected with bondage and liberation.

original: sa saptadaśakenāpi rāśinā yujyate punaḥ' iti /
analyzed: sa saptadaśakena api rāśinā yujyate punar iti
translated: It is again connected with the aggregate of seventeen.’

analyzed: caśabdāt samāmananti ca iti vākya śeṣaḥ
translated: From the word ‘ca’ (and), the remainder of the sentence is ‘they also declare.’

analyzed: tayoḥ anyaḥ pippalam svādvatti an aśnan anyaḥ abhicākaśīti śve iti
translated: ‘One of them eats the sweet fruit, the other looks on without eating’ (Śve. 6.7).

original: 'ekastathā sarvabhūtāntarātmā na lipyate lokaduḥkhena bāhyaḥ' kaṭha / / iti ca // //
analyzed: ekaḥ tathā sarva bhūta antarātmā na lipyate loka duḥkhena bāhyaḥ kaṭhaḥ iti ca
translated: ‘The one Self within all beings is not affected by the misery of the world, being external to it’ (Ka. 1.2.22).

original: atrāha yadi tarhyeka eva sarveṣāṃ bhūtānāmantarātmā syātkathamanujñāparihārau syātāṃ lokikau vaidikau ceti /
analyzed: atra āha yadi tarhi ekaḥ eva sarveṣām bhūtānām antarātmā syāt katham anujñā parihārau syātām lokikau vaidikau ca iti
translated: To this we make the following reply If the individual soul is the internal Self of all beings, how can there be any permission and prohibition either in the world or in the Veda?

analyzed: nanu ca aṃśaḥ jīvaḥ īśvarasya iti uktam
translated: But it has been said that the individual soul is a part of the Lord!

analyzed: tad bhedāt ca anujñā parihārau tad āśrayau avyatikīrṇau upapadyete kim atra codyate iti
translated: And as there is a difference of parts, permission and prohibition, which are based on that difference, are possible without confusion Why then do you raise the question?

original: ucyate naitadevam /🔽anaṃśitvamapi hi jīvasyābhedavādinyaḥ śrutayaḥ pratipādayanti 'tatsṛṣṭvā tadevānuprāviśat' te / / /🔽'nānyo 'to 'sti draṣṭā' bṛ / / /🔽'mṛtyoḥ sa mṛtyumāpnoti ya iha nāneva paśyati' bṛ / / /🔽'tattvamasi' chā / / /
analyzed: ucyate na etat evam  an aṃśi tvam api hi jīvasya abheda vādinyaḥ śrutayaḥ pratipādayanti tat sṛṣṭvā tat eva anuprāviśat te  na anyaḥ taḥ sti draṣṭā bṛ  mṛtyoḥ sa mṛtyum āpnoti yaḥ iha nānā iva paśyati  tat tvam asi chā
translated: We reply This is not so

original: 'ahaṃ brahmāsmi' bṛ / / /🔽ityevañjātīyakāḥ /🔽nanu bhedābhedāvagamābhyāmaṃśatvaṃ siddhyatītyuktam /🔽syādetadevaṃ yadyubhāvapi bhedābhedau pratipipādayiṣitau syātām /
analyzed: aham brahma asmi bṛ  iti evañjātīyakāḥ  nanu bheda abheda avagamābhyām aṃśa tvam siddhyati iti uktam  syāt etat evam yadi ubhau api bheda abhedau pratipipādayiṣitau syātām
translated: For the passages which declare the nondifference of the individual soul and Brahman teach that the soul is not a part of Brahman; cp such passages as It having created all this, entered into it, and became the individual soul Bṛ Up , , ; It is the Self of all, the ruler of all, the protector of all Bṛ Up , , ; It is the one God, without a second Bṛ Up , , ; There is no other seer but he Bṛ Up , , ; He who sees any difference here, between the self and the notself, between what is to be done and what is not to be done, between what is to be desired and what is not to be desired, between what is to be shunned and what is not to be shunned, falls from Brahman Bṛ Up , , ; That thou art Ch Up , , ; I am Brahman Bṛ Up , , ; and many others of the same kind🔽But it has been said that the soul is a part of Brahman, because it is declared to be both different and nondifferent from Brahman!

original: abheda eva tvatra pratipipādayiṣito brahmātmatvapratipattau puruṣārthasiddheḥ /
analyzed: abhedaḥ eva tu atra brahma ātmatva pratipattau puruṣa artha siddheḥ
translated: This would be so if both difference and nondifference were meant to be taught; but nondifference only is meant to be taught here, because thereby the highest human end is attained

analyzed: svabhāva prāptaḥ tu bhedaḥ nu udyate
translated: But the difference that is referred to is one that is natural.

original: naca niravayavasya brahmaṇo mukhyoṃ'śo jīvaḥ saṃbhavatītyuktam /
analyzed: na ca niravayavasya brahmaṇaḥ mukhyaḥ oṃśaḥ jīvaḥ saṃbhavati iti uktam
translated: And it has been said that the individual soul cannot be the principal part of Brahman, which is without parts.

original: tasmātparaḥ evaikaḥ sarveṣāṃ bhūtānāmantarātmā jīvabhāvenāvasthita ityato vaktavyānujñāparihāropapattiḥ // //
analyzed: tasmāt paraḥ eva ekaḥ sarveṣām bhūtānām antarātmā jīva bhāvena avasthitaḥ iti atas vaktavya anujñā parihāra upapattiḥ
translated: Therefore, the one Supreme Self alone, abiding as the individual soul of all beings, is to be spoken of as the one to be known, the one to be chosen, and the one to be avoided.

analyzed: tatra jīva parayoḥ madhye
translated: There, between the individual soul and the Supreme Self,
the individual soul is the self that is based on action.

original: saptadaśakena daśendrayāṇi pañca prāṇaḥ mano buddiśceti saptadaśasaṃkhyāko rāśirliṅgam /
analyzed: saptadaśakena daśa indrayāṇi pañca prāṇaḥ manaḥ buddiḥ ca iti saptadaśa saṃkhyākaḥ rāśiḥ liṅgam
