translated: Or, according to the opinion of the followers of other schools, it is obtained that prana is the function of all the organs.

original: evaṃ hi tantrāntarīyā ācakṣate 'sāmānyā karaṇavṛttiḥ prāṇādyā vāyavaḥ pañce' ti /
analyzed: evam hi tantra antarīyāḥ ācakṣate sāmānyā karaṇa vṛttiḥ prāṇa ādyāḥ vāyavaḥ pañca iti
translated: For the followers of other schools say thus: The general function of the organs is the five Vayu-s beginning with prana.

original: atrocyate na vāyuḥ prāṇo nāpi karaṇavyāpāraḥ /
analyzed: atrā ucyate na vāyuḥ prāṇaḥ na api karaṇa vyāpāraḥ
translated: To this it is said: Vayu is not prana, nor is it the function of the organs.

analyzed: kutas pṛthak upadeśāt
translated: Why? Because of separate teaching.

original: vāyostāvatprāṇasya pṛthagupadeśo bhavati 'prāṇa eva brahmaṇaścaścaturthaḥ pādaḥ sa vāyunā jyotiṣā bhāti ca tapati ca' chāndo / / / iti
analyzed: vāyoḥ tāvat prāṇasya pṛthak upadeśaḥ bhavati prāṇaḥ eva brahmaṇaḥ caḥ caturthaḥ pādaḥ sa vāyunā jyotiṣā bhāti ca tapati ca chāndo iti
translated: First, as to Vāyu, the prāṇa is taught separately from him, in the passage, The prāṇa is the fourth foot of Brahman; he shines and warms by the light of Vāyu Ch Up , ,

analyzed: nahi vāyuḥ eva san vāyoḥ pṛthak upadiśyeta
translated: For if Vāyu were the prāṇa, he would not be mentioned separately from Vāyu

analyzed: tathā karaṇa vṛtteḥ api pṛthak upadeśaḥ bhavati
translated: In the same way the function of the organs is taught separately from the organs themselves

analyzed: vāc ādīni karaṇāni anukramya tatra tatra pṛthak prāṇasya anukramaṇāt  vṛtti vṛttimatoḥ ca abhedāt
translated: For after the organs beginning with speech have been enumerated in different places, the prāṇa is enumerated separately from them🔽And as the function is not different from that which has the function,

original: nahi karaṇavyāpāra eva san karaṇebhyaḥ pṛthagupadiśyeta /🔽tathā 'etasmājjāyate prāṇo manaḥ sarvendriyāṇi ca /🔽khaṃ vāyuḥ' mu / / /
analyzed: nahi karaṇa vyāpāraḥ eva san karaṇebhyaḥ pṛthak upadiśyeta  tathā etasmāt jāyate prāṇaḥ manaḥ sarva indriyāṇi ca  kham vāyuḥ mu
translated: for if the function of the organs were the prāṇa, it would not be mentioned separately from the organs🔽In the same way the prāṇa is taught separately from Vāyu and the organs in the following passages also, From him is born prāṇa, mind, and all the organs; ether, air, &c Bṛ Up , , 0

original: ityevamādayo 'pi vāyoḥ karaṇebhyaśca prāṇasya pṛthagupadeśā anusartavyāḥ /
analyzed: iti evamādayaḥ vāyoḥ karaṇebhyaḥ ca prāṇasya pṛthak upadeśāḥ anusartavyāḥ
translated: And the prāṇa is taught separately from the organs in the following passage also, From him is born prāṇa, mind, and all the organs; ether, air, &c Bṛ Up , , 0🔽And the passages beginning with the one quoted must be followed up

analyzed: na ca samastānām karaṇānām ekā vṛttiḥ saṃbhavati
translated: And it is impossible that the one function should belong to all the organs taken together,

analyzed: pratyekam eka eka vṛtti tvāt samudāyasya ca ākāraka tvāt
translated: because each of them has its own function, and an aggregate has no activity of its own

analyzed: nanu pañjara cālana nyāyena etat bhaviṣyati
translated: But, it may be said, the case will be analogous to that of the opening of a cage;

original: yathaitapañjaravartina ekādaśapakṣiṇaḥ pratyekaṃ pratiniyatavyāpārāḥ santaḥ saṃbhūyaikaṃ pañjaraṃ cālayanti /
analyzed: yathaita pañjara vartinaḥ ekādaśa pakṣiṇaḥ pratyekam pratiniyata vyāpārāḥ santaḥ saṃbhūya ekam pañjaram cālayanti
translated: Just as the eleven birds in the cage, each having their own specific functions, collectively move the single cage.

original: evamekaśarīravartina ekādaśa prāṇāḥ pratyekaṃ pratiniyatavṛttayaḥ santaḥ saṃbhūyaikāṃ prāṇākhyāṃ vṛttiṃ pratilapsyanta iti /
analyzed: evam eka śarīra vartinaḥ ekādaśa prāṇāḥ pratyekam pratiniyata vṛttayaḥ santaḥ saṃbhūya ekām prāṇa ākhyām vṛttim pratilapsyante iti
translated: In the same way, the eleven vital breaths residing in a single body, each having their own specific functions, will collectively attain a single function called 'vital breath'.

analyzed: na iti ucyate
translated: No, it is said.

original: yuktaṃ tatra pratyekavṛttibhiravāntaravyāpāraiḥ pañjaracālanānurūpairevopetāḥ pakṣiṇaḥ saṃbhūyaikaṃ pañjaraṃ cālayeyuriti /
analyzed: yuktam tatra pratyeka vṛttibhiḥ avāntara vyāpāraiḥ pañjara cālana anurūpaiḥ eva upetāḥ pakṣiṇaḥ saṃbhūya ekam pañjaram cālayeyuḥ iti
translated: It is proper there that the birds, endowed with their own specific functions and minor activities similar to moving the cage, should collectively move the single cage.

analyzed: tathā dṛṣṭa tvāt
translated: Because it is seen that way.

original: iha tu śravaṇādyavāntaravyāpāropetāḥ prāṇa na saṃbhūya prāṇyuriti yuktam /
analyzed: iha tu śravaṇa ādi avāntara vyāpāra upetāḥ prāṇa na saṃbhūya prāṇyuḥ iti yuktam
translated: But it is not proper that the vital breaths endowed with the minor activities of hearing etc. should collectively breathe here.

analyzed: pramāṇa abhāvāt  atyanta vijātīya tvāt ca śravaṇa ādibhyaḥ prāṇanasya
translated: Because there is no evidence.🔽And because breathing is extremely heterogeneous from hearing etc.

original: tathā prāṇasya śreṣṭhatvādyudghoṣaṇaṃ guṇabhāvopagamaśca taṃ prati vāgādīnāṃ /
analyzed: tathā prāṇasya śreṣṭha tva ādi udghoṣaṇam guṇa bhāva upagamaḥ ca tam prati vāc ādīnām
translated: Similarly, the declaration of the vital breath as the best and the submission of speech etc. to it as subordinate

analyzed: na karaṇa vṛtti mātre prāṇe
translated: is not possible in the vital breath which is merely the function of the sense organs.

analyzed: tasmāt anyaḥ vāyu kriyābhyām prāṇaḥ
translated: Therefore, the vital breath is different from air and action.

original: kathaṃ tarhīyaṃ śrutiḥ 'yaḥ prāṇaḥ sa vāyuḥ' iti /
analyzed: katham tarhi iyam śrutiḥ yaḥ prāṇaḥ sa vāyuḥ iti
translated: How then is this scriptural passage to be explained, He who is prāṇa is Vāyu?

original: ucyate vāyurevāyamadhyātmamāpannaḥ pañcavyūho viśeṣātmanāvatiṣṭhamānaḥ prāṇo nāma bhaṇyate na tattvāntaraṃ nāpi vāyumātram /
analyzed: ucyate vāyuḥ eva ayam adhyātmam āpannaḥ pañca vyūhaḥ viśeṣa ātmanā avatiṣṭhamānaḥ prāṇaḥ nāma bhaṇyate na tattva antaram na api vāyu mātram
translated: We reply that Vāyu, having entered into the body, abides there in the form of the fivefold vital air, and is therefore called prāṇa, not a different substance, nor mere Vāyu

original: ataścobhe api bhedābhedaśrutī na virudhyete // //🔽syādetat /🔽prāṇo 'pi tarhi jīvavadasmiñśarīre svātantryaṃ prāpnoti /
analyzed: atas ca ubhe api bheda abheda śrutī na virudhyete  / syāt etat  prāṇaḥ u pi tarhi jīva vat asmin śarīre svātantryam prāpnoti
translated: From this it follows that both the passages quoted above, which speak of the difference and nondifference of prāṇa and Vāyu, are free from contradiction

analyzed: śreṣṭha tvāt guṇa bhāva upagamāt ca tam prati vāc ādīnām indriyāṇām
translated: But, an objection is raised, if prāṇa is the highest Brahman, it will follow that it is independent in the body, just as the individual soul is, on account of its being the highest and of speech and the other senses being subservient to it

original: tathāhyanekavidhā vibhūtiḥ prāṇasya śrāvyate 'supteṣu vāgādiṣu prāṇa eko hi jāgarti🔽prāṇa eko mṛtyunānāptaḥ prāṇaḥ saṃvargo vāgādīnsaṃvṛṅ kte prāṇa itarānprāṇānrakṣati
analyzed: tathā hi anekavidhā vibhūtiḥ prāṇasya śrāvyate supteṣu vāc ādiṣu prāṇaḥ ekaḥ hi jāgarti  prāṇaḥ ekaḥ mṛtyunā an āptaḥ prāṇaḥ saṃvargaḥ vāc ādīn saṃvṛṅ kte prāṇaḥ itarān prāṇān rakṣati
translated: For we meet with various passages declaring the greatness of prāṇa, When speech and the other senses have fallen asleep, prāṇa alone is awake;

analyzed: mātā iva putrān iti
translated: prāṇa alone is not reached by death; prāṇa is the absorber, it absorbs speech and the other senses; prāṇa protects the other prāṇas, as a mother her sons Bṛ Up , , 0

analyzed: tasmāt prāṇasya api jīva vat svātantrya prasaṅgaḥ
translated: From this it follows that prāṇa also is independent like the individual soul

analyzed: tam pariharati
translated: To this objection the next Sūtra replies

analyzed: cakṣuḥ ādi vat tu tad saha śiṣṭi ādibhyaḥ
translated: But on account of being mentioned together with the eye, &c, prāṇa is to be viewed like the latter

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ prāṇasya jīva vat svātantryam vyavartayati
translated: The word but discards the conclusion arrived at in the preceding Sūtra that prāṇa is independent like the individual soul

original: yathā cakṣurādīni rājaprakṛtivajjīvasya kartṛtvaṃ bhoktṛtvaṃ ca pratyupakaraṇāni na svatantrāṇi /
analyzed: yathā cakṣuḥ ādīni rāja prakṛti vat jīvasya kartṛ tvam bhoktṛ tvam ca pratyupakaraṇāni na svatantrāṇi
translated: And as the eye, etc., are like the king's subjects, instruments for the soul's activity and enjoyment, not independent.

original: tathā mukhyo 'pi prāṇo rājamantrivajjīvasya sarvārthakaratvenopakaraṇabhūto na svatantraḥ /
analyzed: tathā mukhyaḥ pi prāṇaḥ rāja mantri vat jīvasya sarva artha kara tvena upakaraṇa bhūtaḥ na svatantraḥ
translated: So also the principal life-breath, like the king's minister, is an instrument for the soul by performing all its purposes, not independent.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

analyzed: tad saha śiṣṭi ādibhyaḥ
translated: Because of being taught together with them, etc.

analyzed: taiḥ cakṣuḥ ādibhiḥ saha eva prāṇaḥ śiṣyate prāṇa saṃvāda ādiṣu
translated: The life-breath is taught together with the eye, etc., in the dialogues about the life-breath, etc.

original: samānadharmāṇāṃ ca saha śāsanaṃ yuktaṃ bṛhadrathantarādivat /
analyzed: samāna dharmāṇām ca saha śāsanam yuktam bṛhat rathantara ādi vat
translated: And it is proper to teach together those with the same attributes, like the Brhat and Rathantara (Samans).

analyzed: ādi śabdena saṃhata tva acetana tva ādīn prāṇasya svātantrya nirākaraṇa hetūn darśati  /
translated: By the word etc. he shows that the life-breath's being composed, being insentient, etc., are reasons for negating its independence.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be:

analyzed: yadi cakṣuḥ ādi vat prāṇasya jīvam prati karaṇa bhāvaḥ
translated: If the life-breath's instrumental nature towards the soul were accepted like the eye, etc.,

analyzed: viṣaya antaram rūpa ādi vat prasajyeta
translated: a different object like form, etc., would be entailed.

original: rūpādyālocanādibhirvṛttibhiryathāsvaṃ cakṣurādīnāṃ jīvaṃ prati karaṇabhāvo bhavati /
analyzed: rūpa ādi ālocanā ādibhiḥ vṛttibhiḥ yathāsvam cakṣuḥ ādīnām jīvam prati karaṇa bhāvaḥ bhavati
translated: The eye, etc., become instruments for the soul in their respective functions of seeing form, etc.

original: apicaikādaśaiva kāryajātāni rūpālocanādīni parigaṇitāni yadarthamekādaśa prāṇāḥ saṃgṛhītāḥ natu dvādaśamaparaṃ kāryajātamadhigamyate yadarthamayaṃ
analyzed: apica ekādaśa eva kārya jātāni rūpa ālocanā ādīni parigaṇitāni yad artham ekādaśa prāṇāḥ saṃgṛhītāḥ na tu dvādaśam aparam kārya jātam adhigamyate yad artham ayam
translated: Moreover, only eleven kinds of effects, such as seeing form, are enumerated, for which eleven vital airs are included. But no other twelfth kind of effect is found, for which this twelfth vital air would be the cause.

analyzed: dvādaśaḥ prāṇaḥ pratijñāyeta iti
translated: Moreover, only eleven kinds of effects, such as seeing form, are enumerated, for the sake of which eleven vital breaths are included, but no twelfth kind of effect is found for the sake of which this twelfth vital breath would be postulated.

analyzed: atas uttaram paṭhati
translated: Therefore, the following answer is given:

original: akaraṇatvāc ca na doṣas tathā hi darśayati / / / /
analyzed: akaraṇa tvāt ca na doṣaḥ tathā hi darśayati
translated: And because it is not an instrument, there is no fault, as it is shown thus.

analyzed: na tāvat viṣaya antara prasaṅgaḥ doṣaḥ
translated: First, the fault of leading to another object is not a fault.

analyzed: akaraṇa tvāt prāṇasya
translated: Because the vital breath is not an instrument.

analyzed: nahi cakṣuḥ ādi vat prāṇasya viṣaya paricchedena karaṇa tvam abhyupagamyate
translated: For the vital breath is not accepted as an instrument in the delimitation of objects like the eye and so on.

analyzed: na ca asya etāvatā kārya abhāvaḥ eva
translated: And it is not that it has no effect at all.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is that?

original: tathāhi śrutiḥ prāṇāntareṣvasaṃbhāvyamānaṃ mukhyaprāṇasya vaiśeṣikaṃ kāryaṃ darśayati
analyzed: tathā hi śrutiḥ prāṇa antareṣu a saṃbhāvyamānam mukhyaprāṇasya vaiśeṣikam kāryam darśayati
translated: For thus, the scripture shows the special effect of the primary vital breath, which is not possible in the other vital breaths,

original: prāṇasaṃvādādiṣu 'atha ha prāṇā ahaṃśreyasi vyūdire' ityupakramya 'yasminva utkrānte
analyzed: prāṇa saṃvāda ādiṣu atha ha prāṇāḥ ahaṃśreyasi vyūdire iti upakramya yasmin vaḥ utkrānte
translated: in the dialogues about the vital breaths, beginning with Then the vital breaths disputed about who was the best, it says, He in whom, when it departs,

original: śarīraṃ pāpiṣṭhataramiva dṛśyate sa vaḥ śreṣṭhaḥ' chā / / / /
analyzed: śarīram pāpiṣṭhataram iva dṛśyate sa vaḥ śreṣṭhaḥ chā
translated: the body appears most sinful, he is the best among you. Chandogya Upanishad 8.6.5-6.

original: iti copanyasya pratyekaṃ vāgādyutkramaṇena tadvṛttimātrahīnaṃ yathāpūrvaṃ jīvanaṃ
analyzed: iti ca upanyasya pratyekam vāc ādi utkramaṇena tad vṛtti mātra hīnam yathāpūrvam jīvanam
translated: Having thus introduced the topic, it shows that when each of speech etc. departs, life continues as before, with only the functions of those [faculties] missing.

original: darśayitvā prāṇoccikramiṣāyāṃ vāgādiśaithilyāpattiṃ śarīrapātaprasaṅgaṃ ca darśayantī
analyzed: darśayitvā prāṇa uccikramiṣāyām vāc ādi śaithilya āpattim śarīrapāta prasaṅgam ca darśayantī
translated: Then, when the desire to depart of the life-breath arises, it shows the loss of firmness of speech etc. and the consequent falling of the body.

analyzed: śrutiḥ prāṇa nimittām śarīra indriya sthitim darśayati
translated: Thus the Śruti shows that the life-breath is the cause of the stability of the body and senses.

original: 'tāvanvariṣṭhaḥ prāṇa uvāca mā mohamāpadyathāhamevaitatpañcadhātmānaṃ pravibhajyaitadbāṇamavaṣṭabhya vidhārayāmi /
analyzed: tau an variṣṭhaḥ prāṇaḥ uvāca mā moham āpat yathā aham eva etat pañcadhā ātmānam pravibhajya etat bāṇam avaṣṭabhya vidhārayāmi
translated: Then the best of them, the life-breath, said, Do not fall into delusion. I alone, having divided myself into five parts, support and sustain this body.

original: iti caitamevārthaṃ śrutirāha 'prāṇena rakṣannavaraṃ kulāyam' bṛ /
analyzed: iti ca etam eva artham śrutiḥ āha prāṇena rakṣan avaram kulāyam bṛhat
translated: Thus the Śruti declares the same meaning: Protecting the inner nest by the life-breath (Br. U. 4.4.7).

original: iti ca supteṣu cakṣurādiṣu prāṇanimittāṃ śarīrarakṣāṃ darśayati /
analyzed: iti ca supteṣu cakṣuḥ ādiṣu prāṇa nimittām śarīra rakṣām darśayati
translated: And it shows that when the eyes etc. are asleep, the protection of the body is due to the life-breath.

analyzed: yasmāt kasmāt ca aṅgāt prāṇaḥ utkrāmati tadā eva tat śuṣyati
translated: From whatever limb the life-breath departs, that limb withers away (Ch. U. 8.6.1).

original: 'tena yadaśnāti yatpibati tenetarānprāṇānavati' iti ca prāṇanimittāṃ śarīrendriyapuṣṭiṃ darśayati /
analyzed: tena yat aśnāti yat pibati tena itarān prāṇān avati iti ca prāṇa nimittām śarīra indriya puṣṭim darśayati
translated: And it shows that the nourishment of the body and senses is due to the life-breath: By that [food] which he eats and drinks, he nourishes the other life-breaths (Ch. U. 8.6.2).

original: 'kasminnvahamutkrānta utkrānto bhaviṣyāmi kasminvā pratiṣṭhite pratiṣṭhāsyāmi' iti /
analyzed: kasmin vaham utkrāntaḥ utkrāntaḥ bhaviṣyāmi kasmin vā pratiṣṭhite pratiṣṭhāsyāmi iti
translated: 'In whom, when I depart from this body, shall I depart? In whom, when I am established, shall I be established?'

original: 'sa prāṇamasṛjata' iti ca prāṇanimitte jīvasyotkrāntapratiṣṭhe darśayati // //
analyzed: sa prāṇam asṛjata iti ca prāṇa nimitte jīvasya utkrānta pratiṣṭhe darśayati
translated: And the text, 'He sent forth breath,' shows that the departure and establishment of the individual soul are due to breath.

analyzed: ahaṃśreyasi svasya śreṣṭha tā nimittam
translated: For the sake of his own highest good, i.e., for the sake of his own preeminence.

analyzed: vyūdire vivādam cakrire
translated: They disputed, i.e., argued.

analyzed: aparam nīcam
translated: The other, the lower.

analyzed: kulāyam deha ākhyam gṛham
translated: The nest, the body, is the house.

analyzed: pañca vṛttiḥ manaḥ vat vyapadiśyate  /
translated: The five functions are designated like the mind.

analyzed: itas ca asti mukhyasya prāṇasya vaiśeṣikam kāryam
translated: And for this reason also the principal vital air has a special function.

original: yatkāraṇaṃ pañcavṛttirayaṃ vyapadiśyate śrutiṣu 'prāṇo 'pāno vyāna udānaḥ samānaḥ' bṛ / / / iti /
analyzed: yatkāraṇam pañca vṛttiḥ ayam vyapadiśyate śrutiṣu iti
translated: Because it is designated in the scriptures as having five functions: 'Prana, apana, vyana, udana, samana.'

analyzed: vṛtti bhedaḥ ca ayam kārya bheda apekṣaḥ  prāṇaḥ prāc vṛttiḥ ucchvāsa ādi karmā
translated: And this distinction of functions depends on the distinction of effects.🔽Prana is the function directed forward, having the function of inhalation, etc.
Apana is the function directed downward, having the function of exhalation, etc.

analyzed: vyānaḥ tayoḥ saṃdhau vartamānaḥ vīryavat karma hetuḥ
translated: Vyanas is located in the junction of those two, and is the cause of vigorous action.

analyzed: udānaḥ ūrdhva vṛttiḥ utkrānti ādi hetuḥ
translated: Udana is the upward function, the cause of ascension, etc.

analyzed: samānaḥ samam sarveṣu aṅgeṣu yaḥ nna rasān nayati iti
translated: Sambhava evenly carries the nutritive essence to all the limbs.

analyzed: evam pañca vṛttiḥ prāṇaḥ manaḥ vat
translated: Thus the vital air has five functions like the mind.

original: yathā manasaḥ pañca vṛttaya evaṃ prāṇasyāpītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: yathā manasaḥ pañca vṛttayaḥ evam prāṇasya api iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that just as the mind has five functions, so also the vital air.

original: śrotrādinimittāḥ śabdādiviṣayā manasaḥ pañca vṛttayaḥ prasiddhāḥ /
analyzed: śrotra ādi nimittāḥ śabda ādi viṣayāḥ manasaḥ pañca vṛttayaḥ prasiddhāḥ
translated: The five functions of the mind, having sound etc. as their objects and dependent on the ear etc., are well-known.

original: natu kāmaḥ saṃkalpaḥ ityādyāḥ paripaṭhitāḥ parigṛhyeran /
analyzed: na tu kāmaḥ saṃkalpaḥ ityādyāḥ paripaṭhitāḥ parigṛhyeran
translated: But the enumerated ones beginning with desire and determination should not be accepted,

analyzed: pañca saṃkhyā atirekāt
translated: because they exceed the number five.

original: nanvatrāpi śrotrādinirapekṣā bhūtabhaviṣyadādiviṣayāparā manaso vṛttirastīti samānaḥ pañcasaṃkhyātirekaḥ /🔽evaṃ tarhi 'paramatamapratiṣiddhamanumataṃ bhavati' iti nyāyādihāpi yogaśāstraprasiddhā
analyzed: nanu atra api śrotra ādi nirapekṣā bhūta bhaviṣyat ādi viṣayā aparā manasaḥ vṛttiḥ asti iti samānaḥ pañca saṃkhyā atirekaḥ  evam tarhi para matam apratiṣiddham anumatam bhavati iti nyāyāt iha api yoga śāstra prasiddhā
translated: Here also, there is another function of the mind, independent of the ear etc., having the past, future etc. as its objects. So the excess of the number five is the same.🔽If it is so, then by the rule that 'what is not refuted in another's doctrine is considered approved', even here, the five functions of the mind, well-known in the Yoga scriptures,

analyzed: manasaḥ pañca vṛttayaḥ parigṛhyante pramāṇa viparyaya vikalpa nidrā smṛtayaḥ pāta
translated: are accepted, namely 'valid knowledge, error, imagination, sleep, and memory' (Yoga Sutra 1.7).

analyzed: yoga sū nāma
translated: [These are] the names.

original: bahuvṛttitvamātreṇa vā manaḥ prāṇasya nidarśanamiti draṣṭavyam /
analyzed: bahu vṛtti tva mātreṇa vā manaḥ prāṇasya nidarśanam iti draṣṭavyam
translated: Or it should be seen that the mind is an example for the vital air, merely because of having many functions.

analyzed: jīva upakaraṇa tvam api prāṇasya pañca vṛtti tvāt manaḥ vat iti yojayitavyam
translated: The fact that the vital air is an instrument of the individual soul should also be connected as follows: because it has five functions, like the mind.

analyzed: pramāṇam pramitiḥ
translated: Valid knowledge is ascertainment.

analyzed: viparyayaḥ bhramaḥ
translated: Error is delusion.

analyzed: tāmasī vṛttiḥ nidrā
translated: Vikalpa is a conceptual cognition that does not correspond to an external object.🔽Nidrā is a tamas-type activity.

analyzed: śreṣṭha aṇu tva adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on the supremacy of minuteness. Sūtra.

analyzed: aṇuḥ ca
translated: And it is atomic.

analyzed: aṇuḥ ca ayam mukhyaḥ prāṇaḥ pratyetavyaḥ itara prāṇa vat
translated: This primary prāṇa should be understood to be atomic, like the other prāṇas.

analyzed: aṇu tvam ca iha api saukṣmya paricchedau na paramāṇu tulya tvam
translated: And here, minuteness means subtlety and limitation, not being the same as an atom.

analyzed: pañcabhiḥ vṛttibhiḥ kṛtsna śarīra vyāpi tvāt
translated: Because it pervades the entire body with its five functions.

analyzed: sūkṣmaḥ prāṇaḥ utkrāntau pārśva sthena an upalabhyamāna tvāt
translated: Prāṇa is subtle, because it is not perceived by one standing nearby during its departure.

analyzed: paricchinnaḥ ca utkrānti gati āgati śrutibhyaḥ
translated: And it is limited, because of the statements about its departure, going, and coming.

original: nanu vibhutvamapi prāṇasya samāmnāyate 'samaḥ pluṣiṇā samo maśakena samo nāgena sama ebhistribhirlokaiḥ samo 'nena sarveṇa bṛ / / /
analyzed: nanu vibhu tvam api prāṇasya samāmnāyate samaḥ pluṣiṇā samaḥ maśakena samaḥ nāgena samaḥ ebhiḥ tribhiḥ lokaiḥ samaḥ nena sarveṇa bṛ
translated: But omnipresence is also declared for prāṇa: Equal to a louse, equal to a mosquito, equal to an elephant, equal to these three worlds, equal to all this...

analyzed: iti evamādi pradeśeṣu
translated: and so on in such passages.

original: taducyate ādhidaivikena samaṣṭivyaṣṭirūpeṇa hairaṇyagarṇeṇa prāṇātmanaivaitadvibhutvamāmnāyate nādhyātmikena /
analyzed: tat ucyate ādhidaivikena samaṣṭi vyaṣṭi rūpeṇa hairaṇyagarṇeṇa prāṇa ātmanā eva etat vibhu tvam āmnāyate na ādhyātmikena
translated: To this it is said: This omnipresence is declared by the Hairaṇyagarbha, who is the prāṇa-self in the form of the aggregate and the individual, belonging to the supreme Lord, not by the individual self.

original: apica samaḥ pluṣiṇetyādinā sāmyavacanena pratiprāṇivartinaḥ prāṇasya pariccheda eva pradarśyate tasmādadoṣaḥ // //
analyzed: api ca samaḥ pluṣiṇā ityādinā sāmya vacanena prati prāṇi vartinaḥ prāṇasya paricchedaḥ eva pradarśyate tasmāt adoṣaḥ  /
translated: Moreover, by the statement of equality in the phrase equal to a spider, etc., the finitude of the individual life-breath in each individual being is shown. Therefore, there is no fault.

original: FN / pluṣirmaśakādapi sūkṣmo jantuḥ / nāgo hastī /
analyzed: pluṣiḥ maśakāt api sūkṣmaḥ jantuḥ nāgaḥ hastī
translated: FN: A plushi is a tiny creature, even smaller than a mosquito. Naga is an elephant.

analyzed: jyotiḥ ādi adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on the substratum of light, etc.

original: jyotirādyadhiṣṭhānaṃ tu tadāmananāt / / / /🔽te punaḥ prakṛtāḥ prāṇāḥ kiṃ svamahimnaiva svasmai kāryāya prabhavantyāhosviddevatādhiṣṭhitāḥ🔽prabhavantīti vicāryate tatra prāptaṃ tāvadyathā svakāryaśaktiyogātsvamahimnaiva
analyzed: jyotiḥ ādi adhiṣṭhānam tu tad āmananāt  te punar prakṛtāḥ prāṇāḥ kim sva mahimnā eva svasmai kāryāya prabhavanti āhosvit devatā dhiṣṭhitāḥ  prabhavanti iti vicāryate tatra prāptam tāvat yathā sva kārya śakti yogāt sva mahimnā eva
translated: But the substratum of light, etc. is due to the non-apprehension of that.

analyzed: prāṇāḥ pravarteran iti
translated: Now, these life-breaths that have been discussed - do they operate for their own purpose by their own power, or do they operate under the control of deities? This is being considered. In this regard, it is first concluded that the life-breaths function by their own power, due to their connection with the power for their own effect.

original: apica devatādhiṣṭhitānāṃ prāṇānāṃ pravṛttāvabhyupagamyamānāyāṃ tāsāmevādhiṣṭhātrīṇāṃ devatānāṃ bhoktṛtvaprasaṅgāccharīrasya bhoktṛtvaṃ pralīyeta
analyzed: apica devatā dhiṣṭhitānām prāṇānām pravṛttau abhyupagamyamānāyām tāsām eva adhiṣṭhātrīṇām devatānām bhoktṛ tva prasaṅgāt śarīrasya bhoktṛ tvam pralīyeta
translated: Moreover, if it is accepted that the life-breaths function under the control of deities, then it would follow that those very controlling deities are the enjoyers, and the body's status as the enjoyer would be undermined.

analyzed: atas sva mahimnā eva eṣām pravṛttiḥ iti
translated: Therefore, their operation is by their own power.

original: evaṃ prāptaṃ idamucyate jyotirādyadhiṣṭhānaṃ tu iti /
analyzed: evam prāptam idam ucyate jyotiḥ ādi adhiṣṭhānam tu iti
translated: This being the conclusion, it is said: But the substratum of light, etc.

analyzed: tuśabdena pūrvapakṣaḥ vyāvartyate
translated: The word but sets aside the prima facie view.

original: jyotirādibhiragnyādyabhimāninībhirdevatābhiradhiṣṭhitaṃ vāgādi karaṇajātaṃ svakāryeṣu pravartata iti pratijānīte /
analyzed: jyotiḥ ādibhiḥ agni ādi abhimāninībhiḥ devatābhiḥ adhiṣṭhitam vāc ādi karaṇa jātam sva kāryeṣu pravartate iti pratijānīte
translated: He declares that the aggregate of the organs, such as speech, &c., presided over by the deities, such as Agni, &c., which are the modifications of the light, &c., is employed in its own work.

original: hetuṃ vyācaṣṭe tadāmananāditi /🔽tathāhyāmananti 'agnirvāgbhūtvā mukhaṃ prāviśat' aita / / ityādi /
analyzed: hetum vyācaṣṭe tad āmananāt iti  tathā hi āmananti agniḥ vāc bhūtvā mukham prāviśat aita ityādi
translated: He explains the reason, because it is declared so.🔽For thus it is declared: Agni, becoming speech, entered the mouth.

analyzed: agneḥ ca ayam vāc bhāvaḥ mukha praveśaḥ ca devatā ātmanā adhiṣṭhātṛ tvam aṅgīkṛtya ucyate
translated: And this state of Agni as speech and its entering the mouth are stated on the admission that it is the presiding deity.

original: nahi devatāsaṃbandhaṃ pratyākhyāyāgnervāci mukhe vā kaścidviśeṣasaṃbandho dṛśyate /
analyzed: nahi devatā saṃbandham pratyākhyāya agneḥ vāci mukhe vā kaścid viśeṣa saṃbandhaḥ dṛśyate
translated: For, if the connection with the deity be denied, no special connection of Agni with speech or the mouth is seen.

original: tathā 'vāyuḥ prāṇo bhūtvā nāsike prāviśat' aita / /
analyzed: tathā vāyuḥ prāṇaḥ bhūtvā nāsike prāviśat aita
translated: In the same way, Vāyu, becoming breath, entered the nostrils.

analyzed: iti evamādi api yaujayitavyam
translated: In this way, &c., should be applied.

original: tathānyatrāpi vāgeva brahmaṇaścaturthaḥ pādaḥ so 'gninā jyotiṣā bhāti ca tapati ca' chā / / /
analyzed: tathā anyatra api vāc eva brahmaṇaḥ caturthaḥ pādaḥ saḥ gninā jyotiṣā bhāti ca tapati ca chā
translated: So also elsewhere, speech is the fourth foot of Brahman; it shines and warms by means of Agni as light.

analyzed: iti evamādinā vāc ādīnām agni ādi jyotiṣṭva ādi vacanena etam eva artham draḍhayati
translated: In this way, &c., by the statement that speech, &c., are Agni, &c., as light, &c., he confirms the same meaning.

original: 'sa vai vācameva prathamāmatyavahatsā yadā mṛtyumatyamucyata so 'gnirabhavat' bṛ / / /
analyzed: sa vai vācam eva prathamām atyavahat sā yadā mṛtyum atyamucyata saḥ agniḥ abhavat bṛ
translated: He carried speech upward as the first. When it was freed from death, it became Agni.

analyzed: iti ca evamādinā vāc ādīnām agni ādi bhāva āpatti vacanena etam eva artham dyotayati
translated: And by the statement of the attainment of the state of Agni etc. by Speech etc., this very meaning is indicated.

analyzed: sarvatra ca adhyātma adhidaivata vibhāgena vāc ādi agni ādi anukramaṇam anayā eva pratyāsattyā bhavati
translated: And everywhere the enumeration of Speech etc. and Agni etc. by the division into the individual soul and the deity occurs by this very connection.

analyzed: samṛtau api vāc adhyātmam iti prāhuḥ brāhmaṇāḥ tattva darśinaḥ
translated: Even in the Smṛti, the Brahmins who see the truth declare that Speech is the individual soul.

analyzed: vaktavyam adhibhūtam tu vahniḥ tatra adhidaiva catam
translated: What is to be spoken is the elemental, but the fire is the deity there.

analyzed: ityādinā vāc ādīnām agni ādi devatā adhiṣṭhita tvam sa prapañcam darśitam
translated: Thus, it is shown in detail that Speech etc. are presided over by the deities Agni etc.

analyzed: yat uktam sva kārya śakti yogāt sva mahimnā eva prāṇāḥ pravarteran iti
translated: What was said, that the vital breaths function by their own power due to their connection with the power for their own effect,

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: that is not correct.

analyzed: śaktānām api śakaṭa ādīnām anaḍuh ādi adhiṣṭhitānām pravṛtti darśanāt
translated: Because even for those that are capable, like carts etc., when presided over by oxen etc., activity is seen.

analyzed: ubhayathā upapattau ca āgamāt devatā dhiṣṭhita tvam eva niścīyate
translated: And when both are possible, the fact of being presided over by deities is ascertained only from the scriptures.

analyzed: bhāti dīpyate
translated: Shines, glows.

analyzed: tapati sva kāryam karoti
translated: Shines, performs its own function.

original: sa prāṇo vācaṃ prathamāmudgīthakarmāṇi pradhānāṃ anṛtādipāpmarūpaṃ mṛtyumatītyāvahanmṛtyunā muktāṃ kṛtvā agnidevatātmatvaṃ prāpitavān /
analyzed: sa prāṇaḥ vācam prathamām udgītha karmāṇi pradhānām anṛta ādi pāpma rūpam mṛtyum atītya avahat mṛtyunā muktām kṛtvā agni devatā ātmatvam prāpitavān
translated: That prāṇa, having brought speech, the first to perform the work of the udgītha, beyond death, which consists in untruth, &c, and made it free from death, caused it to attain the nature of the deity Agni

original: yadapyuktaṃ devatānāmevādhiṣṭhātrīṇāṃ bhoktṛtvaprasaṅgo na śārīrasyeti tatparihriyate
analyzed: yat api uktam devatānām eva adhiṣṭhātrīṇām bhoktṛ tva prasaṅgaḥ na śārīrasya iti tat parihriyate
translated: The objection that the presiding deities of the organs are to be considered as the enjoyers, not the embodied soul, is now refuted

analyzed: prāṇavatā śabdāt
translated: On account of the word prāṇavat, the embodied soul is to be considered as the enjoyer, not the presiding deities of the organs

original: satīṣvapi prāṇānāmadhiṣṭātrīṣu devatāsu prāṇavatā kāryakaraṇasaṃghātasvāminā śārīreṇaivaiṣāṃ prāṇānāṃ saṃbandhaḥ śruteravagamyate /
analyzed: satīṣu api prāṇānām adhiṣṭātrīṣu devatāsu prāṇavatā kārya karaṇa saṃghāta svāminā śārīreṇa eva eṣām prāṇānām saṃbandhaḥ śruteḥ avagamyate
translated: Although there are presiding deities of the organs, yet the embodied soul, as the lord of the aggregate of the organs and the body, is to be considered as connected with the prāṇas, on the ground of Śruti

original: tathāhi śrutiḥ 'atha yatraitadākāśamanuviṣaṇṇaṃ cakṣuḥ sa cākṣuṣaḥ puruṣo darśanāya takṣuratha yo vededaṃ jighrāṇīti sa ātmā gandhāya ghrāṇam' 🔽chā / /
analyzed: tathā hi śrutiḥ atha yatra etat ākāśam anuviṣaṇṇam cakṣuḥ sa cākṣuṣaḥ puruṣaḥ darśanāya takṣuḥ atha yaḥ veda idam jighrāṇi iti saḥ ātmā gandhāya ghrāṇam  / chā
translated: For Śruti says, Now when the eye has entered into that ether within, then that person is called the visible, the seer; when he knows, I smell, then he is the self, the smell, the organ of smelling Bṛ Up , , 0

analyzed: iti evañjātīyakā śārīreṇa eva prāṇānām saṃbandham śrāvayati
translated: This passage declares that the prāṇas are connected with the embodied soul only

analyzed: api ca aneka tvāt pratikaraṇam adhiṣṭhātrīṇām devatānām na bhoktṛ tvam asmin śarīre
translated: Moreover, the presiding deities of the organs cannot be considered as the enjoyers in this body, because they are many and each of them is connected with a particular organ

original: eko hyevamasmiñśarīre śārīro bhoktā pratisaṃdhānādisaṃbhavādavagamyate // // 🔽FN / atha dehe prāgapraveśānantaraṃ yatra golake etacchidramanupraviṣṭaṃ cakṣurindriyaṃ tatra cakṣuṣyabhimānī sa ātmā cākṣuṣaḥ tasya rūpadarśanāya
analyzed: ekaḥ hi evam asmin śarīre śārīraḥ bhoktā pratisaṃdhāna ādi saṃbhavāt avagamyate     atha dehe prāk apraveśa anantaram yatra golake etat chidram anupraviṣṭam cakṣuḥ indriyam tatra cakṣuṣi abhimānī saḥ ātmā cākṣuṣaḥ tasya rūpa darśanāya
translated: For in this body, only one experiencer is known, the embodied Self, on account of the connection of the soul with the body, etc.

analyzed: cakṣuḥ
translated: Now, the Self who is the experiencer of the eye, which is the eye in the sense that it is the abode of the eye, is the visual Self. The eye is for the purpose of seeing form of that visual Self.

analyzed: tasya ca nitya tvāt
translated: And because that is eternal.

original: tasya ca śārīrasyāsmiñśarīre bhoktṛtvena nityatvena puṇyapāpopalepasaṃbhavātsukhaduḥkhopabhogasaṃbhavācca na devatānām /
analyzed: tasya ca śārīrasya asmin śarīre bhoktṛ tvena nitya tvena puṇya pāpa upalepa saṃbhavāt sukha duḥkha upabhoga saṃbhavāt ca na devatānām
translated: And because that embodied Self is eternal as the experiencer in this body, and because it is possible for it to be affected by merit and demerit, and because it is possible for it to experience pleasure and pain, the gods are not the experiencers.

original: tā hi parasminnaiśvarye pade 'vatiṣṭhamānā na hine 'smiñśarīre bhoktṛtvaṃ pratilabdhumarhanti /
analyzed: tāḥ hi parasmin aiśvarye pade vatiṣṭhamānāḥ na hi ne smin śarīre bhoktṛ tvam pratilabdhum arhanti
translated: For they, abiding in the supreme state of lordship, do not deserve to obtain the state of experiencer in this low body.

original: śrutiśca bhavati 'puṇyamevāmuṃ gacchati na ha vai devānpāpaṃ gacchati' bṛ / / /
analyzed: śrutiḥ ca bhavati puṇyam eva amum gacchati na ha vai devān pāpam gacchati bṛ
translated: And there is a Vedic text: 'Merit alone goes to him; evil never goes to the gods' (Br. 3.9.26).

original: iti śārīreṇaiva ca nityaḥ prāṇānāṃ saṃbandha utkrāntyādiṣu tadanuvṛttidarśanāt /
analyzed: iti śārīreṇa eva ca nityaḥ prāṇānām saṃbandhaḥ utkrānti ādiṣu tad anuvṛtti darśanāt
translated: And the connection of the embodied Self with the vital breaths is eternal, because their continuation is seen in the processes of departing, etc.

original: 'tamutkrāmantaṃ prāṇo 'nūtkrāmati prāṇamanūtkrāmantaṃ sarve prāṇā anūtkrāmanti' bṛ / / /
analyzed: tam utkrāmantam prāṇaḥ nu utkrāmati prāṇam anūtkrāmantam sarve prāṇāḥ anūtkrāmanti bṛ
translated: ‘When he goes out, the life breath goes out after him; and when the life breath goes out, all the other breaths go out after it.’ Bṛ. Upaniṣad , , 0.

original: ityādiśrutibhyaḥ /🔽tasmātsatīṣvapi karaṇānāṃ niyantrīṣu devatāsu na śārīrasya bhoktṛtvamapagacchati /
analyzed: ityādi śrutibhyaḥ  tasmāt satīṣu api karaṇānām niyantrīṣu devatāsu na śārīrasya bhoktṛ tvam apagacchati
translated: And so on.🔽Therefore, even though there are deities controlling the organs, the embodied self does not lose its status as the experiencer.

analyzed: karaṇa pakṣasya eva hi devatā na bhoktṛ pakṣasya iti
translated: For the deities belong to the side of the organs, not to the side of the experiencer.

analyzed: indriya adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on the senses.

analyzed: te indriyāṇi tad vyapadeśāt anyatra śreṣṭhāt
translated: Those are the senses, because they are so designated, except for the highest one.

analyzed: mukhyaḥ ca ekaḥ itare ca ekādaśa prāṇāḥ anukrāntāḥ
translated: The principal one and the other eleven vital breaths have been enumerated.

analyzed: tatra idam aparam saṃdihyate
translated: Regarding them, this other doubt arises.

original: kiṃ mukhyasyaiva prāṇasya vṛttibhedā itare prāṇā āhosvittattvāntarāṇīti /
analyzed: kim mukhyasya eva prāṇasya vṛtti bhedāḥ itare prāṇāḥ āhosvit tattva antarāṇi iti
translated: Are the other vital breaths just different functions of the principal vital breath, or are they different entities?

analyzed: kim tāvat prāptam
translated: What is the prima facie view?

analyzed: mukhyasya eva itare vṛtti bhedāḥ iti
translated: The other vital breaths are just different functions of the principal vital breath.

analyzed: kutas śruteḥ
translated: Why? Because of scripture.

original: tathāhi śrutirmukhyamitarāṃśca prāṇānsaṃnidhāpya mukhyātmatāmitareṣāṃ khyāpayati 'hantāsyaiva sarve rūpamasāmeti ta etasyaiva sarve rūpamabhavan'
analyzed: tathā hi śrutiḥ mukhyam itarān ca prāṇān saṃnidhāpya mukhya ātma tām itareṣām khyāpayati hanta asya eva sarve rūpam asāma iti te etasya eva sarve rūpam abhavan  /
translated: For thus scripture, having presented the principal one and the other vital breaths, declares the identity of the other vital breaths with the principal one: They said, 'Let us assume the form of this one.' They all became the form of that one.

analyzed: bṛ iti
translated: Bṛhadā.

analyzed: prāṇa eka śabda tvāt ca eka tva adhyavasāyaḥ
translated: And on account of the one word prāṇa, the idea of unity must be adhered to.

analyzed: itarathā hi anyāyyam aneka artha tvam prāṇa śabdasya prasajyeta
translated: Otherwise, the word prāṇa would have the objectionable meaning of more than one thing.

original: ekatra vā mukhyatvamitaratra vā lākṣaṇikatvāmāpadyeta /🔽tasmādyathaikasyaiva prāṇasya prāṇādyāḥ pañca vṛttaya evaṃ vāgādyā apyekādaśeti /
analyzed: ekatra vā mukhya tvam itaratra vā lākṣaṇika tvām āpadyeta  tasmāt yathā ekasya eva prāṇasya prāṇa ādyāḥ pañca vṛttayaḥ evam vāc ādyāḥ api ekādaśa iti

analyzed: evam prāpte brūmaḥ tattva antarāṇi eva prāṇāt vāc ādīni iti

analyzed: śrutau evam vyapadeśa darśanāt

analyzed: etasmāt jāyate prāṇaḥ manaḥ sarva indriyāṇi ca

analyzed: nanu manasaḥ api evam sati varjanam indriya tvena prāṇa vat syāt

analyzed: manaḥ sarva indriyāṇi ca iti pṛthak vyapadeśa darśanāt

analyzed: satyam etat

analyzed: tasmāt tattva antara bhūtāḥ mukhyāt itare

analyzed: bheda śruteḥ  bhedena vāc ādibhyaḥ prāṇaḥ sarvatra śrūyate te ha vācam ūcuḥ bṛ  iti upakramya vāc ādīn asura pāpma vidhvastān upanyasya upasaṃhṛtya vāc ādi prakaraṇam atha ha imam āsanyam prāṇam ūcuḥ iti asura vidhvaṃsinaḥ mukhyasya prāṇasya

original: viṣayālocanahetutvaṃ cendriyāṇāṃ na prāṇasyevañjātīyako bhūyāllakṣaṇabhedaḥ prāṇendriyāṇām /

analyzed: iti śruteḥ prāṇaḥ eva indriyāṇi iti

analyzed: tat ayuktam  tatra api paurvāparya ālocanāt bheda pratīteḥ
translated: But that is not right;🔽for, on a comprehensive examination of the passage, a difference is perceived.

analyzed: tathā hi vadiṣyāmi eva aham iti vāc dadhre bṛ
translated: For the passage says, Speech thought, I will speak Bṛ Up , , 0, 1; and again, Speech indeed said to the prāṇas

original: iti vāgādīnīndriyāṇyanukramya 'tāni mṛtyuḥ śramo bhūtvopayeme tasmācchrāmyatyeva🔽vāk' iti ca śramarūpeṇa mṛtyunā grastatvaṃ vāgādīnāmabhidhāya 'athemameva nāpnodyo🔽'yaṃ madhyamaḥ prāṇaḥ' bṛ / / /
analyzed: iti vāc ādīni indriyāṇi anukramya tāni mṛtyuḥ śramaḥ bhūtvā upayeme tasmāt śrāmyati eva  vāc iti ca śrama rūpeṇa mṛtyunā grasta tvam vāc ādīnām abhidhāya atha imam eva  yam madhyamaḥ prāṇaḥ bṛ
translated: Having enumerated the organs beginning with speech, it says, 'Death, becoming fatigue, seized them. Therefore speech tires even🔽while speaking.' Having stated that speech and the others are seized by death in the form of fatigue, it says, 'But it did not reach this one,🔽this middle life-breath.'🔽🔽

original: iti pṛthakprāṇaṃ mṛtyunānabhibhūtaṃ tamanukrāmati /🔽'ayaṃ vai naḥ śreṣṭhaḥ' bṛ / / /🔽iti ca śreṣṭhatāmasyāvadhārayati /🔽tasmāttadavirodhena vāgādiṣu parispandalābhasya prāṇāyattatvaṃ tadrūpabhavanaṃ vāgādīnāmiti mantavyaṃ na tādātmyam /🔽ata eva ca prāṇaśabdasyendriyeṣu lākṣaṇikatvasiddhiḥ /🔽tathāca śrutiḥ 'ta etasyaiva sarve rūpamabhavan /🔽tasmādeta etenākhyāyante prāṇāḥ' bṛ / / /🔽iti mukhyaprāṇaviṣayasyaiva prāṇaśabdasyendriyeṣu lākṣaṇikīṃ vṛttiṃ darśayati /🔽tasmāttattvāntarāṇi prāṇādindriyāṇīti // //
analyzed: iti pṛthak prāṇam mṛtyunā an abhibhūtam tam anukrāmati 🔽ayam vai naḥ śreṣṭhaḥ bṛ 🔽iti ca śreṣṭha tām asya avadhārayati 🔽tasmāt tad avirodhena vāc ādiṣu parispanda lābhasya prāṇa āyatta tvam tad rūpa bhavanam vāc ādīnām iti mantavyam na tādātmyam 🔽atas eva ca prāṇa śabdasya indriyeṣu lākṣaṇika tva siddhiḥ 🔽tathā ca śrutiḥ te etasya eva sarve rūpam abhavan 🔽tasmāt ete etena ākhyāyante prāṇāḥ bṛ 🔽iti mukhya prāṇa viṣayasya eva prāṇa śabdasya indriyeṣu lākṣaṇikīm vṛttim darśayati 🔽tasmāt tattva antarāṇi prāṇāt indriyāṇi iti
translated: Having enumerated the organs, such as speech, &c., the text says, Death, in the form of fatigue, seized them; therefore speech is fatigued. Having thus declared that speech, &c., are seized by death in the form of fatigue, it goes on to speak of the separate prāṇa, which is not seized by death, in the passage, But he did not obtain this one, this middle prāṇa Bṛ Up , , 0 And in the passage, This is our best Bṛ Up , , 0, it declares the superiority of the prāṇa over the other organs From all this it follows that the fact of speech, &c, being dependent on the prāṇa for the acquisition of their activity must be explained in such a way as not to contradict the passages quoted, and that therefore speech, &c, are not identical with the prāṇa, but only assume the nature of the prāṇa And on account of this the word prāṇa is to be considered as having a secondary sense when applied to the organs of sense The Sruti also declares that the word prāṇa has a secondary sense when applied to the organs of sense, in the passage, They all became the form of that prāṇa; therefore they are called prāṇas Bṛ Up , , 0 For this reason the organs of sense are different from the prāṇa

analyzed: mṛtyuḥ āsaṅga doṣaḥ

analyzed: vādgagdhre dhāraṇa abhiprāyam cakre

analyzed: saṃjñā mūrti kḷpti adhikaraṇam sū

analyzed: saṃjñā mūrti kḷptiḥ tu trivṛt kurvataḥ upadeśāt

original: satprakriyāyāṃ tejobannānāṃ sṛṣṭimabhidhāyopadiśyate 'seyaṃ devataikṣata hantāhamimāstisro devatā anena jīvenātmanānupraviśya nāmarūpe vyākaravāṇīti

translated: In the good creation, having described the creation of fire, water, and earth, it is taught: This deity thought: 'Let me, having entered these three deities with this living soul as my self, evolve names and forms.'

analyzed: tāsām trivṛtam trivṛtam ekaikām karavāṇi iti chā

analyzed: tatra prāptam tāvat jīva kartṛkam eva idam nāma rūpa vyākaraṇam iti
translated: Regarding this, it is first established that this evolution of names and forms is done by the individual soul.

analyzed: kutas anena jīvena ātmanā iti viśeṣaṇāt

analyzed: sat sainya saṃkalanam hetu kartṛ tvāt rāja ātmani adhyāropayati saṃkalayāni iti uttama puruṣa prayogeṇa
translated: He superimposes the collection of good armies on the Self of the King by the use of the third person singular, saying 'I shall collect', because of His being the efficient cause.

analyzed: evam jīva kartṛkam eva sat nāma rūpa vyākaraṇam hetu kartṛ tvāt devatā ātmani adhyāropayati vyākaravāṇi iti uttamapuruṣa prayogeṇa
translated: Similarly, He superimposes on the Self of the Deity the manifestation of name and form by the living being, by the use of the third person singular, saying 'I shall manifest', because of His being the efficient cause.

original: apica ḍitthaḍavitthādiṣu nāmasu ghaṭaśarāvādiṣu ca rūpeṣu jīvasyaiva vyākartṛtvaṃ dṛṣṭam /
analyzed: apica ḍittha ḍavittha ādiṣu nāmasu ghaṭa śarāva ādiṣu ca rūpeṣu jīvasya eva vyākartṛ tvam dṛṣṭam
translated: Moreover, in the names beginning with 'Dittha' and 'Davittha' and in the forms beginning with 'ghata' and 'sara' the living being is seen to be the manifester.

analyzed: tasmāt jīva kartṛkam eva idam nāma rūpa vyākaraṇam iti evam prāpte abhidhatte
translated: Therefore, this manifestation of name and form is done by the living being only - this being the conclusion. In reply to this, he says

analyzed: tuśabdena pakṣam vyāvartayati

analyzed: saṃjñā mūrti kḷptiḥ iti nāma rūpa vyākriyā iti etat
translated: 'The manifestation of name and form' means the manifestation of name and form.

analyzed: trivṛt kurvataḥ iti parameśvaram lakṣayati
translated: 'By Him who makes the three-fold' - by this he indicates the Supreme Lord.

analyzed: trivṛtkaraṇe tasya nirapavāda kartṛ tva nirdeśāt
translated: Because in the making of the three-fold, He is declared to be the unquestionable maker.

analyzed: yā iyam saṃjñā kḷpti mūrti kḷptiḥ ca agniḥ ādityaḥ candramāḥ vidyut iti
translated: This manifestation of name and form, beginning with 'Agni', 'Sun', 'Moon', 'Lightning',

original: tathā kuśakāśapalāśādiṣu paśumṛgamanuṣyādiṣu ca pratyākṛti prativyakti cānekaprakārā /

translated: And so also in the case of the different kinds of grass, such as kuśa, kāśa, palāśa, &c, and of the different kinds of animals, such as cattle, deer, men, &c, and of the different individuals of the same species.

original: sā khalu parameśvarasyaiva tejobannānāṃ nirmātuḥ kṛtirbhavitumarhati /
analyzed: sā khalu parameśvarasya eva tejaḥ bannānām nirmātuḥ kṛtiḥ bhavitum arhati
translated: That variety can be the work of the highest Lord only, who is the creator of fire, water, and earth.

analyzed: kutas upadeśāt
translated: On account of the instruction.

original: tathāhi 'seyaṃ devataikṣata' ityupakramya 'vyākaravāṇi' ityuttamapuruṣaprayogeṇa parasyaiva brahmaṇo vyākartṛtvamihopadiśyate /
analyzed: tathā hi sā iyam devatā aikṣata iti upakramya vyākaravāṇi iti uttamapuruṣa prayogeṇa parasya eva brahmaṇaḥ vyākartṛ tvam iha upadiśyate
translated: For the passage, This deity desired, &c, intimates that the highest Brahman is the creator here spoken of, since it employs the third person in the passage, It will create,

analyzed: nanu jīvena iti viśeṣaṇāt jīva kartṛka tvam vyākaraṇasya adhyavasitam  na etat evam
translated: But the qualification by the individual soul shows that the creation is the work of the individual soul! Not so, we reply,

analyzed: jīvena iti etat anupraviśya iti anena saṃbadhyate ānantaryāt

analyzed: na vyākaravāṇi iti anena
translated: not with the word it will create.

original: tena hi saṃbandhe vyākaravāṇītyayaṃ devatāviṣaya uttamapuruṣa aupacārikaḥ kalpyeta /
analyzed: tena hi saṃbandhe vyākaravāṇi iti ayam devatā viṣaye uttama puruṣaḥ aupacārikaḥ kalpyeta
translated: For if it were connected with the latter, the third person in the passage, It will create, would have to be explained as a mode of expression based on the deity, which is absurd.

original: naca girinadīsamudrādiṣu nānāvidheṣu nāmarūpeṣvanīśvarasya jīvasya vyākaraṇasāmarthyamasti /

analyzed: ātmanā iti viśeṣaṇāt

original: upādhimātranibandhanatvācca jīvabhāvasya /🔽tena / tatkṛtamapi nāmarūpavyākaraṇaṃ parameśvarakṛtameva bhavati /

original: parameśvara eva ca nāmarūpayorvyākarteti sarvopaniṣatsiddhāntaḥ /🔽'ākāśo ha vai nāma nāmarūpayornirvahitā' chā / / /
analyzed: parameśvaraḥ eva ca nāma rūpayoḥ vyākartā iti sarva upaniṣad siddhāntaḥ  ākāśaḥ ha vai nāma nāma rūpayoḥ nirvahitā chā
translated: And the highest Lord alone is the manifester of name and form - this is the conclusion of all the Upaniṣads.

analyzed: ityādi śrutibhyaḥ

analyzed: tasmāt parameśvarasya eva trivṛt kurvataḥ karma nāma rūpayoḥ vyākaraṇam
translated: Therefore, the manifestation of name and form by the highest Lord, who performs the threefold creation, is the same.

analyzed: trivṛtkaraṇa pūrvakam eva idam iha nāmarūpa vyākaraṇam vivakṣyate
translated: The manifestation of name and form here is intended to be preceded by the threefold creation.

analyzed: pratyekam nāma rūpa vyākaraṇasya tejaḥ banna utpatti vacanena eva ukta tvāt
translated: Because the manifestation of name and form individually is stated by the statement of the origin of fire, water, and food.

original: tacca trivṛtkaraṇamagnyādityacandravidyutsu śrutirdarśayati 'yadagre rohitaṃ rūpaṃ tejasastadrūpaṃ yacchuklaṃ tadapāṃ yatkṛṣṇaṃ tadannasya' 🔽chā / / / ityādinā /
analyzed: tat ca trivṛt karaṇam agni āditya candra vidyutsu śrutiḥ darśayati yat agre rohitam rūpam tejasaḥ tat rūpam yat śuklam tat apām yat kṛṣṇam tat annasya 🔽chā ityādinā
translated: And the threefold creation is shown by the Vedic texts in fire, sun, moon, and lightning, as follows: Whatever is the red form of fire, that is its form; whatever is white, that is of water; whatever is black, that is of food (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 3.13.1).

analyzed: tatra agniḥ iti idam rūpam vyākriyate
translated: There, the form 'fire' is declared.

original: sati ca rūpavyākaraṇe viṣayapratilambhādagniritīdaṃ nāma vyākriyate /
analyzed: sati ca rūpa vyākaraṇe viṣaya pratilambhāt agniḥ iti idam nāma vyākriyate
translated: And when the form is declared, the name 'fire' is declared, because the object is obtained.

analyzed: evam āditya candra vidyutsu api draṣṭavyam
translated: The same should be seen in the case of the sun, moon, and lightning.

original: anena cāgnyādyudāharaṇena bhaumāmbhasataijaseṣu triṣvapi dravyeṣvaviśeṣeṇa trivṛtkaraṇamuktaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: anena ca agni ādi udāharaṇena bhauma ambhasa taijaseṣu triṣu api dravyeṣu aviśeṣeṇa trivṛt karaṇam uktam bhavati
translated: And by this example of fire, etc., it is said without distinction that the threefold creation is in all three substances, earthly, watery, and fiery.

analyzed: upakrama upasaṃhārayoḥ sādhāraṇa tvāt
translated: Because the beginning and the end are common.

analyzed: tathā hi aviśeṣeṇa eva upakramaḥ imāḥ tisraḥ devatāḥ trivṛt ekaikā bhavati chā iti

original: aviśeṣeṇaiva copasaṃhāraḥ 'yadu rohitamivābhūditi tejasastadrūpam' ityevamādiḥ 'yadavijñātamivābhūdityetāsāmeva devatānāṃ samāsa iti' chā /
analyzed: aviśeṣeṇa eva ca upasaṃhāraḥ yat u rohitam iva abhūt iti tejasaḥ tat rūpam iti evamādiḥ yat avijñātam iva abhūt iti etāsām eva devatānām samāsaḥ iti chā
translated: And without distinction, the end is: 'What appeared as if red, that is the form of fire' (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 1.6.5), and so on, up to: 'What appeared as if unknown, that is the combination of these very deities' (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 1.6.6).

analyzed: evamantaḥ
translated: Thus within...

analyzed: prakriyā prakaraṇam

original: tāsāṃ tisṛṇāmekaikāṃ devatāṃ tejobannātmanā tryātmikāṃ kariṣyāmīti śrutiḥ pañcīkaraṇopalakṣaṇārthā /
analyzed: tāsām tisṛṇām ekaikām devatām tejaḥ banna ātmanā tri ātmikām kariṣyāmi iti śrutiḥ pañcīkaraṇa upalakṣaṇa arthā
translated: The scripture means that I will make each one of those three deities threefold, with fire, water, and food as their three aspects. It is for the purpose of indicating the fivefold creation.

analyzed: tāsām tisṛṇām devatānām bahis trivṛt kṛtānām satīnām adhyātmam aparam trivṛt karaṇam uktam imāḥ tisraḥ devatāḥ puruṣam prāpya trivṛt trivṛt ekaikā  /

analyzed: bhavati chā iti

translated: The teacher now sets forth the matter just as it is declared in the scriptural passage, with a view to remove some doubt that may have arisen in the mind of his pupil, and to avoid thereby a certain difficulty

analyzed: māṃsa ādi bhaumam yathāśabdam itarayoḥ ca

translated: The effect of the earth, when it is threefold and is enjoyed by the person, is flesh, &c, as declared by Scripture

original: tathāhi śrutiḥ 'annamaśitaṃ tredhā vidhīyate tasya yaḥ sthaviṣṭho dhātustatpurīṣaṃ bhavati yo madhyamastanmāṃsaṃ yo 'ṇiṣṭhastanmanaḥ' chā / 🔽iti /
analyzed: tathā hi śrutiḥ annam aśitam tredhā vidhīyate tasya yaḥ sthaviṣṭhaḥ dhātuḥ tat purīṣam bhavati yaḥ madhyamaḥ tat māṃsam yaḥ ṇiṣṭhaḥ tat manaḥ  iti

analyzed: trivṛtkṛtā bhūmiḥ eva eṣā vrīhi yava ādi anna rūpeṇa adyate iti abhiprāyaḥ

analyzed: tasyāḥ ca sthaviṣṭham rūpam purīṣa bhāvena bahis nirgacchati
translated: The grossest part of it goes out as faeces

analyzed: madhyamam adhyātmam māṃsam vardhayati

analyzed: aṇiṣṭham tu manaḥ

analyzed: asthi majjā vāc tejasaḥ iti

translated: Here it is said: If everything that is made of three parts, the elements and their evolutes, is without distinction, as stated in the text She made each of them threefold, threefold (Tai. 2.1.1),

original: kiṅkṛtastarhyayaṃ viśeṣavyapadeśaḥ 'idaṃ teja imā āpa idamannam' iti /
analyzed: kiṅkṛtaḥ tarhi ayam viśeṣa vyapadeśaḥ idam tejaḥ imāḥ āpaḥ idam annam iti

analyzed: viśeṣasya bhāvaḥ vaiśeṣyam
translated: Predominance of one is the state of being predominant.

analyzed: bhūyaḥ tvam iti yāvat
translated: It means abundance.

analyzed: sati api trivṛtkaraṇe kvacid kasyacid bhūta dhātoḥ bhūyaḥ tvam upalabhyate agneḥ tejaḥ bhūyaḥ tvam udakasya ap bhūyaḥ tvam pṛthivyāḥ anna bhūyaḥ tvam iti
translated: Even though there is threefold creation, in some places the predominance of a particular element is observed: The predominance of fire is in heat, the predominance of water is in water, the predominance of earth is in food.

analyzed: vyavahāra prasiddhi artham ca idam trivṛtkaraṇam
translated: This threefold creation is for the purpose of establishing usage.

original: vyavahāraśca trivṛtkṛtarajjuvadekatvāpattau satyāṃ na bhedena bhūtatrayagocaro lokasya prasiddhyet /
analyzed: vyavahāraḥ ca trivṛtkṛta rajju vat eka tva āpattau satyām na bhedena bhūta traya gocaraḥ lokasya prasiddhyet
translated: And usage, when reduced to unity like a threefold rope, would not be established by the world as having the three elements as its object separately, if there were no such reduction.

original: tasmātsatyapi trivṛtkaraṇe vaiśeṣyādeva tejobannaviśeṣavādo bhūtabhautikaviṣaya upapadyate /
analyzed: tasmāt sati api trivṛtkaraṇe vaiśeṣyāt eva tejaḥ banna viśeṣa vādaḥ bhūta bhautika viṣayaḥ upapadyate
